But unlike the three insurrections that undermined the presidency of Raul Alfonsin, Menem refused to negotiate. Menem declared a state of siege, later approved by Congress. ``This is an attempted coup d'etat and will be treated as such,'' Menem said. One motivation for acting decisively was Bush's scheduled visit. A daylong series of firefights in and near this capital of 10 million was capped late in the afternoon by warplanes bombing rebel tanks on public roads. During the revolt, bullets hit Vice President Eduardo Duhalde's helicopter as it landed at Government House, just two blocks from army headquarters. Duhalde was unhurt. Government House and the Economics Ministry were also hit. At least seven soldiers, one rebel and five civilians were killed before order was restored, the government news agency Telam said. The civilians were in a bus hit by a tank. Twenty people were injured in that crash, Telam reported. At least 11 soldiers and 18 rebels were shot and wounded, army and hospital officals said, as were at least 10 civilians, news agencies reported. The final shootout took place after dark in Entre Rios Province to the north of Buenos Aires and across the Parana River. Seventeen rebels were wounded, Noticias Argentinas reported, and 32 arrested. About 50 escaped. Menem said banks and foreign exchange houses, which closed during Monday's fighting, would reopen today. Jorge Newbery metropolitan airport was reopened Monday night. Menem said the state of siege would be lifted by week's end. The insurrection had been carried live on TV and radio, and public gatherings were banned. In April 1987 and January 1988, then Lt. Col. Aldo Rico led barracks revolts in a bid to halt the trials of officers accused of human rights abuses during the 1976-83 military dictatorship, force generals to retire and the government to increase the military budget. Rico was imprisoned and cashiered, but following the revolts, most trials were halted, military pay was increased and a number of generals retired. The December 1988 insurrection led by Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin had similar motives and results. He was forced to retire. But army chief Gen. Jose Caridi and a number of other generals retired, soldiers received pay increases and nearly 300 officers who faced trial eventually were pardoned by Menem. Under Menem, the military budget has shrunk because of government efforts to control the fiscal deficit, as have the budgets of most other departments. Menem has put the army's biggest base, Campo de Mayo on the outskirts of Buenos Aires, up for sale along with many defense industries. The privatizations are part of his program to spur an economy in recession by reducing the role of the state and attracting foreign capital and technology.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet TV Says Iraq Allowing 1,000 Soviets To Leave
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will allow 1,000 Soviets, about a third of those still stranded in the country, to leave within the next three weeks, according to Soviet television. Twenty-nine Soviet workers whose Iraqi government contracts expired flew home Monday on an Aeroflot jetliner, the airline's Baghdad manager, Alexander Kirichenko, told the ``Vremya'' news program. ``Today we don't have much work to do, only 29 passengers,'' Kirichenko said. ``But the Iraqi authorities have given permission for 1,000 specialists to leave in the next two or three weeks.'' About 8,000 Soviets, including military advisers, were living in Iraq when it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. About 3,000 of them, including children, left shortly after the invasion and another 1,000 left in September and October. Then some began encountering problems securing exit visas. The Soviet Union, which has not sent troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq in Saudi Arabia, was initially reluctant to accuse the Iraqis of refusing to allow its citizens to leave. But as Soviet leaders adopted a harder line against Iraq over its refusal to withdraw from Kuwait, backing the U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq that passed on Thursday, they took Baghdad to task. Last week, the Soviets accused Iraq of breaking a promise to allow 1,000 additional Soviets to leave. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze then warned that the Soviet Union would use military force if its citizens were harmed. None are believed to be among the ``human shields'' held by Iraq at potential military targets. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Monday that about 40 Soviet military specialists remain in Iraq, unable to get out of their contracts to train Iraqi soldiers on using and maintaining Soviet-supplied weapons. He said the remaining Soviets worked for various Iraqi government agencies, mostly in energy and construction. The Soviet Union was Iraq's main military supplier before Iraq seized Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Still Climbing, Stock Fall
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell broadly in thin trading today, while the dollar rose against the yen for the fourth consecutive trading day. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which had gained 271.36 points on Monday, shed 863.38 points, or 3.80 percent, closing at 21,862.61. Volume on the first section was unchanged from Monday's 250 million shares. Traders said there were few buyers because the market anticipated heavy selling by investors who bought stock on credit and need funds to repay the loans this month. They said margin calls in December will total about 1.5 trillion yen ($11.2 billion), with about 300 billion yen ($2.24 billion) slated for this week. Investors also were discouraged by the declining yen and prospects of further arbitrage selling, in which investors seek to profit from price gaps between the spot and futures markets, traders added. The dollar closed at 134.35 yen, up 1.35 yen from Monday's close of 133.00 yen. It opened at 134.33 yen, and ranged between 133.50 yen and 134.55 yen. The dollar now has gained 5.45 yen in the past four trading days. Some $12.73 billion changed hands in spot trading, compared with $11.44 billion on Monday. Atsushi Komatsu, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the day's dollar-buying was mainly for technical reasons. But he said the U.S. currency was in demand because of dollar-denominated interest rates staying high in connection with the Persian Gulf crisis. The yen also weakened against the German mark because of relatively higher German interest rates, Komatsu said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 86.65 from Monday's finish of 86.81. Their yield rose to 7.350 percent from 7.315 percent.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS `effectiveness' in third item, fixing typo.
DOC.TEXT: With PM-Gulf-Hearings, Bjt

``We should be patient in applying military force ... we should give sanctions an opportunity to weaken Saddam Hussein so that if it becomes necessary to use the option of military force, we will have perhaps saved some lives of American boys.'' - Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., suggesting that war with Iraq be considered only as a last resort. --- ``Given the nature of the regime, given Saddam Hussein's brutality to his own people, his very tight control of that society, his ability to allocate resources for the military, their ability to produce their own food ... he can ride them out.'' - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney telling the Senate Armed Services Committee that Saddam could survive the sanctions imposed against Iraq. --- ``If we go to war, we never will know whether they would have worked.'' - Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., urging that more time be allowed to test the effectiveness of the sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: `Nightline' Airs the Naughty Madonna Video - Uncensored
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Nightline'' today aired Madonna's too-hot-for-MTV video in its steamy entirety, and Madonna - the picture of propriety in a buttoned up black dress - defended the clip as a ``celebration of sex.'' ``Why are we willing to deal with the reality of violence and sexism and why aren't we willing to deal with sexuality?'' she asked in an interview. ``If we're going to have censorship, let's not be hypocrites about this,'' the pop singer added. ``Why is it okay for 10-year-olds to see someone's body being ripped to shreds? ... Why do parents not have a problems with that?'' Her ``Justify My Love'' video, which was rejected by the cable music station last week, features the bra-and-garter-belt-clad singer in an encounter with a lover, played by her real-life boyfriend, Tony Ward, in a Paris hotel. The video portrays the couple's fantasies, which run to bisexuality, voyeurism, group sex, cross-dressing and mild sadomasochism. ``Half of me thought I was going to get away with it,'' said Madonna, speaking via satellite from Los Angeles. She said the video - with its chains, black leather and crucifixes - was about ``honesty ... and the celebration of sex. There's nothing wrong with that.'' The video - with some naughty bits electronically altered - had appeared previously on NBC's ``Saturday Night Live'' and on CNN. It also was shown uncensored on The Jukebox Network, a pay TV channel. Before it was shown on ``Nightline,'' ABC lawyers screened the video, said Laura Wessner, a spokeswoman for the program. ``They determined to go ahead with it because of the news value of the video, the late air time, and the focus of the discussion,'' Wessner said. Interviewer Forrest Sawyer asked Madonna to address herself to feminists who have criticized her boy-toy image. ``I may be dressing like the typical bimbo, whatever, but I'm in charge,'' she answered. ``I'm in charge of my fantasies, I put myself in these situations with men.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Aims to Emerge From Poverty by Year 2000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes typo in lead to `capita' sted `capital'
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's leaders have adopted a plan to do away with subsidies and central control of the economy and double the country's per capita income by the year 2000. The 10-year plan was adopted at the Communist Party Central Committee's 10th plenum, which ended last week, the Vietnam News Agency said in a report seen in Bangkok today. The agency said the draft would be presented to the entire ruling party and later to a party congress scheduled for the spring. The congress also will consider a platform that confirms socialism as the goal of the nation and the party's leading role in achieving it, according to an earlier report by the official news agency. A recent official Vietnamese report estimated the country's per capita annual income in 1989 at about $210, making Vietnam among the world's poorest countries. The objectives of the new plan include ``emancipation from the state of being a poor and underdeveloped country and creation of conditions for a faster development in the early 21st century.'' It said the country, shattered by decades of war with France, the United States and its neighbors, should at least emerge from its current economic crisis by 1995. Politically, Vietnam has clung to strict party control over the affairs of its citizens. The country's 1978 invasion of Cambodia and the collapse of the Soviet bloc have led to growing isolation. After its sixth party congress in late 1986, the government adopted economic reforms that gave companies greater autonomy and allowed farmers to work land individually instead of on collectives. Those reforms led to ``turning-point'' changes, the report said, but the new plan will further reduce state control and encourage small- and medium-sized enterprises, it said.

DOC.HEAD: New York Sets Murder Record
DOC.TEXT: New York City is closing out its bloodiest year on record: more than 2,000 murders so far, and December - traditionally one of the deadliest months - has barely begun. Police said the increased availability of guns was directly responsible for the death toll surpassing last year's record of 1,905. This year's count of more than 2,000 reflected the first 11 months of the year, according to unofficial statistics released Monday. Thirteen people were murdered Saturday and Sunday nights, the first two days of December, police said. The murder count included 87 people who died in a fire set at a social club in March. Guns were responsible for 65 percent of the people murdered in the first eightmonths of the year, police said. Deputy Inspector Thomas V. Connolly of the police Office of Management Analysis and Planning said 9,410 guns were taken off the streets through the first six months of 1990, compared to more than 16,000 for all of last year. Connolly said many murders began as disputes or robberies and escalated because a weapon was used. An overwhelming majority - 73 percent - of the homicide victims were known to the people who killed them, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Worry Public Will Become Apathetic After Quake Jitters End
With PM-Quake Projection
DOC.TEXT: Scientists dismissed a climatologist's forecast of a major quake in the Midwest this week but worried that people won't be ready for the real thing. ``We don't want you to stop being prepared for an earthquake'' even if a severe jolt fails to occur, Buddy Schweig, a geologist at Memphis State University, said Monday at a meeting of the American Geophysical Union. Iben Browning, a New Mexico climatologist, has warned that strong tidal forces mean there is a 50-50 chance of a quake on the New Madrid fault of 6.5 to 7.5 on the Richter scale on Sunday or Monday, give or take two days. Many scientists call the forecast nonsense but say it is true the New Madrid fault is capable of producing devastating quakes, as it did in 1811 and 1812. A repeat today of those quakes could cause 4,500 deaths and $51 billion in damage, according to a mid-1980s study by a Memphis engineering firm. A U.S. Geological Survey advisory group issued a report in October disputing Browning's projection. ``There is no scientific basis to the Browning prediction,'' said Lawrence Braile, a Purdue University seismologist and member of the panel. ``Browning has put a 50 percent chance on it, which is a ridiculous number.'' Browning, who lives in Tijeras, N.M., is on vacation and unavailable for comment, said his daughter Evelyn Garriss. Scientists would be embarrassed if the forecast for a big quake in the Midwest, San Francisco Bay area or Japan came true this week, as is possible. ``This is not something we'd like to be wrong about,'' admitted advisory group member Tom Heaton, seismologist in charge of the Geological Survey office in Pasadena. The New Madrid zone stretches from Cairo, Ill., southwest through New Madrid, Mo., to Marked Tree, Ark. In 1811-12, when the region was sparsely populated, the fault produced three and possibly four great earthquakes estimated at 7.5 to larger than 8 on the Richter scale. The quakes killed several dozen people, toppled cabins, snapped trees, temporarily reversed the flow of the Mississippi River and reportedly cracked pavement or rang church bells as far away as Washington, New York and Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Hoopla - But No Quake - Has Missouri Town Reeling
DOC.TEXT: The politicians, the hucksters, the souvenir hunters, they all rumbled through this town like an earthquake. About the only thing that didn't make itself felt was the earthquake itself. Climatologist Iben Browning has shaken this sleepy hamlet of 3,300 by saying there was a 50 percent chance of a major quake along the New Madrid fault this week. Some seismologtists used words like ridiculous to describe the projection. But along the 120-mile fault that runs from Marked Tree, Ark., to Cairo, Ill., schools closed, some people stayed away from work and hordes of reporters arrived just in case the quake really happened. ``It didn't happen,'' said Sean-Thomas Morrissey, technical director of St. Louis University's geophysical observatory. The university runs a network of 60 seismographs that sense the slightest tremor in the fault. ``There is a small probability of an earthquake on any given day, but it's the same today as on any other day,'' said Lawrence Braile, a Purdue University seismologist and member of a U.S. Geological Survey advisory group. ``Browning has put a 50 percent chance on it, which is a ridiculous number.'' Browning was vacationing at an undisclosed location Monday, said his daughter, Evelynn Garriss. Mrs. Garriss noted there was a big quake in the Soviet Union within the same ``30- to 60-degree north latitudes that we were concerned about.'' But Mrs. Garriss declined to say whether that fulfilled her father's projection. In any case, she noted that her father said the quake could happen any time from 48 hours before Monday to 48 hours afterward. ``Let's wait until the whole 48 hours are over,'' she said. Browning said his projection was based on the fact that the sun and moon's tidal pull on Earth's oceans reached a 27-year high at 5 a.m. Sunday. Although that didn't produce a quake on Monday, New Madrid was reeling from all the attention it brought. ``It's been good for business,'' Councilwoman Barbara Jones said after a council meeting Monday night. Among the entrepreneurs who showed up to capitalize on the excitement was Lynn Akins of Sikeston, Mo., promoting his outdoor safety equipment, including a sleeping bag that opens up into a huge ``Help'' banner. Tom Benz of St. Louis pulled a barbecue smoker into town to promote his catering business. At one point 20 TV news satellite trucks jammed Main Street. Jones expressed concern that all the attention could hurt New Madrid, as word of its active earthquake fault spreads. In the winter of 1811-1812, when the region was sparsely populated, it produced three and possibly four great earthquakes estimated at 7.5 to larger than 8 on the Richter scale. But City Administrator Don Lloyd said he wasn't worried that business people considering relocating would think of earthquakes when they think of New Madrid. ``I don't think that will be a factor long term,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tears, Laughter and Disbelief on Ravaged Streets
With PM-Drug Squad Rampage
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Rampaging youths destroyed Daisy Perez's makeshift Catholic church and shoe store. Then they returned to mock her grief. ``They've destroyed me inside,'' said Perez, sitting on the only wooden pew left in the church she ran for 23 years. ``This was my life, this is everything I've got.'' Perez said Monday she understood why the youths were angered after six police officers were acquitted earlier in the day of most federal charges in the beating death of a Puerto Rican drug dealer from her neighborhood. But she couldn't understand who would steal the church pews, and she asked why the youth would take out their anger on her, stealing her livelihood. ``They took my Bibles, they took all of my shoes,'' she said. ``This is such hate.'' As Mayor Xavier Suarez promised Perez the church would be repaired in time for Mass on Wednesday, the same kids who had ruined the store returned and stood behind Suarez. ``Oh, poor me! Oh, poor me!'' they sobbed and laughed sarcastically. The mayor met privately with some community leaders and vowed to give more recognition to the Puerto Rican neighborhood he admitted has been neglected. The violence began after the officers were acquitted of beating to death Leonardo Mercado two years ago. They faced a maximum of life in prison. ``It was supposed to be the chair - the (electric) chair man!'' shouted one looter, who carried a TV set out of a store and smashed it. Two teen-age girls giggled as they ran from the store, holding hands and carrying bottles of scotch. Other youths smashed in the doors and windows and carted off merchandise. Furniture was hauled out, put in a pile and set on fire. A burning chair thrown through the front door sent the store up in flames. Small crowds attacked TV trucks and photographers, smashing van windows and grabbing cameras. Residents hustled some reporters into their homes for protection. When police arrived several hours into the melee, residents hissed and shouted, hardly intimidated by the officers' riot gear. One cop kneeled and pointed his shotgun toward a group of teen-age boys. Another cop shouted at him, ``Don't ... shoot 'em alive!'' ``I'm so depressed to see all this,'' said Dwayne Green, a 21-year-old black resident. ``I can see why they're doing this. But they're going to suffer anyway. It's just like the blacks, they suffer anyway.''

DOC.HEAD: North Carolina About to Get its First Black Speaker
DOC.TEXT: A month after U.S. Sen. Jesse Helms defeated a black man for re-election in a racially divisive campaign, Dan Blue was virtually assured of becoming North Carolina's first black speaker of the state House. The Democrat's chances of winning the leadership position on Friday rose on Monday after his chief rival, Bob Hunter, withdrew from the race, citing the cause of party unity and saying he didn't think he had the votes to win. Another candidate, John J. Hunt, announced that he, too, was pulling out of the race. Since Democrats outnumber Republicans 81-39 in the House, Blue would be assured of being chosen speaker s long as the Democrats maintained unity. There are 14 blacks in the state House. Blue, a Raleigh lawyer, was first elected to the Legislature in 1981, has served as chairman of the legislative black caucus and sponsored the law declaring Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday an official state holiday. He was active in the Jesse Jackson and Michael Dukakis campaigns in 1988. He also was instrumental in changing the state's election laws last year to lower from 50 percent to 40 percent the share of votes needed to win a primary. Blacks, in particular, had complained that the 50 percent requirement discriminated against black candidates. Last month, Helms beat former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt in a bitter and racially divisive contest.

DOC.HEAD: Runoff Election in Liberal Berkeley Test of Political Direction
DOC.TEXT: Today's mayoral runoff in Berkeley offered voters a chance to recalibrate the city's political compass, which has always pointed left. One-term Mayor Loni Hancock wants to continue that liberal agenda that since the 1960s has put Berkeley at the forefront of issues such as human rights, the environment, affirmative action and help for the poor. Challenger Fred Weekes, a one-term city councilman, said local government should concentrate on more mundane problems such as potholes and redevelopment. ``And I think we need to get rid of the ideological practices in City Hall,'' he said. The home of the University of California at Berkeley was a hotbed of leftist politics and student unrest during the Vietnam War. The university was the birthplace of the college Free Speech movement in 1964. Hancock, who was on the council for eight years during the 1970s, said Berkeley can remain dedicated to social change while caring for the infrastructure and other needs in the city of about 109,000 people. ``Berkeley is really at a crossroads,'' she said Monday. ``We pioneered environmental protection. We pioneered many social programs to make people's lives better.'' ``But we also have laid the groundwork for programs in the city, from affordable housing to recycling and downtown revitalization,'' the 50-year-old mayor continued. ``The important thing is to see them through to completion.'' The runoff was necessary because Hancock failed to get more than 50 percent of the Nov. 6 vote. She fell 38 votes short out of 44,339 cast. Weekes, 65, spent about $200,000 and Hancock has spent about half that in her bid to retain the part-time job that pays $21,000 a year. Most of Weekes' support has come from ``the hills'' - the more affluent part of Berkeley - and from developers who don't like rules that require them to pay for programs such as traffic, affordable housing and child care. Hancock's strongholds are the liberal - some say leftist - Berkeley Citizens Action party that she is affiliated with, university students and residents of ``the flats.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against major foreign currencies Tuesday in early European trading. Gold prices also fell. Traders said the dollar's recent rally may be ending. ``I don't see much fresh activity. The market isn't convinced yet that it can go much further,'' said Hussam Kharbotli, a vice president at First Chicago in London. Dealers said markets were volatile in thin trading. ``Sometimes we're amazed by the speed of movement caused by the emptiness of the market,'' a Milan trader said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.35 yen to a closing 134.35 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 134.05 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.5075 German marks, down from 1.5125 -1.2885 Swiss francs, down from 1.2915 -5.0975 French francs, down from 5.1113 -1.6995 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7055 -1,134.25 Italian lire, down from 1,137.00 -1.1655 Canadian dollars, unchanged In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9237, compared with $1.9205 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $377 per ounce at midmorning, from $380.50 late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $377.10, down from $380.85 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.37 to close at a bid $376.69. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.14 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.16.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Warns New Factional Fighting Threatens Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress warned today that the factional fighting that has claimed at least 78 lives in recent days threatens to derail peace talks with the white-led government. An ANC statement charged security forces were responsible for the violence that erupted in black townships around Johannesburg over the weekend. It said the disorder was intended to discredit the ANC in talks on ending apartheid. ``Unrest areas have now been declared to Tokoza, Katlehong, Vosloorus and Bekkersdal, granting the very police responsible for the carnage even greater powers over the lives of our people,'' the statement said. ``The violence placed the peace process in jeopardy,'' it said. ``There's no way we can talk peace if people continue to be killed,'' Communist Party leader Joe Slovo said Monday. The Communist Party is allied with the ANC. Some residents of the townships have claimed that Zulu warriors were being aided by armed whites, but provided no evidence of this. The fighting pitted Zulus loyal to the Inkatha Freedom Party against Xhosas and other blacks who support the ANC, the country's main opposition group. The ANC has long accused the government of siding with Inkatha. President F.W. de Klerk has promised to scrap apartheid and share power with the black majority. Talks between the government, the ANC and other black groups on writing a new constitution are expected to begin next year. No violence was reported today in Tokoza and other townships, police said. Hundreds of terrified residents have fled their homes, and mMore than a half million people live in the townships currently under curfew. South African news reports said the fighting was set off Saturday when Zulu gangs searched houses in Tokoza for Xhosas and killed several people. Inkatha leader Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi said his forces were not to blame. ``I object therefore to blame being automatically apportioned to so-called `impis' (regiments) of the Inkatha Freedom Party,'' he said in a statement. Zulu leaders claimed several of their followers had been shot by police for no apparent reason. About 1,000 blacks have been killed in factional fighting in Johannesburg townships since August. The fighting subsided after September, but flared anew in recent weeks. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid, but are divided by rival leadership and differing visions of a future South Africa. Inkatha favors free-market system, while the ANC leans more to socialist economic programs.

DOC.SECOND: PM-BRF--New York Condoms, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0468,0177
DOC.HEAD: New York Schools Chief Wants to Distribute Condoms to Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to fix `our' to `or.'
DOC.TEXT: The city's schools chief is proposing that condoms be given out on request to New York's 261,000 high school students. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez is expected to present the AIDS-prevention plan on Wednesday to the Board of Education for approval. If approved, the plan would be perhaps the most far-reaching in the nation. Under the proposal, students would be able to get condoms from volunteers at school without having to get parental consent or birth-control counseling. ``People at any age have ready access to condoms at supermarkets and drugstores without the benefit of an educational or counseling component,'' Fernandez explained. He said in a memo to the board that he was taking action because New York leads the nation in adolescent AIDS cases. The board is expected to vote in January. Of the seven members, two have indicated opposition; a third has expressed some reservations.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in East to Turn to Snow as Storm Tapers Off in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain swept the East early today, while snow from a major winter storm tapered off in the upper Midwest and headed for New England. A flood watch was in effect today in the Mohawk Valley, the Catskills, the Susquehanna River region and western Adirondacks in New York state. Snow fell along the mid-Mississippi River valley and the southern Great Lakes region. The system that delivered the first winter storm of the season was expected to bring snow to New Hampshire, Maine, Vermont and New York. Rain fell from Pennsylvania through New England, and from Maine to southern Florida along much of the Eastern Seaboard. Rain also fell in Washington state. Winter storm watches were posted for Indiana and Washington state, and a high wind warning was posted for Montana. The National Weather Service said high pressure will dominate the weather pattern over the nation's mid-section through Wednesday. The nation's high on Monday was 88 degrees at El Cajon, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Police Frisk Palestinians Entering Israel
DOC.TEXT: Police set up checkpoints along Israel's 1967 borders and frisked Palestinians driving from the occupied lands into Israel today, in the first sign of sweeping new security measures. News reports said Defense Minister Moshe Arens also plans to increase deportations of Palestinians and block thousands of Arabs from entering Israel. The measures are a reaction to the stabbing attacks that have claimed five Israeli lives in the last two months. Seven Palestinians involved in the attacks were killed by police or Israeli revenge seekers. On Sunday, three West Bank Palestinians boarded a bus in Tel Aviv, stabbed to death one passenger and wounded three. Police shot to death one assailant and captured the other two. Israel radio reported massive traffic jams on the roads leading to Tel Aviv as the checkpoints went up along the so-called Green Line, the boundary with the West Bank and Gaza Strip before Israel captured them in the 1967 war. ``We're doing body checks to see if they have knives. We also check their bags and their cars,'' police spokesman Adi Gonen said. ``It's not a pleasure for them, but we have no choice.'' Police are now obliged to carry a pistol or Uzi submachine gun at all times, Gonen said. Police also recommended that bus drivers be allowed to carry guns on the job, he said. The Maariv newspaper ran a front-page picture of a driver working the route on which Sunday's attack occurred. Driver Salman Bassu held up a pistol, brass knuckles and a knife. He said he would carry the weapons on the job every day. Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper reported Arens wanted to increase to 15,000 the number of restrictive identity cards for Palestinians. About 10,800 such cards have been issued so far. The cards prohibit their holders from visiting Israel. The stabbings are meant as revenge for the Oct. 8 police shootings on Jerusalem's Temple Mount that killed at least 17 Arabs. About 110,000 Palestinians work in Israel, most as day laborers. Labor Minister David Magen has suggested reducing their number by 50,000 to make room for Soviet Jewish immigrants. Israel radio said Arens is planning to step up deportations of Palestinians. Israel has deported 60 Palestinians since the start of the uprising in the occupied lands nearly three years ago. The expulsions have been criticized by the United States, Europe and human rights groups as a violation of the Fourth Geneva Convention. The convention, which Israel signed, bars deportations of civilians from occupied areas. Israel argues that the Geneva Convention only bans mass deportation, not expulsions of a few individuals.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Capsule Successfully Docks With Space Station
DOC.TEXT: A space capsule carrying a Japanese journalist and two Soviet cosmonauts docked today with the orbiting Mir space station, Tass reported. The Soyuz TM-11 capsule, launched Sunday from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Soviet Central Asia, will return to Earth on Monday with journalist Toyohiro Akiyama and a Soviet crew completing a five-month expedition. Akiyama is the first Japanese in space, and also the first journalist. Tass said the docking at 12:57 p.m. (4:47 a.m. EST) was uneventful. Cosmonauts Viktor Afanasyev and flight engineer Musa Manarov will remain on board the space station until May 1991. They plan four space walks. Akiyama, a 48-year-old news director for Japan's TBS television company, will photograph environmental damage on Earth and conduct experiments on Japanese tree frogs to see how they cope in a gravity-free environment. He has also been broadcasting television and radio reports. TBS, Japan's biggest private television company, paid $12 million for a seat on the space capsule and exclusive rights to Akiyama's reports. It is part of a Soviet campaign to make its space program more profitable. Soviet officials and TBS executives also expressed hopes that the flight could improve ties between the two countries, which never officially ended their World War II hostilities.

DOC.HEAD: Muhammad Ali, 6 Freed U.S. Hostages Touch Down in New York
DOC.TEXT: Six Americans who had been detained in Iraq arrived back in the United States early today with former boxing champion Muhammad Ali, who had secured their release. The former hostages said their treatment in Iraq had been adequate, but they were sorry to leave hundreds of other hostages behind. Ali did not speak to reporters after the group arrived at Kennedy International Airport. An attorney, Paul Sanchi, read a statement from Ali that said, ``I'm on the side of Al Islam, which means peace.'' The six were among the 15 Americans released last week after Ali met with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Freed hostage Harry Brill-Edwards, 49, of Fort Lee, N.J., described Ali as ``a super gentleman'' and said this was ``the real human side of a super sportsman.'' Brill-Edwards, chairman of Chromoloy Corp. in Orangeburg, N.Y., had gone to Kuwait for one day of business and was taken hostage Aug. 3, the day after Iraq invaded Kuwait. He and other hostages said they had been moved frequently within Iraq. He said of his treatment, ``a lot depended on the political situation. As things got tougher, it got tougher for us.'' Brill-Edwards added that while he was happy to be home, ``I can't smile from the inside, knowing that there are 1,500 still left there.'' Richard Iliff of Atlanta, a General Motors executive, said the hostages' treatment depended on individual guards. He said he was fed adequately but added, ``I don't think I'll eat tomatoes or cucumbers again for life.'' Royce ``Red'' Smat of Houston said he had been held north of Baghdad. He described his treatment as ``OK,'' but added that ``my heart hurts'' for those still held. The other hostages were Sergio Coletta of Moss Point., Miss.; George Chanchalis of Reno, Nev.; and Ralph Leidholdt of Lakewood, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Claims Embargo-Caused Shortages Killing Children
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq claims more than 1,400 children under 5 years old have died due to shortages caused by the U.N. embargo, but doctors and Western diplomats say there are no serious shortages of food or basic medicines. Iraq said today it was reducing the December rations of sugar and tea for adults by one-fourth. But it said the allotment for all other foods covered by rationing would remain the same. The report of child deaths stemming from the economic sanctions came from Iraqi Health Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Saeed. He told the official Iraqi News Agency on Monday that 1,416 children had died and that many of them had not received needed medicine or sufficient milk because of shortages created by the embargo. There is no way to independently verify Iraqi figures on child deaths or to confirm how many if any of the children died for those reasons. The government is the sole importer of medicine in Iraq and the only official source of information on supply. However, a doctor at one Baghdad hospital, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said recently there was no shortage of basic medicines or medical supplies in Iraq. Iraqis say they can buy medicines and powdered milk for their children, but mostly only at exorbitant black market rates. Western diplomats in Baghdad, who generally discount reports of acute food and medicine shortages, said Iraq received more than 30 tons of medical supplies between mid-October and mid-November alone in exchange for the release of Western hostages. Another 40 tons of medical supplies reportedly were shipped to Iraq in late November, diplomats said. Italy alone sent 25 tons of medicine, mainly measles, polio and diphtheria vaccines, on Nov. 24. All of it was earmarked for Iraqi children. Some diplomats and medical personnel in Baghdad suggested last month that Iraq might be stockpiling medicine in case of war and that some of the reported shortages resulted from profiteering. Government-run hospitals report shortages of antibiotics, medicines, vaccines and baby formula and tell patients they must bring their own. Iraqis say prices at pharmacies and on the black market are often at least five times higher than normal. They say many pharmacies, enticed by higher profits, have diverted stocks to the black market. The government rationing plan instituted in September limits each child under a year old to three 16-ounce cans of baby formula a month. At government-subsidized stores, each can costs $2.25 at the official rate. Iraqis forced to supplement their children's diet with powdered milk bought on the black market pay as much as 40 dinars for a 2.2-pound can. That price, beyond the means of many Iraqis, amounts to $120 at the official rate and between $8 and $13 at varying black-market rates. Iraq has often claimed the sanctions are inhumane and deny food, milk and medicine to children. But the diplomats note that the sanctions do not prohibit imports of food and medicine for humanitarian reasons. Food shelves at private stores and vegetable markets in the capital are well stocked, often with goods looted from Kuwait or smuggled in from Iran or Jordan. Prices of many goods have soared to three and four times their normal cost. But with the arrival of looted supplies from Kuwait, the price of some goods, such as cooking oil and rice, has actually dropped.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Will Pay Hostage Hotel Bill Sent by Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq sent Britain a $289,000 hotel bill for 27 Britons who worked on the presidential palace and threatened to move them to strategic sites unless it was paid, the Foreign Office said today. The British Embassy in Baghdad will pick up the tab, a Foreign Office spokesman said, and will try to recover the money from Iraq when the Persian Gulf crisis ends. The spokesman, who requested anonymity, said 19 of the construction workers remained at the Babylon and Novotel Hotels, two five-star hotels in Baghdad. The other eight workers have been allowed to return to Britain. A Foreign Office spokesman said Iraq threatened to move the men to strategic sites unless the hotel bill was paid. The men's employer, Interiors International, had not paid the bill, the Foreign Office spokesman said, adding he did not know why. The men had been working on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's presidential palace in Baghdad, the spokesman said. Meanwhile, eight British women flew to Jordan today en route to Iraq, where they hope to meet with Saddam and plead for the release of their relatives. Iraq has prevented many foreigners from leaving since its army occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2. Some foreigners are detained at strategic sites as part of a ``human shield'' against a possible attack by the U.S.-led multinational force.

DOC.HEAD: New Chief Of Staff Named In Turkey
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with successor named, edit for transition. Pickup 7th graf, ``In a farewell...''
DOC.TEXT: The commander of Turkey's land forces was appointed chief of the general staff today to replace a general who resigned because he differed with President Turgut Ozal over Persian Gulf policy. Prime Minister Yildirim Akbulut announced the appointment of Gen. Dogan Gures to succeed Gen. Necip Torumtay, who resigned Monday. The appointment was in accordance with military tradition, as Gures was the second highest ranking army general after Torumtay. However, it may not solve Ozal's problems. Sources said Gures shares Torumtay's view that Turkey should refrain from an active role in any possible war to force Iraq out of Kuwait. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Gures is also uncompromising in his opposition to Islamic fundamentalism in this predominantly Moslem but secular country. Analysts say Torumtay's resignation was an indication of the army's dissatisfaction with what is viewed as the Ozal government's encouragement of Islamic fundamentalist groups. In his letter of resignation, Torumtay said only that he found it impossible to continue in his post in the light of ``principles I believe in and my understanding of statecraft.'' Commentaries in Turkish papers today lauded Torumtay's decision as ``honorable and democratic.'' Torumtay was the third senior official to resign in three months. Defense Minister Safa Giray resigned in November and Foreign Minister Ali Bozer in October, the latter reportedly because he differed with Ozal over gulf policy. Foreign Ministry and defense officials are said to feel that Ozal is dragging Turkey into war with Iraq in his enthusiasm to join the Western coalition grouped against Saddam Hussein. Torumtay, a 64-year-old former military attache in Tokyo and Washington, had been chief of staff for three years. In a farewell message to Turkey's 800,000-strong armed forces, the second-largest army in NATO after the United States, Torumtay said ``the road shown by Ataturk'' was ``the goal which cannot be deviated from.'' Kemal Ataturk set up modern Turkey in 1923 and instituted westernizing reforms, firmly rooting the country in secularism. Fundamentalists, estimated to make up 12 percent of Turkey's population of 57 million, have grown increasingly militant. Many Turks hold them responsible for the killing this year of three prominentadvocates of secularism. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, Ozal has placed Turkey firmly at the side of the United States. He cut off pipelines carrying Iraqi crude through this country and banned all trade with Iraq. Turkish officials have ruled out the possibility of Turkey opening a ``second front'' from the north if the United States and its allies go to war against Iraq. Urged on by Ozal, however, parliament has authorized the government to send Turkish troops abroad and to allow foreign troops in this country if necessary. U.S. Air Force F-16 and F-111 aircraft have been deployed at the Incirlik base in southern Turkey since August. The prominent daily Cumhuriyet reported Sunday that a top-level strategy meeting on the crisis was held Saturday at the Cankaya Palace. Military officials present argued that Turkey was doing enough by tying up eight Iraqi divisions along its border and should stay out of war, the newspaper said. Ozal, who took office last year after serving as prime minister since 1983, has been ignoring sections of the 1982 constitution, written under military rule, that theoretically limit his power. Officials say he runs the country, especially its foreign affairs, through Akbulut, the prime minister and his hand-picked successor. Three times since 1960, the military has toppled Turkey's civilian government. The latest takeover was in 1980, following a period of political violence which claimed 5,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Speculation Rages Over Gorbachev's Aims in Interior Ministry Shake-Up
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper speculated today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may name Vadim Bakatin to the new post of vice president after having removed him as Interior Minister over the weekend. Neither Gorbachev nor Bakatin immediately commented on the report in Komsomolskaya Pravda, which added to a swirl of speculation in the Supreme Soviet legislature on the intentions behind Gorbachev's latest shake-up. Traditionalist, hard-line legislators praised Gorbachev's decision to dismiss Bakatin as Interior Minister and replace him with a KGB general who is expected to crack down on independence movements and black marketeering. But the newspaper report raised the possibility that Gorbachev could be feinting left and striking right: removing a favorite of reformists, only to place him in a more important post. The Interior Ministry commands the Soviet militia, or police, which includes special riot squads and paramilitary troops. Bakatin is popular among reformers who support the independence movements in the Baltics and other restive republics, because he put a tight rein on the riot police after 19 peaceful demonstrators were killed by troops wielding shovels and gas in Tbilisi, Georgia, last year. Traditionalist Communists have criticized the Interior Ministry, and Gorbachev, for not declaring emergencies and cracking down on independence activists in Moldavia, Georgia and other hotspots. Asked whether Bakatin would be named vice president, presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko told a news conference today: ``I cannot tell you. The issue has not been considered yet.'' Ignatenko added that Gorbachev did not remove Bakatin because of any dissatisfaction with his performance. ``I believe that a new post is in line for him, but we will have to be patient to see what that post will be,'' he said. Mikhail Bronshtein, a lawmaker from the Baltic republic of Estonia, said Bakatin was unpopular among hard-liners there because he had agreed to transfer law enforcement authority from central to local officials. Bakatin, who was removed as interior minister on Sunday, was replaced by Boris Pugo, 53, a Communist Party official who became a KGB major general while running the secret police in Latvia in the early 1980s. Col. Victor Alksnis, a lawmaker who has threatened to seek Gorbachev's resignation unless he takes action by Dec. 17 to prevent the breakup of the nation, told reporters Monday that the replacement of Bakatin was a good step. Gorbachev's removal of Bakatin ``is obviously a response to the ultimatum by Alksnis,'' who heads the Soyuz, or Union, group of hard-line lawmakers, said Dmitri Simes, a Soviet expert at the Carnegie Endowment for Peace in Washington. But Simes added that it was difficult to know whether Gorbachev was truly sympathic to their demands or merely making a politically expedient concession to them. Pugo is a friend of Alksnis, Simes said. Both men are Latvians who are extremely unpopular in their native land for their opposition to independence from the Soviet Union, he said. Bakatin previously has been mentioned as a possible candidate for prime minister. He was nominated for president last spring, and declined to run against Gorbachev. Sunday's announcement said Bakatin was being released ``in connection with his transition to another job.'' Interior Ministry spokesman Boris P. Mikhailov said today that Gorbachev has temporarily assigned Bakatin to study ``changes in the structure of the Presidential Council,'' on which he sits. In a Nov. 17 speech to the Supreme Soviet, Gorbachev indicated he would eliminate both the 16-member Presidential Council and the Council of Ministers in favor of several new bodies, including a National Security Council. But he has not provided details on how the new bodies would work.

DOC.HEAD: Border Guards Kill 22 Suspected Militants
DOC.TEXT: Border guards shot and killed 22 suspected Moslem militants today after they illegally crossed into India from Pakistan, authorities said. A group of 25 militants crossed the border in the mountainous Kupwara region at dawn, said a police spokesman speaking on condition of anonymity, and opened fire when challenged by guards about a half-mile from the frontier. After a gun battle, the guards found the bodies of 22 people, he said. Searches were continuing for the other three, he said. There was no mention of casualties among the guards. Kupwara is 50 miles northwest of Srinagar, the largest city in the Kashmir valley. The frontier at Kupwara zigzags across snowbound moutains and steep valleys and borders are guarded by occasional patrols. New Delhi has often accused Pakistan of training Moslem militants agitating for the secession of the Kashmir valley from India, where Hindus predominate. Pakistan, an Islamic nation, denies the charges but says the Kashmiri people have the right to self-determination. The Kashmir valley forms part of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. At least 65 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslems and most of them live in the valley. At least 1,600 people have been killed in Kashmir since early this year.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Kill Guerrilla, Two Soldiers Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops today killed an armed guerrilla in a firefight in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon, the military command said. Two Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded in the clash, which occurred in the western sector near the village of Ramayah, 2{ miles north of the Israeli settlement of Zarit, the army said. ``Israeli forces from the Givati infantry brigade were on an initiated action when they spotted a squad of guerrillas heading toward the Israeli border and they opened fire from a short distance,'' an army statement said. Troops found a LAW antitank bazooka, grenade launchers, and magazines from a Soviet-designed Kalashnikov rifle near the body of the slain guerrilla, the army said. It was not immediately known to which organization the guerrillas belonged. In Lebanon, the Moslem-run Voice of the Nation said the Israelis brought tanks to reinforce their troops and helicopter gunships strafed suspected guerrilla positions in the region after daybreak. Today's clash followed a spate of incidents involving Israeli soldiers or their militia allies in or around the Israeli-controlled zone in south Lebanon. On Monday, Israeli-backed Lebanese militiamen killed five guerrillas who, according to an army statement, belonged to a Lebanese branch of the Baath party and the Lebanese Resistance Front. Last week, five Israeli soldiers from the Givati brigade and two Palestinian guerrillas were killed in a clash on the eastern sector of the buffer zone. The army said those guerrillas belonged to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a PLO faction led by George Habash. Israel carved out the 440-square-mile buffer zone to protect its northern border against guerrilla raids in 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its forces from Lebanon after a three-year occupation. The zone is jointly patrolled by Israeli soldiers and some 2,700 members of the mostly Christian South Lebanon Army militia.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Recent Northwest News
With PM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines has made headlines in recent years for a major jetliner crash, a change in ownership, the convictions of three of its pilots who were flying while intoxicated, and its efforts to eliminate smoking on planes. Here are details of those and other events: -Aug. 16, 1987: Northwest Flight 255 crashed near Detroit Metropolitan Airport, killing 156 people when the MD-80 failed to gain altitude during takeoff and slammed into a highway overpass. The National Transportation Safety Board ruled that the pilots didn't set the plane's wing flaps and slats properly for takeoff and that failure of a cockpit warning device contributed to the crash. -March 23, 1988: Northwest announced that it would ban smoking on all of its continental domestic flights effective April 23, the same day a federal law would take effect banning smoking on all flights of two hours or less. Northwest's policy went beyond the new law's requirements. -Aug. 3, 1989: Los Angeles investor Alfred Checchi signed acquisition papers to complete his group's $3.65 billion buyout of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines. -Dec. 28, 1989: Northwest publicized a bomb threat it received for a Dec. 30 flight from Paris to Detroit. More than 100 people canceled their reservations for the flight; 28 passengers and 14 crew members made the trip. -Jan. 4, 1990: An engine fell off a three-engine Northwest plane flying from Miami to Minneapolis; the Boeing 727 landed safely in Tampa, Fla. Federal officials said improper maintenance was involved and proposed a $200,000 fine. -March 8, 1990: Three Northwest pilots flying a Boeing 727 from Fargo, N.D., were arrested at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport after authorities were alerted that the pilots had been drinking heavily the night before. The three became the first commercial pilots to be convicted for flying a jetliner while intoxicated. Their sentences ranged from one year to 16 months. -May 28, 1990: A Northwest pilot on his way to work was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol. He later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge and was fined $627. The pilot is appealing Northwest's decision to fire him for violating company rules against drinking within 12 hours of a scheduled flight. -Sept. 11, 1990: A Northwest captain's pilot's license was suspended after a hearing in which authorities said he buzzed a snowmobile race in one private plane and crash-landed another because of a fuel problem. -Sept. 20, 1990: Airbus Industrie said Northwest got a $500 million loan from Airbus and General Electric Co. The loan coincided with an order for 75 Airbus planes valued at $4.6 billion. Later, a spokeswoman for U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Hills believed the loan could be an unfair inducement to get Northwest to buy the jets. Representatives of Airbus, a four-nation consortium, denied any unfairness. -Oct. 16, 1990: Checchi said layoffs and a reduced flight schedule were imminent since machinists rejected a temporary wage cut. Northwest announced it was implementing a third major fare increase in as many months due to higher jet fuel prices brought on by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. -Oct. 17, 1990: Northwest said ground workers in Atlanta filled the hydraulic systems of two DC-9 jets with a mixture of hand soap and hydraulic fluid. The airline called it a mistake, not sabotage. Fifty flights were canceled around the country and 12 DC-9s were grounded for inspections. -Nov. 12, 1990: Northwest said higher fuels costs associated with the Mideast crisis caused a 47 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings and will result in a fourth-quarter loss. -Nov. 16, 1990: The Saint Paul Pioneer Press reported that Checchi was exploring a buyout of Eastern Airlines using up to $150 million in pension funds of Eastern's union pilots. -Nov. 17, 1990: The Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported that the Federal Aviation Administration had ordered Northwest to examine 11 planes for possible safety defects. The FAA warned that an instrument critical to controlling the plane has jammed at least six times on A320s operated by foreign carriers and in test flights, the Star Tribune reported. -Dec. 3, 1990: Two Northwest jetliners collide on the ground at Detroit Metropolitan Airport, killing eight people.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NICOSIA
Iraq Says It Will Let Thousands of Soviets Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with more detail, quotes from Iraqi council, new quotes from Moscow. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it will let nearly 3,300 Soviet experts leave the country, but demanded that the Kremlin pay to terminate their work contracts. The official radio and the Iraqi News Agency said the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, headed by President Saddam Hussein, decided to allow the Soviets to depart. In Moscow, presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said the Kremlin has not been officially notified of the Iraqi decision. ``We have not yet had signals that would inspire such a hope,'' said Ignatenko. He said there are 3,232 Soviets in Iraq, mostly construction workers, oil and gas experts and pipeline layers. Thousands of Soviets left Iraq after Saddam's troops overran Kuwait. Iraqi radio and INA quoted the Revolutionary Command Council as saying that the remaining Soviets can go as of Wednesday. The council said it acted ``so that this issue of Soviet experts remains outside the framework of the various deals under way which regrettably involve the Soviet Union. ``We have decided to allow all Soviet experts wishing to travel out of Iraq to do so, provided that the Soviet government alone assumes full responsibility for the consequences of breaking contracts in this regard,'' the council statement said. Iraq had warned foreign companies it would demand compensation for any contract breached after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. After the invasion, the United Nations imposed an international trade embargo on Iraq. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin indicated the Kremlin had no problem over compensation. ``If the matter has been resolved now, then obviously the contract issue has also been resolved,'' he said in Moscow. A Soviet Oil Ministry official, Sarkis Arkilian, has been in Baghdad for more than a week trying to win exit visas for the Soviets. The Soviet Union has backed all 12 U.N. Security Council resolutions against Iraq, including one Thursday authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq from Kuwait unless its army withdraws by Jan. 15. After last week's vote, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Moscow would not hesitate to use force against Iraq to protect its citizens. In Moscow, Soviet television reported earlier that Iraq has given 1,000 Soviets permission to leave. Twenty-nine Soviet workers whose Iraqi government contracts expired flew home Monday, Soviet TV quoted Alexander Kirichenko, Baghdad manager for the Soviet airline Aeroflot as saying. Iraq banned many foreigners from traveling in response to the U.S.-led military buildup that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Saddam's government has relocated hundreds of foreigners to strategic sites to serve as ``human shields'' against possible attack. Soviet citizens were excused from the travel ban, and no Soviets were detained at strategic sites. Moscow was Iraq's main arms supplier during the 1980-88 war against Iran, and there were about 200 military advisers in Iraq at the time of the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman's Brother Shot in Possible Case of Mistaken Identity
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they made arrests in connection with the shooting death of 30-year-old Protestant man whose slaying may have been a case of mistaken identity. The Royal Ulster Constabulary refused to say how many men were being questioned about Monday night's shooting of David Andrew Shiels, a baker's assistant. Shiels was shot as he left his mobile home to feed his dog, police said. The constabulary said the gunmen may have mistaken Shiels for his brother, who works as a police officer. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the shooting. The dead man's wife was slightly hurt by debris which flew into the mobile home during the attack Monday night in County Londonderry, 30 miles northwest of Belfast, police said. The couple's 4-month-old baby was not injured, the constabulary said. In other developments today, the constabulary said four checkpoints along the border with the Irish Republic would be closed at night to prevent IRA ``human bomb'' attacks. The Irish Republican Army has launched four such attacks using civilians who are kidnapped and forced to drive vehicles loaded with explosives to the heavily guarded border crossings. Six soldiers and one civilian have been killed in the attacks. The predominantly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant north with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Verdict Prompts Miami's 5th Riot in 10 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with scene quiet today; picks up 4th graf, `The violence ....' SUBS 8th graf, `Acquittals in ....' to CLARIFY police killings prompted violence, not acquittals. SUBS 16th graf, `The officers' ...' to CLARIFY what police were protecting themselves from.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos of Dec. 3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of youths looted stores and burned cars after six police officers were acquitted in the fatal beating of a Puerto Rican drug dealer. The uprising, Miami's fifth riot in a decade, caught police off guard. The five-hour melee in a Puerto Rican section ended Monday night when about 200 officers in riot gear moved into the dead man's neighborhood and made about 10 arrests. The only injuries reported were to two news photographers, who said they were roughed up and their cameras stolen. Except for curious onlookers, watchful police, reporters, photographers and television news crews, the area was quiet this morning. Among the onlookers was businessman Patrick Gerritts, who somberly surveyed the collapsed, smoldering ruins of his general contracting firm. ``They've ruined us,'' he said of the people who first looted, then torched his office-warehouse. ``They've ruined my life. I'm 53 years old,'' Gerritts said. ``I've been coming here for 35 years, every day of my life.'' The violence began after the officers were acquitted of beating to death Leonardo Mercado two years ago by stomping on him, pummeling him, and smashing him in the ead with a flashlight or nightstick. Several dozen youths, their faces concealed by paper bags and shirts, gathered at a park and began pelting police and passing vehicles with rocks and bottles. As the melee built, several stores were torched and their merchandise and furniture set ablaze in the street. About 10 cars were set on fire, overturned or had their windows smashed. ``We want justice,'' said 17-year-old Yvette Diaz. ``The other people, the black people ... this is how they did it, and it worked.'' Police killings have prompted violence in Miami four other times in the past decade, most recently in 1989 when a Hispanic police officer's shooting of a black motorcyclist set off three days of rioting by blacks. Police relations worsened this year when officers violently broke up a demonstration by Haitians outside a Cuban-owned clothing store. But city officials were stunned by the intensity of anger in the Puerto Rican neighborhood. ``We really didn't expect this riot. We did expect some protests - a group of Mercado's friends, family - but we didn't expect something like this,'' said police spokesman Armando Villorin. No immediate estimate of damage was available. ``This is such hate,'' said Daisy Perez, whose storefront Catholic church and shoe shop had been emptied of shoes, Bibles and wooden pews. Earlier Monday, a federal jury found six members of the police drug squad innocent of 17 of 24 counts and reported itself deadlocked on six civil rights murder counts in the 1988 slaying of Mercado, a 35-year-old small-time drug dealer. The government has not indicated whether it will retry the officers. The officers' lawyers had argued they were just doing their jobs and protecting themselves from Mercado, who allegedly went into a frenzy and was thrashing about when police arrested him. ``This is just what I've been predicting in this case since day one - that the people would back us,'' Officer Pablo Camacho, the 42-year-old alleged leader of the attack on Mercado, said after the verdict. Mercado's family, which has filed a $10 million lawsuit against the officers, was angered by the acquittal. ``If they were (found) guilty, none of this would've happened,'' said Menerva Ramos, a niece of Mercado's. ``I expected justice to be done here this afternoon, and I see there wasn't no justice,'' said Pedro Soto, one of Mercado's stepsons. Mayor Xavier Suarez blamed poverty for the uprising and promised to bring more city money to one of its poorest neighborhoods. ``These things have a tendency to repeat themselves and I guess Miami's now gotten in this rut,'' said former Mayor Maurice Ferre.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Plane Crashes, 10 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with dead all Sudanese nationals, details about relief effort. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Sudanese relief plane crashed and burned early today while trying to land at Nairobi's international airport in heavy fog, killing all 10 people aboard, airport authorities said. The dead, seven crew members and three passengers, were all Sudanese nationals, said Mike Fernandez, an official with Trade Winds Express Ltd., the Kenyan company handling the jetliner's cargo. He said their identities were not immediately known but that the passengers apparently were working with the relief effort. The Boeing 707 was arriving from Sudan's capital, Khartoum, to pick up emergency relief supplies destined for famine-threatened southern Sudan when it crashed at 4:18 a.m., said B.A. Omuse, director of Kenyan airports. The aircraft overshot the runway at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport once and was making a second attempt at landing when it crashed, said Fernandez. The plane hit electric cables and a post supporting the power lines, but it was not known if that is what caused the crash, said the airport source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Debris was spread over a wide area in an empty field about two miles from the runway. Nobody was injured on the ground, Omuse said. The plane was chartered from Sudania, a Sudanese company, by Trans Arabian Transport, also of Sudan. The aircraft was to ferry emergency food belonging to the Lutheran World Federation. G.M. Shaba, in charge of operations at the Lutheran World Federation's office in Nairobi, said the aircraft was scheduled to begin hauling emergency food to Juba in southern Sudan today. The Lutheran World Federation is one of the few relief agencies still delivering emergency supplies to Juba, which is controlled by the government but surrounded by rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army.

DOC.HEAD: China Charges 11 With Counterrevolutionary Crimes, Two on Trial
DOC.TEXT: About a dozen major figures in last year's pro-democracy movement have been charged with counterrevolutionary crimes, and two have been put on trial, a court official and a Chinese source said today. Fan Shumi, a spokeswoman for the Beijing Intermediate Court, said two students, Zhang Ming and Zheng Xuguang, went on trial late last week but their sentences have yet to be handed down. The two students were among 21 on China's most-wanted list and were charged with propagating and inciting counterrevolution. ``It was an open trial, but it's not over yet,'' Fan said, declining to give any other details. A public trial is guaranteed by the Chinese constitution. However, the court decides who can attend a trial, and permission usually is granted only to the defendant's employers and faily. Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, responding to U.S. concerns about human rights in China, said this week in Washington: ``Legal proceedings against Chinese criminals are a matter for China's courts and foreign powers cannot interfere.'' Zheng, 21, a student at Beijing Aeronautics Institute, was arrested a month after the June 1989 military crackdown on the popular movement. Zhang, 25, was a student at Qinghua University's automotive engineering department. In addition to the two students, nine other important figures in last year's pro-democracy movement are known to have been charged in the past three weeks. University professor Liu Xiaobo's family was notified on Nov. 17 that he was charged with propogating and inciting counterrevolution, friends said. Liu, who returned from the United States to take part in last year's student-led protests, staged a hunger strike to protest the imposition of martial law in Beijing in the last days of the movement. He has been regularly and harshly criticized in the Chinese press since his arrest three weeks after the military crackdown. Wang Dan, No. 1 on the most-wanted list, also has been charged, a source said today, speaking on condition of anonymity. Wang, 21, a history student at Beijing University, was one of the top student leaders of the seven-week movement. Legal proceedings also have begun against Liu Gang, 28, No. 3 on the most-wanted list, the source said. Liu, who was unemployed, was formerly a graduate student in the physics of Beijing University, one of the hot spots during the movement. Also charged were Liu Suli, 32, a university professor; Bao Zunxin, a philosopher; Chen Xiaoping, a Beijing University professor; and Lu Jiamin, a professor at the China Labor College and a participant in the 1978 Democracy Wall movement, the source said. Other Chinese sources have said that Chen Zeming, 37, and Wang Juntao, 32, were charged with plotting to overthrow the government. Neither was active in the pro-democracy movement, but they have been accused in the official media of being ``black hands'' who manipulated the students in an effort to topple the government. Chen was the publisher of a now-banned weekly. Wang was its editor.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says 88 Americans Remain Hostage In Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDs: The following expands on the 2nd item in a0443, the Washington in Brief package to include details on other Americans in Iraq and Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: About 88 Americans remain as so-called ``human shields'' in Iraq after the release of 15 others last weekend, the State Department says. The 88 are being held at strategic sites in Iraq. They are among the roughly 1,000 Americans who are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, the department says. The Americans include personnel at the U.S. embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait City as well as the ``human shields'' and other people in hiding. The 15 Americans released over the weekend left Iraq in the company of former boxing champion Mohammed Ali. Margaret Tutwiler, the department spokeswoman, said Monday that 10 of the 15 people who flew out of Baghdad on Saturday had special medical conditions. Once in Amman, Jordan, the group broke up, with six planning to fly to New York late Monday. The others went on to Amsterdam, Netherlands and then to the United States. Tutwiler said six Americans in Baghdad are visited regularly at the Mansour Melia Hotel by U.S. Embassy officials. Tutwiler also said the United States has not received any additional information about Americans in Kuwait being rounded up over the weekend. But she said house-to-house searches in Kuwait continue.

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad Offers to Free Soviet Workers, for a Price
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details on Soviets, flag incident, Pope calls for dialogue. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMN1, NY16,17,LON1,DHA2, DHR2
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad backed away from its confrontation with Moscow today, saying it would allow almost 3,300 Soviets stranded in Iraq to leave, but it demanded the Kremlin pay compensation for canceling their work contracts. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze had warned that Moscow, which has not sent troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force stationed in the Persian Gulf, would use military force if its citizens were harmed. Meanwhile, former world boxing champion Muhammad Ali and six Americans who had been detained in Iraq arrived in New York early this morning. As Iraq apparently tries to chip away at the world alliance arrayed against it by releasing hostages on a piecemeal basis, Senate Democrats for a fifth day expressed reservations over the Bush administration's gulf policy. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said on Monday that the U.N. trade sanctions against Iraq should be given more time to work before Washington considers war to liberate Kuwait. But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress that military action was the only sure way to drive Iraq from the oil-rich emirate. The official Iraqi News Agency said today that the Soviets, mainly oil industry experts, will be allowed to leave beginning Wednesday. It said, however, Moscow would have to pay compensation for broken contracts. Moscow last week accused Iraq of breaking a promise to allow Soviets to leave. The accusation came as Moscow adopted a harder line against Iraq. The Kremlin was Iraq's main arms supplier and chief ally before the gulf crisis began on Aug. 2. In Moscow, presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said 3,232 Soviets remain in Iraq. Thousands more left in the two months after the invasion. Iraq is holding hundreds of Westerners, many at strategic sites to prevent an attack by the 340,000-strong U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the gulf. Soviets are not believed among those used as ``human shields.'' The British Foreign Office said today that Iraq sent Britain a $289,000 hotel bill to pay for 27 British construction workers it is holding at two five-star Baghdad hotels. The British Embassy in Baghdad will pick up the tab, a Foreign Office spokesman said, but claim that money back from Iraq after the crisis ends. Meanwhile, about 30 Britons and Irishmen who returned home Monday said foreigners being held in Baghdad are depressed and bored, but are finding enough food and managing to get by. Six of the Britons were among the 15 Saddam Hussein freed in response to a request from former boxing great, Ali. Desptte Iraq's refusal to allow most Westerners to leave Iraq and Kuwait, Senate Democrats insisted Monday that the sanctions be given more time to work. ``If we go to war, we never will know whether they would have worked,'' said Nunn, who has criticized the president's decision to increase the number of U.S. troops in the region from 240,000 to more than 440,000 by mid-January. Iraq has stationed an estimated 430,000 soldiers in southern Iraq and Kuwait. But Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Senate hearings Monday that Saddam could survive the embargo. ``Given the nature of the regime, given Saddam Hussein's brutality to his own people, his very tight control of that society, his ability to allocate resources for the military, their ability to produce their own food ... he can ride them out,'' Cheney said. But Iraq insisted Monday the sanctions were working. Health Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Saeed said 1,400 children under the age of 5 have died because of shortages of medicine, vaccines and food brought on by the embargo. But doctors and Western diplomats in Baghdad disagreed, saying there were no shortages of food or basic medicines in the country. In other developments: -U.S. military spokesmen in Saudi Arabia today denied that American troops could not display the U.S. flag on their uniforms for fear of offending Saudis. The spokesmen said that in a recent incident the commanding officer of a Florida National Guard unit asked his troops to take off the flag in error. -Pope John Paul II told Italian sailors today that the crises in the gulf and elsewhere in the Middle East must be resolved through dialogue. -Defense ministers of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council alliance met today in Saudi Arabia to review their strategy in the standoff with Iraq. The council's members include Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Japanese Public TV Wants Global News Network
DOC.TEXT: The head of Japan's public broadcasting system said he wants to create a global news network to counter the spread of Cable News Network to dozens of countries. ``I don't mean to bad-mouth Mr. Turner, but CNN is trying to force U.S. news on the rest of the world,'' NHK Chairman Keiji Shima said Monday, referring to CNN head Ted Turner. Under Shima's plan, broadcasters from Asia, Europe and North America would be responsible for eight-hour daily segments focusing on their own region. Shima said he believed Asians should cover issues about Asia, but he did not give a detailed explanation why. He also said there was not enough news about the region being broadcast to other parts of the globe. Shima, in a speech to foreign reporters, acknowledged that the British Broadcasting Corp. has shown little interest in his proposal. But he said other major broadcasters have expressed interest. He did not identify those broadcasters, however, and an NHK spokeswoman said the names could not be released because negotiations were under way. Shima provided no concrete details of his plan, but said he hoped such a network could be set up in about six months. NHK has two channels on Japanese television, one with general programming and the other featring educational fare. It also has two stations for satellite broadcasting. The programming on those stations includes news broadcasts from several different countries.

DOC.HEAD: House Report Blasts Failure to Probe Terrorism as Crash Cause
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with 6 grafs additional comments from Hughes; picks up 5th graf pvs, The Canadian...
DOC.TEXT: U.S. agencies acted in a ``grossly negligent'' and ``unacceptable'' manner by failing to investigate terrorism as a possible cause of a plane crash that killed 256 Americans, most of them soldiers, a congressional report said today. The aftermath of the 1985 crash in Gander, Newfoundland, was marked by ``a near-total absence'' of U.S. participation in the Canadian probe of the tragedy, said the study by the staff of the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime. ``We found no evidence that there was an investigation of possible terrorism'' by either the United States or Canada, added the report, which formed the basis for a subcommittee hearing today. ``Incredibly, no U.S. government agency, or at least none with official responsibility, demonstrated any determination to find out just what caused the crash,'' subcommittee Chairman William Hughes, D-N.J., said at the hearing. ``The National Transportation Safety Board, and other agencies of the U.S. government, chose to sit back and watch as the Canadian efforts became embroiled in controversy,'' Hughes said. ``The NTSB routinely rubber-stamped the Canadian findings, without comment,'' Hughes added. The Canadian Air Safety Board found by a 5-4 vote that icing of the wings was the most probable cause, but a subsequent Canadian review found that ice had not been the cause. The U.S. National Transportation Safety Board nonetheless supported the original finding blaming it on ice. ``The NTSB was grossly negligent and was not acting in the public's interest for taking such a position,'' said the congressional report. ``It appears that the NTSB was predisposed to not find fault.''
