FBI agents sent to Gander the day of the crash apparently ``waited in a ... motel for whatever reports or conclusions Canadian authorities saw fit to share with them,'' said the staff report, which has not been voted on by subcommittee members. After 36 hours, the FBI agents accepted a declaration that terrorism was not involved and returned home, apparently without getting any evidence to bolster that conclusion, it added. ``Such a course of conduct on the part of the FBI is ... unacceptable if not also unbelievable,'' the report contended. Spokesmen for the NTSB and FBI declined comment. Both agencies were sending representatives to testify at the hearing. The DC-8 jetliner crashed on Dec. 12, 1985, less than 30 seconds after liftoff from the airport at Gander. The chartered flight, operated by Miami-based Arrow Air, was carrying soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division home from peacekeeping duties in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula. Rep Robin Tallon, D-S.C., has said the crash could be connected to the Iran-Contra affair. He suggests the plane may have been the target of a terrorist attack as a reprisal stemming from Iran's unhappiness with a weapons shipment authorized by the Reagan administration less than three weeks earlier. Fueling the notion of a terrorist act: -Eyewitnesses claim to have seen a bright orange object in the sky at the time of the crash. -Shortly after the plane went down in Gander, an anonymous caller said that Islamic Jihad, a pro-Iranian terrorist group, had put a bomb on the plane. -A pathologist found that lethal levels of carbon monoxide and hydrogen cyanide in many of the victims' bodies had been inhaled before death, as would be the case in a pre-impact fire.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Told to Remove Flags in Error
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military spokesmen denied today that American troops were prohibited from displaying the U.S. flag on their uniforms to avoid offending the Saudi government. They said that in a recent incident the commanding officer of a Florida National Guard unit had asked his troops to remove the flag in error. The officer, his unit, and the date of the incident were not identified. All troops bound for Saudi Arabia are briefed on the cultural sensitivities in the strict Moslem nation, which bans the mingling of the sexes in public and bars alcohol. In the past, strong ties with the United States have never been emphasized publicly because of Washington's links to Israel. One military spokesman said that some commanding officers take the warnings further than the regulations. ``In trying not to offend someone, in being sensitive ... they err on the side of caution,'' said Capt. Mike Sherman of the U.S. military's Joint Information Bureau. ``It was just a bad word that the commanding officer got.'' The military said a similar false report that letters mailed with stamps showing the American flag would not be delivered had swept through military ranks earlier this year. U.S. military positions in Saudi Arabia are barred from flying the American flag, according to a policy by the Central Command in Riyadh. ``They are encampments rather than bases on the sovereign territory of Saudi Arabia,'' said Lt. Commander David Knox, a spokesman for Central Command. It would not be appropriate to fly the flag, implying that the area was under American control, he said, and is standard military policy worldwide. Troops may, however, display the flag on the walls of their living quarters, in offices, on their uniforms or anywhere else if their commanding officer approves, he said. Knox said he was unaware of any Saudi concern over such displays of the Stars and Stripes.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Church Supporting Walesa
With PM-Poland-Stan's Fans, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The head of Poland's powerful Roman Catholic Church has made clear that believers should vote for Lech Walesa in the presidential runoff election, a newspaper reported today. Cardinal Jozef Glemp, asked about challenger Stanislaw Tyminski's claim Saturday of church support, said in Rome that the communique on Sunday's election issued recently by Polish bishops gave no ground for that interpretation, the Zycie Warszawy daily reported. ``Nobody believes that,'' Glemp said. He said the bishops spoke for ``continuity in the direction of independence and freedom that has been outlined for the last 10 years.'' Glemp's words ``leave us without doubt,'' Zycie Warszawy said in a related commentary. ``They fully uphold support for Lech Walesa. In these short words the highest moral authority expressed a clear and decided message.'' It added that the church speaks so clearly ``only at moments decisive for the future of the country.'' In a country where more than 90 percent of the people consider themselves Catholic, the church endorsement should carry great weight and could be fatal for Tyminski's come-from-nowhere presidential bid. The bishops issued their statement Friday from the Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa, telling Poles they should elect someone who would ``continue and consolidate'' the course of reforms and ``discover anew the meaning of solidarity.'' It was read in all churches Sunday, and at least some pastors were reported to have added their own private instructions to vote for Walesa. In the first round of the elections Nov. 25, in which Tyminski placed second among six candidates, he did particularly well among rural voters. But in the Polish countryside, the pastor often plays a pivotal role in advising the largely closed-off population about public affairs, so a clear endorsement of Walesa should help the Solidarity chairman. On nationwide television Saturday night, Tyminski said: ``I read the bishops' letter ... and I think it was support for my candidacy because I am also striving to end this totalitarian system.'' Asked at a news conference today whether the church was supporting Walesa, Tyminski's Peruvian wife, Graciela, answered: ``This is between Mr. Walesa and Mr. Tyminski. Where is his (Walesa's) plan for the future of the country? ``Forget about the church,'' she said. Public opinion polls show Walesa leading Tyminski by a 2-to-1 margin. However, Tyminski said at the news conference that he believes in his own polls, which he said put Walesa's support at 50 percent and his at 44 percent. He added that he is gaining about 1.5 percentage points daily. Tyminski, a self-proclaimed millionaire, returned to Poland in September after 21 years in Canada and Peru. He has promised to quickly end the country's economic crisis using his Western-acquired business savvy.

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Burned Helping Others from Burning Jet
With PM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fred Guyor didn't think twice about what to do when Northwest Flight 1482 collided with another jet and ignited. He jumped off a wing to the runway and started helping others to safety. Monday's collision at Detroit Metropolitan Airport sent the 39 passengers on the Pittsburgh-bound flight clambering for exits. Eight people died and at least 20 others were treated for burns, broken bones, smoke inhalation and other injuries. ``I didn't even know what was happening. I saw a ball of flame. When this thing went, it was like an explosion. The whole tail of the plane was engulfed in flames,'' said Guyor, 53, of the Detroit suburb of Southfield. He was reading a newspaper when the collision occurred. ``I never knew there was another plane involved,'' he said. The DC-9, also carrying four crew members, was clipped by the wing of a Boeing 727-200, Memphis-bound Flight 299, with 146 passengers and 10 crew members. The collision knocked off one of the DC-9 rear engines. Guyer leapt from his aisle seat, out a middle escape door and dropped about 9 feet to the slushy runway. Once on the ground, he helped six to eight others off the plane, including a few people who were afraid to jump off the wing. A passenger jumped into his hands with a burning nylon jacket. ``I used both hands to beat out the fire,'' he said. ``I got nylon melted all over my fingers. I pulled my skin off.'' Guyor, manager of steel-making maintenance operations at the Great Lakes division of National Steel Corp. in Ecorse, said he declined medical treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor's Van Gogh Painting Fails to Sell
DOC.TEXT: A Vincent van Gogh painting owned by Elizabeth Taylor failed to sell at auction when bidding did not reach the minimum acceptable price. Bidding on ``View of the Asylum and Chapel at St. Remy'' started at $9.6 million and reached $11.14 million, Christie's said, but did not achieve the undisclosed reserve price. The auction house had expected the painting to fetch between $15 million and $19 million. Painted in 1889, the work depicts the asylum where Vincent van Gogh committed himself toward the end of his troubled life. The actress bought it in 1963 for about $165,000. The demand for van Gogh's work has grown since 1987, when ``Sunflowers'' sold for about $40 million. The record price for a van Gogh was about $57 million, paid for a ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' in May. A Christie's spokesman said he believed the current world economic climate was partly responsible for the failure of Miss Taylor's painting to reach the minimum price, but added: ``There is still a strong art market.'' The painting was shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, as part of a van Gogh exhibition in 1986-87. Miss Taylor did not attend the sale.

DOC.HEAD: Zambia's President Fires Defense Minister, Editors of State Papers
DOC.TEXT: President Kenneth Kaunda today announced the dismissals of his defense minister and the veteran chief editors of Zambia's two state-run daily newspapers. The editors, both of whom held their posts for more than 10 years, had sometimes been criticized for not reflecting the line of the ruling United National Independence Party. Kaunda's party has been the only lawful one since 1973, but he has promised multiparty elections next year. The president, who announced the dismissals at a news conference, gave no reason for them. He said the defense minister, Lt. Gen. Hannaniah Lungu, would be replaced by his deputy, Dodson Siatalimi. Lungu, appointed defense chief in July after helping to crush a coup attempt, will probably be transferred to the foreign service, Kaunda said. Lungu was previously commander of the air force. The fired editors are Komani Kachinga of the Times of Zambia and Cyrus Sikazwe of the Zambia Daily Mail. They said they were surprised by the move but expressed no resentment. Under mounting pressure from trade union leaders, academics, students and former political loyalists, Kaunda recently agreed torewrite the constitution and restore the kind of Western-style democracy he inherited from Britain at independence in 1964. But the 66-year-old leader has ordered the two dailies, as well as state television and radio not to report on opposition activities. Kaunda named two academics to replace the editors, and some analysts suggested their lack of journalism experience might make it easier for the government to shape the coverage according to its own wishes. An opposition newspaper, the Sunday Express, which was to have been launched this week, did not appear on the streets after a state company refused to print it. The paper has since found a private printer, the publishers said.

DOC.HEAD: 100 Arrested at ACT UP Protest of CDC's AIDS Definition
DOC.TEXT: Police said they arrested 100 demonstrators when a protest against the federal Centers for Disease Control's definition of AIDS turned destructive. ``They were allowed to demonstrate until they began defacing CDC property,'' said DeKalb County police Maj. J.S. Wilson. ``They painted the building. They beat on the windows and chained themselves to the front entry doors.'' The protesters contend the health agency's AIDS definition costs women health benefits by failing to include some gynecological conditions that afflict women infected with the AIDS virus. The AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power said 700 people from 30 states participated in the demonstration. Police estimated the crowd at 300. About 100 were arrested for criminal trespass and a variety of other charges, police said. The protesters, wearing placards depicting skulls, marched in the rain through the Emory University campus to the nearby CDC complex Monday morning. Another group was detained after they invaded the CDC executive offices about three miles away, Wilson said. ACT UP said in a statement that the demonstration included 30 women infected with HIV who spoke of ``how the out-of-date definition based on the history of men diagnosed with AIDS excludes them.'' Of the 154,917 people diagnosed with AIDS, 14,816 are women, said CDC spokesman Chuck Fallis. He said the agency was studying whether it's a sign of AIDS or just a coincidence that some HIV-infected women get diseases such as pelvic inflammatory disease and vaginal candidiasis. ``We are continuing to look at this whole spectrum of AIDS in women including these gynecological conditions. We may at some point expand our case definition, but we're not ready to do that at this point,'' he said. As for the protesters, he said: ``They're saying that we are letting women die ... and that CDC doesn't care about the fate of women with HIV. It seems rather absurd to me.''

DOC.HEAD: Head of Social Democrats Stepping Down Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Hans-Jochen Vogel, whose Social Democrats failed to unseat Chancellor Helmut Kohl in federal elections, is stepping down as party chief, the party reported today. Social Democratic Party spokesman Eduard Heussen said that during an emergency session of the party leadership, Vogel announced he would not be a candidate for party leader at the Social Democrats' congress in May. The leadership meeting was convened to examine the reasons for the party's devastating loss Sunday to Kohl's coalition in the first all-German elections in 58 years. Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democrats' candidate for chancellor, has said he has no interest in Vogel's job. Party sources said Vogel offered the position to Lafontaine. Vogel has been national party leader since 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Eliminates Some Bank Reserve Requirements
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve, in a move designed to ease the so-called ``credit crunch,'' announced today it is eliminating bank reserve requirements on some deposits. ``The board took action at this time ... in response to mounting evidence that commercial banks have been tightening their standards of creditworthiness and the terms and conditions for many types of loans,'' the announcement said. ``While much of this tightening has been welcome from a safety and soundness standpoint, it has in recent months begun to exert a contractionary influence on the economy,'' it added. There currently is a 3 percent reserve requirement on non-personal time deposits maturing in less than 18 months, which are mostly corporate CDs, and net Eurocurrency liabilities. The requirement means banks have to hold in reserve sums equal to 3 percent of the amount. Both requirements will be lowered to zero in coming weeks. The Fed said lower reserve requirements reduce bank costs and provide incentives to lend to creditworthy borrowers, ``thus countering, to some extent, the recent tightening in credit terms.'' Both Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have said tight credit is causing problems for many businesses. Some critics contend government officials are being overzealous in interpreting banking regulations in the wake of the savings and bond debacle. Brady has urged regulators not to be ``unrealistically negative'' in evaluating loans and urged bankers ``to keep lending to your good customers.''

DOC.HEAD: Angola's President Calls For Economic, Political Reforms
DOC.TEXT: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos called today for sweeping economic and political reforms and told his ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola its 15-year-old, one-party rule will soon be over. Dos Santos told 700 Popular Movement delegates the party's third congress that opened today will be ``the last under a single-party system.'' In a 30-minute speech interrupted by frequent applause, dos Santos said the Popular Movement must abandon its Marxist economic model to embrace the free market and a new strategy of democratic socialism. The six-day congress is scheduled to debate proposals for reforming the centralized economy and introducing multiparty democracy. Delegates will also discuss ongoing peace talks with U.S.-backed UNITA rebels to end a 15-year-old civil war that has devastated what is potentially one of Africa's richest economies. After a fifth round of peace talks between the two sides last month, Portuguese government mediators said they were close to a cease-fire. Dos Santos said today that political advances will be difficult while the war continues with UNITA, the Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. He has said plans to introduce a multiparty system will go ahead early next year, even without an agreement with the rebels. Peace talks are expected to resume in January. Dos Santos criticized the centrally planned economic system followed by the Popular Movement since Angola's independence from Portugal in 1975. ``The inadequacy of the system is showing in an economic asphyxiation because of the high level of collectivism of the means of production and services,'' he said. Angola is rich in minerals and agricultural land, but the war has crippled economic activity and severed communications. Only exports from the heavily-guarded northwestern oil fields have kept the economy afloat. Dos Santos faces resistance to his reform plans from party hard-liners. Observers in Luanda said opposition to some planned changes may delay their discussion until a special party congress early next year. Dos Santos hopes to strengthen his hand at the current congress in elections for members of the policy-making Central Committee and a new position of party general secretary. Expected to win the post is dos Santos' special assistant and leading reformer, Lopo de Nascimento.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Sex Discrimination Ruling Against Accounting Firm
DOC.TEXT: A woman who sued Price Waterhouse for sex discrimination won another round today in her bid to be made a partner in the accounting firm and receive back pay. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia upheld a lower court's order that Anne Hopkins be made a partner of Price Waterhouse and that she receive $371,000 in back pay. The ruling stems from an important 1989 Supreme Court decision that employers have the burden or proving they did not discriminate when there is evidence of bias. The high court's decision in the Hopkins case came after she presented evidence that she was denied a partnership because male partners felt she acted too much like a man. The Supreme Court sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, who last May ordered Price Waterhouse to make Ms. Hopkins a partner in its Washington-based management consulting group. The appellate court decision upheld Gesell's finding that Price Waterhouse failed to prove that it denied Ms. Hopkins a partnership for a non-discriminatory reason. The appellate panel said it found ``no merit'' in Price Waterhouse's appeal of Gesell's order.

DOC.HEAD: New Home Sales Fall Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 9th graf, Existing home, to make it 3.02 million sted billion
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes decreased another 3.5 percent in October, falling to a level not seen since the last recession, the government said today. Sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 491,000, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development said in a joint release. That was the lowest since 480,000 new homes were sold in October 1982, a month before the 1981-82 recession ended. The housing industry has been in a slump for about two years because of high interest rates and home prices and, more recently, fading consumer confidence in the economy. During the first 10 months of this year, new home sales were off 15.8 percent from the same period of 1989. Sales fell in eight of those 10 months, including a 4 percent drop in September and a 2 percent decline in August. The September figure was revised down from 6 percent in the departments' initial estimate, but the October total was worse than the 1.8 percent drop first reported. At the October sales pace, it would take 8.4 months to exhaust the inventory of unsold homes, up from 8.3 months in September and eight months in August. There was a seven month supply of unsold homes in October 1989. The effects of the sluggishness were seen in the Labor Department's employment report for October. It said 185,000 construction jobs have been lost in the last five months, including 80,000 in October alone. Existing home sales also have been weak, slumping 4.7 percent in October to an annual rate of 3.02 million, their lowest level since early 1985, according to the National Association of Realtors. But despite the weakness, new home prices continued to rise in October. The government reported the median price jumped 7.9 percent, to $121,800, while the average price advanced 9.8 percent, to $157,500. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. A year ago, the median price was $123,000 and the average $147,800. Sales in the Northeast, which tumbled to a recent low of 57,000 units in September, rebounded 47.4 percent in October to an annual rate of 84,000 units. Sales fell 18.2 percent, to 112,000 units, in the West - the lowest since 106,000 homes were sold in September 1982. In the Midwest, sales were off 11.7 percent, to 83,000 units - the lowest since 74,000 homes were sold in August 1986. Sales dropped 4.1 percent in the South, to 212,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Secretary Fires Commander for Failure in A-12 Plane Development
DOC.TEXT: The Navy today announced it is forcing the chief of the Naval Air Systems Command to retire early because he failed to inform top Pentagon officials of serious flaws in the proposed A-12 stealth bomber program. Vice Adm. Richard C. Gentz will retire no later than Feb. 1, 1991, the Pentagon said. The A-12 program executive officer, Rear Adm. John F. Calvert, and the program manager, Capt. Lawrence G. Elberfeld, have also been reassigned to other duties and received letters of censure from Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III. Garrett informed Defense Secretary Dick Cheney of the actions in a memo released by the Pentagon today. The Navy secretary told Cheney he acted on the basis of an internal Navy inquiry into the A-12 program, which is a year behind schedule and at least $1 billion over its anticipated development budget of $4.8 billion. The A-12, a classified program, is the Navy's top priority for future aircraft development. The carrier-based airplane is scheduled to enter operation in 1995. The Navy inquiry said a key failure of the senior Navy officers responsible for overseeing the A-12 program was their unwillingness to pass on negative news about the project's problems to higher officials and to top Pentagon civilian leaders. Copies of a report of the Navy inquiry's conclusions, as well as a separate report on the A-12 program by the Pentagon Inspector General, also were released today. The inspector general's report was highly critical of the role of John A. Betti, the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition. It said he put too much credence in assurances by the contractors that the project could be completed on time and within the cost ceiling, and that he dismissed warnings by lower-level Pentagon officials that the project was encountering serious problems. ``We find Mr. Betti's failure especially troublesome in view of a prior warning within the (Office of the Secretary of Defense) of cost growth on the A-12 program,'' Susan J. Crawford, the inspector general, wrote in a letter to Rep. Andy Ireland, R-Fla. Ireland, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement released today that the inspector general's report illustrated a fundamental flaw in the Pentagon's system of assigning responsibility for weapons development. ``Program managers are giving assurances about contractors' adherence to budgets based largely on the word of the contractors themselves,'' he wrote. ``It is a process ripe for abuse.''

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Observatory Repaired And `Steady As A Rock'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with observatory repaired, astronaut spotted Soviet space station. Picks up 7th graf, `The 10-day ...' SUBS 11th graf, ```That is a ...' to delete first reference to astronaut. ^By LAURA TOLLEY
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts repaired NASA's $150 million observatory today and slowly began using it to study stars after losing more than a day of precious star-gazing time. Mission specialist Robert Parker said this morning that all three star trackers in the instrument pointing system finally appeared to be working well. One of the trackers still needed more fine-tuning, said flight director Bob Castle. Nevertheless, the crew started using the automatic pointing system and reported it was ``steady as a rock.'' Mission scientist Ted Gull said it would be several days before the observatory is working at ``100 percent.'' As a result, targets of low priority will be dropped, he said. ``We're really in a stage where the observatory is really starting to come alive,'' Gull said. ``It's a lot later than where we wanted to be. But I see no major show-toppers.'' By manually operating the system, the astronauts were able to look briefly at star clusters early today and a distant galaxy and two stars Monday. More than 10 percent of the shuttle mission's 230 planned observations will have to be scrapped because of the earlier problems in aligning three of the Astro observatory's four telescopes, Gull said. Astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman spotted space station Mir through binoculars late this morning and said it appeared as a small point of light. Mir was orbiting 32 miles above Columbia with four cosmonauts and a Japanese television reporter. The 10-day mission, which began with liftoff early Sunday, was already six months behind schedule because of five launch postponements, four of them caused by hydrogen leaks in Columbia and one by problems with Astro. Observatory repairs were delayed for a few hours Monday when a computer aboard Columbia malfunctioned after a faulty message was included in a series of commands from Earth. After the computer crash, one of the three star trackers failed to return to operating condition, NASA said. The astronauts got some viewing time in Monday and today by manually operating the system and by aligning the three ultraviolet telescopes with the help of a fourth star tracker normally used to keep the shuttle aligned. That process is awkward, time-consuming and not as precise, but it enabled the astronauts to focus one of the telescopes today on two merged star clusters, each of which has 100,000 to 1 million stars. All three telescopes pointed on a nearby star Monday evening. ``That is a milestone. How about that?'' said Hoffman. To operate the system manually overnight, Parker used a joystick, or paddle, and astronaut Ron Parise typed onto a computer keyboard. ``Give me a paddle and a telescope and I can move the universe,'' Parker joked. On Monday, the astronauts manually pointed all three telescopes at a white dwarf star with a powerful magnetic field. The astronauts also pointed one telescope at a galaxy 60 million light years away to look for evidence of a black hole. The observation lasted only a few seconds instead of a half hour because of the imprecise manual operation. ``We're seeing some science. We're very confident about the instruments,'' mission manager Jack Jones said. ``It's enough to tell us the telescope is working great, and we're excited about how well we're going to do once the instrument pointing system starts pointing,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins, the telescope's principal investigator. Columbia's mission mission is the first in five years dedicated entirely to scientific research. Astro's X-ray telescope was unaffected by the trouble since it has its own pointing system. It was expected to start making scientific observations once it was calibrated. Scientists want to use the observatory to study X-rays and ultraviolet rays emitted from high-energy objects. Those rays cannot penetrate Earth's atmosphere. Astro, which is in the shuttle's cargo bay, is expected to look at stars, quasars, galaxies, Jupiter, a supernova and Comet Levy. Columbia was supposed to carry Astro into orbit in March 1986. The flight was delayed indefinitely by the Challenger accident two months earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Mail Stolen Explosives Home
DOC.TEXT: A group of Czechoslovak soldiers mailed themselves packages of explosives they stole from a military warehouse, apparently to make fireworks for New Year's Eve, a newspaper said Tuesday. The contents of the packages were discovered when one parcel was accidentally damaged by the post office, the newspaper said. It quoted police as saying that three soldiers broke into an army ammunition warehouse last week. They shared the munitions they stole with four other soldiers, the report said. The seven were soon to finish their military service and mailed the ammunition to their home addresses in five packages, apparently to make fireworks out of them for New Year's Eve. ``Because grenades were packaged next to detonators, which can explode on a small impulse, there was certainly a danger of explosion,'' the daily quoted police Capt. Emil Holub as saying. The newspaper said police recovered two of the packages on Saturday and two more on Monday. The fifth package was still in the mail, probably somewhere in Slovakia, the paper quoted police as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Diplomat Resigns, Drops Out of Sight With Wife
DOC.TEXT: A senior Chinese diplomat in Sydney has resigned and he and his journalist wife want to stay in Australia to study, a consular official said Tuesday. Wang Yushen, the Chinese consul in Australia, confirmed that cultural attache Zhou Hua had left a ``letter of resignation'' at the consulate before disappearing on Nov. 25 with his wife, Susan. ``His way of doing it is very wrong,'' Wang said. ``We hope he comes back.'' Susan Zhou's term in Australia as a Radio Beijing correspondent was reported to have expired last month. Australian immigration spokesman Victor Boulos said Tuesday that two officials from the Chinese consulate in Sydney recently approached his department with a number of questions. ``They were counseled on their situation,'' he said, adding that he could not disclose their names, their questions or the advice given to the pair.

DOC.HEAD: 321 Injured in Train Crash
DOC.TEXT: Police said Tuesday 321 people were injured when a train crashed into the back of another train in Soweto. A police spokesman said one train had stopped and the other ran into it between stations in Soweto, a black township just outside Johannesburg. The two commuter trains were packed with passengers. The crash was under investigation, the police spokesman said. Scores of people were treated at local hospitals and released, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Resigns in Congo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with opening of party congress, comment from president. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Alphonse Souchlaty-Poaty has resigned in a dispute over government policy, an official communique says. The prime minister, who quit Monday, had reportedly differed with President Denis Sassou Nguesso over how to respond to pressure for political reform and for establishment of a multiparty system. Sassou Nguesso's ruling Congolese Labor Party opened a national congress today. Souchlaty-Poaty, who was named prime minister in August 1989, also resigned from the party. An official communique said the prime minister resigned because of ``profound differences arising from the search for solutions to the political crisis throughout the country.'' Sassou Nguesso, whose government has been beset by a wave of strikes and political protests, said in an opening speech to the four-day party congress that the Congo needed ``new men.'' But he said opposition leaders, who have been pressing for a faster transition to a multiparty system, were guilty of spreading ``lies and calumnies'' about the government. Sassou Nguesso had proposed that a new, transitional government be formed in January, with a multiparty system to be established later in the year.

DOC.HEAD: Mines Explode As Bulldozer Clears War Rubble From Former Beirut Battlefront
LaserPhoto BEI3
DOC.TEXT: A bulldozer roared into the ruined, mine-strewn former urban battleground in the heart of Beirut on Tuesday to remove the fortifications and rubble of 15{ years of civil war. Stray dogs emerged from shell-shattered buildings, barking furiously as the huge yellow machine began demolishing an earth embankment that split the Chrisian and Moslem sectors of the capital. Martyr's Square and surrounding streets, the former business center of Beirut, were part of the no man's land that became overgrown with bushes and small trees sprouting from cracks in pavement. Two small anti-personnel mines exploded under the bulldozer's chains as it went to work. The bulldozer was not affected by the small blasts, but a Lebanese army captain ordered work stopped until troops cleared the area. ``Luckily there were no anti-tank mines planted in this part of the Green Line,'' said an army captain, referring to the demarcation line that once divided the city. ``Such mines would have wrecked the bulldozer.'' The army deployed in downtown Beirut on Monday in the first phase of a government plan to reunify the capital and end the civil warfare that has killed more than 150,000 people. The area around Martyr's Square just north of the port of Beirut was the scene of some of the war's most savage battles as Christian and Moslem militias clashed repeatedly for control. The crumbling facades of the old multistory buildings fronting on the square are peppered with bullet and shellholes, their interiors gutted by fire and shells. A rusty popcorn machine, scarred with bullet and shrapnel holes, stood on the sidewalk outside the Roxy movie theater beneath a sign proclaiming ``non-stop showings.'' Another small sign on the first floor of the Roxy building, also full of bullet holes, said ``Music lessons for 30 pounds a month.'' ``I wonder if they will teach music here again. Anyway, it won't be for 30 pounds a month,'' said the army captain, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The civil war shattered Lebanon's booming economy. The Lebanese pound, once the most stable currency in the Middle East, fell from its prewar value of 2.5 to the U.S. dollar to 1,250 to the dollar in August. The currency began regaining strength after the rival sides accepted an Arab League-brokered peace plan requiring them to withdraw from Beirut as the first step in a pacification program. The militia withdrawal started last month and was considered completed in the greater Beirut area Monday. On Tuesday, the Lebanese pound traded at 690 to the dollar. Despite the withdrawal of most militiamen, armed troops of the Lebanese Forces militia of Christian warlord Samir Geagea remained in control of the port area of Beirut. They prevented reporters from entering the area, saying they had not been ordered to withdraw. A source at Geagea's headquarters who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Lebanese Forces men would be withdrawn from the port area as part of a plan to return control of all Lebanese ports to the government. There are 12 ports now held by various militias, and the government plans to retake control of them after the unification of Beirut. Later, the peace plan calls for disbanding the Christian and Moslem militias and imposing government authority nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: A Different Bagdad Sleeps
DOC.TEXT: There was once another Bagdad, along another oil-rich gulf, facing U.S. troops. It was a boom-town border port at the mouth of the Rio Grande, a city of 10,000 that thrived by exporting Confederate tobacco and cotton, evading the Union blockade of Southern ports. In 1866, after the Civil War, Mexican officials were fighting for control of the town and one faction invited 1,000 American soldiers from the other side of the river to help. But the soldiers stayed for 20 days of looting - a debacle that got their commander imprisoned when he returned to the United States. ``The sack was so total, it was as if Bagdad had been taken from one side of the river to the other,'' says Mexico's Porrua Encyclopedia. The Iraqi capital, Baghdad, also has suffered its share of sacks: The Mongols raped and pillaged in 1258, Tamerlane's followers repeated in 1400 and the Persians took their turn in 1524. Like those attacks, the sack of Bagdad, Mexico, failed to crush the town. It took a hurricane in 1880 and changing trade patterns to do that. There isn't much on either side of the river today: a wind-blasted vista of shoe-high scrub; dry lakes, damp lakes and marshes; a few fishermen's shacks and a few stands of trees, each visible for miles. The only U.S. forces in evidence are the Border Patrolmen, who run an occasional launch up the river, according to Ismael Perez, a fisherman who has lived in what was Bagdad for 12 years. Perez, who had wandered over with Silberio Duenas to help a stranger push his car out of a small bog, said he sometimes found old bottles or coins, a few old building stones in the area. But no monuments, not even any eroded walls, bear witness to the not-quite-splendor that was Bagdad. Why the place was named for the great Arab capital ``is a mystery nobody has been able to solve,'' said Matamoros historian Andres Cuellar. ``It's extremely odd.'' He said one theory is that one of Bagdad's founders was inspired by ``Thousand and One Nights,'' which tells the story of an Arab sailor named Sindbad who sets out on adventures from Baghdad. Even in its heyday, Bagdad lacked the golden domes and tiled spires of the Iraqi capital's mosques, the twisting alley ways of mud brick houses, the brutal Ottoman intrigue of its politics. To say nothing of any Arabs. But both are deadly flat, save for a few sand dunes in the Mexican town. And both are graced by a river, although the Rio Grande resembles the puny Jordan River more than Baghdad's mighty Tigris. Cuellar said Bagdad was born when the authorities sought to stop goods from disappearing between the ships offshore and the customs house in Matamoros, 20 miles inland. They decided to put the tax collector where the imports met the shore. Today, some people in Matamoros go blank when asked about the city that once rivaled their own as a center of northern trade. ``Some people say there was a Bagdad, but it's now under the waters of the sea,'' said a soda pop vender in downtown Matamoros, when asked for directions to the site. For Perez and his fellow fishermen here, the conflict in the Persian Gulf seems just as remote. Asked about the other Baghdad, he at first speculated on a city in Texas. ``We don't have a radio here,'' he said. ``There is nothing here but air.''

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Seek to Drop Limits on Some Donations
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 7 grafs new with Foley comment on proposed change; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng, ``It's as...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley today dashed any hopes for a proposed change in House rules that would have bolstered the Democratic majority in 1992. The House Democratic caucus had been scheduled to vote on a proposed rule change that would let lawmakers accept unlimited donations to cover legal costs they may incur in the upcoming redistricting. But Foley, D-Wash., emerged from the meeting to tell reporters, ``It will not happen. We're going to review the situation.'' Boundaries of congressional districts will be changed nationwide as a result of the 1990 census. Because the changes could critically affect many 1992 House races, key redistricting plans could wind up being settled in the courts. Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, who heads a Democratic group that is reviewing House rules and making suggestions for changes, said before today's vote: ``The likelihood is high that a number of members would want legal advice.'' Foley, in quashing the idea, provided no other details on the issue, which when first disclosed on Monday attracted criticism. Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause, said his citizens group was urging House Democrats to reject the proposal, which he said runs counter to public demand for tighter ethics rules. ``It's as if no one there is paying any attention to the Keating Five hearings going on across the street in the other chamber,'' said Wertheimer, referring to the Senate ethics hearings on allegations of influence-peddling in the savings and loan scandal. The proposed rule change would create an ``outrageous loophole'' at ``a time when the House should be taking steps to eliminate the ability of outside interest groups to provide money to elected officials who decide their interests,'' Wertheimer said. Normally, House rules limit gifts to members to $200. Under Frost's proposal, that rule would be waived for any donations for legal costs associated with redistricting. In addition, federal election law limits on campaign donations would not apply. Lawmakers would have to report contributions and spending from their special redistricting accounts. The reporting would be done as part of Congress' annual financial disclosure process, which allows a lag of up to 1{ years before a transaction must be reported. Another leadership proposal to help incumbents would change the rules in the taxpayer-financed House Recording Studio, which lawmakers use to make pre-recorded messages to their home districts. Lawmakers now must pay studio costs from their office accounts. The new proposal would let them accept private reimbursement for those expenses, thus freeing more office account money for mass mailings and other purposes. Decisions on the rules changes were coming a day after the Democrats and Republicans re-elected their leadership teams from the last Congress. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told the Democrats they faced ``the challenge of improving the reputation and credibility of this institution.'' Gephardt and Foley were chosen without opposition by the Democrats to continue in their posts, as were Majority Whip William H. Gray, D-Pa., and caucus Chairman Steny Hoyer, D-Md. On the Republican side, Minority Leader Robert Michel of Illinois and Minority Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia had no opponents. But while the Democrats were pursuing advantage over the GOP, the Republicans were fighting among themselves Monday. The No. 3-ranked Republican, conference Chairman Jerry Lewis of California, had to survive a vigorous challenge by Rep. Carl Pursell of Michigan. And Rep. Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan held on to his chairmanship of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee in a tough battle with Rep. Don Sundquist of Tennessee.

DOC.HEAD: Charleston-Based Ships Back From Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A brass band played, Santa Claus handed out candy to tots and balloons filled the air today as two Charleston-based ships returned from a six-month deployment in the Persian Gulf. The guided missile frigates USS Taylor and Robert G. Bradley were in the gulf when Iraq invaded Kuwait last Aug. 2. Since then, the vessels were involved in intercepting more than 500 ships and boats in the gulf. Boats were stopped or questioned to enforce the United Nations blockade against Iraq. In August, the Bradley fired across the bow of an Iraqi tanker. The Taylor did not discharge its guns during its six-month tour, said Cmdr. Kevin Green of Summerville, S.C. ``We went over there without any expectation this type of thing would happen,'' Green said. ``We were prepared for it, of course.'' ``All of us have the feeling that when the show is going down you want to be a part of it. But when the show was going down in August, we were a part of it. For four months in the gulf we were very busy,'' he said. The Taylor docked at the Charleston Navy Base this morning and the Bradley returned about 30 minutes later. Cmdr. Kevin Cosgriff would not allow reporters to go aboard the Bradley. Pierside, clowns and Santa Claus handed out candy. Some children held pennants with the names of the ship. A number of women in the crowd also wore pink buttons that read: ``May I have my nervous breakdown now?'' Sailor Tom Moody hugged his wife, Pam, who held their 5{-month-old son Christopher - a son he had never seen. The couple also has a 3-year-old daughter. ``It was really hard,'' Mrs. Moody said. ``He was so far away. But it's times like this that make it all worthwhile.''

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty: Iran Executed More Than 5,000 in Three Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts first 2 grafs to CLARIFY that not all executions politically motivated. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `Amnesty quoted...'
DOC.TEXT: Iran has executed more than 5,000 people in the past three years, many for political beliefs, and the government has done little to stem human rights abuses, Amnesty International said today. Despite some changes since the 1989 death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, government critics continued to be arrested and tortured, some for no more than signing a letter criticizing lack of human rights and freedoms, the international human rights group said in a report. Amnesty quoted ex-prisoners as saying a ``death commission'' of Iranian officials chose prisoners every day and sent them to their deaths after a cursory interrogation if their views were not acceptable. In 1988, more than 2,500 political prisoners were killed secretly in a few months on orders of the commission, the London-based organization said. Thousands more have been executed after summary trials in which they were convicted of criminal offenses, Amnesty said. Crackdowns on drug trafficking led to more than 1,100 executions in 1989, it said. Most criminal executions are by hanging, but some people are beheaded, forced to jump from high places or stoned to death while buried to the waist, Amnesty said. A photo in the report shows the bodies of nine men hanging from a crane on the back of a truck. The report says that after executions these portable gibbets may be driven through the streets with the bodies still hanging from them. The United Nations is considering a draft resolution condemning rights violations in Iran based on findings of its Salvadoran envoy, Reynaldo Galindo Pohl. He noted abuses of due process and a startling number of executions. Iran on Monday persuaded the U.N. General Assembly to delete all references in the resolution to ``executions, ill-treatment and torture.'' In return, it pledged to continue cooperating with U.N. human rights investigations and to begin letting the Red Cross visit its prisons. A vote on the original draft resolution would have been a humiliating public rebuke for Iran, which undoubtedly would have refused to allow future visits by human rights experts. Tehran radio on Monday accused the United Nations of using the original draft resolution to try to pressure Iran into dropping its opposition to U.S.-led forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf region. ``The actions of Amnesty International and the human rights commission of the United Nations tell of a vast, calculated political pressure, whose roots should be searched outside the framework of human rights,'' the radio said. Amnesty said the Iranian government has consistently refused to answer the group's questions and ignored its requests to send a delegation. Despite changes brought by the 1988 end of Iran's war with Iraq and the death of Khomeini, ``The government has done little to improve human rights protection,'' the report says. Amnesty, which opposes the death penalty, said people are often executed days after their arrest with no legal counsel, no right to call witnesses and no right to appeal. ``Torture, beating and intimidation of prisoners is reportedly widespread,'' the organization said. More than 20 prominent government critics, including several ex-ministers, were arrested in June after they supported an open letter to President Hashemi Rafsanjani criticizing lack of freedoms and human rights, Amnesty said. The group expressed fears the imprisoned critics were being tortured to extract confessions of involvement in so-called counterrevolutionary activity. Executions for criminal offenses are usually announced in the Iranian press, but political executions are usually carried out in secret, the report says: ``For this reason the numbers of political executions which have taken place in Iran are disputed.'' But Amnesty has recorded the names of over 2,000 prisoners reportedly executed in secret from July 1988 to January 1989. ``There is overwhelming evidence that in the latter part of 1988 the Iranian government carried out the largest wave of political executions in Iran since the early 1980s,'' it said. After the Iranian revolution of 1979, which ousted Shah Reza Pahlavi and brought Khomeini to power, thousands of political opponents were executed. Amnesty said former prisoners suggested the 1988-89 executions might have resulted from two factors: -The cease-fire in the war with Iraq, which distracted international attention from the prisoners. -Government reprisal for an armed incursion by an Iraq-based Mujahedeen Khalq, or People's Holy Warriors, opposition group.

DOC.HEAD: `Dr. Death' Charged With Murder for Aiding Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Then lawyers...', to UPDATE with hearing adjourned after prosecutors attempted to put doctor on the stand.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: A physician who hooked a woman to a machine that let her take her life with the press of a button was charged with murder by a prosecutor who said the switch did not relieve the doctor of responsibility. Dr. Jack Kevorkian, known as ``Dr. Death'' for his invention, helped a 54-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease use the machine to inject herself with a fatal dose of an anesthetic and a heart-stopping drug on June 4. ``Dr. Kevorkian was the primary and legal cause of Janet Adkins' death. He cannot avoid his criminal culpability by the clever use of a switch,'' Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said Monday. Kevorkian, a 62-year-old retired pathologist from Royal Oak, faces a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole if convicted. ``I don't take this seriously,'' said Kevorkian, who has advocated doctor-assisted suicide. ``What happens to me is immaterial. The time has come for this thing.'' The charges came one day before a hearing today to determine whether Kevorkian's confiscated machine should be returned to him. Kevorkian's attorney, Geoffrey Fieger today told Judge Alice L. Gilbert the state has no right to keep the suicide device because Michigan has no specific law against assisted suicide. The lawyers then met privately in Gilbert's chambers. When the hearing resumed, prosecutors attempted to put Kevorkian on the stand. The doctor's attorneys said he wouldn't testify, and the judge adjourned the hearing until Monday. Mrs. Adkins and her husband traveled from Portland, Ore., to Michigan to meet Kevorkian because the state is one of the few that do not explicitly make it a crime to help someone commit suicide. She had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's, which robs people of their memories, ability to function and eventually their lives. An autopsy confirmed Mrs. Adkins had Alzheimer's disease, but she was not in the terminal stages of illness and was not in any pain, Thompson said. ``For me not to charge Dr. Kevorkian would turn Oakland County into the suicide mecca of our nation,'' he said. The prosecutor said he based the first-degree murder charge on a 1920 Michigan Supreme Court decision. In that case, a man who mixed poison and placed it near his wife at her request was found guilty of murder. The Legislature is considering a bill that would it a crime punishable by up to four years in prison and a $2,000 fine to help someone commit suicide. Fieger said because Michigan has no law against medically assisted suicide, he didn't expect the case to come to trial. ``This is not a crime recognized in the state of Michigan,'' he said. Kevorkian was arraigned and freed on $150,000 bail. A preliminary hearing was set for Dec. 12. Ronald Adkins, Mrs. Adkins' husband, said he had no immediate comment on the charges. The couple had belonged to the Hemlock Society, a Eugene, Ore., organization that promotes death on demand for the terminally ill. Derek Humphry, executive director of the society, ``This will be quite a job getting a conviction, because the law in Michigan is extremely ambiguous.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Saddam Has Yet To Get Message
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CONSOLIDATES material in a0556-a0521-a0416; minor editing changes and deletions thruout to tighten. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he doubts that Iraq's Saddam Hussein has ``gotten the message'' of a United Nations resolution authorizing force unless he gets out of Kuwait by mid-January. During a joint news conference appearance here with Uruguayan President Luis Alberto Lacalle, Bush reiterated that he would not allow talks with the Iraqi leader and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to get into the Palestinian issue and Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Bush also said that ``I don't agree with'' former top-ranking U.S. military commanders who testified at congressional hearings that economic sanctions against Iraq should be given considerably more time to work. ``I've not been one whose been convinced that sanctions alone will bring him to his senses,'' Bush said, although he said ``they're having some effect.'' Of Saddam, the president said: ``I am convinced that up until now, at least, he has not gotten the message. And the United Nations resolution speaks for itself.'' ``To me it was loud and clear,'' he said, ``but i don't think Saddam Hussein yet understands that. And so the best hope for peace is for him to understand that all means necessary to fulfill these resolutions will be used against him. And I hope he understands that.'' Bush announced last week that he was sending Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad to meet with Saddam, sometime late this month or in early January, and that he would receive Aziz for talks at the White House. But the president said these meetings would not constitute negotiations with Iraq's leaders, but would merely represent Bush's last-ditch political effort to get Saddam to withdraw Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``I'm not in a negotiating mood or anything of that nature,'' he said today. In Washington, Senate Democrats have repeatedly urged Bush to stick with the economic embargo. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., made the point repeatedly during five days of hearings that he engineered as chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Day after day, former U.S. defense officials urged the White House to give the sanctions more time - bolstering the Democratic challenge to Bush's strategy. When two current officials - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff - finally testified on Monday, Nunn asked them if the administration was dismissing sanctions too easily. ``If we go to war, we never will know whether they would have worked,'' said Nunn, who has criticized the president's decision to increase the number of U.S. troops in the region to more than 440,000. Cheney and Powell struck a pessimistic tone, saying that Saddam could ride out the international sanctions imposed after his forces invaded the oil-rich emirate of Kuwait on Aug. 2. They also used their appearances before the panel to try to stem the tide of congressional discontent over Bush's conduct. ``Given the nature of the regime, given Saddam Hussein's brutality to his own people, his very tight control of that society, his ability to allocate resources for the military, their ability to produce their own food ... he can ride them out,'' Cheney said. He described the administration position that American and international interests are in jeopardy in the crisis, especially if Saddam gains a stranglehold on oil supplies. The defense secretary also said he does not believe Bush requires any additional authority from Congress before ``committing U.S. forces to achieve our objectives in the (Persian) Gulf.'' In a Washington Post-ABC News poll released Monday, nine out of 10 people approved of Bush's offer to send Baker to Baghdad for talks with Saddam. While 90 percent of the 758 adults selected at random for the poll said they supported the decision to send Baker to Baghdad, 53 percent said they didn't think it would do any good. The poll, conducted by telephone last Friday and Saturday, also found that 69 percent approved of the U.N. resolution authorizing the use of military force. The poll has a likely margin of uncertainity of 4 percent either way.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda's Lawyers Get Look At Her Loot - And Shoes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS 1st graf to change word `loot' to `possessions.'
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' lawyers got a look Tuesday at their client's possessions, including the lavish collection of shoes she left behind when her husband was ousted in a popular uprising four years ago. ``I was impressed by what I saw,'' lawyer Drew Neville told reporters after touring Malacanang Palace, where Mrs. Marcos' late husband, Ferdinand, ruled for 20 years. ``Extravagance is your word,'' he added. ``I said I was impressed by what I saw.'' Neville and colleague Conner Helms arrived Sunday for talks in a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against Mrs. Marcos. A hearing is scheduled next Monday in federal court in Los Angeles. The tour included a look at more than 1,000 pairs of shoes Mrs. Marcos collected during her husband's years in power. The shoes are a major attraction of the palace, which was opened to public tours after the February 1986 revolution that toppled Marcos. Asked what he thought of the shoes, Neville replied: ``They are a little small for me but they appeared to be OK.'' Marcos died in exile in Hawaii in September 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Changes in Plans Kept Some Travelers Off Ill-fated Flight
With AM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Anwer Siddiqui hates to miss a flight, but this time he was grateful. Siddiqui, 29, of Atlanta, had been scheduled to take Northwest Flight 1482 from Detroit to Pittsburgh on Monday, but his connecting flight from Atlanta got a late start and delayed landing in Detroit because of fog. ``Had we landed then, I would have been on that flight and probably dead,'' Siddiqui said. Eight people aboard Flight 1482 were killed and at least 20 people were treated for burns, broken bones, smoke inhalation and other injuries after the DC-9 collided with a Boeing 727 on the runway at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Siddiqui and several others who had been scheduled to take the flight instead ended up on Flight 1484, a later flight, for various reasons. They expressed relief Monday night when their plane landed at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport. Owen Ballow, 30, of Detroit, was traveling to Pittsburgh on business for Schneider U.S.A. Inc. of Minneapolis, a medical products company. He said he ``owes one'' to his company's travel agent for dissuading him from his plan to board Flight 1482. The agent talked Ballow out of taking the earlier flight because bad weather had delayed flights out of Detroit and the terminal was crowded. He ended up taking the same flight as Siddiqui. ``Whey you fly, if your number is up, you lose,'' Ballow said. ``Fortunately, it doesn't happen often. But when you fly frequently, it makes you think.'' Also on Flight 1484 was Mobay Corp. executive Michael Short of the Pittsburgh suburb of Mount Lebanon. He said he had tickets to fly on the burned plane but rescheduled his flight because of a lunch appointment. ``I'm feeling pretty lucky,'' he said. ``I had a few drinks on the plane on the way home.''

DOC.HEAD: Bangladesh President Quitting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES previous, minor editing thruout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Hussain Muhammad Ershad bowed to an increasingly violent campaign for his ouster and agreed today to quit as soon as the opposition nominates a replacement, state radio said. Parliament will meet Saturday to try to choose a successor, the radio said in a late-night news bulletin. Ershad had offered Monday to step down shortly before elections scheduled for June, but the opposition, which had staged a seven-week campaign to drive him from office, rebuffed that offer and demanded that he step down now. The 60-year-old former army general took over Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest countries, in a bloodless coup in 1982. Ershad had declared a state of emergency Nov. 27 to quash the opposition campaign seeking his ouster. Immediately after the announcement, hundreds of opposition workers thronged the streets of the capital, chanting slogans and setting off firecrackers. ``Where is Ershad now?'' they shouted. Pressure on Ershad had been building steadily. At least 19 of his supporters resigned from Parliament, the opposition called for daily dawn-to-dusk strikes, and scores of civil servants quit their jobs. As part of the anti-Ershad program, the country's two largest cities were paralyzed today by a general strike. Word of the president's latest offer came after the opposition announced new protests to intensify its campaign to oust him. In the capital, Dhaka, few buses or rickshaws were on the streets today and shops were closed. Banks and most businesses were closed. Government offices opened, but few arrived for work. In a nationally televised speech Monday night, Ershad offered to resign 45 days before presidential elections set for June, handing over power to a nominee of the opposition. Ershad had said in addition to stepping down before June elections, he was willing to dissolve Parliament and hold parliamentary elections simultaneously with the presidential vote, with international observers as witnesses. But opposition leaders made no move to rescind their call for daily, eight-hour strikes. ``His offer is vague and we don't accept his proposal to hold presidential and parliamentary elections,'' Sheik Hasina, leader of the Awami League, the second major opposition group, had sad after the first announcement. Groups of 100 to 200 demonstrators marched through Dhaka's central Mouchak commercial district earlier today shouting, ``The last days of Ershad have arrived!'' and ``Give Ershad one more push and he will fall!'' On Monday, the government lifted press censorship. But journalists decided to continue their strike until the state of emergency is lifted. Ershad also said on Monday he would lift the emergency on Dec. 16, the 19th anniversary of Bangladesh's independence from Pakistan. His coup in 1982 followed a chaotic succession of presidents installed by the military after the former province of Pakistan won its independence in the 1971 civil war. Bangladesh, with 110 million people, is among the poorest and most densely populated countries in the world.

DOC.HEAD: On One Plane it Felt Like a Blown Tire, While Other Craft Became Inferno
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Karp was...', to CORRECT number of passengers on Boeing 727 to 153 sted 156.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The passengers on one plane felt only a slight bump, like a blown tire, while a few yards away the jetliner that had collided with theirs was already engulfed by a fireball that would kill eight people. ``That's when it really hit me, when I saw the other plane at the end of the runway,'' said Robert Karp, 60, of Jackson, Miss. ``I thought `My God, how close were we to a broadside collision?' '' Karp was one of 153 people aboard a Northwest Airlines Boeing 727 roaring down a runway toward takeoff Monday when it collided with a Northwest DC-9 carrying 43 people. The 727's right wing was sheared off, but the fuselage was largely undamaged and the only injuries suffered were to passengers evacuating. The DC-9 exploded in flames that engulfed its cabin and killed eight people. Twenty others suffered burns, smoke inhalation, broken bones or internal injuries as they scrambled out of the plane. ``I saw a guy with a broken leg, another with a broken ankle and a lot of body burns,'' said Loricel Mangulabnan, 27, of Birmingham. John Izzo, 41, of Pho cares? You're still alive.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Make Christmas Messages on Videotape for Folks Back Home
LaserPhoto DHR3
DOC.TEXT: Troops getting a rare break from desert duty made Christmas messages on videotape Tuesday for loved ones back home. One Marine donned a Santa cap. Another put on his gas mask. And one homesick soldier mouthed a tender ``I love you'' for his wife before getting up from his chair to kiss the camera lens. The taping takes place daily at a Marine Corps Rest and Relaxation Center, better known as Desert World. Troops sit in front of one of eight video cameras to make 15-minute messages called Better Than A Letter. Chief Warrant Officer Randall Anderson, 33, of Swainsboro, Ga., put on a pair of Santa Claus suspenders and a red-and-white stocking cap his wife sent him. The only other things he wore were his Marine Corps gym shorts and shower shoes. ``It was the perfect time to lay down a Merry Christmas message that I'm doing fine and that I'll be home some day,'' said Anderson, who blew a kiss to his wife and daughter. He serves with the Headquarters and Support Company of the 1st Battalion, 7th Marine Regiment. Lance Cpl. Will French, 24, of Johnstown, Pa., showed the folks back home how he puts on his gas mask during alerts. ``I just wanted to show them things were all right and I'm safe,'' said French, who serves with a Marine tank unit. A number of the messages began with ``Hi, Mom.'' One said longingly, ``Don't forget me.'' Another said reassuringly, ``I'll be home as soon as I can.'' One Marine did a segment of his message in sign language for a deaf relative. More than a few Marines spilled their souls in their 15-minute segments. These video messages are a technological leap over the audio cassettes of Vietnam and the crumpled letters of Korea and wars past. Since the video service began operating Nov. 11, more than 8,100 people have recorded messages on cameras donated by Montgomery Ward. They are sent home by the USO. It's just one of the amenities offered by Desert World, which was originally built by the Saudi Royal Commission for oilfield workers. It was unused for six years before being turned over to the Marines. About 1,200 servicemen and women a day come to swim in an Olympic-sized pool, play volleyball or baketball, pump iron in weight rooms donated by Arnold Schwarzenegger, toss a Frisbee, catch a movie, play video games, use one of 21 phones to call home, read books or browse in a store. After checking their weapons with a guard, they trade their battle dress uniforms for gym clothes and their combat boots for sneakers. Some just stretch out in the shade or sun themselves on an irrigated lawn adorned with date palm trees and shrubs. The grass is enough to make an impression. ``The green almost hurts my eyes,'' said Cpl. Michael Flaga, 25, of McHenry, Ill., who serves with the 3rd Battalion, 9th Marine Regiment. ``We're used to seeing no colors in the desert. I couldn't believe they had something like this.'' ``It's as close as you're going to come to a piece of America,'' said Lance Cpl. Anthony Uhler, 20, of Pontiac, Mich. He came to tape a message to his wife, who is expecting their first child in January. ``After being out there in the endless sand, it's good to see grass,'' said Lance Cpl. Michael Buell, 21, of Sioux City, Iowa. Desert City is run by the Marines, but U.S. Navy nurses, British troops from the 7th Armored Brigade and some members of the U.S. Army 82nd Airborne Division use the facilities. ``The Marines and Navy know how to live. We're wasting our money on parachutes and bullets,'' said Lt. Richard Ballard, 29, of the 82nd Airborne Division out of Fort Bragg, N.C. He had only been able to call home twice since he arrived in August. ``This is the first day I had off in 119 days. This is the first time I've seen anything that resembles grass,'' said Staff Sgt. Craig Colberg, 29, of Aurora, Ohio, also of the 82nd Airborne. Since Desert World opened Nov. 4, it has entertained 29,292 service members. A total of 19,378 have watched movies and 15,055 have called home, said Master Gunnery Sgt. John Kulick of Pawtucket, R.I. ``It's got the atmosphere of home. It's one of the biggest morale boosts I've seen,'' Kulick said. ``We get long faces in the morning and smiles at the end of the day.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Approved for Over-the-Counter Sale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `The drug,' with two grafs to add detail on drug and correct shipping to begin Jan. 2, sted Jan. 1
DOC.TEXT: Public health officials are making it easier, faster and cheaper for millions of women who suffer from vaginal yeast infections to get treatment. With the availability soon of the first over-the-counter drug to treat these infections, women will be able to skip the doctor's office and go straight to the pharmacy - and pay less than when it was a prescription drug. ``We're delighted,'' said Cindy Pearson, program director of the Women's Health Network, who testified in favor of the switch before an FDA advisory committee. The committee recommended the action the FDA took Monday. ``We've had nothing but positive and enthusiastic support from our members'' for the FDA action, Ms. Pearson said. ``Some want to give it (the drug) to their friends for Christmas.'' Vaginal yeast infections afflict nearly three-fourths of all women at least once in their lifetimes. About 22 million cases are reported annually. The drug that was approved for over-the-counter use is clotrimazole, which is sold under the trade name Gyne-Lotrimin by its maker, Schering Plough HealthCare Products. It will be sold over the counter at full prescription strength. The company plans to begin shipping its nonprescription product on Jan. 2 and expects to have it on store shelves nationwide by the beginning of February, said Kristie Egstrand, product manager for Gyne-Lotrimin. Pharmacists cannot distribute their prescription supplies of the drug for over-the-counter sales because they would not be labeled properly, she said. Dr. Carl Peck, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, said the drug has been used safely for more than a decade, is highly effective and has little risk. Gyne-Lotrimin costs about $25 for a seven-day course of treatment when it is prescribed. The over-the-counter price will be in the range of $17 to $18, said company spokesman Doug Petkus. Ortho Pharmaceuticals also is seeking FDA approval to allow its anti-fungal product Monistat to be sold without prescription, said Robert Kniffin, a spokesman for Ortho's parent corporation, Johnson & Johnson. Monistat is the leading prescription treatment for vaginal yeast infections with 59 percent of the market, he said, and another Ortho product, Terazol, is second in the market. Schering Plough officials said Gyne-Lotrimin is third. Dr. Raquel Arias, a Los Angeles gynecologist who spoke at the company's news conference in New York on Monday, said the FDA's decision - which takes effect immediately - will allow women to spend their health care dollars more effectively. ``This is one of the most common things you see in practice,'' she said. ``It can be a significant disruptor of a woman's lifestyle. Now they'll be able just to go to the store and get an effective treatment.'' Labeling on Gyne-Lotrimin will advise women experiencing vaginal itch and discomfort for the first time to see a physician for an accurate diagnosis. But women who have had a yeast infection diagnosed by a health practitioner before know the symptoms: itching and burning, sometimes with a discharge and soreness. These women can safely treat themselves, the FDA said. Vaginal yeast infection, or candidiasis, is an overgrowth of a naturally occurring fungus called Candida. The overabundance occurs when the body's natural balance of bacteria is upset. This often occurs with antibiotics or birth control pills. Diabetics also are subject to greater risk of recurring infections, and warm weather can be a factor as well. The symptoms, though, can be similar to those of other conditions, including sexually transmitted diseases, which is why a woman should get an initial diagnosis by a physician, the FDA said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Noriega Transcripts Public - But Not Yet
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled today that court transcripts of tapes acquired by CNN containing prison conversations of Manuel Noriega should be made public, but he didn't release them immediately. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler issued the decision after four media organizations asked for access to the court documents last week, saying the public had a right to know the factual basis of a case that tested the constitutional limits of prior restraint. The judge said he would not release the transcripts until Thursday to allow CNN time to appeal to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. CNN attorney Terry Bienstock said he did not immediately know whether the network would appeal. Bienstock argued earlier that releasing the transcripts would be an ``intrusion into the news-gathering and news-editing process.'' . In his 18-page decision, Hoeveler chided CNN for first fighting to televise the tapes and then seeking to keep the transcripts from being used by other news organizations. The judge said it ``comes as somewhat of a surprise to have CNN, the forceful proponent of a free press operating without judicial intervention, return to this court urging that the press and public be denied a right of access to the very information which CNN has argued is of immediate public interest.'' Hoeveler dismissed CNN's contention that it owned the content of the tapes, saying it was the U.S. government that monitored Noriega's prison conversations and recorded them, not CNN. Karen Kammer, an attorney representing the four media organizations said she was pleased with the ruling. The organizations are The Miami Herald, The Associated Press, Post-Newsweek station WPLG-TV of Miami and Gannett Co. Inc. and USA Today, which Gannett owns. ``I think the court has recognized that the content of the tapes does not belong to CNN, as we had argued,'' she said. Three weeks ago, CNN revealed it had obtained seven tapes of phone calls made from Noriega's prison cell near here. Federal prison officials say they routinely tape phone conversations of inmates unless the prisoner is calling his lawyers, and that all inmates are made aware of this practice. The fallen Panamanian dictator's attorneys went into court Nov. 8 after learning about the tapes and Hoeveler ordered CNN not to play any that might interfere with attorney-client privilege. The network played some portions of the tapes for a day, but withdrew them when a federal appeals court backed Hoeveler. The Supreme Court refused to intervene on a 7-2 vote, forcing CNN to submit the tapes to the judge for review. Transcripts then were prepared by court officials in Miami to aid Hoeveler and attorneys in the case in reviewing the contents of the tapes. Last week, Hoeveler decided to allow CNN to broadcast the tapes and returned them to the network, but they were not immediately aired. CNN has not said where it got the tapes, but Noriega's attorneys said the tapes were released to the government of Panama by the State Department or the Drug Enforcement Administration and that Panama gave them to CNN. Noriega is awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade.

DOC.HEAD: Here's a Stocking Stuffer for Cats Who Have Everything
DOC.TEXT: Steve Malarkey was a disgruntled computer technician looking for a career change when his cat leaped forward with an idea. ``I was sitting in front of the TV with my wife, watching a National Geographic special on birds of the Cayman Islands or somewhere,'' he said. ``Our cat Stick, who never even glanced at TV before, came out of his box like a shot and sat right in front of the screen, growling and meowing.'' Malarkey borrowed a friend's video camera and tripod, scattered birdseed and popcorn in his wooded backyard and recorded the antics of neighborhood birds, squirrels and chipmunks that gathered for a noisy feast. ``When I brought the tape back to the house and showed it to Stick, he went ballistic,'' Malarkey said. ``He was in front of the TV, behind the TV, on top of the TV, knocking things over and swiping at the screen.'' Nice kitty. Malarkey went into the ``cat business'' in a big way. His ``Video Catnip,'' a professional, 25-minute version of the same backyard scene, is one of the hottest gift items to appear on pet store shelves this Christmas season. Malarkey says he's sold 7,000 copies since his video hit the market in September 1989, most of them in the past couple of months. Fewer than 10 tapes have been returned on behalf of dissatisfied feline viewers, he said. Human viewers might find ``Video Catnip'' boring after a while. There's just so much excitement in watching a pair of blue jays squabbling or a squirrel snitching a peanut from a bowl. But Malarkey, who recently moved from this Washington suburb to Morgantown, W.Va., says it's the purr-fect stocking stuffer for the indoor cat who has everything. ``Steven Spielberg it ain't,'' he said, ``but we haven't gotten any complaints yet from the cats.'' The tape, which retails for $19.95, promises ``some cat-a-clysmic fun with no paws in the action.'' It starts with this warning: ``While watching this video, your cat may become excited and attempt to get inside your television set to get at the birds. ... We strongly suggest that you remove all breakables from on top or around your TV set. No kitting.'' The live action is divided into segments titled ``Cheep Thrills,'' ``Mews and Feather Report'' and ``A Stalk in the Park,'' which features plenty of close-up shots of kitty's favorite creatures cavorting on the TV screen. Can cats really ``see'' a TV video? Veterinarians agree with Malarkey that although cats don't discern shapes and colors as distinctly as humans, they are acutely aware of moving figures and sounds that excite them. Malarkey says he's plowing the profits from ``Video Catnip'' into a series of sequels with ``bigger birds, bigger squirrels, maybe some sea gulls thrown in.''
EDITORS' NOTE: Malarkey takes telephone orders at 1-800-TABBY TV.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Threatened Delivery of Liver for Transplant
With AM-Storms Rdp
DOC.TEXT: An ambulance crew drove six hours on snow-covered highways to pick up a liver for a transplant patient after a storm prevented an airplane carrying the organ from landing. The storm, which dumped up to 2 feet of snow in Wisconsin, forced the plane to be diverted Monday from Milwaukee to Green Bay. Despite slippery roads and creeping traffic, the ambulance delivered the liver, allowing the transplant operation to get under way about seven hours later, said Pat Crowley, nursing supervisor at Froedtert Hospital in Milwaukee.
