Mayor Xavier Suarez met with leaders in the largely Puerto Rican Wynwood community to look into reasons for the rioting, which police and city officials admitted caught them by surprise. Merchants complained that police took too long - more than two hours - to move in Monday night after hundreds of youths swarmed through usually tranquil streets, looting stores and burning down businesses. The riot followed acquittal of six police officers accused of beating to death Leonardo Mercado, a Puerto Rican-born cocaine dealer. ``The police knew it was going to happen and they just sat back and did nothing, absolutely nothing,'' said Richard Munoz, who owns Los Hispanos Supermarket. Munoz said his small grocery store was not damaged because he scared off the looters. ``I spent all night armed and on the roof,'' Munoz said. Other merchants were busy sweeping up broken glass and cleaning soot. Police estimate about 300 people were involved in the rioting at its height. From 10 to 15 people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and inciting to riot, said George Law, a police spokesman. Residents said many looters were not from their neighborhood, but came in from other parts of the city to take advantage of the anger in the northwestern Miami community. The trouble began shortly after nightfall, nearly six hours after a federal jury found the members of an elite drug squad innocent of conspiracy in the killing of Mercado, who was from the neighborhood. The jury deadlocked on more serious charges of violating the civil rights of Mercado when he was beaten to death two years ago and Judge Stanley Marcus declared a mistrial. The trial's end set off the city's fifth riot in just more than a decade, the first involving the usually low-profile Puerto Rican community rather than black neighborhoods. Mercado's sister-in-law, Rosa Allende, said some Puerto Ricans feel the need for revenge. ``It's not going to change things, but it's a start to let them know it's not only the blacks who get angry,'' she said. ``They said he (Mercado) was a low-life cockroach. But he had children. A life is a life.'' Some business owners said they got telephone calls in the afternoon, warning them there might be trouble and to close down their shops. ``They (the police) knew all about it,'' said Ricky Perez, whose parents' shoe store was vandalized. ``We called the police and they told us to close down the store and go home. They (the police) were just down the streets, watching them taking TVs and they didn't do nothing about it,'' Perez said. Suarez conceded the police did not react swiftly enough. But he said officials did not expect the number of people involved from other parts of the city. ``We were caught a little bit by surprise,'' Suarez said. ``We're going to have to investigate ... and see if it wasn't some sort of predisposed or pre-organized element to this.'' Anderson agreed the 200-member riot squad came in too late. But he noted that in a recent confrontation with Haitian demonstrators, police were criticized for moving in too quickly. ``With this particular situation we took two hours to respond, and we should have gone in a lot quicker,'' Anderson said. ``So what I'm saying is, you're damned if you do and damned if you don't.'' Fire investigator John Calpini said two stores were destroyed by fire. Other damage appeared limited to a few buildings. Patrick Gerrits, wiped away tears as he watched investigators rummaging through the rubble of his family's construction company. Gerrits' company, which was hardest hit, operated in the same spot since his father started it in 1946. ``They (just about) killed my daddy when they burned this building,'' Gerrits said. ``And it'll probably kill my mama. The whole highlight of her life was coming in here every day.''

DOC.HEAD: Yucatan Crater May Be Killer Asteroid's Ground Zero
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Why did dinosaurs disappear? Scientists wrote 2,000 studies blaming asteroids, volcanoes, slow climate change or even constipation. Researchers said Tuesday they think they found the smoking gun: a 110-mile-wide impact crater in Mexico. But don't bet the 12-year-long debate is over. Earlier evidence suggests other asteroids or comets struck Earth near Manson, Iowa, and in the Caribbean off Colombia or Cuba when the dinosaurs went extinct 65 million years ago. Some scientists say certain basalt rock deposits around the world suggest another object also smacked into the planet to help trigger mass extinction. ``We think we have found the smoking gun, but there may be other guns and maybe a firing squad,'' said Bill Boynton, of the University of Arizona at Tucson. The latest theory came during the American Geophysical Union's fall meeting. The convention of 4,400 Earth scientists leans heavily toward the theory that killer asteroids sent dinosaurs to oblivion. The idea is that an incoming 6-mile-wide asteroid or comet - or a shower of them - smacked into the Earth with the force of 70 million one-megaton bombs, kicking debris into the atmosphere and causing radical environmental damage that wiped out the dinosaurs and up to 75 percent of all living species. Some researchers think the impacts blocked out sunlight, wiping out food supplies. Others theorized, somewhat in jest, that changes in vegetation upset the dinosaurs' diet, leaving them fatally constipated. Other possible deadly effects of asteroids hitting Earth include acid rain, giant tidal waves, dark freezing weather, global warming by the greenhouse effect and worldwide forest fires, said geologist Walter Alvarez of the University of California at Berkeley, who helped start the debate in 1978. Jay Melosh of the University of Arizona said worldwide soot deposits support the fire theory. He believes a single asteroid plowed into the Earth and sent molten rock droplets skyward, where they heated the atmosphere and caused 700-degree surface temperatures. ``It's enough heat to ignite vegetation,'' Melosh said. ``Unprotected animals would have been broiled in their tracks.'' Alvarez, his father - the late Nobel Laureate physicist Luis W. Alvarez - and others found deposits of 65-million-year-old iridium metal in rocks around the world. Iridium is rare on Earth but less rare in asteroids and comets. The killer-asteroid theory was born because an impact would have spread iridium dust around the globe. Some researchers still argue the dinosaurs were rendered extinct by gradual, natural climate changes or by climate disruption from huge volcanic eruptions. They demanded asteroid advocates show where the object or objects hit Earth. The 22-mile-wide crater in Iowa was created by an impact that probably wasn't large enough to cause mass extinction, Alvarez said. Last May, Alan Hildebrand, Boynton and others in Arizona proposed one culprit impact crater in the Caribbean off Colombia's coast. As evidence, they cited rock deposits in Haiti and the U.S. Gulf coast caused by asteroid-induced rock fallout and 3-mile-high tidal waves. In their latest study, presented by Boynton, they propose another asteroid struck shallow Mexican waters. The impact site is a 110-mile-wide crater now covered by sediment on the coast of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the town of Chicxulub. The crater contains once-melted rock and shocked quartz grains that indicate something jolted the shallow sea floor. Boynton called the site ``ground zero'' but said another asteroid probably hit offshore from Columbia. Others say there was in impact near Cuba. Brown University's Peter Schultz said laboratory studies show a single 6-mile-wide asteroid hitting Earth at a 15-degree angle could have broken into 1,000 smaller pieces that caused a series of impact craters. Alvarez said there also must be other impacts because some debris found in worldwide rock deposits contains tiny balls of basalt glass that couldn't have come from an asteroid smacking into Iowa or the Yucatan. Alvarez said the debate is so important it has generated 2,000 studies since 1978. ``We wouldn't be here if it hadn't been for the extinction of the dinosaurs,'' Alvarez said. ``They were ruling the place. Mammals were just running around underfoot until the impact killed the dinosaurs and let us evolve.'' But if a huge asteroid impact happened today, it would cause the extinction of the human race, said Ronald Prinn, of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors to Seek Murder Indictment
DOC.TEXT: Authorities will seek a murder indictment in the 1982 death of a woman who was struck by a stray bullet during an alleged drug-war shootout, a prosecutor said. The slaying of Dennison University student Laura Carter was the inspiration for the popular song ``Think of Laura'' by Christopher Cross. James W. Smith, 52, had been charged with complicity and conspiracy to commit murder, but those charges were dropped Monday. Doug Stead, assistant Franklin county prosecutor, said he and another assistant prosecutor decided to seek an indictment on the more severe charge of murder. They dismissed the conspiracy charge because Smith cannot be charged twice for the same crime, he said. Common Pleas Judge Michael Close ordered the complicity charge dropped because it wasn't filed within six years, the statute of limitations. Smith was arrested in 1988 on the conspiracy charge. He was released from jail and failed to appear for trial. He later was indicted on the complicity charge. Ms. Carter, an 18-year-old student from Wayne, Pa., was riding in a car with her father on a Columbus street when she was shot April 17, 1982. Police believe that Smith and three other men were trying to kill two members of a rival drug gang when a stray bullet struck Ms. Carter. Smith's gang was upset over the other gang's efforts to move in on the city's drug trade, according to court documents. Gordon C. Newlin and Norman Whiteside, two of the three men who allegedly were with Smith, have been sentenced to prison terms of seven to 25 years for conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. Another defendant, Paul Newlin, is charged with aggravated murder, involuntary manslaughter, conspiracy to commit aggravated murder and felonious assault.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator: Two Senators Pushed for Sale, Not Seizure of S&L
With AM-Bennett Profile, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with later Wall testimony, inserting new 4th graf and inserting 3 grafs after 12th graf pvs, In a
DOC.TEXT: As Charles H. Keating's savings and loan hurtled toward failure, two of the Keating Five senators pushed hard for a sale rather than a government takeover of the institution, a former chief S&L regulator testified Tuesday. M. Danny Wall told Senate Ethics Committee hearings that Sen. Alan Cranston contacted him four times and Sen. Dennis DeConcini at least twice to urge that regulators not seize Lincoln Savings and Loan. Wall focused on activities of Cranston and DeConcini from the beginning of January through mid-April 1989 - a hectic period when the Federal Home Loan Bank Board considered and rejected three proposed sales of Lincoln. Regulators took over the Keating-owned, Irvine, Calif., thrift that April 14. The former regulator said Cranston told him that day, ``something to the effect'' that ``I think the board has made a mistake - I hope you are right.'' Two years before the seizure, regulators told Cranston, D-Calif., DeConcini, D-Ariz. and three other senators that criminal referrals on Lincoln were being forwarded to the Justice Department. Testimony in the hearings has shown that only the two senators contacted the bank board after that. The three other senators whose conduct is being investigated by the Ethics Committee are Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. The committee is in its 11th day of hearings to determine whether the five senators improperly intervened for Keating with banking regulators in return for $1.3 million he and associates donated to theircampaigns and causes. DeConcini and Cranston said they contacted Wall about a sale because they were trying to save jobs at the thrift and at its parent company, American Continental Corp., which is based in Phoenix. Wall said that Cranston ``urged the board to give prompt consideration and approval to any legitimate proposals'' for the sale of Lincoln. DeConcini, he testified, sought ``prompt consideration but did not state that a particular proposal be accepted.'' Wall said all three offers were rejected by the bank board or its staff because Keating was not entirely separated from the buyers and it appeared the new Lincoln would not be able to survive economically. The former regulator, now a private financial consultant, said, ``I don't recall any discussion where details were discussed'' with the senators. Wall said Cranston called him three times and they met April 7, 1989, just a week before the takeover. DeConcini called April 7 and again on April 11, Wall said, and added there may have been a third contact with the Arizonan not reflected in his records. In a sworn statement to the committee, Wall said on Nov. 7, ``I have stated many times that my decisions regarding Lincoln were not influenced by Mr. Keating, Sen. Cranston or Sen. DeConcini.'' Wall responded ``no'' when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., asked if any of the senators pressured him to act in a particular way. In his Nov. 7 statement, Wall said the large number of calls by Cranston between 1987 and 1989 was unusual, but not improper. Wall, who formerly worked for Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, was asked whether his former boss would have made the number of calls that Cranston did to regulators. ``Sen. Garn wouldn't have done it. Others certainly do,'' he testified. During the same January to April period, Keating was pushing hard for approval of a sale. Wall quoted Keating as asking for an appointment in January 1989 to discuss a subject that was - according to Keating - the ``culmination of my life, maybe my fortune.'' When the meeting took place on Jan. 17, Wall said, Keating indicated he was trying to sell Lincoln and that it ``was not wise for him to get into a regulated business. He wanted to get out of the business.'' Cranston told the committee, according to the transcript of his closed-door testimony on May 17, that he never inquired about details of the proposed sales. ``All I wanted them (the bank board members) to do was to make sure they didn't block a sale just because they were down on Keating and wanted - some people may have wanted to drive him out of business rather than let him sell his way out of the business.'' Cranston didn't identify the subjects of his remarks, but has been highly critical of Wall's predecessor as bank board chairman, Edwin J. Gray. Gray has been the chief accuser of the five senators, saying they improperly intervened with him on Keating's behalf. Keating has said Gray was prejudiced against Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Bargaining Teeters on Brink of Collapse
DOC.TEXT: An ambitious effort to overhaul the world trading system appeared on the verge of collapse Tuesday as pressure built on European countries to compromise in their fight against major farm subsidy cuts. Some European officials indicated they were willing to offer more agriculture subsidy cuts, although it was uncertain whether any new offer would be enough to satisfy U.S. negotiators. The 12-nation European Community had staunchly resisted a U.S.-backed proposal to slash export subsidies by 90 percent and reduce internal support payments and market barriers by 75 percent over the next decade. Many Third World countries viewed lower farm barriers as their No. 1 priority in the discussions. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round since they began in 1986 in the South American nation, seek to dismantle barriers to trade in agricultural products, manufactured goods and the fast-growing area of services, such as banking and insurance. ``We have a very large stalemate in agriculture and that is unfortunate,'' said a disappointed U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Rufus Yerxa, one of Hills' top aides, said ``negotiations are very close to collapse.'' A U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said even if the farm issue is resolved, it was unlikely a final trade agreement could be completed on schedule this week. He suggested another meeting would be necessary, possibly in January with lower-level negotiators involved. A total of 107 nations are participating in the discussions, which had been scheduled to wrap up with five days of marathon bargaining this week at the Heysel Palaces, a vast exhibition complex on the outskirts of Brussels. Facing the prospect that these talks could fail, officials from Germany said Tuesday they were now campaigning with EC members for more flexibility on agriculture subsididies. Germany's change of position, just two days after national elections, could represent a significant breakthrough. The Germans had been one of the major opponents of farm subsidy cuts. But there was no indication that France and Ireland, two other strong supporters of the subsidies, had softened their position. Assistant German Economics Minister Lorenz Schomerus did not give any details on what level of subsidy cuts the Germans would support. At present, the EC is offering what would amount to a 15 percent reduction in internal price supports. Other members of the EC include: Belgium, Denmark, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain, Spain and Portugal. U.S. officials held out hope that a meeting in Paris on Wednesday between German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand might produce a change in France's opposition as well. The meeting was officially called to discuss next week's summit of European Community leaders in Rome, but it was likely the two leaders would take up the farm question. The Bush administration has estimated a successful trade agreement would help reduce America's huge trade deficits, still running at nearly $100 billion a year, by boosting export opportunities for U.S. farmers and businesses. President Bush, who is on a trip to South America, said Wednesday, ``We must use this meeting to find the political will to limit or reduce distortions in trade.'' Bush in the past has lobbied other heads of state to support the talks, which the administration has made its top trade priority. However, U.S. negotiators have found little progress in the first two days of talks in Brussels. ``For all practical purposes, two days of negotiations here in Brussels have been wasted in so far as agriculture is concerned and there are not that many days left,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. Negotiators in the other 14 areas of the talks also reported little progress. ``I have seen no real movements from entrenched positions in any of the major areas,'' Uruguayan Foreign Minister Hector Gros Espiell, the chairman of the trade talks, said Tuesday night. ``I feel that we need substantial breakthroughs ... if this meeting is to end with a package of results truly meaningful for all participants.''

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Anti-Communist Leader Admits Former Police Informer Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with opposition leader admits former role as police informer, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the major opposition coalition of anti-Communists acknowledged on Tuesday that he had worked as a police informer under the discredited former hard-line Marxist regime. Peter Beron, chief of the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces, was reacting to charges earlier Tuesday that he and 70 other parliamentarians collaborated with the police under the toppled Communist leadership. Beron had said Monday that he wanted to return to work as a zoologist and planned to leave politics. On Tuesday, Beron told state radio he informed on foreign visitors to the Museum of Natural History while in charge of the museum's international relations department during the 1980s. But he denied working for the Sixth Department, the feared political police section that spied on Bulgarians seen as a threat to the Communist leadership. He said his activities were ``normal practice in every normal state.'' ``I never was a member of the Communist Party, unlike many who now accuse me,'' Beron said, alluding to former Marxists who went over to the opposition in the last year, after Bulgaria's Communist dictatorship crumbled. Beron spoke from Budapest, Hungary, en route to Bulgaria. He insisted that his police activities served the state and not the Communist Party. Hours after union leader Konstantin Trenchev leveled his accusations, Parliament voted overwhelmingly to ask the Interior Ministry to hand over files to a special legislative committee within a week on all legislators who had worked with the secret police. Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov and his government of former Communists were toppled last Friday by a UDF boycott of the legislature, prolonged street demonstrations and a general strike called by the Podkrepa trade union federation. Lukanov's administration came under fire largely because of its links with the former Communist system. The Communists changed their name to the Bulgarian Socialist Party after the old regime fell. The former Communists won June elections but saw their popularity fade as economic troubles mounted. Bulgaria now rations basic foods and energy. The Socialists are negotiating the makeup of a new government with the UDF. Trenchev, chairman of Podkrepa, said in an interview, ``Our union has a list with 71 names of deputies who were employees of the former secret police. These people must leave Parliament.'' He said 54 of the deputies were Socialists and 17 were members of the UDF, including Beron. The allegations were likely to split the opposition at a time when it needs unity in its bid for a major share of power in a new government, and to further polarize Parliament. That could make it harder to approve economic reforms needed to bring Bulgaria out of its worst post-World War II economic crisis. In separate comments, the state BTA news agency quoted Trenchev as saying Beron ``has been an informer of ... the `thought police' of the totalitarian regime.'' Prominent members of the UDF refused to dismiss allegations of further police informers in their ranks. ``I cannot exclude the possibility that a whole bunch of (our) people were employees of the security police in the past and continue in such functions even today,'' Alexander Yordanov said in an interview. In such a case, ``the Communist Party remains in power in Bulgaria and the system remains totalitarian,'' he said. Unlike other East bloc countries, where Communists were ousted by popular pressure, reformist Communists toppled Bulgaria's longtime Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov in November 1989. The former Communists - now Socialists - are widely considered the heirs of a bankrupt Communist system that was based on police state controls, a centralized economy and dependence on Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Wally Hickel Sworn in as Alaska's First Independent Governor
DOC.TEXT: Walter Hickel was sworn in as Alaska's first independent governor, declaring ``a new day for this great land'' and promising to protect the resource-rich state from outside interests. ``Alaskans are truly independent, regardless of political party,'' Hickel said at Monday's ceremony. ``And we're not awed by outside interests, however big they are or think they are.'' Hickel returned to the governor's mansion 22 years after he quit halfway through his first term to become U.S. interior secretary under President Nixon. He succeeds Democrat Steve Cowper, who did not seek re-election to a second term. At 71, Hickel is the oldest governor in the state's 32-year history. During his campaign and again Monday, Hickel appealed to Alaskans' historic sense that they have too little control over the state's vast resource wealth. He promised to take a tough stand in dealing with outside business interests, environmental groups and Congress. ``We will not tolerate those who would take advantage of Alaska's people or abuse our beautiful state,'' he said. ``We're going to insist that they play by our rules.'' Although a lifelong Republican, Hickel ran on the Alaskan Independence Party ticket after that party's primary winner dropped out in September. He was elected in November.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Army to Use Volunteers in Caucasus
DOC.TEXT: Serving in the Soviet Army in the ethnically warring regions of the Caucasus has become so dangerous that only volunteers will be sent there in the future, a top army official said Tuesday. Grigory Krivosheyev, deputy chief of the general staff, told the official news agency Tass that the army was having difficulty maintaining units at full strength in the southern district, which includes Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia. Armenians and Azerbaijanis have been in violent ethnic conflict with each other for nearly three years. Krivosheyev said troops in the area are often insulted, both verbally and physically. He said the order came from Defense Minister Dmitry Yazov.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Navy Submarine Has Financial, Technical Problems
DOC.TEXT: Congress should limit funding of the Navy's $48.7 billion Seawolf attack submarine, which is plagued by financial and technical problems rooted in its computer system, a House committee report says. The vessel is ``perhaps the most conspicuous and potentially most costly example of a program struggling with the problems of adapting state-of-the-art computer technology into a multibillion-dollar weapons platform,'' the Government Operations Committee said in its report, scheduled for release Wednesday. It recommends that Congress limit funding for construction of additional Seawolf submarines until the Pentagon clarifies the program's mission and provides assurances that the computer problems will be fixed. Spokesman Lt. Greg Smith said the Navy would have no immediate comment. Pentagon plans call for building 29 of the ships for $48.7 billion, with the first scheduled for completion in 1995. The Seawolf is billed as the largest, quietest and most heavily armed nuclear attack submarines. A key component of the Seawolf is its BSY-2 computerized combat system. General Electric is under contract to develop three of the systems. The report said testimony at committee hearings revealed that more than 800 people will be needed to develop the software programs for the Seawolf and integrate an estimated 3.2 million lines of code. The contractor, the report said, was having trouble finding qualified workers for the task. The Navy has a ``dismal'' track record on combat computer system acquisition, the report said. It said the policy was based on a ``buy now, fix later'' philosophy under which the Navy purchases components before all the problems are worked out. The Navy is developing BSY-2 separately from the rest of the Seawolf on the premise that the combat system will be ready for installation when the rest of the submarine is completed, said Government Operations chairman John Conyers, D-Mich. ``This did not work with previous class submarines and there is no reason to believe it will work now,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: EXPANDS 2nd item to UPDATE with Nielsen ratings
DOC.TEXT: Madonna, a master at making videos that generate almost as much controversy as they do record sales, wants to know why violence is acceptable for television and steamy sex scenes are not. Madonna appeared on ABC-TV's ``Nightline'' early Tuesday in an interview just after the news program aired her too-hot-for-MTV video ``Justify My Love'' in its entirety. The video, rejected by MTV last week, features the bra-and-garter-belt-clad singer in an encounter with a lover, played by her real-life boyfriend, Tony Ward, in a Paris hotel. The video is intended to portray the couple's fantasies, which run to bisexuality, voyeurism, group sex, cross-dressing and mild sadomasochism. She told interviewer Forrest Sawyer via satellite from Los Angeles that the video - with its chains, black leather and crucifixes - was about ``honesty ... and the celebration of sex. There's nothing wrong with that.'' But she said she thought there was a double standard at work on television. ``Why are we willing to deal with the reality of violence and sexism and why aren't we willing to deal with sexuality?'' she asked. The appearance got the show its highest overnight ratings this year, ABC said Tuesday. The 30-minute show averaged a 10.2 rating in overnight A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings from 25 cities. Those ratings represent nearly half of the nation's 93.1 million TV households. The program's national ratings won't be in until next week, but ABC projects that they also will be the highest this year for ``Nightline,'' said spokeswoman Laura Wessner. Monday's show was preceded by ABC's telecast of the San Francisco 49ers-New York Giants' football game, which very likely helped the ``Nightline'' ratings by giving the show a big lead-in audience, Wessner said. Monday's ``Nightline'' marked the first time a major network had run Madonna's much-publicized video without first censoring parts of it. But the video's first uncensored national telecast was Thursday, when it was shown on The Jukebox Network, an interactive cable network. Despite the appearance of Madonna and her video on ``Nightline,'' the show's ratings champion probably will remain Ted Koppel's May 27, 1987, interview of fallen TV evangelist Jim Bakker and Bakker's wife, Tammy. That one-hour special broadcast averaged an 11.4 national rating. A ratings point in 1987 represented 87.4 million homes.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Dangerous Eye Drops, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0544,0778
DOC.HEAD: Contaminated Eye Drops Cause Two To Lose Eyes, Others To Suffer Infections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with officials wrangling over prosecuting pharmacist, subs pvs grafs 6-10 bgng ``State and federal officials'' with 7 new grafs, pickup ``The patients who''
DOC.TEXT: For years pharmacist Edward Kilkeary used arthritis medication, saline solution and sterilizing equipment to whip up hundreds of tiny bottles of specially prescribed eye drops for cataract patients. But sometime this year something went wrong. Two women last month each lost an eye to a virulent bacteria. At least 10 people were hospitalized with infections, and countless others sought help for swelling and burning caused by a toxin that was eating away their eyes. The bacteria, pseudomonas, contaminated an unknown number of bottles that were sold under the name Indocin to patients who had recently undergone cataract surgery. The infection puzzled doctors who treated the patients, and the drops were traced to Hieber's Drug Store, where Kilkeary manufactured them. ``A pharmacy is a place where people put their trust, like their docs, like their priests,'' said Dr. Robert Lewen of Allegheny General Hospital, where eight people were treated. ``When that trust is violated, I think people seem to be somewhat resentful. This was not supposed to be the way things work.'' State and federal agencies investigated, but answers have been hampered by poor records, the sale of the drug to other pharmacies and doctors, and conflicting information from Kilkeary, said Ron Howard of the state Health Department. Kilkeary has refused to be interviewed. District Attorney Robert Colville said Tuesday that investigators lack hard evidence to warrant the filing of criminal charges against Hieber's or Kilkeary because there is no proof of ``gross, wanton and willful disregard for the safety of others.'' But Howard said he has ``one of the tightest cases'' he's seen in 25 years and will try to pursue prosecution with other authorities if Colville decides not to take it. ``There's more than one way of handling legal action,'' Howard's boss, Jack Ogun, director of the Health Department's Bureau of Drugs, Devices and Cosmetics, said Tuesday. Colville characterized the evidence as technical violations, which he called ``bureaucratic nitpicking.'' ``It's selective enforcement, looking at somebody after the fact,'' he said. ``If they had been enforcing these regulations and Hieber's failed to comply, I'd say fine. But there's no evidence they did that. That kind of enforcement the court looks at with a jaundiced eye.'' The patients who experienced the worst problems ranged in age from 55 to 78 and took the drops after undergoing cataract surgery when their wounds were fresh, giving the bacteria access to sensitive tissues. Two women had to have their eyes removed because of irreversible infections from the drops, Lewen said. ``Their eyes were blind, painful and cosmetically unacceptable - ugly, red and draining. The pain was as unrelenting as toothache pain,'' Lewen said. He also said there was a small risk the infection could spread to the brain. Indocin is an anti-inflammatory drug produced by Merck, Sharp & Dohme for pain caused by diseases such as arthritis. At least 15 Pittsburgh-area doctors have legally prescribed it to reduce swelling after eye surgery, Howard said. Indocin has not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use as eye drops, but such use is not illegal. Hieber's is believed to be the only pharmacy in the area that manufactures the drops, which are sold in half-ounce bottles for about $15. Howard said Kilkeary made up to 2,000 bottles a year and either sold the medication outright to patients with prescriptions or for resale to doctors and other pharmacies in violation of state pharmaceutical regulations. Because Kilkeary wasn't registered as a drug manufacturer, there was no inspection of his facilities and methods, which Howard called ``extremely primitive.'' He said Kilkeary used an autoclave - a pressurized vessel used for sterilization - but couldn't answer questions about the amount of heat or pressure applied to kill bacteria. Recent eye surgery patients with Indocin eye drops, or drops that contain the generic ingredient indomethacin, have been warned not to use them. Henry Henrich, a 65-year-old from McKeesport who was treated for infection in one eye, has sued for $20,000, and more lawsuits are anticipated. ``You have a guy making moonshine in the back yard and selling it as medicine,'' said his attorney, Samuel Cordes. ``The methods they were using are so primitive that it's kind of surprising it hasn't happened before.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says 27 Drug Traffickers Hanged
DOC.TEXT: Iran said 27 members of a drug trafficking gang were hanged in the western city of Bakhtaran on Tuesday, the same day a U.N. committee adopted a resolution calling on Tehran to end human rights abuses. The traffickers executed at Dizelabad prison had been involved in buying and selling narcotics in Bakhtaran and Zahedan, the official Islamic Republic News Agency said in a two-paragraph report monitored in Nicosia. The People's Mujahedeen of Iran, an exile group dedicated to toppling Iran's government, has claimed the government sometimes disguises executions of dissidents by claiming they are drug dealers. The U.N. resolution, a compromise version that deleted draft language criticizing ``executions, ill-treatment and torture'' in Iran, came as Amnesty International accused Tehran of perpetrating a wave of political executions. The General Assembly subcommittee dealing with human rights dropped that language so Tehran would continue cooperating with U.N. human rights investigations and let the Red Cross visit its prisons.

DOC.HEAD: Plus, Visa Systems Exchange ATM Cardholder Privileges
DOC.TEXT: Executives of Plus System and Visa USA agreed Monday on a program to provide their cardholders with access to all U.S.-based automated teller machines in the Plus and Visa Networks. During the next two years, the move will add 14,000 domestic locations to the Visa network, and 6,000 locations to the Plus network. Visa's Wesley C. Tallman, executive vice president for debit systems, estimated that financial institutions will generate increased ATM volume from 410 million cards from both networks. Only small technical changes will be required in the respective machines to permit the added access, executives said. Customers will know they can take advantage of the added-access machines when they see the Plus or Visa decals installed on their ATMs. The announcement was made at the Bank Administration Institute's Retail Delivery Systems Conference. Plus is based in Denver, and Visa headquarters are in San Mateo.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Chopper Crashes in Caribbean, Seven Rescued Unharmed
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army helicopter carrying seven people crashed and sank Tuesday in rough seas off the U.S. Virgin Islands, authorities said. The seven were rescued unharmed from a life raft. The UH-1H Huey helicopter from the St. Croix National Guard sank 22 miles south of St. Thomas after crashing Tuesday morning while on a scheduled mission to Puerto Rico, officials said. The four passengers and three crewmen were flown to Roosevelt Roads Naval Station Hospital in Puerto Rico as a precautionary measure. Maj. Gen. Charles M. Hood,of the U.S. Virgin Islands National Guard said cause of the mishap was being investigated. There were no other details immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Identifies Wisconsin Airman Killed in Saudi Accident
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Tuesday identified an American airman killed in a vehicle accident in Saudi Arabia last weekend. Airman First Class Rocky J. Nelson of New Auburn, Wis., was killed at 5:40 a.m. local time Saturday at an undisclosed air base in Saudi Arabia. No other information about the incident was available. Nelson, 21, was deployed to Saudi Arabia from the 4th Tactical Fighter Wing's Civil Engineering Squadron based at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, N.C. It was the 47th accidental death of U.S. military personnel in Operation Desert Shield since the deployment to the Persian Gulf started Aug. 7.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Told U.S., Canada Bungled Gander Crash Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs with FBI saying no credible evidence surfaced on possible terrorism aspect
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. and Canadian governments bungled the probe of a crash that killed 256 American servicemen and may be concealing a possible terrorist connection, a congressional panel was told Tuesday. Rep. Robin Tallon, D-S.C., told the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime that federal agencies appear to be guilty of ``ineptness or the best-contrived cover-up ... ever'' in the Dec. 12, 1985, crash in Gander, Newfoundland. The DC-8 carrying U.S. peacekeeping troops home from the Middle East crashed less than 30 seconds after takeoff. ``Incredibly, no U.S. government agency, or at least none with official responsibility, demonstrated any determination to find out just what caused the crash,'' said subcommittee Chairman William Hughes, D-N.J. ``The National Transportation Safety Board, and other agencies of the U.S. government, chose to sit back and watch as the Canadian efforts became embroiled in controversy,'' Hughes said. ``The NTSB routinely rubber-stamped the Canadian findings.'' The Canadian investigation attributed the probable cause of the crash to ice on the wings of the chartered military jet. A subcommittee staff report that formed the basis for Tuesday's hearing said there was no evidence that either the United States or Canada had seriously investigated possible terrorism. Eyewitnesses say they saw a bright orange object in the sky at the time of the crash, suggesting the plane was on fire. An anonymous caller later said that Islamic Jihad, a pro-Iranian terrorist group, had put a bomb on the plane. ``When a terrorist organization took credit for this abomination, why was this claim not investigated and a report made to the American people?'' asked retired Army Col. Lewis Millett. Millett, a Medal of Honor winner, wiped his eyes as he spoke of his son, a soldier in the Army's 101st Airborne Division who died in the crash. The theory of ice on the wings is ``preposterous,'' said L.T. Filotas, a Canadian aeronautical engineer who served on the investigating panel and dissented from the majority's finding. Filotas said the five-member majority of the Canadian board refused to set aside the ice theory long enough to investigate other possibilities. Tallon and others suggest the plane might have been blown up by terrorists in connection with the Iran-Contra affair. The Reagan administration authorized a shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran less than three weeks before the plane crashed. The missiles weren't the kind the Iranians were expecting and the Iranians felt they had been duped, according to computer messages from former White House aide Oliver North. The messages were uncovered by the Iran-Contra committees. In retaliation, terrorists might have planted an explosive device aboard the plane, said Dr. J.D. Phillips, a pathologist whose only son was killed in the crash. The man who piloted the plane on the first leg of its journey to Cairo, Egypt, told the FBI he believed it experienced structural failure or that a bomb exploded on takeoff. The pilot also told the FBI that the Egyptian Army guard assigned to the plane while it was on the ground disappeared from his post several times. The FBI and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police ``found very serious allegations'' but that information apparently wasn't turned over to the Canadian panel investigating the crash, Tallon said. The FBI said it has no reason to question the accuracy of the Canadian findings. ``No credible evidence has surfaced'' suggesting the charter flight by Miami-based Arrow Air crashed was the result of an act of terrorism, Nicholas O'Hara, deputy assistant director for criminal investigations at the FBI, said in prepared testimony. Arrow Air was one of the subcontractors that hauled weapons to the Contras for Oliver North's secret resupply network. It operated in 1985 and 1986 during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebel force.

DOC.HEAD: Tyminski Appeals to Miners in Home-Stretch Campaign Trip
LaserPhoto WAR50
DOC.TEXT: Dark-horse presidential candidate Stanislaw Tyminski on Tuesday led miners in chants of ``Down With Walesa'' in a return to one of his bases of support. The rally, however, was frequently disrupted by hecklers. Tyminski, an emigre businessman who returned to Poland after 21 years, made a home-stretch campaign trip into the mining region of Silesia, where he did well in the first round of voting Nov. 25. Tyminski said Solidarity leader Lech Walesa ``is finished,'' despite polls that show Walesa ahead by a 2-1 margin for Sunday's runoff election to pick Poland's first popularly chosen president. But Tyminski said his own polls put Walesa's support at 50 percent and his at 44 percent and growing. The 90-minute rally before about 3,000 people turned tense when about 500 Walesa supporters began to jeer Tyminski, who placed second in the first-round voting. There were shouting matches between the camps and several fistfights. Tuesday was the feast of St. Barbara, patron saint of miners, and was a holiday. Many of the miners were drinking before the rally in Jastrzebie, about 225 miles south of Warsaw. ``We are millions,'' Tyminski said shortly after arriving on stage to a din of boos and cheers. ``Now a new decade begins, and this decade belongs to us.'' After being interrupted by chants of ``KGB'' and ``Back to Peru,'' Tyminski, his Peruvian-born wife, Graciela, and their supporters responded with, ``Down with Walesa.'' ``I think he can hear it in Gdansk,'' Tyminski said, referring to the birthplace of Solidarity. ``Let him feel our power, like we could feel his power for the past 10 years.'' ``How much hatred there is for Walesa in our country,'' he said. ``Especially here in Silesia. Why didn't he come here?'' Tyminski claimed he turned down an invitation Tuesday night to meet with U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who is visiting Poland. A U.S. source confirmed Tyminski was on the guest list for an embassy reception for Cheney, but said there was no meeting planned. Cheney is traveling to Gdansk on Wednesday to see Walesa. Tyminski has promised to quickly improve Poland's economy and has blamed many of its problems on Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who was eliminated from the presidential race by placing third in the first round. But Tyminski has also been criticized for his leadership of the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada, his advocacy of nuclear weapons, his long absence from his country and his reported use of hallucinogens while living in an Amazonian river city in Peru in the early 1980s. He denied any use of drugs Tuesday. Tyminski supporters at the rally called Walesa a traitor. Under the Communists, miners were treated as a royalty among workers, earning twice the national average. Now many fear for their jobs as money-losing mines face closure or bankruptcy. Fifty-eight coal mines are losing money or cannot pay taxes this year, while 12 will show a profit, the government reported Tuesday. ``Walesa betrayed us ... He has no support in Silesia,'' said miner Mieczyslaw Kupko, who got Tyminski to autograph a copy of his self-published book of political thoughts titled, ``Sacred Dogs.'' ``Walesa is so fat because he grows on miners' money,'' agreed Legina Sadej. ``Tyminski can give us more.'' But the Solidarity leader also had loyalists in the hall, who believe Tyminski has ties to the Communist Party deposed from power by Solidarity in 1989. ``We have to save Poland against Tyminski,'' said Emilia Bargiel. She said she was ashamed that she voted for Tyminski in the first round. ``Nobody knew the truth about Tyminski, but finally the journalists found out - too late for many people,'' she said, referring to reports that former Communists and secret police are aiding Tyminski's bid. Earlier Tuesday, Tyminski charged there were secret police agents among prominent Solidarity activists. Tyminski repeated that he is a practicing Roman Catholic - 93 percent of Poles consider themselves Catholics - and said it would be up to the church to judge his decision to divorce and have children out of wedlock. Cardinal Jozef Glemp, leader of Poland's Roman Catholic Church, has urged followers to vote for Walesa, one newspaper reported Tuesday. Of the election, Walesa said in a radio talk show, ``I don't believe Mr. Tyminski has a chance. But he was needed as a lesson in democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: President of Angola Asks End of One-Party Rule
DOC.TEXT: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos on Tuesday told his party its political monopoly will soon end and said it must abandon Marxist economics to embrace the free market and democratic socialism. Dos Santos was unanimously re-elected president of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola at its third congress, but faces resistance to his reform plans from MPLA hard-liners. The six-day congress opened Tuesday and is scheduled to debate proposals for reforming the centralized economy and introducing multiparty democracy. The 700 delegates will also discuss the continuing peace talks with U.S.-backed UNITA rebels to end a 15-year-old civil war that has devastated what is potentially one of Africa's richest economies. Dos Santos told delegates this congress may be ``the last under a single-party system.'' His half-hour speech was interrupted by frequent applause. The president criticized the centrally planned economic system followed by the MPLA since Angola's independence from Portugal in 1975. ``The inadequacy of the system is showing in an economic asphyxiation because of the high level of collectivism of the means of production and services,'' he said. He also said political advances will be difficult while the war continues with UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. Portuguese government mediators said after a fifth round of peace talks between the two sides last month that they were close to a cease-fire. Talks are expected to resume next month. Gen. Juliao Mateus Paulo, deputy chief of staff of the Angolan armed forces, criticized the United States for its continued support of UNITA rebels. He told the congress on Tuesday that the Bush administration ``appears to be trying to take advantage of the new (international) situation by promoting instability in countries like Angola.'' In October, Congress passed an administration proposal for a $60 million U.S. military aid package to the rebels. It approved an amendment saying part of the aid may be suspended if Angola's government carries out its pledge to introduce a pluralist system and halts arms purchases from the Soviet Union. U.S. and Soviet observers have attended the peace talks in Portugal. Mateus Paulo is new chairman of a commission to overhaul the southern African state's constitution in preparation for multiparty democracy. He told deputies the armed forces' role will be radically altered in Angola's shift from one-party rule. Removing existing close links between the MPLA and the army and integrating government forces with UNITA guerrillas are among the toughest issues on the agenda of the peace talks. Dos Santos said Tuesday political advances will be difficult while the war continues with UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. He has said plans to introduce a multiparty system will go ahead early next year, even without an agreement with the rebels. Angola is rich in minerals and agricultural land, but the war has crippled economic activity and severed communications. Only exports from the heavily guarded northwestern oil fields have kept the economy afloat.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats, Senators Urge Restraint in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOP 3 grafs new with House Democratic Caucus action; INSERTS grafs 13-16 ``Across the'' with Aspin comment, testimony at separate House hearing on Saddam's personality
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats, on a vote of 177-37, adopted a policy statement late Tuesday which declared President Bush should take no military action against Iraq without prior approval from Congress, ``except to protect American lives from imminent endangerment.'' The Democratic caucus debated the non-binding declaration for two hours, amending it in the end to include language supporting the president's diplomatic initiatives in the Gulf crisis. But the admonition to Bush to seek congressional approval for making war ``is a statement by the Democratic Caucus that we want the Constitution respected on this crucial point,'' said Rep. Norman Lent, D-Wash. Earlier, former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara testified to a Senate committee that prior approval from Congress and the public for making war against Iraq should be a lesson heeded from Vietnam. And a Republican senator agreed that ``If we start having body bags coming back, we will have a very serious revolt'' if the president orders Americans into combat without that approval. McNamara, who was Lyndon B. Johnson's defense secretary at the height of U.S. involvement in Vietnam, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the administration should continue to rely upon economic sanctions as the main weapon against Iraq for a year or more. In Uruguay, Bush took issue with the parade of congressional witnesses who have argued for patience with the sanctions strategy. ``I've not been one whose been convinced that sanctions alone will bring him to his senses,'' Bush said of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Two other former Pentagon leaders, Gen. David Jones and Adm. William Crowe, had suggested earlier that Bush give the sanctions up to 18 months to work. As to that, Bush said ``I don't agree with them. ``I can't say how long, but I don't agree with them.'' McNamara, meanwhile, asked the Senate committee: ``Who can doubt that a year of blockade will be cheaper than a week of war?'' Asked to compare the situation with Vietnam, McNamara said: ``I do not believe the president should - and I do not believe he will - initiate action without the approval of the American people expressed by the approval of the Congress.'' Several committee members, meanwhile, indicated they had not been swayed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's argument to the Senate Armed Services Committee a day earlier that the international sanctions against Iraq were likely to prove futile. ``Sometimes there is more toughness in patience than in lashing out. This is such a time,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., a member of the foreign relations panel. Republican Sen. Larry Pressler of South Dakota said Americans want peace. ``If we start having body bags come back, we will have a very serious revolt in terms of public opinion,'' he warned. And Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., added: ``We have time. I don't see any hurry. I don't see any doubt that he either gets out, or he gets thrown out, blown out.'' Across the Capitol, House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., opened yet another Gulf policy hearing - set to last three weeks - by observing ``The country is united on ends but divided on means.'' Aspin, who has supported Bush's latest troop deployments, agreed that ``action that isn't backed by consensus will mean disaster. Whatever we do, the country, the Congress and the president must do it standing on common ground.'' The House panel heard Jerrold M. Post, founder of the CIA's Center for the Analysis of Personality and Political Behavior, say that Saddam is a ``judicious political calculator, who is by no means irrational, but is dangerous to the extreme.'' Post, now a professor at George Washington University, said ``It is this political personality constellation - meassianic ambition for unlimited power, absence of conscience, unconstrained aggression and a paranoid outlook - which make Saddam so dangerous.'' In making his argument for sanctions, Moynihan said Iraq relies on imports for items as basic as its own currency. Holding up several Iraqi dinars, he noted that they are printed in London, and wear out in about 12 months. Later, speaking with reporters, Moynihan observed that Bush had enjoyed unstinting congressional support until Nov. 8, when the administration announced a new troop buildup to achieve an offensive capability. Since then, Democrats have urged Bush to rely more on sanctions and diplomacy than on military force. But Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., agreed with Cheney's conclusion that a promise of time to let the sanctions work also amounted to a reprieve in pressure on Iraq that would let Saddam husband resources and build military strength. ``If he is able to hold off the entire world for two years, Saddam Hussein will be seen as the new Nasser of the Middle East,'' Boschwitz said, in a reference to the Egyptian Arab leader of the 1960s. But McNamara said those who focus on the costs of a prolonged embargo fail to see the costs of immediate military action. ``If we carry on sanctions for 12 to 18 months, there's no question we risk fracturing the unity of the international coalition'' lined up against Iraq, he said. ``But I can tell you, it's hardly a risk - it's almost a certainty - that if we undertake military action there will be a fracture of the unity ... ``There are divisive forces in the Arab world. They are going to be fed by the initiation of military action that is going to appear to many in the Arab world to be the unilateral action of the United States... . It is a far lesser risk than the loss of thousands of American lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Rejects Idea of Giving Sanctions Year to Work
EDs. LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with House Democrats' resolution; picks up old graf 16, 'Bush firmly; SUBS old graf 30, 'Bush and, to UPDATE with Bush swim; picks up last graf, 'After Argentina
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday rejected recommendations from former Pentagon chiefs to give sanctions against Iraq at least a year to work. A Uruguayan leader urged Bush to have ``infinite patience'' before resorting to military force. Bush, on the second day of a salute-to-democracy tour across South America, said he was not convinced ``sanctions alone would bring (Iraq's Saddam Hussein) to his senses.'' Oil prices driven up by the gulf crisis have devastated many countries economies, he said, vowing, ``This is not going to go on forever.'' Back in Washington, House Democrats voted 177-37 in caucus for a non-binding resolution telling Bush he must first get permission from Congress before sending troops into battle. Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara added his voice to the witnesses before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urging caution in the U.S.-led effort to force Iraq to relinquish its hold on Kuwait. ``Who can doubt that a year of blockade will be cheaper than a week of war?'' asked McNamara, who led the U.S. military buildup in Vietnam. Even in Montevideo, restraint was urged upon Bush. Uruguay's vice president exhorted Bush to exercise ``infinite patient in making a judgment'' in the gulf crisis. ``If the decision is for war, perhaps we will not justify it but we will certainly understand it,'' said Gonzalo Aguirre in introducing Bush to the Uruguay's Congress. Several lefist deputies and senators boycotted the speech and 400 demonstrators protested outside. Bush, at an earlier news conference with President Luis Alberto Lacalle, said Saddam ``has not gotten the message'' so far that he must withdraw from Kuwait or he will be forced out. The United Nations resolution authorizing force against Iraq unless it withdraws from Kuwait by Jan. 15 was ``loud and clear,'' Bush said. ``But I don't think Saddam Hussein yet understands that.'' ``The best hope for peace is for him to understand that all means - all means - necessary to fulfill these resolutions will be used against him,'' Bush said. The Persian Gulf crisis was at the top of his agenda as Bush arrived here from Brazil on the second day of his week-long tour of South America. The House Democrats' resolution states that he must get congressional permission before taking offensive action in the gulf ``except to protect American lives from imminent endangerment.'' McNamara testified that Bush should not act ``without the approval of the American people expressed by the approval of the Congress.'' A Republican senator, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, concurred, saying, ``If we start having body bags come back, we will have a very serious revolt in terms of public opinion.'' ``We have time. I don't see any hurry,'' said Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. ``Either (Saddam) gets out, or he gets thrown out, blown out.'' Bush firmly rejected suggestions from two former chairmen of the joint chiefs - Gen. David Jones and Adm. William Crowe - that he give sanctions against Iraq up to 18 months to work before resorting to force. Senate Democrats also have urged Bush to stick with the sanctions. ``I don't agree with them,'' Bush said. ``I can't say how long (sanctions should be tested) but I don't agree with them.'' Bush endorsed remarks Sunday by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who said the United States would not attack Iraq if it withdrew from Kuwait and complied with all U.N. peacemaking resolutions. ``I did not have any problem with that at all,'' the president said. Bush indicated he would take a tough stand when he meets at the White House with Iraq's Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on the gulf crisis. He said he would not allow any linkage with the Palestinian issue and Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``I'm not in a negotiating mood or anything of that nature when I meet with Aziz,' Bush said. Bush said the sanctions have been costly to Uruguay, as well as other countries, as oil prices climbed and export markets to Iraq and Kuwait were closed. ``And yet you never flinched, your country never flinched, you never wavered in support of these U.N. sanctions,'' Bush, the first American president to visit Uruguay since Lyndon Johnson in 1967, told the lawmakers. On Wednesday, Bush will head across the River Platte to Buenos Aires, mopping up from a failed revolt within the Argentine military. Bush said he did not view Monday's uprising as a sign that democracy is fragile in Argentina. He said he would salute President Carlos Menem for his leadership and economic reforms. Argentina has dispatched two warships to the Persian Gulf, the only Latin nation to join the multinational force. OPEC-member Venezuela, the last stop on Bush's trip, has stepped up oil production to help fill the gap in world supplies. Bush opened his visit here by proclaiming ``a new era in U.S.-Latin American relations.'' ``We in the Americas are on the brink of something unprecedented in world history - the first wholly democratic hemisphere,'' Bush said. ``And in anticipation of that, we need to create together a permanent partnership among all the nations of the Americas,'' he said. Bush and Lacalle both spoke of the importance of lifting barriers to international trade, including farm subsidies. Trade talks are now in their final days in Brussels in the effort to rewrite the global trading rules last forged in Uruguay in 1986. ``We are in the same boat in this GATT negotiations,'' said Lacalle, who said protectionist barriers and subsidies have ``hurt millions of people.'' ``We foresee a whole hemisphere of much more open trade,'' said Bush, who exhorted developing countries to ``move briskly to privatization, to free markets'' in order to attract investments and new technology. Bush said ``we are not locked on a specific figure'' on how deeply farm subsidies should be cut. ``We are locked on the fact that there has to be inclusion of all categories (of products). Bush and Lacalle later flew by helicopter to the ocean resort of Punta del Este, 90 miles east of the capital, where Bush jogged on the beach and took a dip in the Atlantic before dining with Lacalle at a posh restaurant. Bush was spending the night in a luxurious private beachfront home. After Argentina, Bush flies to Chile on Thursday and Venezuela on Friday before heading home on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Moonstruck High Tides Flood Northeast, Midwest Digs Out From Blizzard
LaserPhotos BX7, SB1
DOC.TEXT: The Midwest dug out of a deadly blizzard that dumped up to 2 feet of snow and high tides caused flooding Tuesday along Lake Erie and the New England Coast, forcing the evacuation of an office complex and a school in Maine. Seaside communities from Connecticut to Maine were hit by unusually high tides caused by a rare alignment of the moon, Earth and sun and whipped still higher by gale-force winds. Most of the Midwest was recovering from Monday's snowstorm that left at least nine people dead in Wisconsin, six in Iowa, and one in western Pennsylvania. However, the storm didn't hit Indiana until early Tuesday, causing at least four traffic fatalities as 4 inches of snow and 25 mph winds made driving treacherous in the north-central part of the state. The National Weather Service said high tide averaged 2 feet above normal Tuesday. Firefighters in Portland, Maine, evacuated about 100 people from offices along Portland Pier, which was covered in 3 feet of water by noon, said Capt. Lannie M. McGahey of the city Fire Department. ``We're kind of hoping the tide brings fresh fish in so we can serve it on the menu tonight,'' said Cynthia Moran, the owner of J's Oyster, a tavern doing brisk business among the office evacuees. In neighboring Falmouth, about 45 students were evacuated from the Governor Baxter School for the Deaf on Mackworth Island, hours before waves lapped over the causeway that connects the island to the mainland. In Massachusetts, the body of a Newburyport woman was found washed up at Salisbury Beach Tuesday afternoon. Early reports said the woman had been swept away by a wave at Plum Island, about five miles away, but Newbury Police Chief Roger Merry said later the woman apparently walked into the water. Elsewhere in Massachusetts, flooding washed out an archaeological dig at Coast Guard Beach in Eastham. Volunteers worked overnight Monday to try to save the 6,000-year-old campsite, but were forced to retreat as waters rose. In Revere, residents reported seeing at least one windsurfer testing the water even as waves washed over a seawall. Civil Defense officials in Providence, R.I., closed the city's massive hurricane gates for the first time since Hurricane Gloria brushed the East Coast in September 1985. High water closed sections of roads from New Hampshire's 18-mile seacoast to Washington County in extreme eastern Maine, leaving residents of some beachfront neighborhoods temporarily isolated. In Wisconsin, which was blanketed by up to 22 inches of snow Monday, schools remained closed in several counties, but government offices, banks and shopping malls reopened under sunny skies. Maintenance crews were working around the clock to clear streets and highways. ``The snow is still drifting, but we're getting some of the highways open to two-way traffic,'' said Steve Haag, Dane County highway maintenance supervisor, who called the storm the worst in his 18 years on the job. In Michigan, a 20-mile wide band of snow stretched from Grand Haven south along Lake Michigan to the Ohio border, with accumulations of up to a foot reported in Kalamazoo, the National Weather Service said. Work crews continued to clean up after Monday's high winds that left some 118,000 Michigan homes and businesses without electricity. Detroit Edison Co. spokesman Martin Buffalini said fewer than 1,800 people still were without power Tuesday afternoon, down from 43,000 on Monday. In the Grand Rapids area, Consumer Power Co. spokesman Paul Knopick said about 1,300 customers remained in the dark. Iowa residents made their way back to work and school Tuesday after digging out from up to 14 inches of snow. On Monday, interstate highways were closed, snowplows turned back because of drifts across roads, and mail delivery was canceled in some parts of the state. Kim McCarty, the Iowa City post office's customer service manager, said carriers probably would hear about the decision not to deliver in that city because ``neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night'' is supposed to stop the mail. ``We deliver mail quite often in inclement weather,'' McCarty said. ``Sure, there will be some ribbing. Some days you just don't want to take risks.'' The last time mail delivery was canceled in Iowa City was Dec. 24, 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Mammograms Improving, FDA Says
DOC.TEXT: The ability of mammograms to detect breast cancer early has improved significantly since 1985, though slightly higher radiation is being used, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday. The greater radiation is justified by the improved quality of images, the agency said. The radiation is still within FDA safety guidelines and is about two-thirds lower than 1979 levels. FDA surveys of mammography equipment in 1985 showed that 36 produced substandard images. A survey by the agency in 1988 found the rate had declined to 13 percent. ``I hope the surveys will encourage women to make greater use of mammography,'' said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health at the Department of Health and Human Services. ``Early detection and treatment offer women their best chance of surviving breast cancer.'' The National Cancer Institute recommends that women over 40 have regular mammograms. A report on the FDA's surveys was published in the November issue of the journal Radiology, the agency said. To test the X-ray machines used for mammography, the FDA uses a plastic device embedded with tiny objects. This device is X-rayed and the quality of the image is based on the number of the tiny objects that cn be seen. The acceptable score for an image is 8, the FDA said. In 1985, the average score was 7.8 and in 1988 the average had climbed to 9.9. The better quality in today's imaging devices is partly because of improvements in equipment, including more use of X-ray machines that are specifically designed for mammography, according to Fred Rueter of the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health, one of the authors of the article. He also said screen and film systems more sensitive to X-rays are helping to produce clearer pictures. FDA officials said that even a substandard image may still detect cancer earlier than if a woman relies only on breast self-examination alone. But some members of Congress are concerned that only one out of five mammography facilities meets the voluntary professional standards of the American College of Radiology. Several members plan to introduce legislation next year that would set minimum federal safety standards for mammography services.

DOC.HEAD: EC Preparing Big Soviet Aid Package
DOC.TEXT: The European Community is drafting a multibillion dollar aid package for the Soviet Union, including food, officials said Tuesday. Leaders of the 12 EC states are to approve the aid when they meet in Rome Dec. 14-15. The EC Executive Commission is readying the package in consultation with other nations, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Commission President Jacques Delors outlined the measures to EC foreign ministers at a meeting in Brussels. The package carries no firm price tag, but ``figures are being mentioned of between ... ($1.36 billion and $2.72 billion) over two years,'' Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said. He and other officials said that would mainly provide for food and transportation. The EC also plans to provide technical and administrative aid. German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said, ``We have to give a signal to support reforms'' in the Soviet Union. In addition, the EC is studying more long-term assistance for the ailing Soviet economy, notably by helping make the ruble a convertible currency and balance of payment support. EC aid for these purposes has not yet been calculated. Officials said the Community also planned to help the Soviet Union improve its oil production. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the problem at the heart of food shortages in the Soviet Union was ``a very poor'' distribution system. Germany - in gratitude for Moscow's support of German unification - began a large-scale program last week to ship food, from private citizens and public storage, to the Soviet Union. The Soviet aid package has been kept separate from EC aid plans for other countries because of the scope of Soviet economic, financial and food needs.

DOC.HEAD: Life Returns to Normal For Most After Earthquake Scare
DOC.TEXT: A questionable projection for an earthquake remained in effect Tuesday, but parties along the New Madrid Fault were over and TV crews left residents to their usually quiet lives. The small towns along the fault, which runs from Marked Tree, Ark., northeast through Missouri to Cairo, Ill., began getting back to normal. ``We're not used to traffic jams,'' said Virginia Carlson, director of the New Madrid Historical Museum. ``But I think everybody was amused by it.'' About 40 television satellite trucks rumbled out of this small Mississippi River town in southeast Missouri on Tuesday after the bulls-eye day of the projection had passed. ``Today, you couldn't tell that there'd ever been any talk of an earthquake,'' said Mayor Joe Gude of Blytheville, Ark. Iben Browning, a business consultant from Tijares, N.M., said that there was a 50-50 chance for a major quake in the Midwest or several other locations between Dec. 1 and Dec. 5. He based his projection on unusually high tidal forces, which he claims trigger earthquakes. Earthquake experts around the country said Browning's projection was nothing more than a random guess and tidal forces had nothing to do with earthquakes. Browning was vacationing at an undisclosed location, said his daughter, Evelynn Garriss. Mrs. Garriss noted there was a big quake in the Soviet Union within the same ``30- to 60-degree north latitudes that we were concerned about.'' But Mrs. Garriss would not say whether that fulfilled her father's projection. In any case, she noted that her father said the quake could happen any time from 48 hours before Monday to 48 hours afterward. Scientists have also noted that major earthquakes occur somewhere in the world every three days, so it's easy to make general predictions and be correct. In New Madrid, T-shirts were still available and business owners were talking about sponsoring an ``Iben Browning Day'' next year. Angie Holtzhouser, a spokeswoman for the chamber of commerce, said she didn't think there would be much of a legacy from Browning's projection for the town. ``Such a mega-dose of round-the-clock media I think has created some unnecessary fear and I hope that fades quickly,'' she said. She shrugged off fears that new industries would shun New Madrid because of all the earthquake attention. ``Has it harmed California?'' she asked. Jack Hailey, owner of Hap's Bar, was cleaning up Tuesday from his nearly 20-hour ``Shake, Rattle and Roll'' bash that began at 6 a.m. Monday. He said he may make the party an annual event, but next year will plan his T-shirt order better. He sold all of the 84 he had on hand. ``If I'd known what was going to happen, I would have had 500 more,'' Hailey said. In nearby Malden on Tuesday, city officials were still in the midst of a 10-day disaster drill that sent them out of City Hall and into an emergency center, and they've already learned plenty. ``It's the little things you forget,'' said City Clerk Rhonda Hollingshad. ``One of the things we decided we really need is a sign to let people know where we are.'' The drill, which has brought city business to a near standstill, will end Friday, not a moment too soon for Hollingshad. ``I'm going to go in Monday and work for a solid week without going home because of everything that's piling up,'' she said. Meanwhile, officials began adding up the costs and benefits of the Browning projection. Mississippi Emergency Management Agency Director J.E. Maher said his agency spent at least $31,000 in recent months. ``In travel, in putting together materials for presentations, it's taken a pretty substantial slice of revenue from our budget,'' he said. In Missouri, state officials estimated the cost at between $40,000 and $60,000, but they weren't complaining. ``We got more productivity from the dollars we spent than we did in probably three years worth of spending,'' said R.D. Ross, the director of Missouri emergency management office. Kentucky officials spent about $2,800 to print up extra pamphlets, but Mike Lynch, earthquake program coordinator for the state, said there were other costs for emergency officials. ``Can we put a dollar value on my nerves?''

DOC.HEAD: Tiles From Tunnel Roof Strike Buses
By JIM STRADER
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A pipe carrying electrical wires broke loose from the roof of the nation's fourth-longest land tunnels Tuesday, striking two buses and a car during evening rush hour, police said. One woman was injured. More than 500 cars were stuck in the Liberty Tunnels through Mount Washington for about 45 minutes after five sections of tubing fell out of their brackets onto the outbound lanes at about 5 p.m., said Pittsburgh police Batallion Chief John Schemm. The tubing contained low-voltage electrical wire and communications wires, police said. Police closed both inbound and outbound lanes, snarling traffic that was leaving downtown Pittsburgh for the heavily populated southern suburbs. Ramps leading to the tunnels also were closed. Police Chief Mayer DeRoy said one woman was injured, apparently not seriously, when the pipe hit the roof of her car and dented it. The nature of her injury was not immediately disclosed. Passengers on two Port Authority Transit buses were escorted from the tunnel on foot. Police and firefighters backed some of the cars out of the tunnel, and were able to slowly move one lane of traffic past the fallen pipe. The Liberty Bridge, which feeds the tunnels, was closed temporarily, but reopened shortly after the accident. Tunnel traffic was redirected over local roads on Mount Washington. Police and the state Transportation Department, which owns the tunnels, were considering keeping the outbound lanes closed until Wednesday evening for repairs, DeRoy said. The only tunnels in America longer than the Liberty Tunnels are tw Interstate 70 tunnels in Colorado and the Allegheny Tunnels on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Premier Says 1991 Will be Year of Deprivation
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Jozsef Antall warned Tuesday of a year of privation for many Hungarians, as the government tries to stem growing poverty, inflation and unemployment and introduce a free market economy. ``Next year will be a year of grave tribulations, but there is a way out,'' Antall told a hushed Parliament. ``However, that means we must not undermine our faith and determination, but unite and work together as a nation. ``The country is at a crossroads, and the hour of awakening is at hand.'' Hungary's $21 billion foreign debt makes it the most heavily indebted East European country on a per capita basis. Next year, $2.4 billion of principal will have to be repaid along with $1.7 billion in interest, and the heavy load is expected to add to the strain of switching to a market economy. Inflation is at 35 percent. Unemployment, officially unknown under the former Communist leadership, stands at 70,000 and is expected to include 200,000 of the 4.5 million work force by next year. The state MTI news agency on Monday cited statistics indicating at least 60 percent of families are drawing on savings to make ends meet, compared to 40 percent last year. In October, truckers and cabbies - furious over a planned 65 percent gasoline price increase - blocked main streets and highways throughout Hungary for three days. Most of the population supported the protest, forcing the government to back down and agree to smaller price increases. In his televised speech Tuesday, Antall warned of ``anarchy'' and social unrest that could follow the predicted worsening of the economy. ``If we cannot solve the economic tasks, cannot avoid the decline, there will be social tensions and conflicts which will pose a threat to our fledgling democracy,'' he told legislators. Antall outlined dismaying statistics: -Industrial productivity here is one-third that of developed countries. Energy consumption is two to three times as high. -The forecast rise in oil prices and agricultural losses due to the summer drought will cost Hungarians $2 billion. He blamed past Communist mismanagement for some of Hungary's present problems, saying $4.16 billion will be needed for economic development and $1.67 billion for environmental protection. ``This is what we have inherited and we must accept it - no one will shoulder it for us,'' Antall said. The huge debt is due to large-scale borrowng the past 20 years, with Hungary offering citizens Western imports and other amenities not found elsewhere in East Europe, he said. Antall said dissatisfaction and discontent were justified, but parties opposed to his conservative government coalition have been unable to offer better solutions. The prime minister asked for cooperation by all sides in Parliament prior to his government's presentation next week of a budget with a planned deficit of $1.3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Acquitted of Major Charges in Race Slaying Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Also Tuesday ...' to UPDATE with jurors sequestered, deliberations expected Wednesday in Vento trial. Picks up 4th graf, `The verdicts ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two white men were acquitted of murder Tuesday in the racially-motivated slaying of a black teen-ager in a mob attack in the city's Bensonhurst section last year.
