The jury took just four hours to return the verdicts for James Patino and Joseph Serrano following a two-week trial. The two smiled broadly as the verdicts were read, hugged their lawyer and then embraced in state Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Also Tuesday, another jury heard closing arguments in the case of Bensonhurst defendant John Vento, who is being retried for murder, manslaughter and riot after his first trial ended with a hung jury. Jurors were sequestered Tuesday evening and were expected to begin deliberations Wednesday. The verdict makes Patino the first defendant in the case to be cleared of all charges. ``I feel great, and my lawyer's wonderful, said Patino, 25, outside the courthouse. ``I'm glad everything's over.'' ``I'm sorry for what happened to Yusuf Hawkins, but I had nothing to with it,'' said Serrano, 21, after the verdict. ``I was confident. I was secure in my innocence.'' Both defendants had been accused of murder, manslaughter, riot, discrimination and other charges in the attack that resulted in the death of Hawkins, who was shot in the mostly white Brooklyn neighborhood on Aug. 23, 1989. Patino was found innocent of all the crimes. Serrano was convicted only of a misdemeanor weapons possession charge that is punishable by up to a year in prison. Prosecutor Edward Boyar shrugged and told reporters, ``I never quibble with a jury's verdict.'' Hawkins' killing was the most serious racial incident in the city since the 1986 killing of a 23-year-old black man in Howard Beach. In that confrontation, the victim was struck and killed by a car after a mob of whites chased him onto a highway. Hawkins, 16, was slain when he and three friends - all black teen-agers - went to Bensonhurst to look at a used car. The unarmed youths attracted the attention of a mob of as many as 30 bat-wielding whites looking for a fight. In Vento's case, Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns said Vento was ``an active recruiter'' and ``one of the leaders of the mob.'' ``Joseph Fama, acting by himself, could never have committed this crime,'' Burns said, referring to the convicted murderer of Hawkins. But defense lawyer Gerald J. DiChiara said Fama acted alone in the shooting and said Vento had nothing to do with it. ``Either he aided Joe Fama in the murder, or he's not guilty,'' DiChiara said. Jurors were to begin deliberating his fate later Tuesday. Fama was convicted of pulling a pistol and firing several shots through Hawkins' chest. The mob scattered without pausing to aid their victim or telephone the police. Prosecutors did not charge Serrano and Patino with shooting Hawkins, but alleged they acted in concert with Fama and shared the responsibility for the slaying. After hearing the prosecution's case, state Judge Thaddeus Owens said their evidence was insufficient to uphold many of the charges. He told the lawyers he would set aside the verdicts if Serrano or Patino were convicted of murder or manslaughter. In allowing the jury to deliberate the charges and deliver a finding, Owens preserved the prosecutors' right to appeal any verdict he dismissed. But Owens tossed out several charges before the case went to the jury, citing a lack of evidence. Those counts included one of two murder charges against Serrano, a gun possession charge against Patino and assault for both men. The main prosecution witnesses were Gina Feliciano and her mother, Phyllis D'Agata. The two women said they watched from their second-floor window as the mob pursued the blacks around a corner where the shooting took place. But they were unable to place Serrano or Patino at the scene and their testimony was filled with inconsistencies and contradictions. Fama is serving 32 and two-thirds years to life for his conviction. Keith Mondello, the ringleader, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter, but convicted of several lesser crimes. He was sentenced to five and one-third years to 16 years. Several other defendants are scheduled to stand trial early next year, including Charles Stressler, whose first case ended in a mistrial.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Snow, High Winds Scattered Over Nation
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over much of New England Tuesday, accompanied by high tides and gale force winds, while snow fell over parts of the Midwest and the Pacific Northwest. Warnings of 50-mph winds were issued for the northern half of the Atlantic Coast, much of the Great Lakes and parts of the central Gulf of Mexico Coast. Rain fell throughout New England, eastern and north-central New York, and northern New Jersey. At midafternoon, light snow was falling in western and south-central New York, north-central and western Pennsylvania, the Maryland panhandle, Ohio, West Virginia, western Virginia, eastern Kentucky, northern and eastern Indiana, Michigan and northern Wisconsin. Rain also extended over the northern Pacific Coast, and from eastern Washington state across the Idaho panhandle, changing to snow at higher elevations. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1.8 inches at Portland, Maine, 1.7 inches at Augusta, Maine, 1.35 inches at Providence, R.I., and 1.18 inches in Chatchicopee Falls, Mass., and Rumford, Maine. Snowfall during the same six hours included 3 inches at Caribou, Maine, and 2 inches at Houlton, Maine. Midland, Texas, set a new low for the date with a reading of 19 degrees. Its previous record of 20 was set in 1934. The morning low for the Lower 48 was 11 below zero at Bismarck, N.D. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 12 degrees at Ely, Minn., to 80 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Bangladeshi President Announces he Will Step Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS final graf to 107 million residents sted 90, ADDS four grafs with background on Ershad.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: President Hussain Muhammad Ershad capitulated to a 7-week-old campaign for his ouster Tuesday, promising to resign as soon as the opposition chooses a replacement. State-run radio announced the move in a late-night news bulletin. Soon afterward, hundreds of people thronged the streets, defying a curfew that restricted civilians to their homes. Many danced, set off fire crackers in celebration and shouted slogans. ``Where is Ershad now?'' some chanted. ``Seize the airport so he cannot flee! Catch Ershad, kill his ministers!'' At least 1,000 people attacked a downtown office of Ershad's Jatiya Party, reporters at the scene said. Portraits of Ershad and office furniture were thrown into the street and set on fire, they said. Security forces did not intervene or attempt to get people to return to their homes. But troops were seen being deployed outside the homes of government ministers to prevent further attacks. The radio bulletin said a special session of Parliament was scheduled for Sunday to ratify the choice of Ershad's replacement. Sheik Hasina, one of two opposition leaders heading the anti-Ershad campaign, called his resignation ``a people's victory.'' ``We are watching everything until the final game is over,'' she said, adding that choosing a replacement for Ershad was ``not a problem.'' The campaign for Ershad's ouster had mushroomed in recent weeks. Doctors, university professors, some of Ershad's parliamentarians and civil servants have resigned in solidarity with the opposition. Last week, Ershad imposed a state of emergency and suspended all civil rights in an attempt to crush the movement. The army had been called out to prevent street protests against his rule, and the opposition claimed that at least 100 political activists had been shot and killed. The government said only six people had died. Despite the crackdown, the protests continued. On Monday, Ershad offered to resign 45 days before June's presidential vote. He also offered to dissolve the legislature and hold simultaneous elections for the presidency and Parliament. The opposition said his concessions were not sufficient and urged daily dawn-to-dusk strikes to force the president's immediate resignation. Ms. Hasina and the second opposition leader, Khaleda Zia, have opposed Ershad since the former army general took power in a 1982 coup. But political differences between the two hindered earlier efforts to depose him. The latest campaign was launched in October after the two said they had resolved their differences. Ms. Hasina is the daughter of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's first president. Mrs. Zia is the widow of Ziaur Rehman, another former president. Both men were assassinated. On Monday, the president said in a nationally televised speech that the emergency restrictions would be lifted on Dec. 16, the 19th anniversary of Bangladesh's independence from Pakistan. He also announced the immediate lifting of press censorship, which had been imposed along with the emergency. But on Tuesday at least 19 lawmakers from Ershad's Jatiya Party resigned from Parliament, according to a letter circulated by Speaker Shamsul Huda Chowdhury. The party holds 266 of 300 seats. Giasuddin Ahmed, one lawmaker who resigned, later said: ``The Parliament has now become isolated from the people.'' Despite a ban on political meetings, leaders of the three major opposition alliances addressed rallies in Dhaka and announced daily protest strikes. Cars stayed off the streets, and shops were closed in the capital and in the southern port city of Chittagong. Banks and most businesses were shut. Government offices opened in Dhaka, but with most transportation off the roads few employees showed up for work. If Ershad's replacement is chosen by the opposition and approved by Parliament, it will be the first peaceful transition of power in Bangladesh. The country has had nine presidents since it gained independence in 1971, and all have taken over after assassinations or military coups. Ershad has ruled about half that time. Bangladesh, one of the poorest nations in the world, has more than 107 million people. It is bordered by India, Burma and the Bay of Bengal. Analysts said Ershad stayed in power so long by balancing civilian bureaucrats against army generals and frequently shuffling the military command to block the emergence of any rival power centers within the establishment. But as the protests dragged, on observers said his support in the army appreared less solid than earlier believed. Though Ershad gave Bangladesh a measure of political stability after a quick succession of military-installed presidents, he made little headway in alleviating the misery of his people. Ershad was opposed to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and sent a token force to stand alongside the United States and its allies.

DOC.HEAD: Puerto Rican Leaders Say Community Looking for Respect
With AM-Miami Rampage, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Once again, an ethnic Miami neighborhood erupted, pent-up frustrations sparked by a single incident. This time, though, it was in a community seldom heard from. ``This is singular for the Puerto Rican community, but not singular for Miami,'' said Puerto Rican-born Maurice Ferre, who was mayor for 12 years. ``It seems to be a pattern now for behavior in the poor, disadvantaged neighborhoods of Miami - black, Haitian, Puerto Rican,'' he said. Ferre referred to a rampage Monday night in the city's largely Puerto Rican community of Wynwood after the acquittal of six police officers accused of fatally beating Puerto Rican drug dealer Leonardo Mercado. As with members of other ethnic groups after earlier disturbances, some Puerto Ricans on Tuesday talked of neglect by Miami's dominant Cuban-American population. Puerto Rican flags were waved during the disturbance and there were shouts of ``Viva Puerto Rico!'' from members of an ethnic group that's had a low Miami profile. ``We want the people to know that we exist. We've got Puerto Ricans in this city, too,'' said Clemente Montalvo, who said he's lived all his life in Wynwood. ``It's not just because of the Mercado trial. Cubans get everything, we get nothing. When the Cubans jump, they get what they want.'' Ferre and other community leaders said the reasons behind the outbreak were complex. They said many of the looters were youthful opportunists, and many weren't Puerto Rican or from Wynwood. Ferre was mayor in 1980 during Miami's worst riots, which followed the acquittal of white police officers in the beating death of black insurance salesman Arthur McDuffie. The rioting claimed 18 lives and caused more than $100 million in damage. Black rioting broke out three other times in the 1980s, most recently the January 1989 riots following the deaths of two blacks after a police shooting. Last July, Miami riot police moved in after four days of violent Haitian protests at a shop owned by a Cuban-American accused of mistreating a Haitian in his store. The rioting Monday stunned police, city officials and many in the Wynwood community, where Mercado had once lived. Ferre said such disturbances are waiting to happen in urban areas where people feel helpless economically and politically. ``Somebody pushes somebody in a store. There's a perception of an injustice. It's an explosion,'' said Ferre, who comes from one of Puerto Rico's most influential political families and led Miami until 1985, when he was ousted by the city's first Cuban-born mayor, Xavier Suarez. Wynwood was one of the first large Hispanic neighborhoods in Florida in the post-World War II era, populated mainly by Puerto Rican migrant workers. There are now an estimated 55,000 Puerto Ricans in the Miami metropolitan area, compared with more than 600,000 Cubans and more than 100,000 people each in the Nicaraguan and Haitian communities. Wynwood has become more diverse in recent years, though the Puerto Rican influence is obvious with Roberto Clemente Park, named for the late Puerto Rican-born baseball star, and several stores with the name ``Borinquen,'' the island term for Puerto Ricans. Drugs and poverty have increased, longtime residents said. ``It's changed quite a lot, to the negative side,'' said David Bonilla, who lived there from 1955 and is the Puerto Rican-born Miami city police chaplain. Bonilla said the outbreak involved many outsiders and wasn't a true reflection of Wynwood. But he said some Puerto Ricans were using the attention to seek help for their deteriorating community. ``Some of these people want to let somebody know that we need help in the community,'' Bonilla said. ``They say, `Hey, while the cameras are here, everybody's here ...' ''

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishop Urges Trial Against Honecker
DOC.TEXT: Former East German Communist chief Erich Honecker should stand trial on charges he signed shoot-to-kill orders for guards at the Berlin Wall, a Roman Catholic bishop from east Berlin said Tuesday. ``The law is the law. On humanitarian grounds this individual humn being should not be treated differently than any other,'' Bishop Georg Sterzinsky of Berlin-Brandenburg told a news conference. The Berlin justice office issued an arrest warrant Friday charging Honecker with manslaughter. The charges directly link him to several deaths. If convicted, his prison sentence could range from five years to life. About 200 people died trying to escape East Germany during the 28-year existence of the Berlin Wall. Bishop Sterzinsky, who is based in former East Berlin, said that it would be possible to think about sparing Honecker from prison after sentencing. He spoke to reporters following a meeting of Berlin bishops. Honecker remained Tuesday inside a Soviet hospital 20 miles south of Berlin. Justice officials in Bonn denied talks had taken place with Soviet officials about serving an arrest warrant against Honecker. German police must have permission from the Soviets to enter the hospital. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said in Moscow on Monday that Honecker was staying at the hospital for humanitarian reasons. Honecker's lawyers have lodged a protest against the arrest warrant. But the Berlin justice office said Tuesday it could take days to make a decision. The defense counsels maintain Honecker, 78, is too ill to stand trial.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: ``I've not been one who's been convinced that sanctions alone will bring him to his senses.'' - President Bush in Uruguay, speaking of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. --- ``Sometimes there is more toughness in patience than in lashing out. This is such a time.'' - Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., at Senate hearing, urging restraint on use of military force. --- ``We fully support President Bush when he says that he is prepared to travel the extra mile to achieve such a (peaceful) solution. ... So are we. But there can be no question of negotiations, concessions, partial solutions or linkage to other issues.'' - John Major, Britain's new prime minister, promising to continue Margaret Thatcher's tough stance in the gulf crisis. --- ``If we start having body bags come back, we will have a very serious revolt in terms of public opinion.'' - Sen Larry Pressler, R-S.D., at Senate hearing.

DOC.HEAD: An Iraqi Jew Remembers a Different Saddam Hussein
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT `his brother' sted `her brother.' Picks up 7th graf pvs, `One day...'
DOC.TEXT: A Jewish museum in central Israel seems an unlikely place in which to hear about the warm and human side of Saddam Hussein. Most Israelis know him as the Arab dictator whose threats have forced them to get gas masks. But Vicky, a Jewish immigrant from Iraq, remembers him as the man who comforted her when she came to him for help in getting her husband out of prison. Another woman recalled being protected from anti-Jewish riots by Saddam's family in his home village of Takrit. The two women spoke at the Babylonian Jewry Heritage Center in Or Yehuda, an immigrant town outside Tel Aviv, at a discussion Sunday titled ``Saddam Hussein's mind-set on Jews, Israelis and Zionists.'' Vicky did not want her surname published because, she said, she still has relatives in Iraq. She told her story in Hebrew laced with Iraqi idioms, sitting next to her husband. She believes he was saved from the gallows with Saddam's help. In 1968, a coup had installed Saddam as Iraq's No. 2 man behind Ahmad Hasan al-Bakr. The previous regime had jailed many Jews, including Vicky's husband and his brother, as alleged spies. She and her sister-in-law, Naima, were desperate. One day, she recalled, an acquaintance gave her the address of a man named Saddam Hussein. ``I said, who is this Saddam? Isn't he against the Jews?'' The acquaintance reassured her: ``He's not against anybody.'' Next day she and Naima went to the address next to the Yarmuk mosque in Baghdad. They asked a passer-by where they could find Saddam Hussein. ``I am Saddam Hussein,'' he replied. She hadn't expected a man wearing a simple Arab robe and living in a relatively humble house. ``I got a fright, of course. I started crying and fell around his shoulders. He said, `Sister, what's the matter?''' He invited the women into his house and his wife, Sajida, served coffee. ``How do you know your husband is innocent?'' Saddam asked. ``I know. A wife has to know everything,'' Vicky recalled answering. Saddam retorted: ``When I made the revolution, my wife knew nothing about it.'' He promised to look into the case, and told Vicky to visit whenever she liked. She came to the house eight times hoping for news. She became friendly with Sajida and Saddam's mother. Saddam had also spent time in prison, and Sajida told Vicky, ``I know what you're going through. I tasted it too.'' The last time she saw Saddam, he had changed. He wore a Western suit and tanks guarded the house by Yarmuk mosque. He told her there was testimony implicating her husband, and that he would be interrogated further. ``I knew he was being tortured. I said, `What piece of his body will be left to interrogate?' I was very cheeky. He said, `That's the way it is. We will investigate, and every spy we find will be hanged.''' He spoke sternly, wagging a finger, and told her not to come again. In January 1969, when the Iraqis hanged 13 Jews, Vicky's husband and his brother were sentenced to three years in prison. Vicky is convinced the relatively light sentence was influenced by Saddam having taken a personal interest. ``I believe Saddam helped,'' she said. After they were released, the family immigrated to Israel. How does she feel when she hears President Bush likening Saddam to Hitler? She groped for words. ``I don't know,'' she said. ``To me he was good.'' Raya, who also asked that her surname not be published, grew up in Saddam's village of Takrit and remembers her parents' friendship with his family. She said her father, a wealthy businessman who brought electrical power to Takrit, lent his car to drive Saddam's mother to Baghdad to give birth to an older brother of Saddam. In 1941, when anti-Jewish riots erupted in Iraq, she and her family hid under their beds until the villagers, including Saddam's relatives, came to them to promise them protection. While fiercely hostile to Zionism, Saddam treats Iraq's tiny 150-member Jewish community benevolently, said Mordechai Ben-Porat, an Iraq-born former Cabinet minister who sat next to Vicky and Naima while they talked. He said Saddam's attitude to Jews was shaped in part by the kindness of Takrit's Jews to his mother. ``It didn't totally influence him,'' Ben-Porat said, ``but it definitely had an influence.'' Saddam has said the Israeli-Palestinian dispute should be negotiated along with Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. He had threatened to use chemical weapons against Israel even before his August invasion of Kuwait. The Israeli government in October began distributing gas masks to its citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Checchi Taking Visible Role In Crisis Management
With AM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Unlike his predecessor, Northwest Airlines Chairman Al Checchi went before cameras after the airline's first plane disaster since he took over last year. In Detroit Tuesday, Checchi visited with seven of the injured from Monday's runway collision between two Northwest planes and gave an emotional speech in which he mourned the eight people who died in the accident. By contrast, former Northwest Chairman Steven Rothmeier let company spokespeople do all the talking when Flight 255 went down on Aug. 16, 1987, near the same Detroit airport, killing 156 people. Checchi, who was in Los Angeles when the accident occurred, went to Detroit with a team of company officials after announcing that the airline would pay travel and lodging costs for passengers of the two planes and their families. Checchi announced Tuesday that Northwest would pay all medical expenses and other expenses incurred by passengers and their families. The chief executive spoke in a choking voice near the end of his statement when he said that a Northwest flight attendant died in the crash. ``As most of you know, flight attendant Heidi Joost lost her life in the line of duty,'' Checchi said. ``And flight attendant Mary Kay Ruane-Bolin was severely injured, but managed to pull several peope to safety from the aircraft.'' ``We just feel it's important for him to be there (in Detroit), and he's made the commitment to be there,'' said Doug Miller, a Northwest spokesman. It was the first plane disaster at Northwest since Checchi led a $3.65 billion buyout of the nation's fourth-largest airline in August 1989. Redmond Tyler, a former Northwest spokesman who advised Rothmeier during the 1987 crash, said it was a mistake not to have the chief executive appear on television to explain the company's actions. ``In retrospect I would have had him on there,'' Tyler said in a telephone interview from his home in Atlanta. Tyler, now a crisis management consultant, said there was a perception that Rothmeier was ``aloof, or cold, or cool.'' But Rothmeier cared deeply about the victims and their families and did everything he could to help them, Tyler said. Contributing to Rothmeier's stony image was Northwest's refusal to release the list of passengers on the 1987 flight. Tyler said he made the decision not to release the list and Rothmeier supported him, despite heavy media criticism. In keeping with that policy, Alan Muncaster, vice president of corporate communications at Northwest, said Monday that Northwest would not release the passenger list from either plane involved in the runway collision. ``You infuriate the media, but really what you get is protection for the families,'' Tyler said. ``The families ... thanked us for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Spain Publishes Catalogue of Original Capa Civil War Prints
DOC.TEXT: A half-century after a collection of Spanish Civil War photographs belonging to the late Robert Capa disappeared, the Foreign Ministry on Tuesday made public a catalogue of the original prints. Capa's brother, Cornell Capa, who was instrumental in identifying the 97 prints, looked on. Cornell Capa, now 72 and chief of the New York-based International Center of Photography, catalogued the prints as works of his older brother; or of David Seymour, co-founder with Robert Capa of the Magnum photo agency; or of Capa's companion, Gerda Taro. The younger Capa, himself a photographer who did the lab work for much of Robert Capa's Spanish photos, said the 54-year-old prints were in excellent condition. He said the negatives had disappeared ``somewhere along the line, probably in the next war (World War II).'' Robert Capa, born Endre Erno Friedmann in Pest, Hungary, in 1913, began his storied career as a war photographer in the 1936-39 Spanish conflict. He covered the Allied landings in North Africa and Normandy, the liberation of Paris, the war in China and the birth of Israel. He died in 1954 after stepping on an antipersonnel mine in Indochina. Capa changed his name in 1936, and became a U.S. citizen in 1946. His photographs of Spanish loyalist soldiers and militiamen fighting rebellious troops led by Gen. Francisco Franco and of refugees fleeing aerial bombardments brought the fratricidal conflict into the consciousness of a world edging slowing toward World War II. Included in the collection is a high-quality print of Capa's ``Falling Soldier'' taken at the Cordoba front in early September 1936. The stark photo of the loyalist soldier falling backward after being shot, his rifle in his right hand, became perhaps the best-known image of the Spanish war. Until the late 1970s, most Spaniards were not familiar with Capa's photos of their war. The pictures were published abroad, and because they highlighted the Republican side, copies or collections of the photos were not readily available in postwar Spain. The prints showed up at the Foreign Ministry in Madrid in March 1979 in a small suitcase accompanied by a letter from Swedish Ambassador Lennart Petri. Petri explained that the unidentified collection was delivered to the Swedish Legation in Vichy France during the war under mysterious circumstances and was later shipped to the Foreign Ministry in Stockholm for safekeeping until Spain returned to democracy. Franco ruled Spain from 1939 until he died in 1975. Spain returned to full democracy four years later. Archivists determined that Capa gave the collection to Juan Negrin, then prime minister, who went into exile in France in 1939 and died there in 1956. It wasn't until 1987, however, that serious efforts were made to identify the photographs, at least five of which had never been published. Foreign Ministry archivist Mercedes Perez Vera said the photos would become the property of the Spanish state. The question remains whether the collection will join the Civil War archives in Salamanca - available only to researchers - or become part of a museum collection open to the public. Cornell Capa obtained a set of copy negatives and prints for his brother's estate. The edition of the catalogue was limited to 1,000 copies.

DOC.HEAD: Menem Image Boosted by Handling of Short-Lived Uprising
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs on state-of-siege canceled, claims by Menem's brother of assassination plots.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush, Bjt
LaserPhoto BA1
DOC.TEXT: The bloodiest of four army uprisings in four years was also the shortest, and President Menem's decisive management of the crisis may strengthen his government. Monday's uprising, two days before President Bush's scheduled visit, was quickly crushed. Menem said Tuesday the rebel leaders will be tried by military court and face the death penalty if found guilty. Late Monday, after the rebels had filed out of the last of the buildings they had seized before dawn, Menem told a news conference that ``my pulse isn't going to tremble'' if military officers who had rebelled repeatedly - and killed people in the proces - forfeit their lives. The unofficial death toll in the uprising rose Tuesday to 14 when a soldier died from wounds suffered in putting down the insurrection. Unofficial tallies put the number of wounded at nearly 60 and the arrested at more than 400. The government did not disclose its figures on casualties and arrests. Menem and Defense Minister Humberto Romero signed a decree that legally separated the rebel leaders from their followers. While the leaders could face the death penalty, the followers face charges in civil court, where the worst punishment is life in prison. Menem ``is convinced the death penalty should be applied to end these happenings,'' said Raul Granillo Ocampo, the president's legal adviser. That attitude found support in this capital city of 10 million, whose residents saw their democracy threatened by the uprising. In quelling it, air force planes bombed tanks on public roads and a bridge was dynamited. Rebels fired at and hit Vice President Eduardo Duhalde's helicopter. On Tuesday, rebels who hid overnight at a rural Buenos Aires Province farm gave themselves up, along with three tanks they had seized. Argentina's two biggest political groups, the governing Perronist Party and the Civic Radical Union, issued a statement with 23 other parties saying the government should punish the rebels ``with severity.'' The rebels had demanded a shakeup of the military high command and a bigger military budget. Observers said they also sought to embarrass Menem by forcing Bush to cancel a visit to Argentina on Wednesday. Bush was in Uruguay on Tuesday. Menem refused to concede a single point, and even while rebels still held the army headquarters, Bush said he would arrive on schedule. Menem was sworn in 17 months ago amid hyperinflation, recession, food riots and military unrest. He seemed to have strengthened his government by choosing to fight the rebels instead of negotiating as former President Raul Alfonsin did on three occasions. It did not escape Argentines' notice that under Menem, the air force and navy for the first time helped put down an army rebellion. So no one would doubt that rebels surrendered unconditionally, they were ordered to walk out with their hands behind their necks and shoeless, a gesture meant to humiliate them. The rebels ``thought the president would be frightened and give in to their pressures,'' and become ``their puppet,'' said Adelina Dalesio de Viola, a national deputy with the opposition Union of the Democratic Center. ``But at every moment, Menem showed himself to be very firm,'' she said. Granillo Ocampo, Menem's aide, said the jailed leader of a December 1988 revolt, retired Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, admitted he played a role in the rebellion. He said Seineldin asked for ``a pistol with one bullet,'' presumably to kill himself, but authorities refused. Several other current and former officers under arrest sided with Seineldin or cashiered Lt. Col. Aldo Rico during the April 1987 and January 1988 military uprisings. Late Tuesday, Menem canceled the state-of-siege decree. Menem's brother, Eduardo Menem, who is president of the Senate, claimed Tuesday night the rebels intended to assassinate key political figures. The list included the president, at least one Cabinet minister and the leader of the ruling Peronist party bloc in Congress, Eduardo Menem told the independent news agency Noticias Argentina. He cited state intelligence agency information, but offered no proof to support his claim.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Saddam Wants Oil Field in Withdrawal Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with British, U.S. comments, background on Sky, edits to tighten. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq may be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait as long as it is allowed to keep the disputed Rumailah oil field, according to a British news report Tuesday. British and U.S. officials said they have heard nothing of such a proposal. Sky television news said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has been spelling out his negotiating position on the Persian Gulf dispute in private meetings with senior mediators, including Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov, a top adviser on foreign affairs to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Te report pushed spot oil prices sharply lower and propelled the Dow Jones average in New York from a 25-point loss a half-hour before closing to a 14-point gain to 2579.70 points at the end of Tuesday's trading. In Washington, however, a senior U.S. official said on condition of anonymity, ``We know absolutely nothing about this ... It comes as no surprise to us that these types of rumors will be surfacing more and more.'' Britain's Foreign Office also said it knew of no such negotiations, but added ``there's got to be a full and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of the legitimate government and a release of hostages.'' The Sky-TV report said a source close to one of the negotiations outlined to its reporter the sort of deal Saddam had in mind: In exchange for a guarantee against any Western attack on Iraq, he would pull out of Kuwait except for the oil field on the border. While much of the Rumailah oil field is in southern Iraq, it also crosses about two miles into Kuwait. Sky-TV, a 24-hour news channel, is part of the Sky Television satellite system launched by media mogul Rupert Murdoch in February 1989. A multinational force of more than 400,000, led by the United States, is in the gulf to oppose Iraq. Following the passage of a U.N. resolution last week, Saddam has been given until Jan. 15 to withdraw or face possible attack. Saddam also would give back the strategically important islands of Bubiyan and Warba, as long as Kuwait would discuss leasing them, and he would accept the return of the Kuwaiti royal family, which fled when Iraq invaded Aug. 2, according to the report. The report said the Western allies already heard of this Iraqi position and their ambassadors discussed it after the U.N. meeting last week. Sky quoted unidentified U.S. sources as saying Western acceptance of the loss of the oil field, one of the largest in the region, would hinge on whether the Kuwaitis were prepared to give it up. It also said a delegation of senior Kuwaiti officials in the Netherlands said all aspects of the dispute are negotiable once the Iraqis have withdrawn, which the television report saw as an indication the Kuwaitis might take the offer seriously. The delegation is in Amsterdam to urge support for armed action against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Adopts Iran Human Rights Draft; Amnesty Cites Executions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to RESTORE dropped words in 3rd graf, CORRECT typo, compromise sted comprise, in 7th graf. Picks up 8th graf, `I feel...'
DOC.TEXT: A resolution calling on Iran to end human rights abuses was adopted by a General Assembly committee Tuesday, just as Amnesty International accused Tehran of a wave of executions. The strongest wording in the draft resolution was dropped Monday so Iran would continue cooperating with U.N. human rights investigations and let the Red Cross visit its prisons. Draft language criticizing ``executions, ill-treatment and torture'' in Iran was deleted by the assembly subcommittee dealing with human rights. The adopted draft expresses concern over ``allegations of violations of human rights'' in a U.N. report. Iran joined in the consensus Tuesday to recommend sending the resolution to the full General Assembly, where it will be adopted later this month. At the same hour the resolution was adopted, London-based Amnesty said Iran has executed more than 5,000 people in the past three years. Many people were killed for their political beliefs, the organization said. Amnesty officials said it was coincidence that the release of the report came on the same day as the resolution vote. Isobelle Jaques, Amnesty International's delegate to the United Nations, criticized the compromise wording of the resolution. ``I feel that the resolution ought to address the actual human rights situation in Iran,'' she said. ``I don't think that the resolution which was adopted today really reflects that.'' But a European diplomat involved in the compromise defended it, saying it ``contains the substance of the original resolution'' in return for securing Iran's cooperation. The diplomat spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It's not ideal, but it's significant,'' added Saleh Rajavi, a U.N. representative for the People's Mujahedeen of Iran, an exile group seeking to topple Iran's Moslem fundamentalist government. ``What's important is that the continuation of the monitoring of rights abuses in Iran is still stipulated as a mandate of the U.N. body,'' Rajavi said. ``It was a failure for the Iranian regime,'' he said. ``They admitted in that resolution to their own crimes.'' Amnesty International's report said Iranian dissidents are arrested and tortured, some for only signing a letter criticizing a lack of human rights and freedoms. The organization quoted former prisoners as saying a ``death commission'' of Iranian officials chose prisoners daily for execution if their views were not acceptable. In 1988, more than 2,500 political prisoners were killed secretly in a few months on orders of the commission, Amnesty International said. Thousands more have been executed after summary trials in which they were convicted of criminal offenses, it said. Crackdowns on drug trafficking led to more than 1,100 executions in 1989, it said. The U.N. report used as the basis for the resolution was prepared by Reynaldo Galindo Pohl of El Salvador, who has done critical U.N. reports on Iran's human rights abuses since 1984. He was only allowed to visit the country in the last year. Tehran invited Galindo because his previous reports were based heavily on testimony from exiles and emigres who resent Iran's theocracy. Galindo's latest U.N. report was not as harsh as many human righs advocates might have hoped, but it severely criticized the climate of fear he found in Iran and noted many executions and abuses of due process. The original resolution would have had the General Assembly express ``its concern about the numerous allegations of violations of human rights contained in the report ... notably those concerning executions, ill-treatment and torture.'' The draft now calls on Iran to ``investigate and rectify the human rights issues raised by the special representative, in particular as regards administration of justice and due process of law.'' Responding to the Amnesty report, Iran's official news agency IRNA said Galindo reported that ``many of the people listed by Amnesty International as having been executed are actually still alive.'' The news agency said Galindo spoke with four of them in a Tehran prison. IRNA said the names were on a list given to Amnesty International by the Mujahedeen Khalq opposition group. Amnesty said it would have no comment until it reviewed the IRNA statement.

DOC.HEAD: The Curious Gather For Look at Runway Collision Wreckage
With AM-Planes Collide, Bjt
LaserPhoto DTX3
DOC.TEXT: The curious crowded windows at an airport terminal Tuesday for a look at the scorched DC-9 jetliner where eight people died in a runway collision. ``As I look at that plane, just thinking how miraculous it was that anyone got out of there alive,'' said Ken Blake, a Detroit resident waiting for a friend to arrive. A squat tug-like tractor pulled the charred hulk of the Northwest DC-9 to a hangar, then dragged the Northwest Boeing 727 to another hangar. The DC-9 turned into the path of the 727 on Monday at Detroit Metropolitan Airport in a heavy fog. The eight dead apparently died from noxious fumes before a flash fire on the DC-9 burned them beyond recognition, authorities said. A total of 188 people on the two jets survived. Runway 3C was closed Tuesday while the airport bustled with normal activity. Christmas music played softly throughout the airport. ``It's so gruesome. And then you sit and listen to this Christmas music,'' said Ronnie Vest of Canton Township, Mich. ``I'm not crazy about flying anyway and this only makes it worse.'' Dennis Betz of Toledo stood in the concourse awaiting a flight to Kansas City, eyes fixed on the DC-9 wreckage. ``I was thinking about driving back to Kansas City but it's still the safest way to travel,'' he said. Barb Wolf of Phoenix was back in the concourse for the second straight day. Her flight to Phoenix was canceled a day earlier. She was in a perfect place to see Monday's accident, if anyone could have. The fog was so thick, she couldn't see more than 50 feet out the window. ``It had to be right in front of us,'' she said. ``The first thing we knew something was wrong was when we saw fire trucks and ambulances heading out that way. And then the fog cleared and there it was.'' ``It horrifies me to look at that plane there and to know people died on it,'' Ms. Wolf said.

DOC.HEAD: `Liberty Bell' Maker Trying To Wring Money Out of City Hall
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of Liberty Bell replicas is trying a bit of bill wringing on nearly broke City Hall. City contracts for diminutive copies of the cracked bell - the ones proudly handed out to visiting VIPs - represent about one-fifth of Ampros Trophy Kings' business, says owner Burt Liebman. Mayor W. Wilson Goode's administration has stopped paying its bills on time as the city's fiscal crunch has worsened over the past three months, leaving Liebman out $21,828.14 he says he's owed. Because the city won't pay, Liebman says he's had to lay off workers - and delay payments to his own creditors. ``Everything has been geared back,'' Liebman said Tuesday. ``I'm upset, but I can't be angry. The city has been good to me for 30 years.'' The city knows that its action will cause problems for many of its small suppliers, but says it can pay only high-priority bills, related to health and safety, or for services performed before Sept. 1. The bell miniatures, which are given to dignitaries as a symbol of Philadelphia's heritage, are made at Liebman's plant. Each year, the family business makes about 1,200 small bells and 600 larger ones for the city, and also makes plaques and trophies and markers for veterans' graves. City Finance Director Elizabeth C. Reveal said Tuesday that the city owes about $36.7 million to its vendors, and may withhold another $30 million until the fiscal crisis is solved. ``There's going to be a very serious effect on the local economy'' if the problem continues another three months, she said. Administration officials have urged the state treasury, city pension fund, local banks and private investors to back the sale of more than $250 million in short-term notes to keep the city from running out of money later this month. On Monday, State Treasurer Catherine Baker Knoll said her department could not legally lend money to help Philadelphia. The city's financial mess will harm some of the city's 10,000 vendors, with whom the city does more than $2 billion business annually, and may force others into bankruptcy, Ms. Reveal acknowledged Tuesday. Liebman says his company already is hurting. While waiting for the city to pay up, he's been forced to lay off four of his 29 workers and has had to do some creative accounting to stay afloat. ``I realize the city of Philadelphia has many financial problems and the only bills that are being paid are those deemed necessary to keep the city running,'' Liebman wrote Goode on Nov. 28. ``You can understand, Mr. Mayor, what may not be critical bills to the city are indeed critical to the lifeblood of our company.'' Despite the problems, Liebman said the company would continue to supply the city with the Liberty Bells. ``We're Philadelphians,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel May Use Deportations To Stem Arab Stabbing Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Cabinet ministers said Tuesday that Israel may deport Palestinian activists as one way to stem a wave of Arab stabbing attacks. Israel has expelled 60 Palestinians during their 3-year-old revolt, but eased up on deportations in recent months following repeated Western protests that such action was inhumane. Right-wing leaders want deportations back again following Sunday's fatal bus stabbing of an Israeli near Tel Aviv, the 12th such attack on Jews in six weeks. Justice Minister Dan Meridor said on Israel television, ``Not only is there no deterrent to expulsions but we must acknowledge there is no choice but to use the weapon of deportation as well against inciters'' of violence. Meridor, of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, added: ``The developments of the last few weeks show a need for new thinking, intensive action ... If we prove our forbearance, our ability to stand up, we will win.'' Israeli news media said Defense Minister Moshe Arens was exploring ways of expediting deporation procedures, since expulsions are often delayed by appeals to the Supreme Court. Arens' spokesman Danny Naveh said in an interview that the idea of deporting Arabs linked to attacks on Israelis is ``always on the agenda.'' He noted that Arens considered deportations an ``effective means'' against violence, but declined to elaborate. In Beit Fajar, a West Bank village near Bethlehem, soldiers ambushed activists Monday night at a common site for stone-throwing attacks, shooting and wounding one protester in the leg, the army said. Arab and Israeli reports said a second youth Anwar, Ahmad Taqatqa, 17, was wounded and later died of injuries. The army said it could not confirm Taqatqa died as a result of gunfire because the body was buried without autopsy. He was the 776th Palestinian killed by Israelis in the revolt against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Fifty-three Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad Offers to Free Soviets, Kuwait Deal Could Be in Works
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 3rd graf, The rumors ... to UPDATE with U.S., British officials know nothing of proposal. Picks up 4th graf, In New ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY16,17,LON1,2,DHR2,AMM2
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein on Tuesday backed away from his confrontation with the Kremlin, promising to release the 3,300 Soviets he was holding. Moscow had warned it would use military force against Iraq if Soviets there were harmed. Meanwhile, according to a British news report late Tuesday, Iraq may be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait as long as it is allowed to keep the disputed Rumailah oil field that crosses two miles into Kuwaiti territory. The rumors fanned speculation the Persian Gulf crisis could be resolved without bloodshed. British and U.S. officials said they have heard nothing of such a proposal. In New York, a late burst of buying sparked by the Sky television report lifted the stock market from a 25-point decline a half-hour before closing to a gain of 14.11 points to 2,579.70. The report also pushed crude oil prices below $30 a barrel on the spot market, analysts said. The report came after the close of the New York Mercantile Exchange, where crude closed up $1.51 to $30.66. Sky TV said Saddam has been detailing his negotiating position on the gulf dispute in private meetings with mediators that include Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov, a top foreign adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In Washington late Tuesday, a senior U.S. official said the report was news to the Bush administration, and that they had heard nothing on any such negotiations. In exchange for a guarantee against any Western attack on Iraq, the report said Iraqi forces would pull out of all of Kuwait except for the oil field in southern Iraq. Saddam also would give back the strategically important islands of Bubiyan and Warba, as long as Kuwait would discuss leasing them, and he would accept the return of the Kuwaiti royal family, which fled when Iraq invaded Aug. 2, according to the report. Before the gulf crisis began, Moscow was Iraq's chief weapons supplier and main ally. The Kremlin has not sent troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force stationed in Saudi Arabia. Speaking in Montevideo, Uruguay, earlier Tuesday on his second stop on a South American tour, President Bush said Saddam ``has not gotten the message'' that he must get out of Kuwait. Britain's prime minister, John Major, also talked tough on the gulf, ruling out negotiations with Iraq or any ``partial solutions or linkages to other issues.'' The Soviets, mainly oil industry experts, will be allowed to leave Baghdad beginning Wednesday, the official Iraqi News Agency said. It reported, however, that Moscow would have to pay compensation for broken contracts. Iraq had warned foreign companies and employees it would demand compensation for any contract breached after its invasion. In Moscow, presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said 3,232 Soviets remained in Iraq. Thousands more left in the months after the invasion. Moscow adopted a harder line against Iraq last week when it accused Saddam of breaking a promise to allow Soviets to leave. Iraq is holding hundreds of Westerners, many at strategic sites, to deter attack by the 340,000-strong U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the gulf. Soviets are not believed among those used as ``human shields.'' Saddam has said he would free all hostages between Christmas and March 25 provided Washington and its allies do not take military action. That period is considered the optimum time for an offensive to drive the Iraqis from Kuwait. The Iraqi decision Tuesday was seen as an attempt by Saddam to forestall any Soviet military intervention in the gulf that might cement the U.S.-led coalition already poised in the region against him. But releasing the Soviets is not likely to assuage Moscow's mounting impatience with Saddam over his refusal to leave Kuwait, nor imperil its growing alliance with the West. In Washington, congressional hearings continued on the Bush administration's gulf policy. Senate Democrats have repeatedly urged Bush to stick with the economic embargo against Iraq, rather than rush into a war. White House officials, however, have said the sanctions aren't working. ``I've not been one whose been convinced that sanctions alone will bring him to his senses,'' Bush said Tuesday. Of Saddam, the president said: ``I am convinced that up until now, at least, he has not gotten the message'' that he must withdraw from Kuwait. Major addressed his first Conservative Party rally as prime minister and said he supported President Bush's recent offer to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Iraq. But he said there should be no compromises. ``There can be no question of negotiations, concessions, partial solutions or linkage to other issues,'' he said. Earlier, Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, conferred with British Defense Secretary Tom King and held his first meeting with Major at the start of a two-day visit to London. Britain last month decided to send another 14,000 troops to the gulf, bringing its troop total to 30,000. Only the United States has committed more soldiers to the effort against Iraq. Saddam has suggested a resolution to the gulf crisis should be linked to an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab lands. The United States and its allies have said the Palestinian issue is unrelated. Saddam met Tuesday with Jordan's King Hussein, PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat and Yemen's vice president in advance of the U.S.-Iraqi talks on the crisis, a PLO official said. The three comprise Saddam's main support in the conflict. Also Tuesday, Health Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Saeed said 1,400 children under age 5 have died because of shortages of medicine, vaccines and food brought on by the U.N. trade embargo. There was no way to independently verify the reports. But a doctor at one Baghdad hospital said on condition of anonymity there was no shortage of basic medicines or medical supplies in Iraq. Western diplomats in Baghdad said Iraq received 30 tons of medical supplies between mid-October and mid-November alone in exchange for the release of Western hostages. Another 40 tons of medical supplies reportedly were shipped to Iraq in late November, diplomats said. In other developments, the British Foreign Office said Tuesday that Iraq sent Britain a $289,000 hotel bill to pay for 27 British construction workers it is holding at two five-star Baghdad hotels.

DOC.HEAD: New FAA Seating Rule and Quick-Acting Passenger Credited with Saving Lives
With AM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bill Trappen was miffed that his seat wouldn't recline on Northwest Airlines' Flight 1482. But when the plane collided with another jet at Detroit Metropolitan Airport, his seat assignment made him a hero. Because of a new Federal Aviation Administration regulation, the 21-year-old University of Pittsburgh student was assigned a seat near an emergency exit through which he helped several passengers flee the burning DC-9. On Oct. 5, the FAA began requiring airlines to assign exit row seats to passengers strong enough to open exit doors in the event of an emergency. The passengers are asked before being given the seat if they are willing to help evacuate others. If they say no, they are assigned another seat. ``In an emergency situation, it's just the sheer quickness of a person who is able-bodied and can get the exit door open in time to help others,'' FAA spokesman Mort Edelstein said Tuesday from his Chicago office. At Northwest, gate agents are charged with recruiting passengers for emergency exit seats, said spokesman Kevin Whalen. Trappen, returning to Pittsburgh after a weekend in Florida, said he had nodded off when the wingtip of a Memphis-bound 727 jetliner speeding toward takeoff clipped the DC-9, which had turned in front it on the fog-shrouded runway. The DC-9's engine was ripped off and fuel started streaming from the jet, which held 39 passengers and four crew members. Eight people died and 20 were injured. With the aisle jammed with people trying to get off at the front of the plane, Trappen turned to the emergency exit by his seat in row 8. He and another passenger, John Izzo, 41, of Pittsburgh, opened the door and began leading other passengers across the win to the runway. ``Until I turned around, things didn't look so bad,'' Trappen said. ``But when I looked behind me, I could see people strapped in their seats who were already dead, you could tell. And there were screams.'' Trappen said he considered Izzo the hero. After leading four passengers to safety, they saw a man on fire. Izzo ``threw him on the ground, patted down the flames and got him to a paramedic,'' Trappen said. Trappen was treated for a cut over his right eye. He said he'd drive to school later in the week. Izzo, who works for Westinghouse Nuclear Services Division near New Stanton, Pa., was on his way home from an assignment in Michigan. Edelstein said disabled rights groups have criticized the FAA rule as discriminatory. ``Maybe so, but if I were handicapped, I would prefer an aisle seat, leaving the emergency exit seat to someone who can get it open more quickly,'' he said. ``This is a perfect example, if it happened that way.''

DOC.HEAD: INS Releases 75; Many in California
DOC.TEXT: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said Tuesday it had released 75 Salvadorans from custody in anticipation of a new form of legal residence for them. The 75 were those who may qualify for so-called ``Temporary Protected Status'' under the new immigration law signed last week by President Bush. This provision was established for Salvadorans illegally in this country who fear returning to their war-torn homeland but nonetheless do not qualify for regular refgee status. To be admitted to legal residence as a refugee, an immigrant must demonstrate a ``well-founded fear of persecution'' at home. The Immigration and Naturalization Service in the past has contended that most Salvadorans who enter the United States illegally could not qualify as refugees. The new law permits those Salvadorans in the United States before Sept. 19 and here continuously since then to apply for ``Temporary Protected Status'' as of Jan. 2, permitting them to work legally and banning their deportation. The law contains provision for eventual extension to citizens of other nations. ``Temporary Protected Status'' is to last only 18 months from Jan. 1. An INS statement quoted the head of the service, Gene McNary, as saying, ``In keeping with the humanitarian spirit of the Temporary Protected Status program,'' the service was releasing Salvadorans in custody who could qualify. They must remain in the United States to remain eligible. The statement said, ``All Salvadorans who are encountered by INS agents in enforcement actions while this program is in effect will be advised of the benefit and given the opportunity to show their eligibility.'' Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the service, said the 75 were released from cities ``all over the country, but a good number of them were in California.'' Jervis estimated that about 300 Salvadorans were in custody. Those not released either had criminal charges pending against them, or had entered the United States after Sept. 19, he said.

DOC.HEAD: German State Wants More Soviet Jews in Germany
DOC.TEXT: One of Germany's most influential states, Baden-Wuerttemberg, suggested Tuesday that Soviet Jews receive special status to bypass the country's tough immigration laws. The announcement by the southern state comes amid debate whether the number of foreigners seeking to come to Germany should be limited. There has been a great deal of pressure to let in more Soviet Jews for humanitarian reasons. Germany's Jewish population was virtually wiped out during Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. In 1933, there were 530,000 Jews living in Germany. Today there are fewer than 40,000. Six million Jews were killed during the Nazi Holocaust. Baden-Wuerttemberg, home to such economic giants as Daimler-Benz, said it wanted to accept Soviet Jews on a special status called contingency refugees, which would allow them to live and work in Germany without having to apply for formal immigration or go through the lengthy political asylum process. The special classification requires approval of Germany's 16 states, whose top officials will discuss the issue this month. ``We are not a country of immigrants,'' Detlef Dauka, spokesman for Bonn's Interior Ministry said. ``That means Soviet Jews normally would have no possibility to come to Germany, except to apply as asylum seekers.'' About 3 percent of all people claiming political asylum are legally accepted, officials say. Dauka said the proposal regarding Soviet Jews was being considered because the opening of Soviet society has made it difficult for Jews to prove they are persecuted and entitled to political asylum. At the same time, rising nationalism has provoked an increase in anti-Semitic incidents in the Soviet Union. An estimated 150,000 Soviet Jews have emigrated this year to Israel, where officials say services are strained by the influx. Israeli officials believe the number of Soviet Jewish immigrants could reach 1 million by 1992. Only residents of other European Community countries and ethnic Germans can easily settle and work legally in Germany. The rest must apply for political asylum or immigrate. Baden-Wuerttemberg spokesman Manfred Zach said in the state capital of Stuttgart that quick action was needed to help the Soviet Jews. Zach said the process should be coordinated through leaders of the German Jewish community. He said the special status should apply mainly to German-speaking Soviet Jews, those of German origin or those who could prove family relations in Germany. The government's Interior Ministry announced Tuesday that the number of asylum-seekers in Germany continued to climb in November. The ministry said 18,314 people entered Germany seeking asylum, an increase over 18,261 in October. In September, 24,048 asylum seekers registered with the goverment. Jewish community leader Heinz Galinski, reached at home in Berlin for comment Tuesday night, hung up the teeephone before a question on the issue could be asked. Other Jewish leaders could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Two Earth Tremors in Peruvian Andes
DOC.TEXT: Two earth tremors of medium intensity shook parts of the central Andes Tuesday, the Geophysical Institute said. Institute chief Mateo Casaverde said the jolts measured 4.3 and 4.2 degrees on the Richter scale. Casaverde said the first was centered in the mountainous Cerro de Pasco region 110 miles northeast of Lima and the second in the department of Lima 80 miles southeast of the capital. Neither temblor caused casualties or damages, he said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Drivers in East More Likely to Drink and Drive
DOC.TEXT: Drivers in the East are more likely to drink and drive than those in the South, and people in the wide-open West are most likely to speed, a study released Tuesday showed. But Westerners are slightly more likely to buckle up when they drive. The Louis Harris poll on auto safety in America was commissioned by Prevention magazine and General Motors Corp. Among its findings: - A significant drop - 17 percent - in the past five years in the number of young drivers who say they sometimes drink and drive. But more affluent, college-educated people are four times as likely to drink and drive than those who never graduated from high school. - In states without a mandatory seat belt law, 72 percent of those responding would support one. - Twice as many men as women admit to sometimes driving after drinking (28 percent to 14 percent). - Seventy-nine percent of those surveyed support expanded use of police roadblocks or checkpoints to reduce drunken driving. - While 30 percent would pay an extra $500 for an air bag, 38 percent think accidental inflation is a serious problem and 35 percent think they can trap people in their car. ``Greater public understanding of air bags and their benefits would likely result in greater willingness to pay for them,'' said Thomas Dybdahl, one of the report's authors. The survey showed a big jump in the percentage of people who say they always wear seat belts in the front seat, from 19 percent in a 1984 survey to 63 percent in the recent survey. Sixty-seven percent of the drivers in the West said they always buckle up; Easterners ranked lowest at 60 percent, although this difference is minimal, the authors said. Seat belt use is reflected in education and income levels, the survey found. It said 74 percent of college grads always buckle up, compared with 52 percent of those who didn't graduate high school. Among those with household income above $50,000, 73 percent always wear belts, compared with 51 percent in the under-$15,000 income bracket. Younger drivers may be increasingly aware of the hazards of drinking and driving: The survey said 24 percent of those 18 to 29 said they sometimes drive after drinking, a drop from 41 percent in 1984. For those 30 to 39, the drinking-and-driving figure was 31 percent, down just 2 points from the earlier survey; for the 40-to-49 age group, 23 percent, down from 32 percent; for the 50-to-64 age group, 14 percent, down from 22 percent. Twenty-seven percent of the Eastern adults said they sometimes drink and drive; in the South, the figure was 15 percent. One reason, the survey said, is that half of all Southerners say they don't drink at all, compared with 31 percent of Easterners. The figure for drinking and driving in the Midwest was 25 percent, and in the West, 21 percent. The survey showed that 53 percent of the drivers in the Midwest and South say they never exceed the speed limit; in the East, it was 45 percent; in the West, 41 percent. And which sex is more likely to obey the speed limit? Women, by a 54 percent to 44 percent margin. The random survey of 1,250 adults nationwide was done in November and December 1989. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points. Prevention magazine is published by the Emmaus-based Rodale Press.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Upholds Housing Project Gun Ban
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge upheld a ban on guns in the city's public housing projects, setting a precedent for the rest of the nation, the housing authority director said Tuesday. The ruling Monday by U.S. District Judge Richard L. Williams marked the first time a court has decided whether public housing residents can be barred from having guns, said Richard Gentry, executive director of the Richmond Redevelopment and Housing Authority. Gentry said guns also are banned in public housing projects in Chicago, but that ban has not been challenged in court. ``This is a unique court case,'' he said. ``Now this can be used as a precedent throughout the country.'' Williams said the ban was ``part of a good faith effort to improve the safety and quality of life in public housing.'' Richmond, which has one of the highest murder rates in the country, has been plagued by drug-related shootings and other violence at its 4,500 public housing units. A third of the city's 600 shootings a year take place in public housing complexes, evidence showed. In its lawsuit challenging the gun ban and other provisions of a new lease, the Richmond Tenants Organization said the requirements made the city's 14,000 public housing residents second-class citizens. Williams issued an injunction that kept the lease from going into effect last month, but after hearing testimony last week upheld all but a few of the lease provisions. ``The widespread presence of drugs and guns have created an atmosphere of fear and intimidation which now permeates the public housing developments,'' he wrote. ``There is substantial evidence that eliminating guns will reduce crime in the developments and reduce accidental death. Despite conflicting expert testimony, this court finds that a prohibition on firearms from public housing is a reasonable lease term,'' Williams added. He permitted specific bans on firearms, blackjacks, explosive devices and nunchucks, a martial arts weapon. He struck a line banning ``weapons of any type'' because that could mean kitchen knives or anything else used to hurt someone. Williams also struck a provision that would have caused tenants to lose their lease if they committed misdemeanor drug or alcohol violations away from the public housing area. Alma Barlow, president of the tenants organization, said she was disappointed with the ruling but had not decided whether to appeal. Lawyers for the Central Virginia Legal Aid Society, which represented the tenants, would not comment. Gentry said tenants would be given civil court hearings before being thrown out for violating the lease. ``It has never been our intent nor will it ever be to conduct raids on residents or to hassle our residents,'' he said. ``When we become aware of a problem, we will be able to take action.''

DOC.HEAD: Suicide Machine Inventor Invokes Fifth Amendment During Hearing
DOC.TEXT: The inventor of a device used by a woman to kill herself refused to answer questions Tuesday during a hearing on whether the machine should be shelved forever. Dr. Jack Kevorkian invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when questioned by a prosecutor seeking a permanent injunction against Kevorkian's use of the machine. The retired pathologist hooked a 54-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease to the machine so she could inject herself with a fatal dose of an anesthetic and a heart-stopping drug. Kevorkian, 62, was charged Monday with first-degree murder in the June 4 death of Janet Adkins of Portland, Ore. He refused to answer any questions when prosecutor Michael Modelski called him to the witness stand during the hearing to determine whether a temporary order against Kevorkian's use of the machine should be made permanent. ``On the advice of counsel, I invoke the Fifth Amendment,'' Kevorkian repeated to each of Modelski's questions, including requests for the doctor to state his name, occupation, education and medical background. Circuit Court Judge Alice L. Gilbert adjourned the hearing until Monday. If Kevorkian testified, his right to a fair trial in a criminal case would be jeopardized, said Kevorkian's attorney, Geoffrey Fieger. ``Dr. Kevorkian in this case has a right to defend himself but he can't get on the stand while he has a criminal case against him,'' Fieger said. ``I believe the prosecution has engaged in manipulation of the judicial process,'' he said, referring to the timing of the criminal charges filed just a day before the scheduled hearing on a permanent injunction. Fieger said he would ask the Michigan Court of Appeals to dismiss the civil case. Kevorkian, who has deferred questions about the criminal charges to Fieger, spoke to reporters briefly after the hearing. ``I'm committed to the medical aspect of this,'' he said, adding that the medical community should address the rights of terminally ill patients to take their own lives. Kevorkian spent several hours Monday night at Oakland County Jail before he was freed on $50,000 bond.

DOC.HEAD: First Photo from Massive New Hawaii Telescope Revealed
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: Scientists on Tuesday displayed the first picture taken by what will soon be the world's most powerful optical telescope, a huge instrument designed to peer deeper into space than ever before. When it is completed, the $94.2 million Keck Telescope at Mauna Kea, Hawaii, will be the world's largest, with a mirror 10 meters in diameter. It also is the first to be built of automated mirror segments. Astronomers say the Keck will enable them to gaze back 12 billion years in time by revealing light images still traveling toward Earth. ``These are really time machines, given the finite speed of light,'' said Edward Stone, chairman of the California Association of Research in Astronomy, composed of scientists from the California Institute of Technology and the University of California. The photo of galaxy NGC 1232, taken with only a quarter of the Keck's 36 mirror segments in place, more than matched the quality of images from the world's largest effective telescope, the 5-meter Hale Telescope at Palomar Observatory. The image was taken Nov. 24 from the W.M. Keck Observatory on Mauna Kea, a 13,796-foot volcano on the island of Hawaii. The picture of the galaxy, 65 million light years from Earth in the constellation Eridanus, marks the telescope's ``first light,'' a term astronomers use to describe the first viewing through a new telescope. The photo has no particular scientific value; NGC 1232 was selected simply to demonstrate the optical quality of the telescope, said mirror designer Jerry Nelson, an astronomer at the University of California, Berkeley. ``When we first saw the picture we were really thrilled,'' said Nelson. ``We were all hopping up and down.'' The telescope won't be fully functioning until late next year, with all mirror segments in place and precision cameras mounted to record the images it returns. When it is completed, the Keck Telescope is expected to be twice as powerful as the Hale and far more accurate and reliable than a 6-meter Soviet telescope that is frequently inoperable. The Keck differs from other large telescopes in that its mirror is made up of separate hexagonal mirror segments 6 feet in diameter. The aluminum-coated mirrors are kept in alignment within 1-millionth of an inch by computer-controlled sensors. Stone said a single-piece 10-meter-wide mirror probably could not be constructed with existing technology. The telescope will offer research opportunities not possible with the Hubble Space Telescope, launched earlier this year by a space shuttle. Because it orbits Earth above the distorting effects of the atmosphere, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope was supposed to see farther into the universe than the Keck, even though the Hubble has a smaller mirror. NASA discovered after it was launched that the Hubble's mirror was flawed during construction, rendering it less powerful than planned until a space shuttle crew can fix it in 1993. However, the Keck, with its large, light-gathering mirror, will be a better instrument for analyzing the light spectrums of stars. Stone said this will enable scientists to better understand the nature of the stars and calculate their speed. By providing images that reach back 12 billion years, scientists will see stars as they appeared some 3 billion years after the birth of the universe. Palomar, by contrast, reaches back only 8 billion years. Caltech and the University of California are sharing the cost of the telescope. Caltech, aided by a $70 million grant from the W.M. Keck Foundation, put up the $87 million the project originally was expected to cost. Overruns of $7.2 million will be shared by the two universities, and UC will pay the annual operating cost of about $3 million, Stone said. Nelson said Mauna Kea is considered the world's best site for a telescope because its high altitude reduces atmospheric distortions. But the thin air often impairs researchers' thinking ability and causes severe headaches, he said. As a result, operations must be carefully planned and monitored by the project's sea-level headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Academy Won't Award Milli Vanilli Grammy To Another Group
DOC.TEXT: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced Tuesday the 1989 best new artist Grammy, which was stripped from Milli Vanilli last month, will not be awarded to another group or artist. ``The Grammy process does not, and is not intended to produce a ranked result,'' Michael Greene, president of the academy, said Tuesday. ``The Grammy procedure is not structured as a `win, place or show' situation,'' he said in a statement. ``There is one winner. There is no first runner-up. We either have a winner or we give no award.'' Greene said the organization's Board of Trustees met Monday in New York and decided that ``when a Grammy award is withdrawn following the presentation, as is the case with Milli Vanilli, the category will remain vacant.'' The academy stripped Milli Vanilli of its Grammy on Nov. 19, after German record producer, Frank Farian, confirmed rumors that Rob Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan were just front men on the album that won the award in February as best new artist. In a separate action, the academy reaffirmed that the Milli Vanilli single, ``Blame It On The Rain,'' written by Diane Warren, remains eligible for the 1990 Song of the Year category because the award is for songwriting. ``All other entries from Milli Vanilli have been deemed ineligible,'' Greene said. Three Milli Vanilli entries were among the 8,000 other entries in the 1990 Grammy nomination process and were distributed and compiled before the academy's decision to rescind the duo's Grammy, he said. The group's first and only album, ``Girl You Know It's True,'' sold 7 million copies and made the two unknowns international stars. Pilatus and Morvan, both 25, said the album actually featured vocalists Johnny Davis, Brad Howell and Charles Shaw. The deception began to unravel at a 1989 concert when their audio system playing the album ``Girl You Know Its True'' started to skip like a broken record. The recording at the Bristol, Conn., show kept rerunning the lyrics: ``Girl you know it's, Girl you know it's ...''

DOC.HEAD: Colonel Jailed as Plotter Flees Panamanian Jail
DOC.TEXT: A retired army colonel, arrested in October on charges of plotting against President Guillermo Endara's government, broke jail Tuesday and fled in a helicopter, government sources and his lawyer said. Former Col. Eduardo Herrera Hassan escaped from Naos Island in the Pacific Ocean and flew to the Tinajitas military barracks on the outskirts of Panama City, an official at the attorney general's office said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he had no details and did not know what Herrera was doing at the barracks. Herrera served in the now disbanded Defense Forces of ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Following his arrest on charges of plotting against the security of the state, he was held for trial at Nao, a small resort island that also has a jail. Rafael Rodriguez, Herrera's lawyer, confirmed in a live interview with the private radio station La Exitosa that Herrera fled the island, but refused to elaborate. A U.S. military invasion of Panama deposed Noriega in December 1989 and he was taken to Miami, where he is awaiting trial on drug trafficking and money laundering charges. Endara's government succeeded Noriega the day after the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Down Warplane
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas using a surface-to-air missile Tuesday downed a Salvadoran air force AC-47 gunship, the military reported - the second aircraft shot down since a rebel offensive began two weeks ago. There was no immediate word on the crew. The Armed Forces Press Office also reported fighting Tuesday in at least five of the country's 14 departments with 18 dead and 24 wounded, most of them rebels or soldiers. Since the rebel drive began, at least 220 people have been killed and 500 wounded. The office said the gunship was hit about 50 miles north of the capital. On Nov. 23, a rebel rocket downed an A-37 fighter bomber over eastern El Salvador, the first such incident in 11 years of civil war. The military office also reported a rebel artillery attack on government bases in Usulutan, 70 miles east of the capital, but reported no government casualties. It said five rebels died in the fighting there. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, in its daily radio broadcast, claimed it killed or wounded 23 soldiers and captured two. The rebels say the offensive was launched to push along a stalled peace process. President Alfredo Cristiani has said the offensive could endanger the peace talks. U.N. officials have said they see no immediate danger of that.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Officer Killed in Rebel Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels killed a security police officer Wednesday about two miles from where negotiators were holding talks on the future of U.S. military bases in the Philippines, authorities said. A policeman was also wounded in the attack, the third officer injured by rebels in the capital this week. Police said three gunmen opened fire on a vehicle carrying Constabulary Maj. Rolando Aguila as it slowed down to cross a railroad track in the city's San Andres district near his home. Aguila, 42, died instantly from at least 15 gunshot wounds, police said. The gunmen also fired on a passing police car before they fled. The constabulary, the country's security police force, is a branch of the armed forces. ``I heard the shots and I was told by my neighbors that the major was ambushed,'' she said Aguila's wife, Mer.``He was unescorted because he is confident that he has no enemies.'' The attack was not believed to be directly related to the talks on the bases.
