U.S. officials have issued travel restrictions for the 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents during the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached With Whistle-Blower
DOC.TEXT: An engineer who complained she was harassed after raising safety concerns about draining nuclear waste storage tanks reached agreement Tuesday with her employer, the company said. Inez Austin agreed to withdraw a complaint she filed with the U.S. Department of Labor and also agreed not to participate in any legal action against Westinghouse Hanford Co. arising from the case. Westinghouse is the main government contractor at the 560-square-mile Hanford nuclear reservation in south-central Washington. Hanford for decades produced plutonium for nuclear weapons, but now is largely focusing on cleaning up years of contamination at the site. Ms. Austin told reporters recently that she had been harassed by her supervisors after warning last summer that pumping radioactive liquids from two nuclear waste storage tanks could cause the contents to explode. A General Accounting Office report issued later said too little was known about the explosive potential of the tanks, and plans to pump them were canceled. Under Tuesday's agreement, the company admitted no wrongdoing. Ms. Austin, who has worked at the company since 1979, remains a Westinghouse employee. The company pursued the agreement to encourage whistle-blowers to come forward, said Westinghouse Hanford President Roger Nichols. ``Now is not the time to send our employees the wrong messages about our desire to have them raise concerns.'' Calls to Ms. Austin's office and home for comment were not immediately returned Tuesday. Under terms of the agreement, a letter of reprimand will be removed from Ms. Austin's file; her latest performance appraisal will be upgraded; she will be offered a choice of new transfer assignments within the company; she will get a pay increase and overtime; she will receive one month of paid time off; and her $5,000 in legal fees will be paid by the company.

By repeatedly urging President Bush to stick with the economic embargo against Iraq, Senate Democrats are turning aside the administration's bleak assessment of the sanctions' effectiveness. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., made the point repeatedly during five days of hearings that he engineered as chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Day after day, former U.S. defense officials urged the White House to give the sanctions more time - bolstering the Democratic challenge to Bush's strategy. When two current officials - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff - finally testified on Monday, Nunn asked them if the administration was dismissing sanctions too easily. ``If we go to war, we never will know whether they would have worked,'' said Nunn, who has criticized the president's decision to increase the number of U.S. troops in the region to more than 440,000. ---= ROMULUS, Mich. (AP) - Investigators today tried to determine whether a pilot was lost on a foggy runway when he turned his jetliner into the path of another and caused a ``kerosene torch'' collision that killed eight people. Monday's collision of a Boeing 727 and a DC-9, both operated by Northwest Airlines, reduced one plane to a blackened shell, its roof burned away. At least 20 people were hospitalized with burns, broken bones, smoke inhalation and other injuries. The 727 was racing down a runway toward takeoff at Detroit Metropolitan Airport when its wing was sheared off by the DC-9, which had turned in front of it. Fuel poured from the planes and the DC-9 burst into flames, killing eight of the 43 people aboard. ``It was like a big kerosene torch,'' said passenger John Izzo, 41, of Pittsburgh, who escaped uninjured by jumping off a wing. ---= PONTIAC, Mich. (AP) - A physician who hooked a woman to a machine that let her take her life with the press of a button was charged with murder by a prosecutor who said the switch did not relieve the doctor of responsibility. Dr. Jack Kevorkian, known as ``Dr. Death'' for his invention, helped a 54-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease use the machine to inject herself with a fatal dose of an anesthetic and a heart-stopping drug on June 4. ``Dr. Kevorkian was the primary and legal cause of Janet Adkins' death. He cannot avoid his criminal culpability by the clever use of a switch,'' Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said Monday. Kevorkian, a 62-year-old retired pathologist from Royal Oak, faces a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole if convicted. ---= PITTSBURGH (AP) - For years pharmacist Edward Kilkeary used arthritis medication, saline solution and sterilizing equipment to whip up hundreds of tiny bottles of specially prescribed eye drops for cataract patients. But sometime this year something went wrong. Two women last month each lost an eye to a virulent bacteria. At least 10 people were hospitalized with infections, and countless others sought help for swelling and burning caused by a toxin that was eating away their eyes. The bacteria, pseudomonas, contaminated an unknown number of bottles that were sold under the name Indocin to patients who had recently undergone cataract surgery. The infection puzzled doctors who treated the patients, and the drops were traced to Hieber's Drug Store, where Kilkeary manufactured them. ---= BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) - The military rebellion that turned parts of Buenos Aires into a battleground two days before President Bush is to arrive was Argentina's fourth since 1987, and may have been the least effective. Challenged immediately by the air and armored power of loyalist troops, Monday's was the shortest and bloodiest of the four revolts. At least 13 people were killed and about 60 wounded. In Brazil, Bush said he would go ahead with the scheduled state visit. While earlier barracks rebellions forced shake-ups in the high command and bigger service budgets, this time ``surrender was unconditional,'' President Carlos Menem said Monday night about 18 hours after the insurrection began. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Financier Charles H. Keating Jr. probably intended a link between his contributions to Sen. lan Cranston and the senator's help in contacting bank regulators, the lawmaker's former chief fund-raiser says. ``In retrospect, I think that there was a link there,'' Joy Jacobson told the Senate Ethics Committee on Monday. She denied any wrongdoing in soliciting more than $850,000 in contributions from Keating. ``In the context in which I saw these contributions, I did not know all the other things that were going on,'' she said. Testifying in the committee's hearings into the so-called Keating Five senators, Jacobson said she didn't know of Cranston's repeated contacts with federal banking regulators at the time Keating was making contributions to the California Democrat's voter registration drives. ---= HERNDON, Va. (AP) - At last, the purr-fect Christmas stocking stuffer for indoor cats who have everything. It's their very own videotape, featuring a mouth-watering parade of live birds, squirrels and chipmunks cavorting on the TV screen. The 25-minute, full-color video, taped in a wooded backyard of this Washington suburb, is sure to delight all those latchkey kitties who are bored with napping, scratching the furniture and swatting ornaments off the Christmas tree. Just slip a $19.95 copy of ``Video Catnip'' into the VCR and watch them turn into regular couch furballs. But heed the warning at the start of the tape: ``While watching this video, your cat may become excited and attempt to get inside your television set to get at the birds. ... We strongly suggest that you remove all breakables from on top or around your TV set. No kitting.''

DOC.HEAD: City Tries To Polish Tarnished Liberal Image
DOC.TEXT: The daily dose of government debate at the state Capitol and the steady shuffle of students between university classes can't muffle the question. Is Madison's long, proud tradition of liberal politics, student activism and unbending tolerance to widely divergent groups and views in jeopardy? It's the question lobbyist Ken Opin's mother, who lives on the East Coast, asked him after reading news accounts about a rash of anti-Semitic vandalism in Madison this summer. It's the question political analysts asked after U.S. Rep. Robert Kastenmeier, a Democrat who built a reputation as a champion of liberal causes, was ousted by a conservative after 32 years in Congress. And it's the question aldermen asked after a Southeast Asian refugee collecting aluminum cans to supplement her welfare checks was arrested under a law designed to protect recyclables in the city trash. Has this city of 180,000 changed? ``The world has changed,'' said Mayor Paul R. Soglin, a Vietnam War protester whose political views and garb earned him the nickname ``hippie mayor'' during his first term of office in the 1970s. After 10 years in the private sector, Soglin returned to office two years ago. But instead of beads, tie-dye shirts and ponchos, he sports tweed jackets and striped ties. And he doesn't march past the Capitol with a throng of students to lobby for the latest cause in social justice. Instead, he strolls downtown to court business interests. ``Madison is no longer the Emerald City,'' said Orlando Bell, president of the Madison chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``It has big-city problems and it is going to have to find some big-city solutions.'' Madison's enthrallment with its proud liberal past allowed problems to rear mostly unnoticed during the late 1970s and 1980s, Bell said. ``During the time we were in suspended animation, these problems have been knocking on our door,'' he said. Striking the deepest blow to the city's image this year was the spate of anti-Semitic vandalism, including the cutting of brake lines on a bus carrying school children from a Jewish camp that nearly caused a tragedy. The incidents forced police to guard temples and synogogues during recent Jewish holidays. ``Anti-Semitism had finally hit home,'' said the Rev. Frederick Trost, president of the Wisconsin Conference of the United Church of Christ. ``People were astonished and shocked by it.'' Added Mary Rouse, dean of students at the University of Wisconsin: ``It was a very painful reminder that discrimination occurs in every community.'' Added to that: - The Nov. 6 ouster of Kastenmeier, whose incessant pursuit of civil rights, nuclear disarmament and openness in government became a symbol of the city's political climate during the 1960s and 1970s. Both Democrats and Republicans say political newcomer Scott Klug capitalized on voter dissatisfaction with Congress in general. - The arrest of the refugee woman by police, using an anti-scavenging ordinance passed by the city council. Prosecutors dropped the charge in September after one alderman declared during a council meeting that his colleagues had become more interested in giving tax breaks to rich companies than protecting the interests of the poor. - The attack on two white youths by black youths in September. Also, in November, a gang of about 20 young men and women attacked and robbed three people outside a tavern. But in Madison tradition, instead of downplaying the incidents, city leaders condemned them as threats to the city's prevailing ideology and discussed solutions. Clergy joined to assist the Jewish community and allay fears with impassioned sermons and sharply worded editorials. The university instituted mandatory classes to promote racial sensitivity. ``The outpouring of community response has been decisive and overwhelming,'' state Rep. David Clarenbach said. ``Law enforcement, the religious community, minorities have spoken with one voice.'' Opin, the lobbyist, said the incidents did not surprise him as much as the reaction. ``I've been Jewish a long time, and I've encountered a lot of anti-Semitism,'' he said. ``I don't think Madison is any different in its degree of anti-Semitism. ... What's primarily different is the community's response.'' Even with the initial response, city leaders wonder if they have done enough. The NAACP is seeking to build a coalition of activists similar to the one formed in Madison in the 1960s to advance the causes of peace, civil rights, feminism and gay rights. The university, with its 45,000-student body, is seeking additional uses of its resources in fighting problems. ``We have to renew our commitment to civil rights and human rights every day,'' Ms. Rouse said. ``People of all walks of life have come together. To the extent that you can take something that is ugly and painful and make it positive, we've done a great deal.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Indian Bowed But Vows To Keep Fighting
DOC.TEXT: The old fishing platform sags, held up by ropes, a few rotting boards and perhaps the ghosts of fishermen who lived at a time when Indians pulled as many salmon as they wanted from the Columbia River. David Sohappy, Yakima Indian, religious leader and rebel, believes that is a right worth a lifelong fight. ``I want to go fishing whenever I feel like it. With no strings attached whatsoever,'' Sohappy says. It is an idea as dated as the old-fashioned platform, long since supplanted by powerboats. But for Sohappy, there is no compromise on his belief that Indians have the right to fish when and where they want, guaranteed by the Yakima Indian Nation's Treaty of 1855. Despite a 20-month prison term, a stroke and the threat of eviction from his ramshackle home, he refuses to give up. In 1984, U.S. District Judge George Boldt of Tacoma issued a ruling limiting Indian rights to half the harvestable salmon and steelhead in the Puget Sound region. That decision arose in part from protests Sohappy and other Indian fishermen began in 1968 over the state's restrictions on their fishing. But for all the fuss he has created, Sohappy rarely fishes, preferring to spend his time watching soap operas and news. A frail 65-year-old man with one arm crippled by the stroke, he speaks barely above a mumble and must lean on an old golf putter to walk. ``I speak softly but carry a big stick,'' he joked, brandishing the putter. In the latest chapter of this rebel's saga, Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., and Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, are asking the government to stop eviction efforts against Sohappy. The government argues that the Cooks Landing fishing site where Sohappy lives with his wife and some of his seven children is supposed to be a river access point for all Indians, not a dwelling site. Sohappy built a longhouse - a communal dwelling that also serves as a church - on this spit of land on the shore of the mile-wide Columbia east of Vancouver, Wash., in the early 1960s. The longhouse was a protest over the 40 homes and 37 fishing sites of Indians that were flooded by construction of Bonneville Dam in 1937. The government agreed in 1945 to replace those homes and fishing sites, but has made little progress. Sohappy says he has a historic right to live and fish on the river, and he vows never to leave the home he returned to after his release from prison in May 1988. ``Move out and let them win? No way,'' he said. ``We still own the land.'' Sohappy, a leader of the Indian feather religion, speaks of the dire consequences awaiting whites who harass Indians. ``They're just asking for trouble,'' he said. ``People have told them to leave us alone. If they don't, nature will step in and make you spend millions of dollars on weather-related things.'' Buried in the 365-page appropriations bill for the Department of the Interior was one paragraph directing Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan to reconsider the 21-year battle to evict Sohappy and his family. It asks Lujan to meet with the Yakima tribe and report back to Congress within four months. The bill still awaits the president's signature. The fight over his home is just one of many Sohappy rebellions. Sohappy and his son David Jr. were arrested by federal and state wildlife after an undercover sting operation called ``Salmonscam'' in 1981 and 1982. They were accused of selling 317 fish out of season. The Sohappys were convicted in federal court in Los Angeles in 1983 and sentenced to five years in prison. They served 20 months each and remain on probation. A Yakima Tribal Court jury in 1987 acquitted them of tribal poaching charges. That trial, labeled ``Tradition on Trial,'' won international attention from human rights groups. Some members were angry when the tribe prosecuted Sohappy in the ``Salmonscam'' case, tribal prosecutor Jack Fiander said. Others were glad a violator of tribal fishing laws was on trial. The tribe for 25 years has set fishing seasons for its members and regulated the type of equipment they could use, Fiander said. They insisted on prosecuting Sohappy to protect tribal sovereignty in such matters, he said. ``David Sohappy, like any human being, is neither all good nor all bad,'' Fiander said. ``Sometimes, he was both.''

DOC.HEAD: Have Yourself a Video Christmas - On a Budget
DOC.TEXT: There's more than one way to change a channel. Here's a penny-pincher's guide - well, sort of - to a merry, video Christmas for you and your loved ones:
DOC.HEAD: THE BIG TICKET:
DOC.TEXT: - Stereo VCR. This one piece of hardware should be as central to your home video system as the TV tube itself. It's much more versatile and it's the easiest purchase to justify. A stereo VCR converts any television into a stereo TV by delivering its right and left audio channels to your home audio system. It's the biggest, cheapest single improvement you can make to a conventional TV. With the stereo VCR hooked up and tuned in and your good old 19-inch black-and-white Philco between the speakers, you have stereo TV. It gives you much finer acoustic detail to go along with the video image, and you'll be surprised at how much a good soundtrack enhances your viewing. And there's a lot to hear: Most major TV markets have more than one stereo broadcaster, most cable systems can deliver a stereo signal, and most videocassettes sold and rented today are in stereo. With that much programming available, it's just foolish not to upgrade. When you're shopping, remember: A ``two-head'' or ``four-head'' or ``Hi-Fi'' VCR isn't necessarily a stereo model. Every VCR needs one tape head to play and one head to record. Four-head models allow for slow-motion, freeze frames and other special effects. With a stereo VCR, you also get SAP, or Secondary Audio Program services (also known as MTS or Multi-Channel Television Sound). PBS stations use it for descriptive narrative, weather reports and simultaneous translation to a second language. Full-featured models retail for $300 to $450, but basic models can be had for less than $250. - Stereo TV monitor. Here's where shopping pays. Discounters offer stereo-ready, 25-inch TV monitors for just less than $400, and basic 27-inch models for just more than $400. These are just about perfect for home viewing. This is where belt-tightening gets tough, because the more bells and whistles you tack on to that basic picture tube, the faster that big ticket fattens. Then you find yourself paying $50 for delivery of a $2,500, 35-inch behemoth that claims to have 700 lines of resolution, picture-in-picture, ``super-woofer'' and a microwave popcorn maker. Singlehandedly, you have tipped the economy into recession and yourself into debtor's prison. And that bigger tube whets your appetite for that sweet, $500 LaserDisc player that has a 60 percent sharper picture, letterbox formats, CD sound and handles audio Compact Discs - a whole new way to spend money! Be strong (or at least have the decency to wait for the after-Christmas sales). - Video Player. This is the biggest bargain for a budget. Discounters offer rugged, play-only VHS machines for less than $150. For the simple pleasure of home video viewing, they're hard to beat.
DOC.HEAD: THE LESSER TICKET:
DOC.TEXT: - A decoder. Yes, that $1,500 ``Surround-Sound'' loudspeaker system would match your living room decor, but Radio Shack sells the basic decoder for around $130. So you find a couple of extra speakers, hook 'em up, rent your favorite disaster movie, and strap yourself to the couch. ... Apartment dwellers note: THIS DOES NOT INDEMNIFY YOU FROM PLASTER DAMAGE! - A cassette rewinder. For about $30, you can spare the wear-and-tear that sends most VCR and players to the shop. - LaserDiscs. Got a finicky videophile on your list? These beauties sell for anywhere from $19.95 red tag specials to $200 boxed sets, although most releases retail for $30 to $35. Give 'em ``Motel Hell.'' That scene with the dueling chainsaws is high point of 20th century cinema. Heh, heh, heh. ...
DOC.HEAD: THE LOW TICKET:
DOC.TEXT: - Multiple-outlet strips. Anyone with electronic gear will welcome one of these. At $20 to $30, a four- or six-outlet strip feeds into a safe, heavy-duty cord and a three-prong plug. - Spike protector. At about $20, it can prevent a lightning bolt from frying a home entertainment center. - Prerecorded cassettes. There are thousands of movies on the home market, and you already know what movies and stars your friends and relatives enjoy. And is there a better way to tranquilize the kids late on Christmas Day than a movie on cassette? Lassie, come home! - Blank tapes. In the history of videocassette recording, no one ever has been known to have enough blank tapes. No one. Ever.
DOC.HEAD: THE LITTLEST TICKET:
DOC.TEXT: - Compressed air. A spray can of this sure beats dusting with Lemon Pledge. - A good penlight. Fumbling in the dark for tiny switches, wires and RCA sockets is not unlike hell. - Videotape labels. Quick, which is it: SIS-'N'-MOM '86, VAC`N H'LITES '85, NATIONAL VELVET. New labels mean never having to say you're sorry. Happy holidays!

DOC.HEAD: The Slaughter of The Innocents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't long ago, you may recall, when the airwaves and newspapers and books and magazines promoted the idea of leverage, of borrowng to the limit, of using other people's money - OPM - to succeed. Leverage was the way to wealth, you were told, and, if you had doubts, the promoter of the notion could parade before you names of some mighty successful people, such as Michael Milken and a half-dozen local developers. The concept had plenty of ``can't lose'' relatives, such as, ``You can only lose pennies if you buy penny stocks,'' and, ``Anyone with common sense can make it big in commodities,'' and, ``Yes, you can outwit the stock market.'' All such ideas have been slain by the realities. As popular economist Howard Ruff says, among the most vicious of all crimes is the slaughter of popular theories by brutal gangs of facts. Ruff, who made a name years ago by forecasting bad times, takes a look back at the carnage wrought by some of those flighty ideas generated by the free-loose-and-easy (floosy) 1980s. He identifies these among the victims: -Stock prices will rise and rise and rise. Well, for a time they did. And as time grew, people became more convinced than ever it was true. Those too young to recall earlier bloodbaths thought they had identified new truths when they were succumbing to old lies. The phrasing of those ``truths'' was very familiar. The old rules don't apply, it was said. We're in a new era, it was explained. Those who stuck to the old rules were viewed as has-beens, unable to adjust to the new reality. -You can borrow, borrow and borrow, without every worrying about debt. Pay back in cheaper dollars, take a tax deduction and eventually sell your investment for a killing. Don't you know that prices always go up? One of the popular self-help books of the early 1980s managed to squeeze the entire mood of the times into its title, ``How To Borrow Your Way To A Great Fortune Starting From Scratch.'' It might have been possible for a time. In the early 1980s you could profit from real estate investments but take a paper loss for tax purposes. You could raise your rents. You could repay your loans in cheaper dollars. Uncle Sam rescinded the tax benefits, and that put real estate in the category of just another business. Then inflation was brought to manageable levels. As the economy slowed it became more difficult to raise rents. And finally it became impossible to find buyers, especially at inflated prices. Reviewing the '80s, one of the more remarkable observations you can make is that these and similar errors weren't made only by the informed or by those convinced that they had discovered a quick way to riches. Some of the allegedly wisest financial brains in the universe fell for such notions - bankers, brokers, builders, insurance executives, financial advisers, corporate officials, corporate raiders, and not-for-profit institutions. And, oh yes, that profligate old rake Uncle Sam had the best time of all. He squandered, borrowed, refinanced and borrowed more and, for a time, had the ``experts'' convinced it was true, that you needn't ever face the consequences.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, Dec. 5

DOC.HEAD: Self-Appointed Executioners Prey on Guatemalan Street Children
LaserPhotos Planned
DOC.TEXT: Pictures from a scrapbook of horrors stare up from the table: the broken faces and bodies of street children murdered, witnesses say, by police. It is the work of self-appointed executioners who impose the death penalty for petty crimes or sniffing glue or just hanging out. Sometimes they torture their young victims first. They work swiftly, unfettered by legal niceties like arrest or trial. Due process has never quite caught on in Guatemala, which has one of the world's worst human rights records. ``The people who are killing these children probably feel they are doing good,'' said Bruce Harris, director of Casa Alianza, a branch of the New York-based Covenant House that runs several children's shelters in Guatemala. Harris showed yet another picture, of Nahaman Carmona Lopez, a 13-year-old Casa Alianza boy, on his deathbed. His murder began Harris' crusade to bring the killers of street children to justice, and exposed Guatemala's ugly secret. ``He was the kid who had to die to bring this to our attention,'' the first victim from a Casa Alianza shelter, Harris said. Since Nahaman's death in March, Casa Alianza has filed criminal complaints against scores of police officers. Prominent international human rights groups have issued reports condemning official inertia. Western diplomats have tried, without success, to persuade the government to act. There has been no official comment on the murders, and no response to Associated Press requests for an interview with police or a statement from them. In most ways, Nahaman's murder was typical of the fate that has befallen scores of rootless children in the crime-ridden streets of Guatemala City. He just took longer to die. ``The police hate us,'' said William Chalin, 14, a friend of Nahaman's who is nursing several fractured ribs from a recent encounter. Five national police officers on their way to work saw Nahaman and eight other children sniffing glue two blocks from the Casa Alianza shelter. Witnesses said Nahaman resisted when police tried to pour glue on his head, a common curbside punishment for sniffing. It was a fatal error. The officers kicked him viciously, then left him for dead, the witnesses said. By the time an ambulance came, someone had covered Nahaman with paper flowers and white crepe, a funeral tradition for children in Guatemala. He wasn't dead, but was mortally wounded. Nahaman spent 10 days in intensive care, regaining consciousness only long enough to tell a Casa Alianza social worker he knew he was dying. Harris said the boy had bruises over 70 percent of his body, six fractured ribs, two broken fingers, open wounds on his head and face, a ruptured liver, brain injuries and a slash on his back. Casa Alianza demanded an investigation. President Vinicio Cerezo's human rights adviser, Eliona de Rosario Acuna Ordonez, responded that police had ``acted on their personal initiative and not under official orders.'' Harris and his colleagues began gathering evidence. They accumulated statements from witnesses, autopsy reports, photographs, death certificates and other material about attacks on 63 Casa Alianza children, including 13 who died. One was only 8 years old. So far, Casa Alianza has charges pending against 35 national police officers, three treasury police officers, three government-licensed private officers, a military policeman, nine civilians and nine unidentified attackers. The charges range from murder and torture to abuse of authority. Among the defendants are four of the police officers accused of beating Nahaman. Casa Alianza's crusade has provoked an ugly reaction. Its workers have been attacked and threatened. Child witnesses, including several who saw Nahaman Carmona beaten, have been assaulted. ``We got a funeral wreath the other day,'' Harris said. ``They know who we all are and the work we are doing.'' Mario Salazar, a Casa Alianza street worker, said police had threatened him. ``The police see these kids as the scum of society,'' he said. ``They tell me I am wasting my time with them.'' Murders of street children coincide with a crime wave of such alarming proportions that law and order is a pivotal issue in Guatemala's presidential campaign. An estimated 5,000 street children and hundreds of youth gangs roam Guatemala City. ``I can understand the police being frustrated,'' Harris said. ``These kids aren't angels, but nothing excuses the organized killing of children.'' Amnesty International, which also has denounced Brazilian police for murdering street children, said: ``The desire to control crime cannot be used as an excuse for violating basic human rights, including the right to life.'' No one is sure how many children the street-corner executioners have killed. Casa Alianza can act only on behalf of those in its shelters and the authorities have yet to investigate any of the cases. Powerful forces impel children into the streets. Many come from families in such dire poverty that 10 people share a single room. Others are among the thousands orphaned by political violence that has torn Guatemala for 30 years. ``Their lives are precarious and dangerous,'' said a recent report by America's Watch, a human rights monitoring group based in New York. ``Many of them sniff glue to alleviate their hunger. Many of their families live on the streets. ... Others survive alone. Petty street crime is often their only source of food or money.'' Juan Jose Rodil, a former interior minister, said: ``We lack orphanages, youth homes, effective juvenile courts. Our juvenile detention centers are centers of putrefaction that create little monsters. But you don't cut off your head when you have a headache.''

DOC.HEAD: At the Movies: ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' ``Havana''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' currently in early stages of a stepped release in selected markets throughout country; ``Havana'' opens in New York on Dec. 7, in limited markets on Dec. 12 and will open more widely Dec. 14.
DOC.TEXT:
``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge''
India Bridge can't comment about the current political situation because her husband hasn't yet told her what to believe. She is, you see, a woman of the 1920s, when women were expected to cook and sew and take care of the children. And maybe play bridge. Walter Bridge knows what he believes in: business, Republicanism and solid Midwestern values. He is oblivious to any of his wife's aspirations. When his longtime secretary confesses her desperate love for him, he responds in cool disbelief. Three decades in the lives of India and Walter are traced in ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' which stars Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward in the best of their long collaboration in films. They are marvels to watch - two Academy Award professionals employing all their skills to bring life and shading into a pair of seemingly humdrum characters. ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' is the 15th feature film of James Ivory (director), Ismail Merchant (producer) and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala (writer). Their work is unfailingly literate and meticulously produced, a ``Masterpiece Theater'' of the big screen. This is not a putdown; ``Masterpiece Theater'' is the single reliable oasis in television's half-vast wasteland. This time the trio have chosen the much-loved novels, ``Mrs. Bridge'' and ``Mr. Bridge'' by Evan S. Connell. There is no linear plot. The story of a marriage is told in a series of anecdotes that have little connection except for employing the same protagonists. The central figure is the frustrated and confused India, born a few generations too early. Woodward brings pathos to India Bridge without a hint of pity-seeking. Newman has the more difficult job of submerging his famed charisma into the grayish hues of the granite-like Walter. Only an actor of his skill could preven Mr. Bridge from becoming a bore. Ivory (``The Bostonians,'' ``Room With a View'') is richly talented in evoking the spirit and the look of a bygone time and place. He has directed an expert cast, particularly Blythe Danner as India's free-thinking best friend, and Simon Callow as a waspish psychiatrist. The Bridges children are well played by Robert Sean Leonard, Margaret Welsh and Kyra Sedgwick. The Miramax Films release is rated PG-13, for adult situations. Running time: 124 minutes. - By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer. --- ``Havana''
Havana, 1958: a time and place when rum flowed as freely as fast bucks at the craps table, and sex was as open as a 50-foot ketch. Americans came in wild abandon to soak up the withering spoils of corrupt Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. It was the twilight of the aristocracy and the dawn of the peasant - when the rumba met the revolutionary and more than just the music died. Sydney Pollack shakes the death rattle in ``Havana,'' his bittersweet love story of a high-rolling gambler named Jack, played by Robert Redford, who comes to Havana for the biggest poker game of his career, and instead falls in love with Roberta Duran (Lena Olin), a Swedish revolutionary. Roberta is married to an influential aristocrat (Raul Julia) who supports Fidel Castro and the rebel forces. Redford, looking like he just stepped off the set of ``The Way We Were'' in his All-American '50s garb, arrives in Havana on the car ferry just as Batista's thugs board the boat in search of contraband (translation, weapons for the rebel forces). Roberta looks mighty sweaty through it all, and an effete food writer (Daniel Davis), who we immediately know works for The Company (translation CIA), looks on with grand bemusement and interest. Roberta's car carries a cache of American-issue military weapons and ammunition. She hires Jack to drive the car through customs because she fears Batista's men already have her fingered (they probably noticed the look of pure terror on her face). Jack, a middle-aged guy who's gone through life committed to nothing but his one pleasures and nomad existence, is fascinated by Roberta, a sensual, deeply committed woman - committed to her marriage and husband and to the cause. She's everything he isn't. Jack is also drawn towards Arturo, Roberta's husband, who mesmerizes with his eyes, his genteel ways. But the revolution is meaningless for Jack, who merely follows the game wherever it might be. But these are dangerous times with dangerous players. The Durans are arrested, Arturo is believed dead, Roberta is taken off to be tortured.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$Adv 00
DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: be tortured.
DOC.TEXT: Jack's loyalties - to gambling and to his emotions - collide. He carries his desire to save Roberta to the big game with its selective group of heavy hitters, including the head of Batista's security police. Jack does a no-no: He mixes politics with cards. But through his wits, he manages to free Roberta. He hides her in his rooms, but she doesn't stay. The revolution can't wait. Cuba is falling apart as the New Year approaches. Batista is about to flee and Castro is about to come down from the hills. Roberta puts her life on the line and the rebels regard her as a leader. Jack puts his life on the line to find her and spirit her to safety in Miami, and especially by falling in love with her. It is the eve of success for the revolution. And here's where the screenplay falls completely apart. A woman of such intense commitment to such an intense cause would hardly abandon it and the people who depend on her for a man - especially one like Jack. But a predictable twist shakes her back to her destiny. Pollack avoids the polemics of the rebel cause and aims his camera on the decadence and brutality of the Batista regime. He's in his Hemingway mode - the colors, the booze, the women, the fearlessness, the intrigue, the flirtation with death and dying. But the movie lacks any real hard edge or toughness. The movie ends years later. There's a voice-over as Jack gazes out to sea in Key West, Fla., watching the sunset and the ships. Afterall, Roberta might be on one. Another Hemingway nudge. Pollack is a thoughtful and intelligent director who is very good with character development. He wins with Roberta; the jury's still out with Jack. Unfortunately, there's very little sensuality between the two stars. Redford is far too restrained and distant to add fuel to Olin's natural fire. She is an extremely talented and passionate actress who scorched the screen in ``Enemies, A Love Story'' and ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' (another love story set against the politics, confusion and death of a revolution). Redford is likewise a cold fish in what's supposed to be one of the film's hot scenes and an example of the fast life in Havana: a menage a trois with a two American tourists. There are touches of grim wit in ``Havana,'' provided by Alan Arkin as the casino boss and second in command to mobster Meyer Lansky, and by Davis as the CIA gourmand, who gives a coy exit line about being off to write about the food in Southeast Asia. The streets of old Havana were replicated for the film, shot almost entirely in the Dominican Republic. But Owen Roizman's photography is merely pedestrian. Judith Rascoe (``Who'll Stop the Rain,'' ``Endless Love'') wrote the screenplay. Produced by Pollack and Richard Roth, with Ronald L. Schwary as executive producer, Universal Pictures' ``Havana'' is rated R. - By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor. ---= Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. NC-17 - No one under 17 admitted.

DOC.HEAD: Technology Invades Toddlers' World
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Computers are challenging the sandbox and easel in preschool programs across the country, although educators have mixed opinions about introducing technology to toddlers. Youngsters should ``begin as early as possible to view computers as a tool,'' said Suzanne Thouvenelle, vice president of an Alexandria, Va., firm that developed software for young children. But John Lindley, principal of South Colby Elementary School in Port Orchard, Wash., countered, ``Children need to be involved in active learning. Computers are too passive. Computer introduction to them is something they get too much of already and that's television.'' Even Bernard Gifford, vice president of education marketing for Apple Computer Inc., acknowledged that computers in preschool may be ``a bit too early.'' ``I believe strongly in making it available to kids but I would be reluctant to impose a structured program at that age. I think the most important skills for youngsters at ages 3 and 4, frankly, are social skills.'' In a sampling of Head Start preschool classes around the country, children used computers to create animals and plant imaginary gardens. One program allowed them to combine facial features on the computer while dictating stories to their teachers. The youngsters were so excited and motivated by the computers that attendance improved, Thouvenelle said. Parents also showed a greater interest in their children's work and enthusiastically volunteered to work in the classroom. Walt Disney Computer Software, Inc. recently introduced a line of software that had been tested at two Burbank, Calif., preschools. ``Nowhere on the package does it say educational software,'' notes Sam Palahnuk, Walt Disney product developer. ``What we claim this stuff is a `fun exploratory software for your kid.''' Fun is what 3-year-old Heather Leffler, 4-year-old Emily Koleini and her 2-year-old brother Massoud were having during a demonstration of the software at an upscale Virginia mall. With parents nearby, the children watched in delight the colorful, animated graphics of Mickey Mouse and his friends and listened to the digitalized speech, fully orchestrated music and real-life sound effects. The youngsters used numbers to help Mickey Mouse plan a birthday party for Goofy, named animals at a county fair with letters of the alphabet, and identified shapes as Mickey performed magic acts. ``It certainly isn't boring,'' said Andrea Fleury of McLean, Va., as she threatened to leave her 3-year-old, who had tinkered with the computer for nearly two hours. ``We went for the approach `let kids really have fun and they'll learn as a side effect,''' said Palahnuk. ``We don't want to claim that it's going to teach your kid anything. We think it will, but you start getting into teaching philosophy and curriculum and all that kind of thing.'' A study by the National Association of Elementary School Principals found that elementary school children are more likely to use computers in school than high school or college students, and even 15 percent of kindergartners and preschoolers in the public schools use computers. ``Research dating back to 1932 showed that technology as simple as a typewriter had significant effects on the reading and writing performance of elementary students,'' said James E. Dezel, International Business Machines Corp. vice president. ``The technology available to schools today and in the future could bring about amazing results.'' IBM sponsored the three-year study exploring classroom uses of computers with children and parents in Head Start, a popular federal preschool program that provides education, meals and health screening for poor youngsters aged 3 through 5. Eleven of Head Start's 1,300 programs participated, including four in Baltimore, Md., and one each in Winder, Ga., DeRidder, La., New York City, Lexington, Ky., Toledo, Ohio, Las Cruces, N.M., and Dayton, Ohio. Head Start was used ``because of its emphasis on providing equity for kids from low-income families,'' said Thouvenelle, vice president of Mobius Corp., which developed new software after evaluating the program. She said the software meets the guidelines of the National Association for the Education of Young Children ``as being developmentally appropriate.'' Association officials take no position on computers in preschool. ``Our major concern was whether or not computers were applicable, or would work for preschool children 3 and 4 years old,'' said Thouvenelle. A second concern, she said, was whether ``young children can use computers as a tool the same way they use blocks or easel painting.'' Each of the 44 classrooms participating in the experiment had two computers that shared a printer, mouse and a large, touch-sensitive device known as the Powerpad. Thouvenelle said the Powerpad is important to young children who often do not have the fine motor skills needed to hold a pen or pencil. The computers ran a program called KidsWay, which came equipped with voice cards in the native language of the parents of the children who participated, such as Spanish, Navajo, Swahili and Japanese. A key finding, said Thouvenelle, is that computers should be available and accessible to youngsters in the classroom, the same as reading materials, art work, blocks, sandbox and other so-called learning center areas. Preschoolers should not be marched down the hall to a computer laboratory, she said. She said a lack of teacher training and support remains a key drawback to the program. Winnie Porter, a 12-year teaching veteran of kindergarten through fifth grade in San Francisco, is against pushing academics too early in kindergarten. Computers, she said, ``are good as long as kids are allowed to explore with them and they are not forced on them.'' ``I think children could learn what they would learn from a computer as they would learn from other things,'' said Pat Wynne-Evans, who retired last year as a San Francisco teacher. With many school districts plagued by tight budgets, Lindley, the South Colby principal, said, ``If I had to make a financial decision between buying big blocks for $400-$500 and a computer for $850, I'd go with the big blocks every time. ``Kids need active learning. Computers are not multi-dimensional. Also you want children using their imagination, rather than looking at a screen,'' Lindley said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice or Quotas? Political Parties Wrestle With a Hot Issue
DOC.TEXT: The next presidential campaign will likely feature a fiery debate over affirmative action. But one party will call it simple justice, the other will label it unfair quotas and voters will have to decide whom to believe. Sen. Jesse Helms rode to re-election in North Carolina after accusing his black challenger, Democrat Harvey Gantt, of supporting racial quotas. And while some denounced the tactic, others detected a way to bolster the identity and electoral strength of the Republican Party. ``Helms came from 13 points behind to win comfortably, I think solely on this issue,'' said GOP consultant Roger Stone. ``It is the kind of cutting social issue that conservatives need to hold onto the White House.'' A number of recent developments suggest voters may be hearing a lot more about affirmative action and racial quotas between now and November 1992: -Democratic congressional leaders have renewed their pledge to once again pass a civil rights bill that President Bush branded a quota bill and vetoed in the last Congress. -Virginia Gov. Doug Wilder, the only Democrat blatantly testing the 1992 presidential waters, blasted Bush's characterization of the bill and said it gave Helms phony ammunition. ``I know what racial quotas are; I have experienced them firsthand,'' Wilder, who is black, said in a letter to Bush. -William Bennett, the new Republican Party chairman, defended Helms' use of the quota issue and said he was ready to debate affirmative action if the Democrats bring it up. ``Most Americans are troubled'' by racial preference programs, he said. -Disaffected Democrats at a conservative forum predicted doom for their party unless more moderate voices are heard. ``Until we give up fear and discuss these issues rationally and logically, we are going to continue to lose,'' said former New York Mayor Ed Koch. Prominent Democrats say their party has a sound position but others have distorted it. ``I don't know what there is to redefine,'' said party chairman Ron Brown, who is black. ``The Democratic Party and its chairman in particular vehemently oppose quotas. We vehemently oppose anything that could lead to reverse discrimination. The legislation that the Democratic Congress sent forward to the president was not a quota bill. It was supported by a number of conservative Republicans.'' But the Democrats - including Gantt himself - acknowledge that they haven't communicated well with voters, many of whom equate affirmative action with quotas. As Stone noted, ``Harvey Gantt ran up and down North Carolina saying he wasn't for quotas, but nobody believed him.'' Working against the Democrats is a feeling among some voters that the civil rights agenda of the 1960s has been fulfilled - that affirmative action was supposed to be temporary and small-scale and has outlived its time. But Gantt said hundreds of years of discrimination cannot be remedied in two decades. ``That's not even one generation,'' he said. ``We need to do it, and we need to remove the stigma that we're going to discriminate against whites or we're going to promote blacks who aren't qualified. None of that is true.'' Many Democrats maintain the heart of the matter is economics. They say Republicans want to divert attention from the recession, and the whole idea of affirmative action is more threatening now because jobs are scarce. ``This issue is about a shrinking economic pie and people thinking someone's going to give their slice to somebody else,'' said Democratic strategist Mike McCurry. ``You have to recast the debate to show the Republicans are trying to peddle fear instead of a plan to get the economy going. And you have to have an answer for the working person who fears for his job,'' he added. ``You have to say, `my plan is to develop a red-hot economy so we all have jobs.''' Republican analyst Doug Bailey thinks his party, too, should look at the big picture. He said it would be ``a big political mistake'' to lean heavily on affirmative action to fill the void left by the end of the Cold War and the splintering of the GOP on abortion and taxes. ``It turns off a large corps of moderate voters, Northern suburban voters who have supported the Repulican party in the past,'' Bailey said. ``They will not want to see a party intentionally choose an issue, even though it may have some merit, which divides people on racial lines.'' However, Stone said the theme would appeal to a group that is equally if not more important to the party - blue-collar ``Reagan Democrats.'' And he maintained it could be pursued without the GOP appearing to be insensitive or divisive. ``You can use other issues to illustrate your desire for economic growth in the minority community,'' Stone said. ``Go out and campaign against quotas but for enterprise zones and greater financial assistance for minority education.'' But the Democrats firmly believe they hold the higher ground on civil rights and can persuade voters of that. Foreshadowing the rhetoric to come, Wilder has accused Bush of failing to provide moral leadership and Brown called his veto of the civil rights bill a disgrace. ``He had an important choice to make,'' the party chairman said, ``and he chose the politics of Jesse Helms and David Duke rather than the politics of Martin Luther King and Abraham Lincoln.''

DOC.HEAD: Customs Kids: Baby-Faced Scouts Looking for Bad Guys
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: International travelers arriving at Kennedy Airport may think the U.S. Customs inspectors checking their luggage look a tad baby-faced - and they're right. Some are as young as 14. The youths are part of the Boy Scouts of America's Explorer program, but this group is not just interested in earning merit badges - they're looking for drugs, weapons and counterfeit goods. These Explorers are involved in nearly every aspect of Customs activities, from searching foreign cargo planes to X-raying cartons of frozen shrimp. Before going out in the field, they attend classes where they learn essentials like search, arrest and seizure techniques and how to conduct a proper patdown. Later, they'll also perform surveillance with agents investigating money laundering and child pornography. Sunds exciting, right? Most days it is, the group insists. They get to meet a lot of celebrities: Steve Martin and Mel Brooks among them. But they also discover there's a downside as well. Like rummaging through someone's sweaty, dirty underwear. Or sniffing the contents of a suspicious vial only to learn a dozen sneezes too late that it's chili powder. Or being pelted with overripe, illegal fruit by passengers who believe, ``If I can't have it, neither can you.'' ``Yeah, I came in here really thinking that every day was going to be like `Miami Vice,' '' said Donald Pearce, 20, of Queens. ``Trust me, it's not.'' The program, which began in 1984, is designed to give hands-on experience and help participants decide if they want a career in law enforcement, said Customs Officer Patricia Leyden, post supervisor. ``It also gives them a different view of what life is like,'' she said. ``Some of them come from disadvantaged homes or neighborhoods where kids don't grow up with the greatest dreams in the world. This program hopefully teaches them they can do something positive with their lives.'' The latter is what attracted Pearce. He joined the group at 15 and is in college pursuing a degree in criminal justice. ``I grew up in a rapidly changing community. The crime rate was going up. Drugs were everywhere. I could have stayed out on the streets with my friends, but I knew where they were headed,'' Pearce said. ``I didn't want to be 21 with a GED and have a motorcycle be the most important thing in my life.'' Nationwide, some 1.1 million youths are involved in Explorer programs that run the gamut from movie producing to medicine and commercial art to aerospace engineering. Brian Archimbaud, director of Exploring for the Boy Scout Council in New York, said the focus shifted from camping and nature programs around 1970 after a survey showed senior Scouts wanted career-oriented programs. ``They also, not surprisingly, wanted a program that had girls in it,'' Archimbaud said. The 11 males and three females at the Kennedy post, who range in age from 14 to 20, nearly blend in with their official U.S. Customs counterparts, helping enforce the laws of 40 federal agencies. Only their youthful faces and trendy hairdos give them away. Dressed in the Customs uniform of starched white shirts and blue trousers, they politely answer travelers' questions as they look through luggage for contraband. Though the Explorers haven't been in on any big busts, they have had some small successes. Charles Sierra - a serious, bearded 19-year-old who refused to smile for a photographer because he was ``on duty'' - found a carton of guns in a shipment of luggage while working cargo inspection. David Chianes - a 16-year-old nicknamed Bart because of his Simpson-like hairdo - uncovered 40 ounces of opium inside some hollowed tree branches while working the mailroom detail. ``They were just regular branches, but they smelled funny,'' the youthful sleuth said. And then there was ``the great mango caper,'' said Robert Nici, 19, giving a companion a high five. Nici, tie slightly askew, busily chomping gum, recalls how he discovered an illegal cache of mangoes inside a Caribbean woman's suitcase. He was the one who got pelted. ``You think you've got the big load here, the one that's going to make Medellin (cartel) crumble, and it turns out to be illegal fruit.'' Though he made light of his big bust, Leyden gently reminded him that he might have stopped another Mediterranean fruit fly infestation, a fact that prompted another high five. Of all the jobs, the Explorers seem to like doing plane searches best. ``It's the lttle kids in them,'' Leyden said. ``They get to go in and search the electrical systems, under floors, looking for whatever.'' Most volunteer between 10 and 30 hours a month at the airport. They also give anti-drug lectures at high schools and community fairs. To become an Explorer, no previous Scouting experience is necessary. Members must be between 14 and 20 and, if in high school, maintain a C average. The mix, nationwide, is 60 percent male and 40 percent female. Though the group falls under the auspices of the Boy Scouts, the program is run through the participating agency or business. Archimbaud said about 60 percent of the Explorers go into some aspect of their career posts; two former members of the JFK post now are working as full-time Customs inspectors. ``The rest go off in a totally different direction,'' Archimbaud said. ``That's one of the program's main advantages. They get to experience different careers before they're forced to make a serious commitment.'' He knows firsthand the benefits of the program. His daughter was a journalism Explorer at a Dallas newspaper. ``By her exposure to a newspaper, she got a real good sense of what the career had to offer - the pluses, the drawbacks.'' Pause. ``And as a result, she's in law school today.''

DOC.HEAD: Latin America: Dumping Ground for Toxic Wastes
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and European companies dump millions of tons of toxic waste in Latin America every year, leaving poisonous residues that health officials say will endanger lives for decades. Everything from household trash to radioactive sludge is sent to the region because lax anti-pollution laws make disposal easier and cheaper. Waste exporters say they are doing nothing wrong, but environmentalists claim Latin Americans are not being told the full story behind the toxic garbage they receive. Scientists in Brazil say the toxic waste, dumped haphazardly in rivers, marshlands or earth wells since the late 1960s, causes cancers, birth defects, nerve damage and blood disorders. ``This is an illicit trade, shrouded in secrecy and often done by small unregistered companies, that is devastating the environment and will affect generations to come,'' said Dr. Anthony Wong, president of the Brazilian Society of Toxicology and director of the Sao Paulo Poison Control Center. No precise figures are available for Latin America, but Mostafa Tolla, director of the U.N. Environmental Program, estimates that 40 million tons of toxic waste entered the Third World in 1989. The United States, which generates 275 million tons of hazardous garbage a year, is the world's leading waste exporter. American companies wanting to export hazardous waste must tell the Environmental Protection Agency. Such notifications rose from 12 in 1980 to 626 in 1989. A growing share of the waste went to Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and the Caribbean, according to EPA documents. ``Latin America is a perfect dumping ground,'' said Rubens Born, director in Brazil for Greenpeace, the international environmental group. ``There's lots of space, loads of corrupt inspectors and widespread ignorance of the problem.'' Waste exporters say wastes are tightly monitored by the EPA and shipments could not leave the United States if they contained dangerous levels of toxins. They also say the disposal methods they practice in foreign countries are comparable to those in the United States. Latin health officials argue that poorly paid, ill-equipped port inspectors are easily bribed to sign consent forms for importing hazardous waste or to look the other way when cargoes are disposed of illegally. U.S. law says foreign countries must be notified about waste shipments, but many Latin governments complain about the quality of the information. ``The information we receive from the U.S. EPA is grossly misleading,'' said Dr. Waldemar F. Almeida, head of Brazil's National Institute of Health Quality Control. ``We are rarely informed of the quantity, the type of waste or its destination.'' Wendy Grieder, director of the EPA's international office in Washington, responded in a telephone interview: ``Waste is shipped with the understanding of all countries involved. Latin countries are told through our embassies what kind of waste they are getting, how much and the point of exit and entry.'' A 1988 report by the EPA inspector general said, however, that the agency did not know how much waste was shipped abroad or which exporters failed to comply with requirements for notification of intent. Foreign firms often approach debt-ridden Latin governments with offers of public works projects or increased investment in return for permission to dump waste. In 1988, a New York company offered to build schools, hospitals and roads in San Clemente, Peru, in return for the right to dispose of incinerator ash near the city. After public protests, Peruvian officials rejected the offer. On July 7, 1989, the Summit Cement and Development Corp. asked the Bahamas government for permission to blend 88,000 tons a year of hazardous solvents with prime fuels to fire cement kilns on Grand Bahama Island, according to company documents. In return, Summit promised to create 180 jobs and give $4.5 million to the Caribbean island. The government turned the offer down. ``Hazardous wastes would have been unloaded and burned 50 yards from where cruise ships dock in the harbor,'' said Edward St. George, chairman of the Bahamas Port Authority. ``For a few jobs, we would have polluted the island and severely damaged our reputation with tourists.'' The Associated Press telephoned several times to the office of the company owner, Finn Moller, in Alhambra, Calif. His secretary said he would have no comment. Chile, Argentina, Guatemala and Bolivia have received offers from U.S. and European companies to build incinerators and dump sites for foreign waste, government officials of those countries told the AP. All offers were refused. Jim Vallette, a Greenpeace coordinator in Washington, D.C., said: ``These governments have so far resisted pressure to enter potentially lucrative dumping contracts because nationalists will accuse them of pandering to Uncle Sam's interests.'' Environmentalists say the cash offers are tempting for Latin American governments, which have a combined foreign debt of more than $400 billion. ``We are being forced to choose between poverty and poison,'' said Juan Shroder, founder of the environmental group Earth Alert in Buenos Aires. Some waste is intended for use in development projects. In January, International Energy Resources Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., offered to underwrite the cost of resurfacing 400 miles of roads in Guatemala with 5.5 million tons of ash from U.S. municipal incinerators. The government backed out after Greenpeace told Guatemalan authorities the ash contained dangerous levels of arsenic, cadmium and mercury. Douglas Berardo, president of the company, said the chemicals did not pose a health or ecological threat because the ash had been ``washed,'' and what toxicity remained would be immobilized when the ash was mixed with concrete. ``Everything was done according to the EPA's specifications,'' he said by telephone from Greenwich. ``This ash is clean.'' He said Venezuela, Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and San Andres Island in Colombia had refused similar deals. Several European and U.S. scrap suppliers have mixed toxic sludge with ordinary metals meant to be recycled by Latin American industries. Last year, Greenpeace complained about a shipment of 430 metric tons of toxic zinc residues from Belgium, Italy and Denmark to Brazil's Produquimica Co., said Eduardo San Martin, pollution control director of Sao Paulo state. Brazilian environmental officials found the residue to contain dangerously high levels of lead, mercury, cadmium and PCBs that Produquimica was unequipped to handle and the waste was sent back, San Martin said. Greenpeace blocked a second shipment of 1,000 tons of tainted zinc residue. To sidestep controls, some foreign-owned multinationals ship wastes to subsidiaries in Latin countries. In 1978, dioxanes and benzene produced by foreign multinationals abroad were buried in earth wells in the Samarita district of Cubatao in southern Brazil, said Wong, director of the Sao Paulo center. Housing was built on the well sites several years later and dozens of residents suffered blood disorders, such as sickle cell anemia and leukemia, because of the toxins, said a report by Sao Paulo state health officials. In 1989, Mexican health officials in Ciudad Juarez said scores of children sniffed glowing toxic waste dumped by a ``maquiladora,'' one of more than 1,000 U.S.-owned assembly plants on the Mexican side of the border. They said the waste could cause infertility, genetic damage and organ and brain lesions. A study of seven border cities by the Colegio de la Frontera Norte, a Mexican think tank, said maquiladoras were contaminating the water table and contributing to cancer, congenital defects and nervous system damage. Chile, Argentina and Paraguay are drafting laws to prohibit waste imports. Brazil restricted imports of scrap metal imports on Aug. 1.

DOC.HEAD: After Captivity and Cancer, Robert Polhill Is Still Cracking Jokes
With BC-Hostages At Home-Reed
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: If ever a man has had his sense of humor put to the test, it's Robert Polhill. First, he's held hostage by Lebanese extremists more than three years and, being diabetic, must find a way to get daily insulin from captors who don't speak his language. Then, when the former Beirut University College lecturer is released, he learns he has throat cancer and must have his voice box removed. Now Polhill, at 56, is without a job, breathing through a hole in his neck and trying to get people to understand him through a fatiguing process called esophageal speech. Still, the one-liners keep coming. ``I'll talk again,'' he wrote on a yellow pad. ``But I'm a realist, too. I'll never have another hit record.'' Polhill was taken hostage Jan. 24, 1987, and freed last April 22. Three and a half weeks later, doctors at Walter Reed Hospital removed his larynx. A short time later, he and his wife moved into a hospital apartment near the speech clinic where he gets therapy twice a day. ``He's an A-plus student,'' said Prof. William T. Simpkins Jr. ``He made a sound the first month after surgery. At four months, he's where many people are at six months.'' Polhill said that for 39 years, including his days as a hostage, he smoked up to four packs of cigarettes a day. More than 90 percent of the 25,000 people who require the surgery were heavy smokers, Simpkins said. ``He was always smoking,'' said Polhill's wife, Ferial. ``He got up in the middle of the night to smoke.'' Polhill can't smoke anymore, because he no longer can breathe through his nose and mouth. He talks by capturing air between his tongue and teeth and compressing it to create sounds. That, and note-writing, are the ways he answers questions. Laryngectomy patients who perfect this esophageal speech sound like normal talkers with headcolds, Simpkins said. Polhill said he rejected the electronic device preferred by some throat-cancer victims because ``you sound like you are trying out for `Star Wars.' '' Tall and slim, Polhill is generally low-key, bantering playfully with his wife and cracking jokes with visitors. When he tires of talking, he reaches for his pencil and pad and keeps the conversation going in neat, precise print. He bristled only once, when he was asked if losing his voice was worse than being a hostage. ``To me there is no comparison to being chained to the floor,'' he said. ``You couldn't even get up to go to the bathroom.'' When Polhill was released, he was quoted as saying he ``strived to continue to be angry'' as a means of coping with captivity. Later, he said he was angry at being a captive, but not consumed by it. ``The point was that anger is a great energizer,'' he said. ``Then you use humor to tone it down and rechannel it more productively. ``I guess I've always been able to laugh at myself,'' said Polhill. ``I didn't have the psychological problems I was expected to have.'' He said a State Department psychiatrist was assigned to him at Damascus immediately after he was released. But by the time they reached Wiesbaden, Germany, the two men were friends, not doctor and patient. ``They warned me that he would go into a depression,'' Ferial Polhill said. ``But I said, `I don't think so.' '' Polhill's plans for the future are vague. A certified public accountant, he said he's too out of date to step right back into an accounting job. ``All of my energy to date has been devoted to the return to freedom, recovery from cancer and learning to talk,'' he said. His medical bills and living arrangements have been handled by the government since his release, though he knows Uncle Sam's generosity won't go on forever. ``I'd like to write. I'd like to speak and teach again,'' he said. He also said he would like to help diabetics, throat cancer patients and hostages and their families. Ferial Polhill, who is Palestinian and fluent in Arabic, English and French, is ready to go back to work. She and Robert met in Cyprus when she was an office manager at the international accounting firm for which he worked. An openly affectionate couple, they've been married for 10 years. They will move wherever there is a job opportunity, Polhill said, but he would like to stay in the United States. Meanwhile, the couple's social life has included functions arranged by No Greater Love, a non-profit organizations that helps hostages and their families, and the American Diabetes Association, which published Polhill's account of how he coped with his diabetes as a captive. In the association's Forecast magazine, he wrote about how he and another diabetic hostage took care of each other and communicated their needs to their captors. Otherwise, he declines to give extensive details about his 1,182 days as a captive. ``I have a responsibility to those still there,'' he said. ``I've made my recommendations directly to the man who can do something. I have no public recommendations to make.'' He said President Bush listened intently and took notes when they met shortly after Polhill was released. Ferial Polhill said if her husband wants to discuss his days as a hostage, she's there to listen, but she doesn't ask questions and doesn't feel a need to know the details. ``Thinking about it doesn't bother me,'' said Polhill. ``But does the world need to know?'' While Polhill was a captive, Ferial stayed on in Beirut, the city where she grew up, trying to find her husband. She left only when fighting became intolerable, but returned later and was in Beirut when Robert was released. She said people have been surprised at how easily the couple has adjusted to being together again after the long ordeal. ``It's as if we were stepping back in time,'' she said. ``We fell back into our lives as if nothing had happened.'' She said her friends have asked her how her husband hollers at her now that he has no voice box. ``I say, `His writing gets very messy','' she said. ``That's what's depressing,'' joked Polhill. ``I can't shout at her anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: A Bittersweet Coming Home for a Hostage Held in Lebanon
With BC-Hostage at Home-Polhill
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: After 44 months of blindfolds and bonds, of arsenic and aches, former hostage Frank Reed is trying to find his place in the world. It hasn't been easy. Jobless and living in a furnished apartment, homecoming for Reed has been pleasure fused with pain this fall. There have been holidays and birthdays, football games and homecomings, reunions with old friends, and a sentimental journey into the past to review his life. But what Reed has found since he was freed by his Shiite Moslem kidnappers in Lebanon on April 30 is that he is not the same man, that things are not the same, that life is getting shorter. ``The healing process takes time,'' he said. ``I'm trying to find out who I am, what America is, how do I fit into all of these things, where do I belong, where should I live, how am I going to pay the rent over the rest of my life. ``One of the problems about hostaging is you become very self-centered because your major concern is yourself,'' he said. ``And I brought that out with me. ... I'm certainly a hell of a lot happier. But am I enjoying contentment and happiness? No. I'm not there yet.'' A triplet whose Siamese-twin sisters died shortly after birth, Frank Reed was a born survivor. Now he is trying to survive again, trying to complete his reentry into the world. He has launched a movement he calls ``Hostagepeace'' to work for the release of 13 Westerners still held in Lebanon. Most of them are believed in the hands of Shiite factions belonging to the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Reed calls them ``our boys,'' distinguishing his generation of hostages from new ones held by Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait last August. He has taken his movement to college campuses across the country on a lecture circuit that has been providing his only income. He talks often of friends left behind, among them six Americans, including Terry Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, and Thomas Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut. They are in their sixth year of captivity, the longest-held hostages. Reed, who turned 58 last Monday, lost his school and his property in Lebanon. He spent 11 weeks in a hospital after his release. Doctors found arsenic in his system. His weight dropped to 131 pounds. He talks of beatings and of months blindfolded in solitary confinement for twice trying to escape. Fifi Reed, his Syrian-born wife 20 years his junior, said the husband who stepped out of captivity is not the giving, kind man she met and married in 1977. She was in teacher training at the Lebanese International School he founded and directed. He became a Moslem before marrying her. Today, some of the romantic luster has given way to the reality of starting anew. Mrs. Reed, who moved to the United States in 1989 and works at a Boston insurance firm, helps support the family. She and son Tarek lived in an apartment with Reed's mother, Leota Sprague, during the last year of her husband's captivity. ``I'm coming out of Lebanon with nothing,'' Reed said. ``What I've left behind is the school, the income and the property that I owned.'' Mrs. Reed said they are struggling financially. ``Every now and then I have to resort to my parents, as usual,'' she said, ``but it is a struggle.'' Publicly, Frank Reed is adjusting much better than expected, his wife said. He's negotiating for a book and a movie and hopes to complete his Ph.D. in education at Boston College. He is healthy again, the arsenic flushed from his body, his weight back up to 176 pounds. ``Privately, it's a bit hard,'' Mrs. Reed said. ``I expected that and I'm facing it. A lot of Frank was a very spontaneous, naturally giving kind of person. Right now, I don't see that.'' Tarek turned 10 in November. Reed had missed the boy's past four birthdays. On Thanksgiving Day, Reed went to the Malden High School football game with old friends, then sat down to dinner with his mother and his older brother for the first time in more than a dozen years. They all gave thanks that he is alive and that they were together this year. ``Not only that, I might not be here another year,'' said his mother, Mrs. Sprague, who will be 92 in February. ``I'm giving thanks that we're all together, that I'm free,'' Reed said that day. ``But I will never be free until the others are. I pray for the others.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - George Esper is the AP's Northeast regional reporter, based in Boston.

Robert Polhill, released after three years, hasn't lost his sense of humor, despite his battle with throat cancer.
