DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, Dec. 8-9

DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., the remnants of Frank Lorenzo's Texas Air Corp. empire, filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors, saying it was overwhelmed by a heavy debt load and surging fuel prices. The company, parent of Continental Airlines Inc., filed its Chapter 11 petition Monday in Wilmington, Del., where it is incorporated. The filing is the second time in seven years Continental has sought to reorganize. The filing didn't affect any operations or schedules among the 88 U.S. cities and 55 international destinations Continental serves with a fleet of more than 300 planes. --- NEW YORK (AP) - AT&T said its proposed $6 billion buyout of NCR Corp. would create a worldwide computing powerhouse, but the chairman of the nation's fifth-largest computer maker said he's not interested. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Monday that it first approached NCR about a buyout Nov. 15, and that the two companies held talks on the offer since. Though AT&T described its stock-swap bid announced Sunday as friendly, NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. said AT&T's decision to disclose the talks made the $90-a-share proposal hostile. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Business continued to slow at the nation's industrial companies in November, extending a decline that is likely to continue for some time, the National Association of Purchasing Management said. The purchasing managers said Monday that production and new orders both dropped, pushing the group's index of economic activity down to 41.3 percent from 43.4 percent in October. Private economists predicted the downturn will continue until interest rates fall and the Middle East crisis is resolved. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Consumers continued to pay their bills in the July-September quarter but were scaling back borrowing as the economy headed into what many analysts say is a recession, a banking group said. The percentage of consumer loans 30 or more days delinquent was a seasonally adjusted 2.56 percent at the end of the third quarter, virtually unchanged from the 2.55 percent rate at the end of the April-June period, the American Bankers Association said Monday. The rate was 2.46 percent at the end of the first quarter and 2.64 percent at the end of the fourth quarter of 1989. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - Negotiations to complete an unprecedented global free trade pact opened in turmoil as delegates inside the hall clashed on farm issues while police outside battled angry demonstrators. Almost 30,000 farmers marched Monday to protest a U.S.-backed proposal aimed at trimming billions of dollars in trade-distorting agricultural subsidies. Police at one point used tear gas and water cannons. The talks involve 107 member nations in an effort to rewrite the constitution of world trade, a document known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Businesses facing lawsuits over pensions received some protection from the Supreme Court as the justices ruled workers cannot sue in state courts on grounds they were fired so their employers would not have to pay pension benefits. The court ruled unanimously Monday that state suits are pre-empted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, which is aimed at assuring that workers get their retirement pay. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A smell can be registered as a trademark just as a word, name, symbol, color or sound can be, the Patent and Trademark Office said in a ground-breaking decision. The office Monday approved registration of the scent of a type of embroidery yarn and sewing thread produced by Clarke's OSEWEZ (pronounced ``Oh Sew Easy'') of Goleta, Calif. --- PITTSBURGH (AP) - Westinghouse Electric Corp. said 600 employees in its energy systems business unit will lose their jobs at the end of the year. The company said Monday the reduction, which involves 300 layoffs and 300 voluntary retirements, is necessary to strengthen Westinghouse's competitive position in the commercial nuclear power market in the United States and abroad. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration predicted in a report to Congress that the U.S. trade deficit would remain steady even though Americans are paying sharply more for imported oil. Prepared by the Treasury Department as a requirement of the 1988 trade law, the report Monday also indicated that a further decline in the value of the dollar was not needed to improve the nation's trade balance. The deficit has dropped from a peak of $162 billion in 1987 to $129 billion in 1988 and $110 billion in 1989. During the first six months of 1990, it ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $87 billion. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens and building trade unions from Ohio and Kentucky said they are starting a research organization to investigate foreign investment in a six-state region. Jerry Hammond, executive secretary-treasurer of the Kentucky State Building & Construction Trades Council, said Monday the study will focus first on Japanese investment in the region's auto industry because of the investments by Toyota, Nissan, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Honda and Subaru-Isuzu. ---

Stock prices posted modest gains Monday, as oil prices appeared to stabilize at lower levels and interest rates slipped. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.94 points to close at 2,565.59. Bonds rose moderately. The dollar closed sharply higher. Gold skidded. Oil prices were slightly higher, soybean futures prices soared, cattle futures were mixed and pork futures were lower.

DOC.HEAD: `Business as Usual' as Humbled Carrier Files for Bankruptcy
With PM-Continental-Analysis, PM-Continental-Chronology
DOC.TEXT: The bankruptcy court filing by Continental Airlines leaves an empire built by ousted chairman Frank Lorenzo in disarray, but the carrier says it will continue flying while it tries to reorganize. The nation's fifth-largest airline blamed $2.2 billion in debt and increased jet fuel costs due to the Persian Gulf crisis for Monday's decision to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws. Continental said the move did not affect any of about 1,400 flights Monday. The airline serves 88 U.S. cities and 55 international destinations with more than 300 planes. Its main hubs are in Newark, N.J., Houston and Denver, and the airline is building up a fourth hub in Cleveland. Management sought to reassure the airline's passengers and 37,000 employees the carrier planned to emerge from bankruptcy court as an operating entity. The airline would fly its normal schedule and honor contracts with travel agents and other airlines. ``We are confident that there will be no need for layoffs, pay cuts or reductions in benefits,'' said Hollis Harris, chairman of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., the airline's parent, which also filed for Chapter 11. The move, though, leaves in tatters an empire crafted by Lorenzo from a hodgepodge of carriers including Eastern Airlines, People Express and Frontier and its huge debt is a legacy of its growth during the 1980s. Subsidiary Eastern is struggling as it seeks to reorganize after filing for bankruptcy protection in 1989, Lorenzo was ousted as chairman earlier this year and his Texas Air Corp. was renamed. The trip to bankruptcy court was the second in seven years by Continental, which filed in 1983 amid a bitter labor dispute with the airline's union. Under Chapter 11, a company gets a reprieve from debts while it figures out how to pay bills and tries to reorganize as a healthy business. ``This is not a bankruptcy as was Continental's in 1983 or Eastern's last year,'' Continental's general counsel, Charles T. Goolsbee, said. ``Remember, those airlines shut down. ... We are doing none of that. This is absolutely a business-as-usual program.'' Some analysts said Continental may have a relatively smooth ride through bankruptcy court, but recent shakeouts in the industry and the uncertainty of the Middle East situation remain troubling. ``It's still a strong airline,'' said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon Read & Co., a Wall Street investment firm. ``They've got good hubs and fairly cheap operating costs. They want to hold onto most of these assets. In the long term, that could be good.'' Continental said it had agreed to sell its Seattle-Tacoma to Tokyo route to American Airlines for $150 million, pending bankruptcy court approval. The route sale is to be concluded at the end of 1991, but $140 million of the sale price is expected to be advanced to Continental before the deal closes. As part of the sale, Continental withdrew its other international routes from the market. Last month, Continental put those up for sale instead of seeking bankruptcy protection. Continental has about $2.2 billion in outstanding debt, about $1.7 billion of which is secured. It also has nearly $4 billion in aircraft operating losses. Harris said the airline is spending an extra $70 million a month on jet fuel because of a sharp rise since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. Prices more than doubled from about 57 cents in July to $1.28 in mid-October before falling back in recent weeks. Continental now is paying $1.07 per gallon. In addition, the airline has increased passenger fares 15 percent in recent months, but spokesman Ned Walker said the hikes ``come nowhere near to recovering our fuel costs.'' Continental lost $88.3 million in the third quarter of this year, compared to a loss of $158 million in 1989. For the first nine months, losses totaled $97 million, compared with $523 million in the same period a year ago. Rising jet fuel costs have affected other airlines, but none had filed for Chapter 11 before Continental. Earlier this fall, Pan Am Corp. announced it would sell five prized London routes to UAL Corp., the parent of United, in a $400 million deal. In addition, airlines have laid of thousands of workers and some plan to cut capacities.

DOC.HEAD: Nations Talk, But Some in Third World Say Deal Will Hit Hard
With PM-Trade Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Not everyone views this week's trade talks as a key to economic prosperity. Some Third World activists see them fostering more hunger, foreign economic dominance and pressure for lucrative drug cultivation. The focus at the main conference center here was a brewing crisis over foreign agriculture subsidies that threatened the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade - GATT - talks on reforming the rules of the world trading system. In an adjacent hotel, a diverse collection of environmentalists, leftists, workers for non-governmental organizations, activists and others labeled the negotiations a ``GATTastrophe.'' ``GATT will have very grave consequences on the environment,'' said Belgian researcher Myrian Vander Stichele, reporting the conclusion of a week-long alternative Conference of Civil Associations for Development. ``GATT doesn't deal with development or issues that matter to people in the Third World,'' she told a news conference. Diplomats and trade ministers from nearly 100 countries, including many in the Third World, at the GATT talks say new rules to expand world trade will benefit people in developing countries as well as prosperous nations. The main roadblock at the talks was a U.S. demand that the European Community and Japan stop heavy subsidies of agriculture and permit breakthroughs in regulating new areas. The talks opened Monday. Panelists from non-governmental organizations in the Philippines, Peru, Senegal and Japan at the alternative conference said the end of argiculture subsidies would have dire effects in some nations. ``If the United States wants to combat drugs, Third World farmers shouldn't be stopping production' of normal crops, said Manuel Lajo, a Peruvian economist. Lajo said developing nations fear the end of farm subsidies in wealthy nations will distort farm activity in poorer countries and may lead to more cultivation of coca, the raw material for cocaine. ``The relation between coca production and farm prices is very strong,'' Lajo said. Amadou Kanoute of Senegal challenged the GATT aim of extending free-trade rules to agriculture. ``Food security is an elemental right of each nation,'' he said. Kanoute, who was in Brussels as a representative of Environmental Development Action in the Third World, said 25 percent of people in Senegal suffer malnutrition and changing GATT rules will not help develop small farmers. Teresita Oliveros of Manila, representing interests of peasant women in the Philippines, said international trade rules were unbalanced in favor of rich countries and powerful transnational companies. ``Powerful nations are imposing their rules on us, especially the United States and Japan,'' she said. In her ironic description of the rules, Americans and Filipinos have equal rights to go to each other's country and exploit resources, but only Americans are able to do so. ``In the game of wealthy and powerful nations, the poor farmers, peasants and fisherfolk are sent to the margins,'' Ms. Oliveros said. Mika Eba of Japan represented a range of consumer, farming and environmental groups. She said the U.S. demand to open Japan's closed rice market would damage the Japanese environment and backfire on Washington, because Japanese probably would buy cheaper rice from Thailand, not American rice. Humberto Campodonica Sanchez, a teacher at San Marcos University in Lima, Peru, said the GATT goal of extending free-trade rules to services will harm infant industries in developing countries. For instance, he said, if a French bank was blocked from expanding in Bolivia, Paris could threaten to block exports of tin and wool that are Bolivia's lifeline. ``It's like a lion playing with an ant,'' Campodonica said. He also attacked a plan to ban developing countries from imposing conditions on foreign investments, such as requiring a certain percentage of local parts or foreign exchange limits. The plan does not account for advantages foreign companies receive in lower-paid workers in the Third World, Campodonica said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Continental Airlines, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key events in the evolution of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., formerly known as Texas Air Corp., which filed for protection from creditors Monday under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws. 1934 - Varney Speed lines is formed in El Paso, Texas, with four Lockheed Vega aircraft flying round trips to Denver. Earnings in the first two weeks total $261.69 from nine paying customers. 1937 - Varney is renamed Continental Airlines. Its eight employees relocate to Denver. 1968 - Continental opens routes to the South Pacific. 1972 - Airline entrepreneur Frank Lorenzo, future boss of Continental, acquires Texas International Airlines. 1976 - Texas International offers ``Peanut Fares,'' the precursor to the discount fares that would spread throughout the industry after deregulation in 1978. 1980 - Lorenzo creates Texas Air Corp., parent of Texas International, headquartered in Houston. 1981 - Texas Air gains control of Continental Airlines. 1983 - Continental employees strike, accusing Lorenzo of unfair tactics to drive down costs. The airline, losing $1 million a day, files for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws. Employment drops from more than 12,000 a year earlier to 4,000. 1984 - Using nonstrikers and new hires, Continental resurrects much of its pre-strike operations. Lorenzo builds reputation as anti-union manager. 1985 - Continental begins first European service. Lorenzo loses a bid to buy Trans World Airlines as its employees, fearing his union hostility, support takeover by investor Carl Icahn. 1986 - Continental re-emerges from bankruptcy with a plan to fully repay all debts. Employment reaches 14,500 and aircraft fleet totals 200, double the pre-bankruptcy level. Parent Texas Air acquires Eastern Airlines as well as remnants of People Express and Frontier, making it the largest airline operator in the country with 20 percent of the market. 1987 - Continental's employment reaches 24,500 and fleet totals more than 300 jets serving 140 destinations. Lorenzo introduces ``Maxsaver'' discount fares and announces plans to cut labor costs at Eastern. 1988 - Texas Air undertakes joint venture with Scandinavian Airline System, the beginning of a growing relationship between the two companies. Texas Air also shows the effects of fare-cutting and debt-financed spending spree, losing $466.2 million in 1987 vs. earnings of $72.7 million a year earlier. 1989 - Lorenzo rejects Eastern union demands in contract negotiations, workers strike, Texas Air puts Eastern under bankruptcy-court protection and begins to sell many of its assets. Parent company loses $885.6 million for the year, an industry record. Lorenzo insists he'll remain in the airline business despite speculation he might get out. January-February 1990 - Texas Air drastically reduces proposal for repaying Eastern creditors and faces increased trouble in bankruptcy court. April 1990 - Lorenzo loses control of Eastern to court-appointed trustee. Texas Air is renamed Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. August 1990 - Lorenzo resigns as chairman and chief executive and sells most of his Continental holdings to Scandinavian Airlines System. He remains a board member. November 1990 - Continental denies speculation it will file for bankruptcy but concedes the board considered the move. Airline puts some prized routes up for sale to raise cash. Lorenzo predicts that trouble in the airline industry could leave just three or four carriers dominating within a few years. Dec. 3, 1990 - Continental files for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws, blaming the move on excessive debt and high fuel costs.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Seen As Fallout from Gulf Turmoil
With PM-Continental Airlines, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The success of Continental Airlines' decision to file for bankruptcy court protection might depend on how long tough times linger in an industry ravaged by high fuel costs and a sinking economy, analysts say. Passengers should see no changes in Continental's service as the Houston-based carrier buys time and holds creditors at bay - for now anyway. But analysts said the strategy depends on outside factors changing. ``They're trying to hold the thing together as much as possible and try to wait it out,'' said Thomas Canning at Standard & Poor's Corp., a leading debt-rating agency. ``It could work, provided this recession is not too prolonged and too deep.'' If on the other hand Continental and other weak airlines continue bleeding and even go out of business, financially powerful airlines such as American and United will be in a much better position. That could mean, for example, fewer fare discounts and even some big fare increases as competition declines. Even as Continental announced the Chapter 11 filing Monday, it said it was selling a prized Seattle-Tokyo route to American for $150 million. The move seemed to affirm the view of analysts who have said the Persian Gulf crisis is serving as a catalyst to speed industry shakeups. The bankruptcy filing ``appeared to have been necessary because of a liquidity crisis where assets could not be sold in a good time frame,'' said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon Read & Co. The other major airline in bankruptcy court is Eastern, a Continental subsidiary. It ran into life-threatening troubles this fall when unsecured creditors asked a bankruptcy judge to order a liquidation, saying Eastern has no chance of a healthy recovery. But last week, Eastern's court-appointed trustee Martin R. Shugrue Jr. persuaded a bankruptcy judge to give Eastern up to $135 million from an escrow fund. Shugrue said the cash will keep Eastern alive through March, and after that he believes the airline can stop losing money. Analysts don't believe it will be that simple. But they say Eastern's experience shows that an airline can stay alive in bankruptcy court indefinitely. ``As we've seen them with the Eastern bankruptcy, the airline under the protection of Chapter 11, can continue as a very effective competitor,'' said Bruce Thorp, airline analyst with Provident National Bank in Philadelphia. ``In fact, Eastern's presence is very much felt by competitors such as Delta,'' he said. ``The important point here is going into Chapter 11 does not take you out of business by any means.'' Still, the uncertainties posed by the Persian Gulf crisis and the slow economy will remain big obstacles. Airlines have all been hit hard by the jump in jet fuel prices that came after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, throwing world oil markets into chaos. Coupled with sluggish demand for air travel, the airline industry has been limping toward its worst year ever, with losses estimated at more than $1 billion. Seeral weeks ago, Continental had considered the bankruptcy option, but it decided at the time to try and avoid it. Apparently, the carrier was unable to make any other options work for the immediate future, analysts said. ``I don't see Chapter 11 as any panacea,'' Thorp said. ``I think it holds creditors at bay. It's a buying of time more than anything.''

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Says It Offers NCR Brighter Future, NCR Wants To Hang Up the Phone
With PM-AT&T-Computers, PM-NCR-Profile
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. says it will fight to retain its independence, but industry analysts said any defensive move to ward off AT&T's $6 billion takeover bid would prove costly. AT&T said Monday its proposed buyout of the nation's fifth-largest computer maker would create a worldwide computing powerhouse. NCR said it isn't interested. ``Our position consistently has been that this doesn't make business sense,'' NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. said. ``I don't see what it would add to the NCR system. We want them to go away.'' American Telephone & Telegraph Co., which announced the stock-swap bid Sunday, said it first approached NCR about a buyout Nov. 15, and that the two companies held talks on the offer since. Though AT&T described its bid as friendly, Exley said AT&T's decision to disclose the talks made the $90-a-share proposal hostile. ``If this is their idea of a friendly takeover, they must look like Attila the Hun when they're feeling unfriendly,'' he said at a news conference at NCR headquarters in Dayton, Ohio. AT&T's decision to make the discussions public puts pressure on NCR by letting NCR shareholders know of the deal - the $90-a-share bid represents a 60 percent premium over NCR's stock price Friday. NCR shares shot up $24.75 to close at $81.50 Monday as 5 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, making it the second most actively traded issue behind AT&T. AT&T fell $2 a share to $30.12{, with 8.5 million shares traded. AT&T is the nation's most widely held stock. AT&T said its offer remained open until the end of business Wednesday. If NCR does not accept by then, AT&T may make a tender offer directly to NCR stockholders, AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen said. Several industry analysts viewed AT&T's talk of a tender offer as a tactic to get NCR to agree to a negotiated deal. Rick Martin of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said NCR had several options if it chose to fight AT&T's bid, all costly. One would be a leveraged buyout, in which NCR would borrow money to buy back its shares and go private. A second would be to buy another computer company to make itself less attractive, Martin said. NCR also could seek a ``white knight,'' a third company that would buy NCR to save it from AT&T. But Martin said it would be difficult to find a better suitor than AT&T in the computer industry. Exley said in the interview that NCR was exploring ``all the available alternatives'' to fight an AT&T takeover. He also said the company was contacted by other potential suitors since rumors of an AT&T bid appeared in the press early last month. ``We made no response to any of them,'' he said. ``We're not interested in being acquired by anybody.'' In a strongly worded letter Monday to Allen released by NCR, Exley said AT&T had ``resorted to the pressure takeover tactics of the 1980s - actions more suited to a corporate raider than a responsible corporate citizen.'' He said AT&T had exaggerated the length and nature of the companies' conversations, and had damaged the market value of both companies. He said Monday's stock activity had erased $2 billion from AT&T's market value while adding $1.6 billion to NCR's. In a letter last week, released by AT&T, Exley said NCR would be willing to discuss a merger if the price were raised to a level that reflects ``the substantial prospects of NCR's business plan, the strategic importance of NCR to AT&T's future and the value of avoiding a disruptive takeover battle.'' Allen said he believed the letter reflected the legal duty of NCR's directors to consider such offers. He said he had no plans to increase AT&T's bid unless NCR provided documents that would justify it. Allen said AT&T decided to make its offer public Sunday after NCR refused to negotiate over the weekend as a follow-up to Exley's letter. But Exley said the company refused to provide confidential information because AT&T would not sign an agreement to postpone further action on a takeover, as is typical in corporate mergers.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T's Computer Operation Never Lived Up to Promise
With PM-AT&T-NCR, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When American Telephone & Telegraph Co. was granted the right to enter the computer business as part of the 1984 breakup of the Bell System, some predicted the phone giant would become a computer colossus to rival IBM. It didn't happen. AT&T has barely made a mark in the computer industry. Its computer sales ranked about 17th in the world last year - far behind No. 1 International Business Machines Corp., according to Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. AT&T has lost an estimated $2 billion to $3 billion trying to make a name for itself in the increasingly competitive computer market. Analysts say that until recently, its strategy had been muddled and its products mediocre. ``We were on the right track,'' AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen said Monday. ``We were moving positively and having more successs. But we were not going to achieve the critical mass of customers alone.'' Gregory Sawers, an industry analyst at the investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., agreed. ``They've tried for six years now. It simply hasn't worked. They don't have the critical mass. They don't have the product-line breadth. They don't have the distribution facilities,'' he said. That realization prompted AT&T's effort to buy NCR Corp., the nation's fifth-largest computer maker, in a $6 billion offer announced Sunday. NCR is resisting. Allen said NCR and AT&T's Data Systems Group would make a good match. Both are committed to ``open'' computing systems, machines that follow industry standards and can easily work with computers made by other companies. Both also use the popular Unix operating system, invented by AT&T. An operating system is the base layer of software that controls a computer's internal functions. Rick Martin, a computer analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said NCR would make a good mate for AT&T. ``These two companies have virtually the same strategy and the same products,'' he said. Though AT&T's computer business has not met expectations, it has improved sales in recent years by focusing on selling ``networked,'' or connected, computer systems, and by striking alliances with other computer makers. AT&T owns almost 20 percent of Sun Microsystems Inc., the top-selling maker of computer workstations. Last year, it bought Istel Group Ltd., a British computer company, for $290 million. AT&T earlier held a 22 percent stake in Olivetti, the Italian computer and office-equipment maker, but traded it last year for a stake in Olivetti's parent company. Olivetti made personal computers for AT&T, but AT&T ended the deal after sales were disapppointing. But the NCR bid would be AT&T's biggest deal yet. Through it, AT&T would gain NCR's customer base as well as its highly regarded line of computers. In September, NCR announced a bold strategy to replace its entire computer line, from closet-size mainframes to desktop machines, with industry-standard models built on the same Intel Corp. computer chip. AT&T said its expertise in communications would meld well with NCR's computer sales in the retail and banking fields, which rely on instantaneous transactions over phone lines and computer networks. AT&T had been believed to be looking for a major computer acquistion for some time, with both Unisys Corp. and Digital Equipment Corp. mentioned as contenders. But AT&T may view the smaller NCR as an easier target. The biggest-ever computer industry merger was Burroughs Corp.'s $4.8 billion takeover of Sperry Corp. in 1986 that formed Unisys. While the merger initially resulted in higher profits, Unisys has run into trouble in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: NCR: From Mechanical Cash Registers to Modern Computers
With PM-AT&T-NCR, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A proposed merger between AT&T and NCR Corp. comes at a time when NCR is at the zenith of its transformation from a maker of low-tech cash registers to a leading producer of innovative computer systems. NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. said Monday his company opposes American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s offer to buy NCR for $6 billion because it would distract NCR from its plans to market a new line of computers in the 1990s. NCR was founded in 1884 when John Henry Patterson bought the National Manufacturing Co. and renamed it National Cash Register. The company nearly cornered the market in cash registers, creating thousands of jobs for the Dayton-area economy. The company also developed a community-minded image. During a major flood in 1913, NCR workers turned out boats made from packing-crate lumber to rescue stranded citizens. And during the Depression of the 1930s, NCR set up a relief kitchen for stricken residents. ``If the independence of NCR is snuffed out, it will have some impact on the community,'' Exley said. During World War II, NCR made motors for anti-aircraft rockets and other defense contracts. With materials scarce for civilian production, the company found a booming market in reconditioning old cash registers. By 1960, the market for mechanical cash registers hit its peak, and the Dayton NCR complex boasted 33 buildings on 55 acres. But the company was hit with high costs and labor strife in the early 1970s, and the production of electro-mechanical cash registers ended in Dayton, with the loss of 16,000 jobs. The company then stepped up production of electronic cash registers and started to lean more heavily on its line of business computers, which it began developing in the 1950s. Last September, NCR announced it would replace its entire computer line with industry-standard machines that could communicate easily with each other. The company said it would produce the entire line - from tiny laptop models to powerful mainframes - using the same Intel Corp. microprocessors. The move was the boldest yet by a traditional computer maker to contend with the industry's move to ``open'' systems, or those that follow industry standards so they easily can be connected. Analysts said the new line of machines could strengthen NCR's position in the computer industry. The company is the nation's fifth-largest computer maker. Exley said a merger with AT&T doesn't make any business sense for NCR. ``We think it would be a distraction from the great opportunity that we have for the product programs that have been announced over the last couple of months,'' he said. And Exley said NCR employees are concerned about the offer. ``It brings an entirely new element into the scene that our people haven't confronted before,'' he said. NCR employs 56,000 workers at its 1,200 offices around the world, including about 5,400 at its Dayton headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Fore! Hawaii Leaders Seek Huge Fees From Golf Course Developers
DOC.TEXT: Japanese demand for golf, Hawaii's sunny climate and a limited supply of land for housing have political leaders here asking for up to $100 million as par for the course. The idea to charge golf course developers ``community impact fees'' to pay for rental housing has drawn support of Gov. John Waihee and Honolulu Mayor Frank Fasi. Supporters call it a way to force developers - who stand to make huge profits exploiting Hawaii's limited land - to give something back to the community. Critics say it's a tempting but legally questionable scheme to tax developers under the guise of state and county land-use regulations. With about 50 golf courses being proposed statewide by various developers - many of them Japanese - proceeds to the local government under the plan could climb well into the billions of dollars. Some developers are ready to pay. Jurigi Co. of Japan agreed to pay Honolulu $111 million for a just-completed $40 million municipal golf course near Pearl Harbor and $200 million more in community impact fees for permission to build two more courses on Oahu, where Honolulu is located. The City Council rejected the proposal, but its chairman, Arnold Morgado, agrees with the concept. In September, Morgado, the governor and the mayor said golf courses take up land that could be used for housing, and ``require large tracts of undeveloped land at or near locations which have scenic, recreational or cultural significance to the community.'' Fasi said the fees would be subject to negotiation. Hawaii's leaders are trying to cash in on high-priced memberships in Hawaii golf courses being peddled in Japan. For instance, Shinwa Golf Corp., owner of the Wailea Resort on the island of Maui, has offered Japanese citizens 1,000 memberships at $115,000 each in a new Wailea golf course. University of Hawaii Professor David Callies, an expert on land-use law, said impact fees have been found unconstitutional when they exceed a development's actual effect on such things as roads, sewers and the environment. ``Impact fees are not revenue-raising tools and golf courses are appropriate open space uses in the right places,'' Callies said. ``It is difficult to see how a golf course generates $100 million in infrastructure costs, which is the sole legal basis for charging such a fee,'' he said. Dan Davidson, executive director of the Land Use Research Foundation, a research and trade organization for landowners and developers, said impact fees are tempting from a fiscal standpoint. ``It is, however, a tax and the city has no authority to impose this sort of tax in the guise of a land-use regulation,'' he said. Harold Masumoto, director of the state's planning office, said Hawaii could avoid the potential problem of linking golf course fees to actual impacts by entering into development agreements. That way it would not be an impact fee, but a mutual agreement by the developer to make a contribution to a rental housing fund, he said. In 1988, the state Land Use Commission decided that major developers had to make 60 percent of their homes ``affordable'' for low- and middle-income families. In August, the same group for the first time imposed the governor's new policy of requiring hotel and resort developers to create one non-tourism job for every hotel room they build, or pay the state $25,000 per room. Wali Osman, director of research for the real estate firm Monroe & Friedlander Inc., said the trend is a result of the state's frustration in handling housing problems and diversifying the economy through traditional means. He said exactions from developers won't solve the housing problems. The state is going ahead anyway. Last month, the Board of Land and Natural Resources proposed that Minami Group USA pay $15 million in impact fees in exchange for extending a permit to complete a $100 million golf course on land zoned for conservation use. The extension was needed because rain had delayed construction. An attorney for Minami told the board he doubted the legality of the new proposed assessments, but said his client wanted to be ``a responsible neighbor'' and was willing to work with the state and local groups.

DOC.HEAD: Company Announces 600 To Lose Jobs In Energy Systems Unit
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said 600 workers in its energy systems unit will lose their jobs in an effort to make the company more competitive. The company on Monday said the reduction, which involves 300 layoffs and 300 voluntary retirements at the end of December, is necessary to strengthen Westinghouse in the domestic and foreign nuclear power markets. ``Like many other U.S. companies, we face intense competition in our home market and internationally,'' said Nathaniel D. Woodson, vice president of the unit. ``We intend to win, but to do so we must reduce costs.'' All of the employees affected by the move are in salaried positions and all but 11 work in the Pittsburgh area, where Westinghouse is headquartered. The company has 17,500 employees in the Pittsburgh area and is the largest private employer in the region. Westinghouse said it offered a ``voluntary separation program'' to employees aged 57 or older to lessen the impact of the reduction. About 300 employees accepted the offer, which will provide a year's pay to those who agree to quit before the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Board Rejects Latest Simmons Offer
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp.'s board rejected a $1.6 billion takeover offer from Texas investor Harold Simmons, saying the buyout proposal would burden the company with too much debt. Lockheed Chairman Dan Tellep informed Simmons of the board's decision in a letter Monday in which he called the proposal ``highly risky.'' Simmons, Lockheed's single largest shareholder with 19.8 percent of the stock, had proposed turning Lockheed into a private company. He lost a battle to take control of Lockheed's board last March, but won concessions from the aerospace company. Among them was a promise from Tellep to appoint up to three new directors to the board. Lockheed announced four appointments Monday - all approved by big shareholders other than Simmons, Tellep said. The appointments increased the size of the board to 18. ``I think we have more than fulfilled the commitment we made at last year's annual meeting,'' Tellep said Monday in a telephone interview. Simmons' chief strategist, J. Landis Martin, criticized the company for not conferring with Simmons on the new board members. ``How about the 20 percent shareholder?'' Martin said in a telephone interview. ``He didn't come to the 20 percent shareholder on any of these people.'' Through his NL Industries, Simmons had offered $40 a share for the Lockheed stock he doesn't already own. He said he would put up $400 million in cash and $400 million in his own assets, but wanted t use $800 million of Lockheed's assets to finance the rest. Aerospace analyst Lawrence Harris with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles, values Lockheed at $55 per share. He said the proposal appeared to be merely preparation for a second proxy war for control of Lockheed. ``The next annual meeting is not that far off, so this is one way NL can be on record as saying, `We attempted to get $40 for the shareholders,''' Harris said. Asked if another fight for the board was likely, Martin said: ``We're going to consider our options, which would include that.'' Lockheed's $1.3 billion in debt would have to be refinanced if the board went along with Simmons' plan. That, plus the new $800 million in debt, would have to be borrowed at a time when loans from any source are hard to come by. Simmons maintains the additional debt could be taken on because Lockheed could stop paying an estimated $113 million in annual dividends. After accounting for taxes, that would yield the equivalent of $165 million per year, Martin said. Tellep said that was not enough to justify loading Lockheed with $2.1 billion in debt. The new directors are: Robert G. Kirby, 65, board chairman of Capital Guardian Trust in Los Angeles; Frank Savage, 52, senior vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Socety of the United States; retired Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, 60, former chief of naval operations; and Douglas C. Yearley, 54, chairman and chief executive of Phelps Dodge Corp. in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments Begin in Soybean Trader Trial
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors scoffed at the claims of soybean traders on trial for fraud that they violated Chicago Board of Trade rules to benefit their customers. Closing arguments began Monday in the trial of 10 traders fingered in a federal probe of corruption at the BOT and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. In all, 48 people were indicted after FBI agents posed as traders and secretly tape-recorded conversations. Defense attorneys presented testimony and evidence during the three-month trial intended to show that unauthorized trading outside the pit was common and necessary to satisfy customers and large brokerage houses. The prosecution's closing arguments were scheduled to conclude today. The defense will then begin its summary, which is expected to continue through Thursday. Monday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Rotert urged the jury to disregard testimony from traders claiming that the exchange's rules were outdated. ``That's a defense?'' Rotert asked. ``Well, I don't think it is.'' The Board of Trade allows grain producers and handlers to lock in prices and pass the risk on to speculators, who accept that risk and try to make money from it, Rotert said. ``They took that premise and perverted it,'' Rotert said. ``Their risk was passed back. The risk was passed on to the next customer.'' Rotert said soybean traders should have the same responsibility to treat clients fairly and honestly as lawyers and doctors have. ``The customer has every legitimate right to believe and trust that the rules of the Chicago Board of Trade are being followed,'' he said. ``Lawyers are appropriately governed by rules,'' he said. ``Doctors hold people's lives in their hands and they are governed by rules. Commodities traders hold people's money in their hands and they also should be governed by rules.'' U.S. District Judge George Marovich presided over the jury trial of the traders, charged with conspiring to defraud customers through illegal trading practices. On trial are: Martin J. Dempsey, Charles W. Bergstrom, Bradley Ashman, William A. Barcal III, Edward A. Cox, Thomas P. Kenney, John Ryan, Joel J. Fetchenhier, Sheldon Schneider and John A. Vercillo. They face scores of charges including racketeering, mail fraud and wire fraud. Rotert said the traders deliberately violated the Board of Trade's rules prohibiting trading outside the open-outcry system and the board's operating hours. In the open outcry system, traders crowd into designated trading pits where they buy and sell contracts for future deliveries of commodities through a combination of hand signals and shouted buy- and sell-orders. The defendants are accused of conducting trades outside of the open-outcry system of the Board of Trade. Profits from those trades were used to make up any money traders cost customers while making a mistake, the prosecution said. The exchange's rules state the trader must personally make up the difference in the event of a mistake. ``These men intended to get money from customers under false pretenses,'' Rotert said. ``They think things like ethics, fairness and the law are a matter of context.''

DOC.HEAD: Consultant Sentenced to Probation in Iranian Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A businessman with ties to the Iran-Contra affair has been sentenced to two years probation for his role in a conspiracy to sell confidential Ashland Oil Inc. documents to Iran. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum on Monday also ordered Roy M. Furmark, a private consultant in the oil industry, to pay Ashland $15,000 in restitution. Furmark pleaded guilty in March to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. Furmark, of Brooklyn, testified to Congress in 1987 that he was involved in the sale of American arms to Iran. In the Ashland case, Furmark cooperated with prosecutors for more than a year before his plea and helped implicate former Ashland chairman Orin E. Atkins in the conspiracy. On Friday, Atkins, who also pleaded guilty to conspiracy, was sentenced to two years probation and 600 hours of community service for his role in the scheme. Furmark admitted that he agreed to help Atkins arrange meetings with representatives of the Iranian National Oil Co., which was contemplating a lawsuit against Ashland for the company's decision not to pay $283 million for crude oil purchased in 1979. Atkins has said he wanted to sell to the Iranians confidential documents involving the disputed oil deal that he obtained after he was forced to resign as chairman in 1981 but remained as a paid Ashland consultant. While the Iranians never bought the documents, they later sued Ashland and last year obtained a $325 million settlement, which with interest was worth more than $500 million. ``This episode in my life has been totally uncharacteristic to my life and what I stand for,'' Furmark told Cedarbaum. ``I am deeply sorry.'' Cedarbaum said she considered Furmark's cooperation in deciding his sentence. Furmark set up a meeting with Atkins in 1988 where they discussed renewed efforts to sell the documents Iran. A videotape of that meeting made by investigators led to charges against Atkins.

DOC.HEAD: Growth Slows in Third Quarter Compared with Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Japan's economy grew 1.0 percent in the third quarter from the previous quarter, reflecting falling corporate investment and personal consumption, the Economic Planning Agency reported Tuesday. The nation's gross national product grew at an annualized rate of 4.1 percent in the July-September period. In the second quarter, the Japanese GNP was up 1.4 percent from the firt quarter, and was growing at an annualized rate of 5.5 percent. Agency officials said high interest rates are limiting growth by cutting into capital investment, which has been the largest force driving the economy. But they said the latest figures indicate the fall in corporate spending is gradual and won't lead to a sudden drop in expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Saturn Production Startup Slow
DOC.TEXT: Saturn Corp. has produced lerss than 2,200 Saturn cars at its Tennessee plant since retail production began this summer, and dealers are feeling the pinch. Some dealers say they have only one or two cars to show off to prospective customers. Saturn officials had said they expected to build about 17,000 cars by the end of the year, but now say they won't meet the target. Spokeswoman Jennifer Schettler said Monday that just 2,162 Saturn cars have been built at the company's Spring Hill, Tenn., plant since retail production began in the summer. She and other Saturn officials said the company has a rigid quality control system at the plant which has resulted in lower-than-expected shipments to dealers. The company is a $3 billion project set up as a subsidiary of General Motors Corp. There are 52 Saturn dealers open in the United States, up from 29 when the line of small cars went on sale Oct. 25. ``We opened our doors Thursday evening, but aside from a display model on loan from Saturn, I don't have any cars,'' said Karen Tibus, president of Saturn of Plymouth, about 15 miles west of Detroit. ``I can tough it out for a while, but it gets expensive when you have a payroll to meet and the utility meters are running.'' She said she wanted to open with an 18-person staff, but that was cut to nine. Jeremy Anwyl, an automotive marketing consultant in Irvine, Calif., said the situation would be worse if Saturn had released to dealers cars with quality problems. ``You're better off being uncomfortable for two or three months than ending up with a $3 billion turkey that you eventually have to kill,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Arab Oil Group Won't Leave Kuwait or Expel Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A senior Egyptian oil official Tuesday ruled out the possibility that Iraq might be expelled from an Arab petroleum organization as punishment for invading Kuwait. Mohammed Shawkat, adviser to Oil Minister Abdel-Hady Kandil, said there is no plan for oil ministers of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries even to discuss the idea at their meeting Saturday in Cairo. ``To begin with, this is not on the agenda,'' said Shawkat, who will be the conference spokesan. ``Moreover, it's a political issue, and OAPEC's charter excludes politics. The organization has economic objectives involving cooperation and policy coordination among its members.'' Shawkat was commenting on speculation that Kuwait or other members of the 10-country group would suggest to the ministers that Iraq be expelled. There also have been reports that the ministers would consider moving the organization's headquarters from Kuwait, which Iraq annexed on Aug. 8, six days after the invasion. Such a suggestion might come before the ministers, Shawkat said. Iraq might want it moved to Baghdad to dramatize its assertion of sovereignty over Kuwait, or another member may propose temporarily relocating OAPEC's headquarters because of its inability to function under Iraqi occupation. ``Again, this is not on the agenda, but someone may suggest it under the customary agenda item of other business,'' he said in an interview. But he indicated that Egypt, the meeting's chairman, would contest it as a double violation of the charter: the suggestion, at least if proposed by Iraq, would be political, and the charter specifies Kuwait as the organization's home. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Libya founded OAPEC in 1968 partly to stimulate investment by member countries in each other's oil industries. In addition to the founders, it now includes Egypt, Iraq, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Syria and Algeria. Shawkat said the agenda of the Cairo meeting includes a joint project for building a drydock in Algeria, a plan to develop an OAPEC training institute in Baghdad and the group's 1991 budget. He refused to disclose the proposed budget estimates. Iraq has not notified Egypt as the organizer whether its oil minister will participate, Shawkat said. If he does not come, Iraq will be represented by its Cairo ambassador, Nabil Najm. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last month named his son-in-law Hussein Kamel Hassan acting oil minister after firing Issam al-Chalabi from the oil portfolio.

DOC.HEAD: Inland Steel Says Indiana Harbor Works to Close
DOC.TEXT: Inland Steel Co. has announced plans to close the 74-year-old structural mill at its Indiana Harbor Works unit on March 3 if business conditions don't improve, officials said. The move would affect about 300 hourly and 25 salaried workers in East Chicago, Ind. Officials at the Chicago-based Inland informed the United Steelworkers Union of the plans Monday. ``It's not a shock,'' said Mike Mezo, president of United Steelworkers Local 1010. ``We knew it was coming for years.'' Mezo said he expects most of the workers eventually will find positions in other parts of the Harbor Works, which will remain open. Company officials said a substantial number of workers at the northwestern Indiana plant also are expected to take early retirement. The closure comes because competition is hurting Inland, said Delmar Rediger, president of Inland Steel Bar and Structural Steel Co., a division of Inland Steel. The structural mill has been producing about 275,000 tons a year, mostly for use in the construction industry. Officials said the mill has produced a ``modest cash flow''' in recent years. But they expected the structural unit would lose money in 1991 because of difficult market conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Deck The Malls With Santa, Reindeer, And Much More
DOC.TEXT: Gordon Becker never stops thinking about Christmas. As president and founder of Becker Group - the nation's largest retail decorator - visions of sugar plums dance 'round his head all year as he concocts ways to turn ubiquitous shopping centers and malls into customer-luring winter wonderlands. The company's creations go beyond strings of lights and plywood reindeer. There are castles and Christmas trees as tall as office buildings. There are scenes of Disney characters, Sesame Street creatures, Peanuts, Rudolph the Red-Nose Reindeer and Garfield the Cat. Becker Group installed new displays in 145 shopping centers and malls this year at an average cost of $100,000 apiece. The company's clientele, though, totals 350 malls and centers nationwide. Becker said revenue for the privatly owned company is expected to exceed $13 million in 1990, with the Christmas decorations accounting for nearly 95 percent of business. ``It's a fun business, but there are nerve-wracking moments,'' said the slightly rotund 57-year-old Becker, a former store Santa. Becker's busiest time is the two months before Christmas, when the company ships and assembles its Christmas creations. Throughout the year he's taking orders, making plans and surveying malls and stores. Business wasn't always so brisk, however. Becker said he was forced to file for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws in 1976. Although he managed to stay in business, he struggled until 1983, when things finally started to take off. It was that year when Becker began targeting developers who own groups of malls. Those contracts now comprise 60 percent of his business. ``I was meeting with a developer in Dallas in 1983 and he told me I might have a good year. He had 12 malls and he was thinking about giving me five or six,'' Becker said. ``I said why not all 12? I came back with almost a million dollar order.'' Revenue immediately jumped from $3 million, where it had been mired for several years, to $4.7 million. Today, Becker's company decorates malls for 13 developers, including Taubman Co., which owns 22 shopping centers, and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corp., which owns 17 shopping centers, the San Francisco 49ers and the Pittsburgh Penguins hockey team. Among his clients, the Northwest Plaza in St. Louis, Mo., recently paid Becker $400,000 for a giant Santa Castle complete with 50-foot banners strung through 10-foot high wreaths. The owner of the mall is the New York-based development company Paramount Group Inc., which owns three other malls in the United States. All are clients of Becker. ``We probably do the largest Santa photo concession. Because its so breath-taking, people will drive from miles around to get their picture taken in our Santa castle rather than somewhere else,'' said Christi Parks, marketing director for Northwest Plaza. ``There's absolutely no doubt its worth the money we spent on it,'' she said. ``Our mall has always had a reputation for having special Christmas decorations. For us to do something every few feet was not acceptable. We literally need to fill the mall with Christmas.'' Fair Lane and Twelve Oaks shopping centers in Detroit spent more than $350,000 each on Becker holiday decorations. At Cherry Creek Mall in Denver, Becker provided a 52-foot high Christmas tree that measures 28 feet in diameter. The Cranberry Mall in Westminster, Md., paid $50,000 for its ``Help Garfield Find Pooky'' display. Several Garfield figures powered by compressed air pop up in a house as the fat orange cartoon cat searches for his favorite stuffed animal. Most of Becker Group's decorations fall in the traditional line and the more elaborate Fifth Avenue line, Becker said. Displays last about three years, meaning one third of the company's customers purchase new decorations every year. Becker's passion for Christmas began in high school, when he worked as a store Santa for some pocket money for the holidays. After he graduated from the University of Maryland, he started a Santa school and rental business. The school was abandoned in the early 1960s as he became more involved in the decorating business. ``When it started 35 years ago, my office was my bedroom in my mother's house and the garage was a warehouse,'' said Becker, who operates today out of a 19th century townhouse in a fashionable neighborhood in Baltimore. The firm employs more thn 100 people. ``In the 1950s, you have to remember, shopping centers were new. There were no companies that existed. You had to really jury-rig everything,'' recalled Becker. In the beginning, he said, he would do anything for a client and became known for setting up spotlights in front of stores. Becker said a background in show business helped - his father, Lou Becker, was a bandleader who worked with Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey. ``It's theater in its purest form,'' he said. ``The way we deal with people, there are the same technical problems as in mounting a show. ``It has to look like the Empire State building, but when its over, two guys have to be able to pack it up and put it away.''

The Dow Jones industrial average, which gained 5.94 points Monday after adding 40.84 points on Friday, fell 9.15 to 2,556.44 by 10 a.m. EST. Among broader market barometers, the New York Stock Exchange index of all listed stocks fell 0.55 to 176.52. On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 0.65 to 301.95. Declining issues outnumbered gains by about 2-1 on the NYSE, with 647 up, 344 down and 465 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 21.9 million shares after a half hour of trading. Stock strategists said the market's behavior partly reflected a decline in prices overseas. Stocks on the London and Tokyo markets weakened overnight. They also attributed the decline in U.S. stock prices to an underlying anxiety about the domestic economy, which by many assessments has fallen into recession. The gnawing uncertainty about the outcome of planned U.S.-Iraqi talks to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis also weighed on stock prices. Citicorp and Chase Manhattan, the nation's largest banks, led the list of actively traded NYSE stocks early in the session, both rising on word that Federal Reserve was loosening reserve requirements to stimulate lending and ease a credit crunch. The move was expected to help boost the profit of banks. Citicorp rose } to 13| and Chase rose \ to 11\, both on volume exceeding 300,000 shares. Among blue chip industrials, Boeing fell \ to 44}, Digital fell ] to 54[ and Eastman Kodak fell 1 to 41}. DOC.HEAD: British Airways Seeking to Create Berlin-based Airline
DOC.TEXT: British Airways said Tuesday it is seeking to create a new Berlin-based airline which would compete with the German carrier Lufthansa. Such an airline, which aims to turn Berlin into a hub, could expand greatly in coming years by providing East-West European air services and feeding into long-haul transcontinental flights. British Airways would hold a 49 percent stake in the new carrier, and unspecified German investors would own the rest, said a British Airways spokeswoman, who wasn't identified in accordance with airline practice. ``We are still talking to a number of German interests. It's not going to be an immediate announcement. It's very much at the planning stages,'' she said. The new airline, as yet unnamed, isn't expected to begin operating until 1993. British Airways is advertising in the trade press for pilots in preparation for the airline's creation, the spokeswoman said. The carrier has been spurred to seek such a deal by German unification, which effectively forces foreign carriers out of Germany by 1993. British Airways currently operates a Berlin-based fleet of nine airplanes providing 86 daily flights to nine German cities. ``We're keen to continue to operate in Berlin. We've been in there for 44 years. We want to continue, and expand it,'' the spokeswoman said. British Airways has served Berlin since World War II when it flew in supplies as part of the airlifts through which the Allied forces replenished the blockaded city. After the Berlin Wall came down, Pan American World Airways, the primary provider of Berlin air services, sold its operations to Lufthansa, which had been prohibited from operating out of Berlin's Tegl airport since the war. British Airways, which has transformed itself from a poor airline into a world class carrier since its 1987 privatization, has been expanding its European operations. It recently announced plans to create a new Moscow-based airline called Air Russia, which the British airline wants to operate jointly with the state-owned Soviet carrier Aeroflot. It also is seeking to turn the government-owned Belgian airline Sabena into a carrier jointly owned by British Airways, KLM Royal Dutch Airways and Sabena. That deal, which aims to make Brussels another hub, awaits regulatory approval from the European Commission.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Ends Delay of Chevron Stock Purchase By Pennzoil
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission has cleared Pennzoil Co. to proceed with previously announced plans to boost its 8.8 percent stake in Chevron Corp., Pennzoil disclosed today. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Pennzoil said the FTC had lifted a delay imposed in August on the Houston-based oil giant's plans to buy an additional 3.9 million shares of Chevron stock from time to time. The FTC said it wanted more information after Pennzoil, which already held 32 million shares of San Francisco-based Chevron's stock, said in July that it intended to spend about $291 million to acquire some 3.9 million more shares. That would boost Pennzoil's stake to just under the 10 percent level that would a trigger a Chevron shareholders' rights plan, also known as a ``poison pill'' anti-takeover defense, according to Pennzoil. Pennzoil said the stock purchase was only for longterm investment. The company said it already had spent more than $2 billion to obtain the 32 million Chevron shares it now holds. Under federal antitrust laws, companies seeking to take over a publicly-traded company worth $100 million or more, or trying to acquire stock worth more than $15 million, must obtain anti-trust clearance from the FTC.

DOC.HEAD: Reports of Soviet Grain Needs Boosts Market
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market received a boost from reports the Soviet Union will be making large purchases on the world's grain markets next year, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The reports indicated the Soviet Union may be importing about 10 million metric tons of grain from foreign producers in the first quarter. A sharp drop in soybean and soymeal prices on the Rotterdam market is putting pressure on soybean futures. Corn prices were higher on speculative buying. Wheat futures were steady to slightly lower due to commission house selling. In early trading, wheat was a { cent to 1 cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.46} a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were a { cent lower to a { cent higher with December at $1.13\ a bushel; and soybeans were 2{ cents lower to } cent higher with January at $6 a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed and pork futures sharply lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures were boosted by their steep discount to cash prices, with feeder cattle futures pressured by lower cash prices paid at auction. Pork futures were pushed lower by an expected increase in movement of hogs to market. Lower cash prices also weighed on the market. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .05 cent higher with December at 78.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .28 cent lower to .10 cent higher with January at 87.32 cents a pound; hogs were .30 cent to .85 cent lower with December at 49.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to 1.65 cents lower with February at 64.30 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mixed and pork futures settled lower in Monday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official: Trade Talks `Close to Collapse'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comment. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Despite pressure... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Talks to revamp the world free trading system are very close to collapse, a U.S. trade official said today. Ambassador Rufus Yerxa, a deputy U.S. trade representative, told a news conference the European Community had not responded to demands from most other countries for greater liberalization on farm trade. ``It's quite clear the ball is now in the community's court,'' he said. Yerxa, asked about Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett's statement that something had to give by the day's end, replied: ``It is safe to say we share the concern of Minister Blewett of Australia that these negotiations are very close to collapse.'' President Bush, in Uruguay, the birthplace of the so-called Uruguay Round talks, expressed hope that the negotiations might yet succeed. ``We must use this meeting to find the political will to limit or reduce distortions in trade,'' Bush said. Yerxa said it was ``highly unlikely'' there would be further negotiations unless the EC changed its position. No talks on the key farm trade question were scheduled. As he spoke, EC trade ministers were gathering to discuss their position in talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a treaty pledging its members to free trade. Despite pressure from many sides on the Europeans for deep cuts in the EC's costly farm support programs, community officials showed no willingness to make new reductions in their agriculture offer at the 107-nation Uruguay Round, the most ambitious trade talks ever. ``There is absolutely no hope of having an agreement this afternoon or even tomorrow afternoon - but possibly by Friday,'' said Ray MacSharry, the farm chief of the 12-nation trading bloc. Officials are locked in a make-or-break effort to overhaul the global trading system by week's end. The comprehensive agreement they are seeking would lower trade barriers and write new rules covering trade in 15 areas, including agriculture, manufactured goods, textiles, trademarks and patents and services, such as banking and telecommunications. The Uruguay Round bargaining, which opened in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este, has broken down in recent months because of a stubborn fight between the European Community and its major trading partners over government payments to farmers. The United States, backed by Argentina, Australia and other nations, has demanded - so far without results - that the European Community peel away much of the support program for its 10 million farmers. There appeared to be growing anger over the community's refusal to budge on agriculture, which a number of nations, including the United States, Australia and Argentina, have said is key to an overall deal. The EC has offered to trim only 30 percent in subsidies for major crops over a 10-year period, counting from 1986. The United States is urging it to slash subsidies by 75 percent to 90 percent over the next decade. Canadian State Minister Charles Mayer dismissed the community's offer as ``mumbo jumbo'' and said: ``In our country, someone who comes around selling snake oil, we call him a quack.'' Many European farmers view the subsidy cuts as threatening their livelihood. Police fired tear gas and water cannons Monday to disperse 30,000 farmers outside the European Parliament building in the Belgian capital. The United States believes that without a commitment to reduce farm subsidies, Third World countries will walk away from the negotiations, dooming any chances to get new trade rules to cover service industries and copyright theft. Third World leaders say the subsidies steal potential markets from their farmers, ruining agriculture in their countries.

DOC.HEAD: Portman Announces Lenders Have Approved Pool Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta architect John C. Portman Jr. said he has won preliminary approval from lenders of his debt restructuring plan and completed a separate agreement refinancing the Peachtree Center office complex. Portman has been meeting with about 20 lenders since August in an attempt to refinance a debt that reportedly tops $1.6 billion. Lenders participating in the restructuring had been asked to approve the terms by Saturday. Portman on Monday called the plan ``the best way to protect the long-term interests of our company, our creditors and our tenants.'' Dennis Glass, executive vice president and chief financial officer for The Portman Companies, said the loan agreements and other documents on the restructuring should be finalized in late January. ``We have received overwhelming support for the collateral pool agreement from our lenders,'' Glass said. The group has been using that term collateral pool to describe the process of converting unsecured loans into loans backed by collateral. Terms have not been disclosed. Portman also announced Monday completion of a separate agreement to refinance Peachtree Center by increasing the equity position of the holder of a $332.6 million mortgage on the property, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc. The agreement with Equitable had been announced in early November, when Portman and the mortgage company agreed to terms designed to stop foreclosure proceedings initiated by Equitable. Limited partners in the property, mainly Portman relatives and employees, had to approve the deal before it could be finalized. Under the agreement, Equitable increased its ownership of the complex and agreed to make significant property improvements, including completing a current mall expansion. The Peachtree Center complex in downtown Atlanta includes six office towers, a retail shopping mall, two parking decks and an athletic center. Portman also has under construction a 60-story addition to the complex called One Peachtree Center and another building nearby called the Atlanta Gift Mart. He just opened an apparel mart in San Francisco and a massive office-hotel-retail complex in Shanghai, China.

DOC.HEAD: Deere Earnings Down for Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Farm manufacturing giant Deere & Co. on Tuesday reported its fourth-quarter earnings fell 27 percent from a year ago, due mainly to lower production of lawn-care and industrial products. Deere reported net income of $74.5 million, or 98 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31, down from $103.2 million, or $1.37 per share, in the same period of 1989. Revenue totaled $2.06 billion, up 3 percent from the $2 billion earned in the same three months last year. Deere attributed the earnings decline to lower production of its lawn and grounds-care products and industrial equipment. It also cited higher sales incentive costs in an extremely competitive market, as well as a four-week strike at the company's lawn and grounds-care equipment factory in Wisconsin. The company has put about 500 factory workers on indefinite layoff in the past two months in response to slumping sales. In addition, plant shutdowns will idle 4,500 workers in Iowa and Illinois in the next couple of weeks as the company tries to slow down production to match demand. Company spokesman Robert J. Combs said uncertainty over the economy and the Persian Gulf standoff were combining to depress sales of farm equipment and other products. ``There's an atmosphere of uncertainty we've been seeing since August,'' Combs said. ``As a result, we expect North American farm equipment sales to be somewhat lower.Our response has been to reduce production levels for 1991 by 12 percent.'' Deere's financial subsidiaries also reported an earnings decline. The farm credit, insurance and health care operations earned $33.7 million in the quarter, down from $36.5 million last year. For the year, the farm equipment manufacturer said it earned a record $411.1 million, or $5.42 a share, marking the third consecutive record-setting year for the 153-year-old company. The company made $380.2 million, or $5.06 a share, in fiscal 1989. Yearly revenue came to a record $7.8 billion, up from $7.2 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: American General Says It Reviews Two Bids on Subsidiaries
DOC.TEXT: Insurance giant American General Corp. said Tuesday it is reviewing two bids for its Home Service insurance subsidiaries, but received no bids for the company as a whole. The company put itself up for sale in May amid speculation it could be the target of a hostile takeover. But a dearth of buyers led American General to set a Monday deadline for bidding and to offer to sell parts of the company. Senior Vice President James S. D'Agostino declined comment on who submitted bids for the four subsidiaries, based in Nashville, Tenn., and Jacksonville, Fla., or how much they offered. He said American General's board of directors was due to meet Thursday and a more detailed announcement would be made then. Torchmark Corp., an insurance firm based in Birmingham, Ala., has been frequently mentioned as a potential bidder. Torchmark has been trying to acquire all or a part of American General since March, when it informally proposed buying the company for $50 a share, representing a total offer of more than $6 billion. The offer was turned down by American General officials, who said the company was worth more. In midday trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, American General was up 25 cents a share at $29.25.
