DOC.SECOND: BC-The New Workplace II, Adv09-2 Takes,1224
DOC.NOTE: $adv09
For release Sunday, Dec. 9, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Second in a series
Us Vs. Them: Labor and Management Become Partners To Survive
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, AP Graphic, Series Logo. Also moved on general news wires
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Competition has revolutionalized relations between management and labor, who have found in many industries that they have to become partners to survive. In the second of a three-part series, ``The New Workplace,'' Midwest Regional Reporter Sharon Cohen explores the changes that have led to no more Us vs. Them. ---

Each Monday, two guys named Mike get together to talk about their future. Their jobs seemingly make them rivals, but, in fact, they share a goal: survival. Mike O'Brien is a union leader. Mike Spitzley is a company man. But in their meetings here at the General Motors plant, the two talk costs, labor, quality - topics workers wouldn't have been privy to years ago. ``Most of the things we talk about, it's `we.' It's not us vs. them. We've pretty much recognized our goals are the same,'' said Spitzley, manager of GM's 5,300-worker car-truck plant. ``We make decisions together. ... I don't think there's anything I know I wouldn't tell them if they asked me.'' ``There's something different going on,'' said O'Brien, president of UAW Local 95. ``Years ago, it wasn't any of our business what went on in the business.'' Like two boxers bloodied and bruised, union and management in a small number of industries - mostly auto and steel - have stopped fighting. Instead, they're joining forces, sharing ideas and working together in ways they never would have before. Nowadays, blue and white collar, company and union, travel, lobby and meet customers together. In perhaps the most revolutionary example, Saturn Corp., both parties share all big decisions, from choosing suppliers to the advertising agency for the new auto company. ``An adversarial relationship cannot be compatible with today's market. We're part of a world trade. We're no longer king this and king that,'' said John Smith, administrative assistant to the president of the United Steelworkers of America. ``Survival is probably not too strong a word for what drives the two parties together,'' said Steelworkers' president Lynn Williams. Though there's a growing alliance, conflict remains, as evidenced by bitter strikes against the New York Daily News, Eastern Airlines and Pittston Co. Some labor officials also contend unions' acceptance of concessions in the '80s didn't ensure job security. And cooperation, they say, really is co-opting. ``The largest loss is the union's autonomy. We become one with the corporate agenda. It's an unnatural place for the union to be,'' said Jerry Tucker of the New Directions Movement, a dissident autoworkers group. Even so, a survey released this year found at least half of 350 unionized manufacturers had some formal joint activities, most begun in the 1980s. ``We've never seen anything as widespread in our own history,'' said William Cooke, a professor and associate dean at Wayne State University, who conducted the survey and wrote a book on the topic. ``In every case, it's come out of the same, `If we don't change, we're out of the market. The old way doesn't work well.' '' The biggest test of cooperation may be the layoffs and idling of plants in the current economic downturn. Hard times, Cooke said, could have a demoralizing effect and, perhaps, even crush the more fragile partnerships. ``If (workers) perceive management as doing this without due consideration for the welfare of employees ... it will have the potential of destroying the efforts altogether,'' Cooke said. ``If employees have information shared with them about the market ... then employees, generally speaking, are able to accept management decision-making.'' Cooke's survey found partnerships in almost all industries - including trucking, mining and public utilities - but they tend to be most common in autos and steel, both battered by foreign competition, plant closings and job losses. In the steel industry, the workforce shrank from 453,200 in 1979 to 168,900 in 1989, the American Iron and Steel Institute said. The average annual employment in the auto industry dropped from 990,000 to 857,000 in the same period, the government said. Union ranks have shrunk, too. Nationwide, 17 percent of workers were represented by a union in 1989, compared with 20 percent six years earlier. For partnerships to make their businesses more competitive, experts say, both sides must adapt: Managers must relinquish some authority and give workers more responsibility, while unions must become more flexible to increase competitiveness. The auto industry has been in the vanguard of this movement, with joint training, health and safety, education and quality programs, some since the 1970s. Labor-management partnerships vary in scope. For example: - AT&T and the Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers formed a joint non-profit corporation in 1986 that provides training and job placement and finances employee education. About 66,200 AT&T workers have participated in the programs. The CCWA, however, adopted a measure this summer expressing anger over layoffs, consolidations and forced transfers and questioning cooperation with the company. - Northwest Aluminum Co. in The Dalles, Ore., reopened in 1986 under new ownership with a team concept and a new philosophy. Labor and management participate in interviewing prospective employees. Union meetings are held on company property; management attends at the beginning to answer questions. There no longer are separate worker-manager showers or Christmas parties. ``Those little things when you stack them up, put them in a bucket, made a big difference,'' said personnel manager Dick Schon. ``We argue like hell. It's not a love-in. The difference is basically I think we are a team.'' - The New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., a Toyota-GM venture in Fremont, Calif., holds quarterly union-management meetings, and representatives from both parties share an office in the labor relations department. ``They're treating (workers) as if people had brains. Before you had to check your brain outside when you came in the door in the morning,'' said George Nano, bargaining committee chairman for UAW Local 2244. The plant has a rancorous labor-management record when operated by GM alone. ``It was like a war here,'' Nano said, adding that now ``it's not peaches and cream. (But) it's a hell of a lot better.'' There's probably no more innovative partnership than at Saturn, the GM subsidiary in Spring Hill, Tenn. The union has a seat on the plant's governing body. Saturn's president and UAW coordinator have offices in the same suite and do business together. All major decisions - including product design, suppliers, dealers, equipment, machinery, investments - are made by consensus. In one ad, one Saturn autoworker explains: ``We've had our share of knockdown-dragouts over the years. ... It's hard to tell engineers from technicians, and, you know, it doesn't seem to matter. It's just labor and management on the same team.'' ``It's like a marriage,'' said Mike Bennett, UAW Local 1853 president at Saturn. ``You make vows. Fidelity is a matter of choice. Both GM and the UAW are working to make this marriage work.''

DOC.HEAD: JANESVILLE, Wis.: marriage work.''
DOC.TEXT: But not everyone believes the parties should be married. ``Why should we work together on speeding up assembly lines, pitting workers against each other as the team concept does?'' said Tucker, of New Directions. ``Why should we aid corporations whipsawing one plant against the other?'' By trying to get along, he said, grievances aren't filed and safety may be jeopardized. ``The `I'm your pal, you're my pal' - it's almost a California New Age philosophy implanted in the industrial heartland,'' said Harley Shaiken, professor of work and technology at the University of California-San Diego. ``It raises expectations about participatory democracy. If those expectations aren't met, then the situation can become very conflict-ridden very early.'' At Janesville, cooperation has grown through the years, ranging from abolishing separate worker-manager parking lots to more drastic changes like a four-day workweek and elimination of dozens of restrictive job classifications. GM brought in consultants to talk with workers about on-the-job problems and sent rank-and-file employees to Michigan to help on truck prototypes. Labor and management now lobby for state funds and meet suppliers and dealers together. ``We want them to know this is the way we operate,'' Spitzley said. ``It used to be you'd say something to management and they'd say `I'm the boss. You're the worker.' Now what they do is we sit down and talk about the problem,'' said John Resch, an autoworker for 20 years at the plant. ``For us to survive, it takes both of us to do it together.''

DOC.HEAD: Testimony Ends In Vernon Trial
DOC.TEXT: Former Vernon Savings Association owner Don R. Dixon blamed his employees for wrongdoing at the failed thrift as testimony ended in his bank fraud trial Tuesday. ``I thought they were loyal at the time,'' said Dixon, who took the stand for the third time. Dixon is charged with 38 counts of bank fraud, misapplication of funds, conspiracy and other crimes. He is accused of using Vernon money for prostitutes, personal beach homes in California and illegal political contributions. Dixon bought the small-town thrift in 1981 and its assets grew more than tenfold by the time he sold it in 1986. The following hear, Vernon failed at a cost to taxpayers of more than $1.2 billion. It was one of the first costly collapses of the thrift crisis and focused national attention on the troubled industry. Federal prosecutors and defense attorney Billy Ravkind were scheduled to present closing arguments Wednesday before the case goes to the jury. If convicted on all counts, Dixon could be sentenced to up to 190 years in prison and fined as much as $9.5 million. The trial began in mid-October and included more than four weeks of testimony from about 25 prosecution witnesses and a handful for the defense. Dixon took the stand in his own behalf Friday, Monday and for about 30 minutes Tuesday. He finished by repeating his contention that he did not authorize Vernon officers to reimburse themselves with Vernon funds for donations to political candidates. He said he gave ``conditional'' approval, telling the executives to check with attorneys before reimbursing themselves. ``If those officers had thought it was illegal, not one of them told me,'' Dixon said. Later, prosecutors recalled one witness, George McGuffey, who was Dixon's loan officer at Republic Bank in Dallas for eight years. McGuffey disputed Dixon's testimony that Republic allowed him to redirect money it loaned him from one project to another. He also said Dixon would have had to document any use of Republic's money for purposes other than what it was borrowed for. McGuffey also said Republic did not make financial agreements on a handshake, as Dixon said he did with a Dallas developer concerning payments on a $1 million beach house near San Diego. Prosecutors contend Dixon developed an elaborate scheme using developer James Atkinson to pay for the house, preventing its discovery by federal regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Testing of Electronic Trading System to Begin in Spring
DOC.TEXT: The testing of Globex, an electronic global trading system developed by Chicago's futures exchanges, will get underway at the end of the first quarter of next year, a spokesman for one of the exchanges said Tuesday. Globex is being developed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and Reuters Holdings PLC. It will link investors in North America, Europe and Asia through an electronic system for trading futures and options contracts. It will operate during hours when the Mercantile Exchange and Board of Trade trading floors are closed. Andrew Yemma, a spokesman for the Mercantile Exchange, said the testing of Globex will involve about 250 terminals stationed in Chicago, New York and London. ``The goal of the testing is to make sure the system performs totally up to its capabilities before it is placed into service,'' Yemma said. The results of the testing will determine the actual launch date for Globex. Yemma said negotiations are continuing between the exchanges and Reuters for a final agreement on operating the system. When an agreement is finalized, it will be submitted to the exchanges' membership for approval. Globex was the idea of the Mercantile Exchange. After initial opposition, the Board of Trade decided earlier this year to join the Merc in developing the system, abandoning plans to develop its own 24-hour electronic trading system. Reuters, a British news agency and disseminator of financial news and market information, is providing the technical expertise.

DOC.HEAD: Market Drifts on Lack of News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with the soybean market getting some support from an expected increase in business from the Soviet Union. There was little news to influence the market, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. He said traders used the day to consolidate gains made in Monday's trading, which saw the market climb sharply. Soybean futures were pressured by a decline in the price of soybean and soymeal on the European market. However, soybean futures received a boost from expectations of increased soymeal demand from the Soviets. The first quarter of 1991 could see the Soviet Union importing about 10 million metric tons of grain from foreign producers. Wheat futures were pushed lower by reports of large worldwide supplies and aggressive overseas competition. Corn futures were lower on pressure from commercial house selling. At the close, wheat was 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.45 a bushel; corn was 2{ cents lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.28 cents a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2\ cents lower with December at $1.11{ a bushel; soybeans were 5\ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with January at $5.96 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Comedians Told There's Nothing Funny About Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines is using comedians to lighten the atmosphere on some flights this week, but they're not allowed to make jokes about the company's bankruptcy court filing. Peter Bales, one of five comics chosen, said the airline's financial troubles were the least of his worries. Turbulent skies on the Newark-New Haven, Conn., route on Monday forced the stand-up comedian to deliver his 10-minute shtick sitting down. ``It's difficult to be funny when you're try not to vomit,'' Bales said in a telephone interview Tuesday from his home in Northport, N.Y. On Monday, the airline said it would continue normal operations while it seeks protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws. The nation's fifth-largest airline said a $2.2 billion debt and increased jet fuel costs due to the Persian Gulf crisis forced the move. Continental first served up cabin comedy on its Detroit-Cleveland route in August, said spokeswoman Nancy Compel. This week, its Continental Express division is offering stand-up comedians and business speakers on its 46-seat commuter service to New Haven - the serious stuff in the mornings and the funny stuff in the afternoons. The promotion was hatched two months ago and will continue despite the bankruptcy proceedings, Continental said. ``It's going well,'' Compel said Tuesday. ``Travelers seem to enjoy it, even though it was a little bit rough and our comedian had to sit down.'' The comedians were advised last week to keep the cabin humor clean and not make jokes about airplanes. On Monday, Compel said, she ``told them the news of the day'' and reminded them to ``stay away from inappropriate material.'' Bales said he avoided negative airline jokes, but added that he generally says what he wants. He began by warning hecklers they would be asked to leave. Then he griped about the gig, saying there were ``two guys with headphones'' in his dressing room. The jokes were delivered while he was strapped into his seat, with his head craning down the aisle to catch a glimmer of response over the noisy engines. ``I thought at one point I got applause but I think my ears were just popping from the pressure,'' he said.

A late burst of buying sparked by rumors that Iraq was considering withdrawing from Kuwait lifted the stock market to its third consecutive gain today. The market's major indicators were trading well below Monday's closing levels late in the session when rumors swept the market that Iraq had come up with a new proposal to withdraw from Kuwait. The rumors, based on a British television news report, fanned speculation the Persian Gulf crisis could be resolved without bloodshed. Up until those reports circulated in the last half hour of trading, the market was generally lower on what analysts attributed chiefly to profit-taking in the wake of a big gain on Friday and a smaller advance on Monday. Bank stocks were doing well, however, in the wake of today's anouncement by the Federal Reserve that it was easing reserve requirements to stimulate lending and ease a credit crunch hurting the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Board Elects Chairman, CEO
DOC.TEXT: D. Leonard Wise was elected chairman and chief executive officer of Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. Tuesday, succeeding William J. Scharffenberger, the company said. Wise, 56, has been vice chairman since April 23 and a member of the board since January 1988. He has been involved in the steel industry for 33 years. James L. Wareham will continue as president and chief operating officer, the nation's eighth-largest steelmaker said. Scharffenberger, whose resignation was effective Tuesday, will continue as the ``responsible officer'' in leading the company from Chapter 11 status in compliance with a June 1987 bankruptcy court order, the company said. Scharffenberger said the timing of his resignation would help accomplish ``a smooth transition from the `old' company to the `new' company under the plan or reorganization.'' The company and the United Steelworkers union reached settlement in mid-August on a contract that expires March 1, 1994. The agreement was seen as a key to allowing the company to emerge from Chapter 11 status after five years. The Wheeling-based company employs 5,500 union workers and 1,600 non-union workers in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Paul Loses Bid to Keep from Paying $30.8 Million Restitution
DOC.TEXT: Ousted CenTrust Chairman David Paul, a national symbol of excess in the savings and loan crisis, lost his bid Tuesday to keep from paying $30.8 million in restitution sought by federal regulators. U.S. District Judge Edward Davis rejected Paul's motion for a temporary injunction to hold off the Office of Thrift Supervision. But Paul attorney Sanford Bohrer promised an appeal even before seeing the opinion, saying, ``What OTS did doesn't bear any resemblance to what the constitution requires.'' Davis' ruling did not address a deadline for Paul to pay up, but OTS attorney Deborah Siegel said, ``Hypothetically, the order has always been in force and the bond is due.'' Thrift regulators ordered Paul to submit the bond by Nov. 1 to cover CenTrust funds converted to his personal use, but payment was delayed by Paul's appeal. OTS targeted a $15 million legal defense fund for the failed savings & loan's officers and directors, sumptuous furnishings and fixtures at CenTrust's 47-story office tower, Old Masters paintings and a private dinner cooked by European chefs flown in for the occasion. Paul, CenTrust's majority stockholder until the Resolution Trust Corp. became conservator last February, faces numerous civil suits over his control of Florida's once-largest thrift. No criminal charges have been filed against him. Great Western Savings has acquired most of CenTrust's branches, but its headquarters and money-losing projects remain in federal hands. The federal takeover already has cost an estimated $1.8 billion. Bohrer attacked the restitution order as ``an Alice in Wonderland approach to due process'' that reached a judgment against Paul without allowing him to defend himself. ``What OTS as done is they've talked to themselves and said, `We should win this lawsuit, shouldn't we?' and declared themselves the winner,'' he said after learning of the ruling. ``No proof or nothing.'' Bohrer said Paul was in Miami but would not make any comment.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Surge Despite Reports of Middle East Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices rebounded Tuesday from steep declines of the past two trading sessions, shrugging off reports the Kuwaitis were willing to enter into negotiations with the Iraqi on withdrawal from Kuwait. On other markets, grains were lower and soybeans higher; precious metals gained; and livestock and pork futures were lower. Analyst Brian Tagler of Shearson Lehman Bros. Inc. said energy futures were stronger on New York's Mercantile Exchange because of a fire in the Saudi Arabian oilfield and nervousness over an upcoming OPEC meeting. The market sold off at mid-session on news the Kuwaiti royal family may be willing to hand over two islands in exchange of Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. However, the market later recovered from the losses and moved higher. ``It is an indication that the market is in a bullish stage,'' Tagler said. Light sweet crude settled 95 cents to $1.51 higher with the contract for delivery in January at $30.66 a barrel; heating oil was 1.63 cents to 2.23 cents higher with January at 86.90 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.40 cents to 3.85 cents higher with January at 75.92 cents a gallon. Grain futures prices settled lower and soybeans were higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, with the soybean market getting some support from an expected increase in business from the Soviet Union. There was little news to influence the market, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. He said traders used the day to consolidate gains made in Monday's trading, which saw the market climb sharply. Soybean futures were pressured by a decline in the price of soybean and soymeal on the European market. However, soybean futures received a boost from expectations of increased soymeal demand from the Soviets. The first quarter of 1991 could see the Soviet Union importing about 10 million metric tons of grain from foreign producers. Wheat futures were pushed lower by reports of large worldwide supplies and aggressive overseas competition. Corn futures were lower on pressure from commercial house selling. Wheat was 2\ cents to 3{ cents lower with December at $2.44} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2 cents lower with December at $2.28\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2\ cents lower with December at $1.11{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents lower to 2{ cents higher with January at $6.01\ a bushel. Precious metals prices were higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with gold pushed higher by renewed Middle East war fears. The fears were spurred by more militant tones in remarks President Bush made Tuesday in Montevideo, Uruguay. The president said he did not believe economic sanctions would force Iraq out of Kuwait. Gold was $1.80 to $2.30 higher with December at $378.90 a troy ounce; silver was 1.3 cents to 1.4 cents higher with December at $4.151 a troy ounce. Live hog futures were sharply lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with selling interest spurred by lower cash hog prices and expectation of further price declines, said Paul Georgy of Allendale Inc. in Chicago. Frozen pork belly prices were pushed lower by an expected sharp increase of bellies in storage. Live cattle futures were pushed lower by commodity fund selling and spillover weakness in the hog market. Live cattle were .05 cent to .28 cent lower with December at 78.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .30 cent lower with January at 87.32 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to 1.32 cents lower with December at 49.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.85 cents to 2 cents lower with February at 63.90 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Judge Upholds Pension Obligations of Steel Company
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday affirmed a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that ordered the LTV Corp. to re-assume liability for nearly $3 billion in employee pension plans it stopped funding in 1987. The Dallas steel, aerospace and energy concern, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, had opposed restoring the plans because it claimed such a move could possibly force the company to liquidate. LTV lawyers had argued that the high court decided only legal issues regarding events that were three years old and had not taken into account the company's current financial situation. Attorneys for LTV's various creditors also had urged against returning liability to the company, arguing that it could disrupt LTV's attempts to reorganize. But U.S. District Judge Robert Sweet of Manhattan rejected the company's and creditors' position and granted a request by the federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. to make LTV take back responsibility for the pension plans. In his 22-page decision, Sweet said: ``In view of the Supreme Court's holding, PBGC is entitled to attempt to restore the plans before determining the effect or propriety of such action.'' The PBGC insures pension benefits, much like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. insures bank deposits. The high court's June ruling upheld PBGC's decision to force LTV's Cleveland-based steel unit, LTV Steel Corp., to re-assume pension obligations for three underfunded plans. Those plans were to provide for more than 60,000 LTV retirees and active employees. Sweet's decision means liability for the three funds will be transferred to LTV from the PBGC. ``With today's order, LTV can now take the necessary steps to complete its bankruptcy reorganization and emerge as a viable company while workers and retirees can have their full pensions as originally promised,'' said PBGC executive director James B. Lockhart. LTV spokesman Charles M. Palmer said the company would continue to make payments from the pension plans. ``Because we're in Chapter 11 we can't put any additional money into the pension funds, so future pensions will be paid from existing assets of the three plans,'' Palmer said. Last month, the PBGC issued a proposed payment schedule for the restored plans that would allow LTV to pay its unfunded pension liabilities over a 30-year period. ``We believe the proposal is not workable but we would expect to have more discussions in the future,'' Palmer said. Sweet conceded that his order left unresolved ``the survival of LTV and the means by which the benefits under its pension plans are to be paid.'' The judge recommended that all parties involved in the dispute select an arbitrator to address these problems. ``The difficulty of these issues has engaged, and to date, defeated the best efforts of administrators, judges and legislators at all levels,'' Sweet wrote. ``Perhaps all parties should agree than an instance-specific global solution would be preferable to the continuation of the present trench warfare.'' LTV filed for protection from its creditors in July 1986. The litigation stems back to 1987 when LTV stopped funding the pension plans and the PBGC assumed liability. A few months later, a new LTV labor contract with the United Steelworkers of America restored some retirement benefits similar to those in the terminated plans. The PBGC ordered LTV to re-assume liability for the three terminated plans. When LTV challenged the order, PBGC went to court. In 1988, Sweet ruled that the agency improperly ordered LTV to re-assume the plans' operations. A year later, a federal appeals court agreed that PBGC had exceeded its legal authority. But the Supreme Court reversed the lower courts and sided with the PBGC.

DOC.HEAD: Report that Iraq May Withdraw from Kuwait Triggers Stock Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A report that Iraq may be ready to withdraw from Kuwait peacefully triggered a powerful rally in the stock market on Tuesday, lifting key market indicators to their third consecutive advance. The news that suggested the Persian Gulf crisis could be resolved without an armed conflict between Iraq and the multinational military force led by the United States ignited a market that sank gradually for much of the afternoon. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which was down more than 25 pouints with a half hour left in the session, finished with a gain of 14.11 points to close at 2,579.70. That represented a turnaround of about 40 points in only 30 minutes. ``This is a news headline type of market,'' said Larry Wachtel, a market analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities. He said the report ``turned market psychology around'' even without official confirmation. But he warned that if the report proves inaccurate, the market could reverse course just as quickly. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 907 up, 639 down and 457 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 185.82 million shares, up from 177.07 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 227.06 million shares. News of a British satellite television report that Iraq would be willing to withdraw from Kuwait in as long as it was not attacked and could keep the disputed Rumailah oil field triggered the rally at about 3:30 p.m. EST. Wachtel said the report triggered buying in the futures markets, which in turn set off a scramble to buy the stocks on which stock index futures contracts are based. But Wachtel and several other analysts said that the stock market faces some tough going, given the depressed state of the economy and the damaging effect that that may have on corporate profits. ``The market is getting a little tired,'' Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co., said before the late turnaround. He said the market's early decline reflected profit-taking in the wake of last week's 32 point-plus advance in the Dow Jones industial average. That advance had included gains of 40.84 points in the Dow industrials on Friday and another 5.94 point rise on Monday. Bank stocks got a lift Tuesday from the Federal Reserve's announcement that it was reducing reserve requirements in an effort to encourage more bank lending. First Chicago Corp. was the most active issue on the NYSE, rising 1 to 18}. Citicorp gained 1{ to 14], Chase Manhattan rose { to 11{, BankAmerica climbed 1{ to 24{ and First Bank System rose ~ to 13}. NCR rose 2 to 83{. On Sunday, AT&T said it was offering to buy NCR for $90 a share, but NCR has indicated it wants to remain independent. AT&T rose \ to 30]. Continental Airlines led the Amex's most-active list, dropping \ to 1}. The debt-laden carrier filed for bankruptcy court protection on Monday. In the over-the-counter market the most active issue was MCI, down { to 18} with more than 4.6 million shares traded. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $20.71 billion, or 0.68 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.12 to 178.19. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.88 to 381.93, and S&P's 500-stock composite index climbed 2.25 to 326.35. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.78 to 364.10. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 302.64, up 0.04.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Rallies, Then Plunges on Report of Iraq Retreat Plan
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rallied on the futures market Tuesday, then a news report indicating Iraq might vacate Kuwait pushed crude down sharply. Light sweet crude, the benchmark grade, settled at $30.66 a barrel, up $1.51, at the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for January delivery. Later contract months all settled higher, mostly by more than $1 per barrel. But soon after the Mercantile Exchange had closed for the day, oil traders were jolted when they received word of a British television news report indicating that Iraq might have a plan for pulling its army out of Kuwait. Sky television news said Iraq might be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait as long as it is allowed to keep the disputed Rumailah oil field and as long as it gets a guarantee that Western forces will not attack. Prices for petroleum at loading platforms and docks, commonly called the cash or spot market, tumbled by more than $1 per barrel minutes after the Mercantile Exchange closed, traders said. The cash market ordinarily follows the bahavior of prices at the exchange, which is known as the futures market. ``That's a lot,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``They usually don't move as dramatically as on the futures market, because it's not an open cry system.'' In early afternoon trading on the Mercantile Exchange, oil prices had fallen on a report indicating Kuwait might be willing to negotiate the future of some of its islands if Iraq withdraws its troops, which invaded the oil-rich emirate on Aug. 2. ``But it did not continue to sell off. In fact it snapped back up,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Everybody interpreted that as as a very bullish event, the fact that the market did not collapse.'' Crude oil futures shot up nearly $2 above their lows for the day, puzzling many traders. Once the market was closed, they began trying to piece together what had happened before news of the British television report came in and they began nervously watching the cash market. Financial markets that were still open at that point made sharp moves on the possibility of peace in the Gulf. Futures prices for refined petroleum products had moved pretty much in tandem with crude prices Tuesday. Home heating oil rose 2.23 cents to 86.90 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. Unleaded gasoline for January delivery rose 2.40 cents to 75.92 cents a gallon. Natural gas prices, which are not directly affected by the potential for Mideast war, fell 3.5 cents, to $2.44 per 1,000 cubic feet, on contracts for delivery in January. Later Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the nation's supply of crude oil fell last week to 335.5 million barrels, down from 337.1 million barrels a week earlier and 351.9 million barrels a year earlier. The stockpile of gasoline was at 221.1 million barrels, up from 218.3 million barrels a week earlier but down from 223.1 million barrels a year earlier, API said in its weekly report. The stockpile of distillates, which include home heating oil, totaled 132.9 million barrels, down from 134.8 million barrels a week earlier but up from 121.5 million barrels a year earlier, API said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Hears Arguments in Hacker Case
DOC.TEXT: The conviction of Robert Morris for unleashing a computer ``worm'' program in 1988 should be overturned because he didn't intend to paralyze thousands of computers linked to a nationwide program, his attorney told an appeals court Tuesday. The oral arguments in Morris' appeal were presented to three judges of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, who didn't immediately make a decision. Morris, 25, of Arnold, Md., was the first person brought to trial under a section of a 1986 federal computer fraud and abuse law that makes it a felony to break into a federal computer network and prevent authorized use of the system. The former Cornell University student was convicted at trial and sentenced to three years probation, 400 hours of community service and a $10,000 fine. The appeal presentations of defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni and the prosecutor, Justice Department attorney Ellen Meltzer, focused on their different interpretations of the law, which a federal jury in Syracuse found Morris violated. Morris' worm immobilized an estimated 6,000 computers linked to the Internet network, including ones at NASA, military facilities and major universities. Witnesses testified that it did not permanently harm the computers or computer files, but in some cases victims were unable to use their computers for several days while the worm was hunted down and removed from their computers. Morris testified during his trial that he had made a programming error that caused the worm to go berserk and cripple the Internet system on Nov. 2, 1988. He said he did not intend to cause permanent damage to computer files - only to infiltrate the network's security. In court Tuesday, Guidoboni said he interpreted the computer fraud law to mean that the government had to prove that Morris not only intended to access the computer program but also planned to interrupt access for others. He said there was insufficient evidence to support his interpretation of the statute. The lawyer also claimed Morris did not break into computers illegally, but rather merely exceeded authority already given to him for computer access. Meltzer, however, argued that the conviction should stand because the language of the law explicitly stated that proof that a hacker intended to cause damage or loss to others was not required. The appeals court will issue a written opinion at a later date.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Prices Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against other major currencies Tuesday, hit hard by the Federal Reserve's decision to ease its grip on interest rates and by a news report that Iraq may be willing to withdraw from Kuwait. Gold prices were mixed, falling overseas and then rising in New York. The dollar first slumped after the Fed said it was relaxing its reserve requirements for banks, an unusual move aimed at stimulating the deteriorating economy by easing a shortage of credit. The central bank said its action, the first change in reserve requirements since 1983, was taken in part for technical reasons but also to encourage banks to increase lending. Ideally, if banks have more money to lend, interest rates would fall, although some private economists questioned whether that would in fact be the result of the Fed move. But the foreign exchange markets, taking no chances, sold the dollar down. The dollar, like all currencies, draws support from higher interest rates, which make U.S. investments more attractive. When rates fall, the dollar tends to follow suit. The U.S. currency took another hit shortly before the close of trading, after a British news report said Iraq may be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait as long as it is allowed to keep the disputed Rumailah oil field. The report raised the prospects for a peaceful end to the Middle East crisis. The dollar, seen as a relatively safe investment in times of international strife, has advanced as tensions increased in recent months and dropped as they were defused. James T. McGroarty, senior vice president with Greenwich Capital Markets Inc., noted that the dollar stormed higher last week as the Persian Gulf situation appeared to worsen. That surge upward made the dollar particularly vulnerable to a sharp decline, he said. The British pound rose against the dollar Tuesday. In New York, sterling closed at $1.92925, up from $1.9180 late Monday. In London earlier, the pound rose to $1.9255 from $1.9205 late Monday. The dollar fell to 133.30 Japanese yen in New York from 134.735 late Monday In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 1.35 yen to a closing 134.35 yen, and it was later quoted in London at 134.00 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.5030 German marks, down from 1.51395; 1.2825 Swiss francs, down from 1.2935; 5.0825 French francs, down from 5.1135; 1,129.25 Italian lire, down from 1,138.00; and 1.16325 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16625. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.5030 German marks, down from 1.5125; 1.2840 Swiss francs, down from 1.2915; 5.0835 French francs, down from 5.1113; 1.6955 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7055; 1,130.00 Italian lire, down from 1,137.00; and 1.1638 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1655. Gold advanced in New York, climbing $2.30 on the Commodity Exchange to close at $378.90 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $376.25, up 75 cents. Gold fell earlier in London to a late bid price of $378.20 a troy ounce from $380.50 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $377.40 from $380.85 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $3.37 to close at a bid $376.69. Silver prices advanced. The metal rose 1.3 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.151 a troy ounce. Earlier, silver rose in London to a late bid price of $4.18 a troy ounce from Monday's $4.16.

DOC.HEAD: Home Sales Down Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, Economist Mark, to CORRECT name to Obrinsky, sted Obrinski. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes dropped 3.5 percent in October to the lowest level in eight years, the government reported Tuesday. But analysts said the free fall may be bottoming out and sales should begin rebounding by spring. ``Sales should be leveling off at this number in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of next year,'' assuming mortgage rates continue to fall and the Mideast problem is resolved, said economist David G. Seiders of the National Association of Home Builders. Economist Mark Obrinsky of the Federal National Mortgage Association suggested sales may zig-zag for several months, ``but assuming no blowup in the Middle East ... I expect to see a more sustained pickup by spring of 1991.'' Sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 491,000, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development said in a joint release. That was the lowest since 480,000 new homes were sold in October 1982, a month before the 1981-82 recession ended. So far this year, new home sales were off 15.8 percent from the same period of 1989. Sales fell 4 percent in September and 2 percent in August. The September figure was revised down from 6 percent in the departments' initial estimate, but the October total was worse than the 1.8 percent drop first reported. Obrinsky said the main reason for the decline ``is great consumer uncertainty and generally negative buying sentiment.'' Consumers, he said, are experiencing rising prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis and increasing unemployment as the economy slows. ``But, really, the big one is the great uncertainty over the Mideast ... concern over war breaking out,'' Obrinsky added. At the October sales pace, it would take 8.4 months to exhaust the inventory of unsold homes, up from 8.3 months in September. There was a seven-month supply of unsold homes in October 1989. But Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said builders are cutting back on housing starts to counter the slow sales. And, ``once the market recovers, you're going to find relatively few new homes,'' he said. That, in turn, will drive up prices which have been declining recently. The median price of a new home in October was $121,800, up from $112,900 in September but down from $123,000 a year ago. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Seiders attributed the price increase to a hefty 47.4 percent gain in sales in the Northeast which has the highest housing costs in the nation. Sales there totaled an annual rate of 84,000 units after falling 12.9 percent the previous month. Sales in all other regions fell, including a drop of 18.2 percent in the West, to 112,000 units. That was the lowest since 106,000 homes were sold in September 1982. In the Midwest, sales were off 11.7 percent, to 83,000 units - the lowest since 74,000 homes were sold in August 1986. Sales dropped 4.1 percent in the South, to 212,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: New York Investment Group Proposes Merger with DeSoto
DOC.TEXT: Sutton Holding Corp., a New York investment group that has been pursuing DeSoto Inc., proposed acquiring the manufacturer through a merger. In a letter to Des Plaines, Ill.-based DeSoto's board of directors, Sutton Chairman William Spier proposed a merger in which stockholders would get $4.25 per share in cash and securities. The securities would entitle shareholders to a pro rata share in the proceeds from any dissolution of DeSoto's pension plans. ``This security could be distributed as a dividend to DeSoto stockholders immediately prior to consummation of our acquisition,'' Spier said in the letter, dated Dec. 3, which was included in a Sutton filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In October, DeSoto shareholders approved a plan to sell off most of the company's assets and terminate its pension plans in return for a one-time dividend of $35.50 per share. Under the restructuring the company would sell substantially all of its businesses, including its domestic consumer paint business, which has supplied Sears, Roebuck & Co. for 80 years. Only DeSoto's detergent business would be retained. DeSoto has estimated that the partial liquidation and restructuring would raise about $222 million before taxes with $85 million earmarked to retire corporate debt. It noted that its plan to terminate pension plans and recover some $28 million in excess assets is subject to approval by the Internal Revenue Service and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., the federal agency that guarantees workers' pensions much like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. guarantees bank deposits.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Report, Fed Credit Easing Buoy Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Fed-Markets listed on AMs digest.
DOC.TEXT: Prices for stocks and bonds jumped sharply and oil fell on the cash market in late afternoon trading Tuesday after a British television report of an Iraqi withdrawal plan raced through the financial markets. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip stocks, which was down more than 25 points with a half hour left in trading, finished with a gain of 14.11 points to close at 2,579.70. The move amounted to a turnaround of about 40 points in 30 minutes. Bond prices also moved higher. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond closed up { point, or $5 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, was down to 8.32 percent from 8.36 percent late Monday. ``This is a news headline type of market,'' said Larry Wachtel, a stock market analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities. He said the report ``turned market psychology around'' even without official confirmation. But he warned that the market could reverse course just as quickly if the report proved inaccurate. News of the British television report hit trading floors just after 3:30 p.m. EST. Sky television news said Iraq might be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait as long as it was allowed to keep a disputed oil field and as long as it received a guarantee that Western forces would not attack. A multinational force of more than 400,000, led by the United States, has been deployed in the region to oppose Iraq. Following the passage of a U.N. resolution last week, Iraq has been given until Jan. 15 to withdraw or face possible attack. The oil futures market had just closed when the Iraq report reached U.S. financial markets, but the news pushed prices down on the cash market, where the commodity is picked up and delivered. Prices for petroleum at loading platforms and docks, also called the spot market, tumbled by more than $1 per barrel to below $30 minutes after the futures market closed. In futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude for January delivery had settled at $30.66 a barrel, up $1.51. Prices on the cash market have closely followed those at the exchange throughout the Persian Gulf crisis. Also Tuesday, some stock and bond prices were buoyed by the Federal Reserve's loosening of bank reserve requirements. The Fed's move followed other important credit-easing steps by the central bank, including a steady lowering of the federal funds rate. ``This validates the view that the Fed is on a prolonged path of easing. It doesn't initiate it; it strengthens it,'' said Richard B. Hoey, managing director and chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc. In the long-term, the progressive easing in credit conditions could soften the negative effects of an economic slowdown and potentially strengthen the stock market, some analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Airlines No Stranger to Trouble
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines is planning on retaining its ranking as the nation's fourth largest carrier despite a spate of setbacks the carrier has suffered in recent years. ``The public knows we run a safe airline and an airline of integrity. These things can happen to any airline,'' Northwest spokesman Doug Miller said after the latest disaster, a runway collision Monday that left eight people dead at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. In the past four years, Northwest has suffered through two crashes, a takeover, bitter labor strife and the convictions of three pilots for flying while intoxicated. Monday's runway collision came three years after Northwest Flight 255 went down near the same airport, killing 156 people in the second-worst air crash in U.S. history. In that Aug. 16, 1987, accident, the MD-80 failed to gain altitude during takeoff and slammed into a highway overpass. The National Transportation Safety Board ruled that the pilots didn't set the plane's wing flaps and slats properly for takeoff and that failure ff a cockpit warning device contributed to the crash. Northwest gained its fourth-place ranking, behind United Airlines, American Airlines and Delta Airlines, after the Eagan-based carrier acquired in-state rival Republic Airlines for $884 million in August 1986. What followed was an epidemic of late flights and lost baggage roundly attributed to union warfare that stemmed from pay disparities. As union leaders fought the company for more than two years to unify contracts, many former Republic workers were getting paid less than their Northwest counterparts. By the time Los Angeles investor Al Checchi led a $3.65 billion buyout completed Aug. 3, 1989, the airline was fighting to overcome a new nickname: ``Northworst.'' Checchi ushered in new management and improved service. The airline in March 1988 already had scored points with some travelers by banning smoking on all of its domestic flights - not just on flights of two hours or less as federal rules mandated. But other problems mounted. On Dec. 28, 1989, Northwest publicized a bomb threat it received for a Dec. 30 flight from Paris to Detroit. More than 100 people canceled their reservations for the flight; 28 passengers and 14 crew members made the trip. On Jan. 4, 1990, an engine fell off a three-engine Northwest plane flying from Miami to Minneapolis. The Boeing 727 landed safely in Tampa, Fla. Federal officials said improper maintenance was involved and proposed a $200,000 fine. Then on March 8, 1990, three Northwest pilots flying a Boeing 727 from Fargo, N.D., were arrested at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport after authorities were alerted that the pilots had been drinking heavily the night before. The three became the first commercial pilots to be convicted for flying a jetliner while intoxicated. Their sentences ranged from one year to 16 months. That was followed with a company report in October that ground workers in Atlanta filled the hydraulic systems of two DC-9 jets with a mixture of hand soap and hydraulic fluid. The airline said it was a mistake. Fifty flights were canceled around the country and 12 DC-9s were grounded for inspections. Checchi called a news conference Oct. 16 to say that layoffs and a reduced flight schedule were imminent because of higher jet fuel prices brought on by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But at the same meeting, he told reporters the airline was in good financial shape and positioned to possibly acquire another airline, or part of another airline. The takeover debt stands at $1.7 billion, two years ahead of schedule, and the company has cash reserves of $1 billion available. Despite a 47 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, Northwest's market share in the first 10 months of this year was 11.7 percent, up 0.7 percent from the same period a year ago. Although Northwest and other U.S. carriers are expected to lose a total of more than $1 billion in the fourth quarter, Checchi said last week in an interview with the Star Tribune that he was content with the airline's position. ``I feel that under circumstances we're in pretty good shape,'' he said. ``But it's nothing to crow about.''

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Up, Largely Because of Tax
DOC.TEXT: An increase in the federal gasoline tax pushed up prices at the pump when they otherwise would have dropped, the American Automobile Association said Tuesday. In its weekly survey, AAA found the average nationwide retail price for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded was up 2.1 cents at $1.387 per gallon. It was just .1 cent less than the AAA's highest recorded price of $1.388 per gallon just before the Easter holiday in 1981. Self-serve unleaded had risen 31.2 cents a gallon since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and threw world oil markets into a state of chaos, AAA said. AAA said gasoline prices would probably have fallen for the week without the imposition of an additional 5.1-cent per gallon tax that took effect Saturday. The average pump price was up in all regions, AAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Bank Reaches Settlement With SEC
DOC.TEXT: The troubled Bank of New England Corp. has reached an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations the firm failed to properly disclose financial problems, bank officials said Tuesday. SEC commissioners were expected to vote this week on the settlement. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed, and SEC officials would not comment further. SEC staff had alleged the bank refused to acknowledge the deterioration in its loan portfolio until December 1989, when shareholders were told the bank would increase its loan-loss reserves and cancel its quarterly dividend. The bank then posted a $1.1 billion loss for the year. But a quarter earlier it reported a $42.7 million profit and $121.6 million in nine-month earnings. Bank of New England spokesman James Dorsey would not give any details of the settlement but said the firm had cooperated fully with the investigation. ``We've been discussing this settlement with the SEC staff,'' Dorsey said. ``We have agreed to a resolution whereby the company would consent to an SEC enforcement proceeding.'' Dorsey said the company had brought in new management since the time of the allegations. ``The issues being reviewed relate to the firm's disclosures in 1989, and don't in any way involve matters during 1990, or our new management team,'' he said. ``This relates to a different era and a different time for this company, and we're pleased this is coming to a resolution.'' Bank of New England and its loan portfolio have been shaken by bad loans made during the 1980s and by New England's recession. The firm reported a $123.2 million loss in the third quarter, or $1.78 a share. Bank of New England is a Boston-based bank holding company with assets of $23 billion. It has offices in Maine, Connecticut and Rhode Island.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Concedes Rule Violations But Denies Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A defense attorney conceded Tuesday that a soybean trader at the Chicago Board of Trade broke exchange rules but said he did not attempt to cheat customers or commit fraud. The comments came during closing argumnents in the 11-week-old trial of 10 soybean traders and brokers charged in a federal investigation of alleged corruption at the Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Attorney Jim Epstein called the government's evidence insubstantial, conceded violations of Board of Trade rules and vigorously denied charges of wire fraud, mail fraud and racketeering conspiracy. ``Did he violate the rules? Absolutely,'' Epstein said of his client, Martin J. Dempsey. ``Did he attempt to commit fraud? Absolutely not.'' Epstein told a federal court jury that testimony indicated many of the rule violations were common on the trading floor and often benefited customers for whom the defendants may have been trading. One such violation is curb trading, which occurs in the trading pit in the seconds or minutes after the closing bell. ``Sure, he did curb trading,'' Epstein said of Dempsey. ``Is he proud of it? No. Did he try to conceal it? Of course, he did - but not because he was committing ... fraud, but because he was breaking the rules.'' The defense contended the prosecution wanted the jury believe concealing the trades was a sign of trying to cheat customers. ``Other than breaking the rule, you're not cheating anyone,'' Epstein said. The attorney also contended that government witnesses lied and presented misleading testimony. Earlier, in their closing arguments, prosecutors scoffed at the idea that traders broke the rules to benefit customers. ``These men intended to get money from customers under false pretenses,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Rotert said. ``They think things like ethics, fairness and the law are a matter of context.'' In all, 48 people have been indicted after FBI agents posed as traders and secretly tape-recorded conversations.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Puts 2,000 on Furlough After Indiana Strike
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said it has indefinitely laid off about 2,000 workers at an assembly plant here because a strike in Indiana has reduced the flow of parts. Workers who assemble Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable autos at the plant learned of the layoffs Monday. The strike is at a Ford-owned warehouse in Munster, Ind., that supplies bumpers, body panels and other parts to the assembly plant. The United Auto Workers union called the strike Friday for the 92 members at the plant seeking wage and benefit increases. Their contract expired Sept. 14, but work continued under an extension of the pact.

DOC.HEAD: Baltimore Walkout Ends; Philadelphia Strike Continues
DOC.TEXT: Shipping cargo clerks in Baltimore ended a two-day strike Tuesday after reaching a tentative contract agreement, while negotiations continued to halt a longer walkout at ports in and around Philadelphia. The strike by 415 clerks, who process paperwork for loading and unloading cargo, had brought the Baltimore port to a near standstill. Officials sai the workers were to return Wednesday. The clerks, members of International Longshoremen's Association Local 953, walked out Monday after failing to reach agreement with management over pension, health benefits and job security issues. Details of the new 46-month pact were not available. A handful of ships was unloaded Monday but activity came to a near stop Tuesday because clerks weren't there to operate gates and process cargo. At a few locations, ship line managers and office workers performed the work. In Philadelphia, negotiators for about 2,500 dockworkers and a marine trade association continued talks Tuesday night in an attempt to end their four-day strike. Eight ILA locals, representing about 2,000 dockworkers at ports in Philadelphia, southern New Jersey and Wilmington, Del., went on strike Saturday, a day after rejecting an offer by the Philadelphia Marine Trade Association, an employers' group. The ports had been scheduled to receive 22 ships by Wednesday, according to the Philadelphia Maritime Exchange, a trade group. Some ships already have been diverted to other East Coast ports, officials said. The dock workers' 14-month contract extension expired at midnight Friday. The disputes came two weeks after ratification of a master ILA contract and concerned local issues affecting work rules. Labor agreements have been reached in New York; Hampton Roads, Va., including Norfolk; and in South Atlantic ports from North Carolina to Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Upjohn, Biopure Agree To Market Blood Substitute
DOC.TEXT: The Upjohn Co. and Biopure Corp. on Tuesday signed an agreement to develop and market a human blood substitute derived from cow hemoglobin. Under the agreement, Upjohn will pay $25 million for world marketing rights for all Biopure's blood-related products. The pharmaceutical firm also must foot the bill for pre-clinical and clinical development of Hemopure, the blood substitute for use on humans. Hemopure is awaiting Federal Drug Administration approval for clinical testing, which has been completed for Oxyglobin, a blood substitute for animals. ``Biopure has worked diligently over the past seven years to develop a mammalian-based substitute for human and animal blood,'' said Carl Rausch, co-founder and chief executive officer of Boston-based Biopure. ``The potential product for human use, when approved, will begin to lessen the estimated 100 million-unit annual shortfall in human blood,'' he said.
